fields.headline: Portugal players face bans
fields.trailText: Uefa was last night preparing a package of disciplinary measures aimed at making an example of Portugal after some of the worst scenes of player dissent ever seen at an international tournament.
fields.body:
Uefa was last night preparing a package of disciplinary measures aimed at making an example of Portugal after some of the worst scenes of player dissent ever seen at an international tournament.

European football's governing body launched a top-level inquiry into the tumultuous reaction of Portugal's players before and after Zinedine Zidane's golden-goal penalty winner for France in Wednesday's semi-final at the King Baudouin stadium in Brussels.

The referee Günter Benkö was jostled by Portugal's players and coaches, chased off the pitch, spat at and had a plastic bottle thrown at him after awarding what was, by any standard, a legitimate spot kick on the advice of his Slovakian assistant Igor Sramka.

In the subsequent melee Nuno Gomes was sent off for shoving Benkö and several others could have followed, with Paulo Bento shaping as if to butt the Austrian and Joao Pinto throwing his shirt at him.

Although television pictures showed clearly that Abel Xavier had handled Sylvain Wiltord's goalbound shot, Sramka was also jostled and abused by the Portuguese players, coaches and other members of their backroom staff.

The fourth official, Scotland's Hugh Dallas, had to help him leave the pitch as several players tried to mob him. The trouble is believed to have continued into the tunnel, with players storming the door of the referee's room and shouting abuse at him.

After a relatively controversy-free tournament, Uefa was so appalled by the scenes that its control and disciplinary committee held a specially convened meeting yesterday.

Preliminary statements have been taken from all the officials and the governing body is now awaiting Benkö's official match report before announcing its decision on disciplinary measures on Sunday.

The Portuguese Football Federation is certain to be heavily fined, although the fact it is hosting the 2004 championship rules out any possibility of Portugal being thrown out of the competition. But if the noises emanating from Uefa yesterday indicate that it means to treat the situation with the utmost gravity, Gomes and at least three or four colleagues can expect a lengthy international ban.

It is also likely Uefa will review allegations by several Portuguese players that they were the victims of a conspiracy. "It's incredible to lose a semi-final to a penalty given by the assistant referee," their goalkeeper Vitor Baia said yesterday. "Now I understand better the words of the Uefa secretary-general when he said that he wants a final between France and Holland."

webTitle: France are missing the boy David

fields.headline: France are missing the boy David
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: Ron Atkinson believes the presence of David Ginola would make all the difference for France.
fields.body:
France were disappointing in their semi-final victory over Portugal and have far from set the tournament alight. But I still feel this is a stronger team than the one which won the World Cup two years ago.

The current side has the confidence of having been there and done that, and the biggest things that strike me are the players' great physical power and mental strength. The quality may not quite have clicked but they have got other things in their locker.

Even if games become a scrap it is never easy to imagine France being bashed out of their stride. Marcel Desailly, Lilian Thuram and Patrick Vieira epitomise the power of the team and they have a useful habit of grinding out results. I believe the first-choice back four of Thuram, Desailly, Laurent Blanc and Bixente Lizarazu has not lost together in 25 competitive matches. Some of that will come down to mental toughness, which the French have in abundance.

That much was obvious even in the warm-up on Wednesday when Didier Deschamps and Blanc were very prominent. They seemed to be laying down the law.

Deschamps has had plenty of criticism at Chelsea and in his homeland. I'm not sure he was needed at Stamford Bridge with Dennis Wise, and a lot of people in France feel he's no longer worth his place in the national side. But the longer the semi-final went on, the more influential he became. He sets an example, brings those around him on and helps the team keep their shape.

The obvious advantage this France team have over the 1998 side is the quality of their strikers. But to get the best out of them on Sunday I think Roger Lemerre needs to make a change and start with Robert Pires, who added an extra dimension when he came on against Portugal.

France played most of Wednesday's match with three midfielders - Vieira, Deschamps and Emmanuel Petit - who do not gallop into the box off the ball or get down the flanks. That meant they suffered a real lack of width, particularly because the full-backs could not get forward much. Lizarazu had his hands full with Sergio Conceicao and I got the impression Portugal had sacrificed Luis Figo for the team cause to block Thuram.

What that meant was that when one of France's strikers raided down the flanks and wanted to pull the ball back into the danger zone there was often only one team-mate to aim for. Even Zinedine Zidane rarely gets himself into the area without the ball.

A classic example of the problem came late in the match when Thierry Henry got down the left, was desperate to pull the ball back but lacked support and was squeezed out. France need a midfield player to join them up.

Vieira has the energy and ability, but if they use Pires in the wide areas the two strikers could stay in the box. For me, Petit, who has been struggling with injury, should make way. This is one of the reasons I would have had David Ginola in the squad, if only as a substitute.

The shame is that France have not shown as many moments of quality as we expected. Portugal made it difficult by putting the emphasis on a solid midfield and defence, with the defensive midfielders, Jose Vidigal and Costinha, very effective at times. But no one has lit up this French side.

Lizarazu has been the most consistent and there have been moments of brilliance from Zidane, but there have been a lot of French seven out of 10s. Maybe they have decided to be solid, confident someone will do something for them. Perhaps they have a massive performance in them for the final.

On Wednesday night they were indebted to Fabien Barthez for a great save from Abel Xavier's header and I'm sure Manchester United fans are looking forward to seeing him next season. He's a bubbly character.

He exudes confidence and his kicking is immense but he doesn't look much bigger than Deschamps. I wonder whether a taller keeper might have got closer to Nuno Gomes' goal. He might have the charismatic aura of Peter Schmeichel but not the physical presence.

If there is another potential worry it is that he sometimes looks like a graduate from the Bruce Grobbelaar school of goalkeeping, making erratic decisions and chasing the ball to all points of the globe. But his reactions are great and he is lively and decisive.

Given that I rate Mark Bosnich as the best goalkeeper I've worked with, I'm biased on who should be No1 at Old Trafford. Barthez's kicking is an advantage but otherwise I think Bossie is the better keeper. Being in and out of the side knocked him last season. He'll make it hard for Barthez early on but ultimately I think he will have to move.

webTitle: Dalglish left out in the cold

fields.headline: Dalglish left out in the cold
fields.trailText: Kenny Dalglish was yesterday sacked from his £600,000-a-year job as Celtic's director of football, his position having become untenable after the arrival of the new manager Martin O'Neill.
fields.body:
Kenny Dalglish was yesterday sacked from his £600,000-a-year job as Celtic's director of football, his position having become untenable after the arrival of the new manager Martin O'Neill.

O'Neill flew to Glasgow for 20 minutes yesterday to meet the players for the first time since his appointment four weeks ago, and the club later released a statement that Dalglish's contract had been terminated.

A group of Newcastle United season-ticket holders are facing legal costs of £198,000 after losing an appeal against the decision to move them from their seats at St James' Park to make way for corporate hospitality.

An 85th-minute penalty from Rivaldo salvaged a 1-1 draw for Brazil in their World Cup qualifier against Uruguay in Rio de Janeiro.

fields.headline: Downsized and disgruntled
fields.standfirst: Far from small gifts and cards, virtue is often the only reward for the lawyer working pro bono, an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: Brief encounters: Far from small gifts and cards, virtue is often the only reward for the lawyer working pro bono, an employment tribunal lawyer writes.
fields.body:
Part of the attraction of pro bono work to lawyers, I sometimes think, is that it provides a rare opportunity for the lawyer to bask in the radiance of actual gratitude. Gratitude, or anything nearer to it than hard-eyed suspicion, is not something you often come across in the paying punter.

The average pro bono client, by contrast, is embarrassingly, cravenly grateful, even when you lose the case. This gratitude sometimes manifests itself, warming the lawyer's hard little heart, in small gifts and cards - novelty booze, flowers, book tokens. My best was from a transsexual client whom I couldn't assist much but who nonetheless remembered me at Christmas with a portrait of herself in a playful satinette Mrs Santa outfit.

I have a lot of sympathy for my client, Davina, made redundant after her large employer "reorganised". Future societies studying ours will doubtless marvel at our occult management practices, the hocus-pocus of downsizing. There was a time, they will say, when people believed that if you moved a lot of employees about and changed their job titles and the names of their departments and got rid of some, you would make your business more efficient and profitable. The more times you did this, the people of the late second millennium and early third believed, the better your business would be. The symposia of the future will erupt with strange laughter.

But what bothers me a bit, as Davina squints at me morosely in the waiting room before her tribunal hearing - and I am ashamed that I feel this - is that it doesn't seem to matter to her at all that I am doing her case free. The conversation goes like this: Me: "Given the date of your dismissal, the most we would be able to get for your compensatory award would be £12,000". Davina looks at me with considerable disbelief. Davina: "That can't be right. What about that policewoman I just read about? She got a million pounds." Me: "But your case is just an unfair dismissal case. I haven't really read about that policewoman but it must have been a sex discrimination claim. There aren't any limits on the awards in those cases." Davina by now is giving me a look not dissimilar I suspect to the one I once gave to a ready meal from Tescos which purported to be bean enchiladas and turned out to be full of mince.

Things get a bit better (for me anyway) when we go into the tribunal because Davina then shares her surliness with everyone else. Employer's barrister: "Then you refused to come to the meeting with Mr Sacker to discuss redeployment opportunities?" Davina: "Were you there? How do you know what I did?"

Employer's barrister: "Uhh, Mr Sacker will give evidence that you he asked you to come the meeting and you refused. That's right isn't it?" Davina: "Yeah, well everybody knows Mr Sacker is a big old liar and he was knocking off Emma from accounts and lied to her as well..."

And so it goes on. Davina alienates everyone in the tribunal and manages to lose what should have been quite a good case. I try to shake her hand and wish her luck as she leaves but she mutters something about how she should have had whatever lawyer that policewoman had.

I restrain myself from shouting: "I WAS FREE. I DID YOUR CASE OUT OF THE GOODNESS OF MY HEART. WHY AREN'T YOU GRATEFUL?" No, no, virtue must be its own reward. Or something like that.

fields.headline: Barclays faces U-turn on charges
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Barclays last night was battling to resist an embarrassing U-turn over its controversial plan to levy a £1 surcharge on customers of rival banks using its cash machines after all but one of its competitors pledged to make withdrawals free.
fields.body:
Barclays last night was battling to resist an embarrassing U-turn over its controversial plan to levy a £1 surcharge on customers of rival banks using its cash machines after all but one of its competitors pledged to make withdrawals free.

Amid rumours of a split among the bank's senior management, the final decision is now expected to be taken next week by Matt Barrett, the chief executive, after he considers the risks to the bank's reputation of imposing a charge.

The bank insisted last night that it was still planning to introduce its controversial surcharge from January, a decision which - when first mooted last year - led to furious public rows among members of the Link cash machine network.

Barclays was the loudest proponent of a plan to alter the entire structure of cash machine charging, which many rivals believe will make it all the more painful for the bank to cave in to peer pressure and abolish the fees.

Instead of levying a "disloyalty fee" on its own customers when they used rivals machines, Barclays wanted to shift the industry towards surcharging, making customers of rival banks pay for using its machines but giving its own customers free access to the network.

After the threat of legal action by Nationwide, the Link members finally agreed that surcharges could be introduced from next January.

But, six months before the date, only Barclays and Lloyds TSB are poised to introduce a surcharge. In contrast, their two largest rivals, NatWest and HSBC have gone a step further. They will abolish all charges for cash withdrawals - including the existing disloyalty charges - from next year.

Their decisions followed that of the Halifax, which was the first of the banks to scrap its charges.

Barclays is thought to be holding out against making any decision until HSBC confirms its decision not to charge - which could come as soon as next week.

A spokesman for Barclays insisted last night: "Our plan is still to surcharge". However, he said the charge would not be £1, the level first suggested by the bank. Lloyds has said it will charge 50p. Barclays acknowledged that pressure was mounting on the bank to make a decision and said it was "taxing a few people's minds".

He played down speculation that it was causing rifts inside the bank but one senior industry source said last night: "Some major stresses and strains are starting to develop within the management structure: they are very split on this issue. This will drift up to Matt Barrett for the ultimate decision."

The move to allow surcharging - already used by banks such as Woolwich and Alliance & Leicester in some remote locations - has encouraged non-banks to set up machines, such as last week's announcement by Securicor.

fields.headline: A master at his peak
fields.standfirst:
Alfred Brendel *****
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText:
Alfred Brendel *****
Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.body:
Alfred Brendel is one of the most familiar figures of the piano world. His integrity as an interpreter of the core classical repertoire is legendary, as is his command of the intellectual dimension of his craft. And his latest Royal Festival Hall recital proved that he is continuing to question and evolve as a musician.

Brendel's Mozart has always been famous for its transparency and thoughtfulness. But those expecting his performance of the C Minor Sonata, K457, to evince only those qualities would have been disappointed. Brendel's tempi in the outer movements bordered on the wild. He launched into the opening arpeggios with white-hot energy. But for all this extraordinary velocity, Brendel reined in the expressivity of his playing, especially in the first movement. This sonata is sometimes played as a prototype for Beethoven's famous C minor pieces, but here, Brendel contained Mozart within strict, classical limits of dynamics and articulation. He was even willing to forego absolute clarity in favour of the overall sweep of the movement.

The method behind Brendel's approach was revealed in the central slow movement. Here, every phrase was lovingly nurtured. Where in the first movement the emphasis had been on the large-scale, in the second, Brendel focused on the finesse of each note of Mozart's lavish ornamentation. He savoured the florid appearances of the main theme. Brendel created a greater range of colours and timbres, allowing the instrument to blossom in the meltingly simple melody that appears halfway through the piece. The final allegro returned to the blustery, C minor world of the opening movement.

There were more surprises in Haydn's E Flat Major Sonata. Brendel is peerless in communicating the subtle games Haydn plays with his listeners and performers. With minute changes of emphasis and tempo, Brendel led us through the richnesses of Haydn's musical imagination with complete assurance. Mozart's Adagio, K540, was startling for other reasons. Brendel revealed a disturbing obsessiveness in this self-contained slow movement, and hinted at an archaic and private soundworld, altogether removed even from the intimacies of the C Minor Sonata.

Schubert's A Minor Sonata, D845, closed the programme, in a performance that created an unstoppable and ever-changing musical momentum. As Brendel approaches his eighth decade, there is no sign of him taking any aspect of his music-making for granted.

webTitle: How do you judge a 75-minute suicide note?

fields.headline: How do you judge a 75-minute suicide note?
fields.trailText: Five-and-a-half years ago Sarah Kane burst upon an astonished world with Blasted at the Royal Court's Theatre Upstairs. Now her final play, 4.48 Psychosis, gets a posthumous production at the same address. What is staggering is the contrast between the two occasions.
fields.body:
Five-and-a-half years ago Sarah Kane burst upon an astonished world with Blasted at the Royal Court's Theatre Upstairs. Now her final play, 4.48 Psychosis, gets a posthumous production at the same address. What is staggering is the contrast between the two occasions.

Blasted, in which the raw violence of Bosnian civil war erupted into a Leeds hotel room, was greeted when I saw it with a mixture of disbelief and outrage: the homburg-hatted man in front of me stomped out shouting "bring back the censor".

At the new play, a sombre, poetic and subjective meditation on suicide, the audience watches in near-silence: lovers clutch each other for comfort, someone quietly weeps, and, at the end, one person incongruously rises to applaud the cast.

In just over five short years Sarah Kane moved from disrupter of the peace to dramatic icon.

Judging 4.48 Psychosis is difficult. How on earth do you award aesthetic points to a 75-minute suicide note? - which is what the play, written shortly before Kane's death, effectively is. Three actors - two women and a man - sit under a vast tilted mirror in Jeremy Herbert's spare, beautiful design and explore the rage, pain, turbulence and self-excavation that leads to suicide.

It is not a play in the familiar sense of the word. It is more, in the manner of Kane's penultimate work Crave, a dramatised poem. A piece for voices. But one in which the main voice has been stilled. "After 4.48," runs one prophetic line, "I shall not speak again."

But does the play, which takes us inside Kane's head, have any general application?

I cannot speak for others, but what it taught me was the frustration of the potential suicide at the way the rest of the world marches to a different, rational rhythm, and assumes there are cures and answers for a state of raging alienation.

"I am deadlocked," says Kane, "by that smooth psychiatric voice of reason which tells me there is an objective reality in which my body and mind are one. But I am not here and never have been." It is the sheer disconnectedness of the suicide that Kane expresses so vividly.

A Tennessee Williams character says that we are all sentenced to solitary confinement inside our own skins. For Kane, a poetic metaphor became a literal truth. And it is her own tragic isolation she so fiercely articulates: "My life is caught in a web of reason spun by a doctor to augment the sane." It is a ruthlessly self-analytical theatrical poem. But within it there is evidence of Kane's gallows-humour.

At one point she contemplates a conclusive method of suicide: take an overdose, slash one's wrists and then hang oneself. "It couldn't possibly be misconstrued," she wryly says, "as a cry for help."

At other moments Kane seems be taking her sly, posthumous revenge on her critics. "An expressionist nag," she calls herself, which is exactly the phrase used by one reviewer of Cleansed; but then she adds, in a typical Kane touch, "stalling between two fools."

As a piece of theatre, 4.48 Psychosis is grave and haunt ing. James Macdonald directs it with meticulous precison; Daniel Evans, Jo McInnes and Madeleine Potter perform it with unsparing honesty.

But the play is as much a literary as a theatrical event. Like Sylvia Plath's Edge, it is a rare example of the writer recording the act she is about to perform.

"The woman is perfected," wrote Plath just before her own suicide. "Her dead body wears the smile of accomplishment."

I am not sure if you could quite say that of Sarah Kane: what this play proves is that her death was every bit as uncompromising as her creative life.

 Royal Court Theatre Upstairs (020 7565 5050) till July 15.

webTitle: Pearson fuels learning sites with US buy

fields.headline: Pearson fuels learning sites with US buy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pearson yesterday increased the pace of its investment in the online education market by paying £85m for control of Family Education Network.
fields.body:
Pearson yesterday increased the pace of its investment in the online education market by paying £85m for control of Family Education Network.

The deal was struck as Pearson added flesh to the bones of its agreement earlier this year with America Online to provide content to the internet service provider's education-based websites.

Pearson is buying 87% of the Boston-based Family Education Network, a series of websites dedicated to children's learning. It has seven sites, which generate more than 50m page views per month, including familyeducation.com, funbrain.com, infoplease.com and mygradebook.com.

Pearson aims to launch its online service branded the Learning Network in September and has agreed a three-year deal to appear on the main screen of AOL's Research and Learn Channel. It will provide educational content from kindergarten to professional training.

The agreement with AOL builds on Pearson's Simon & Shuster division which the group bought in 1998 to make it the world's biggest educational publisher.

In addition, Pearson services will be promoted through other parts of the AOL network, including AOL Workplace and AOL Families plus learning related areas of Netscape, Netcenter and CompuServe.

Pearson said the online education market in the US will be worth around $50bn a year by 2005.

Marjorie Scardino, Pearson chief executive, said: "The internet personalises learning to individual needs in a way that has never been possible before."

Learning Network content will be available on four co-branded websites covering school, higher education, professional development and non-academic studies.

The plans are part of the internet strategy outlined in January when Pearson, which also owns the Financial Times, TV production companies and Penguin books, raised £250m to ease its passage on to the web. The company has made a series of investments in dot.com companies operating in education and made another small investment in a business called Classroom Connect yesterday.

Among other plans, FT.com, Pearson's online version of the Financial Times has been relaunched on a far more ambitious scale while FTMarketWatch, the online service for retail investors, launched in Britain two weeks ago.

Bob Pittman, president of AOL said: "We are committed to improving education by leveraging all the online medium has to offer. Together with Pearson we can present educational opportunities for people at every stage of their lives."

fields.headline: Delight of the divas
fields.standfirst:
Randy Crawford, Dionne Warwick and Gladys Knight ****
Hammersmith Apollo, London
fields.trailText:
Randy Crawford, Dionne Warwick and Gladys Knight ****
Hammersmith Apollo, London
fields.body:
For a night going under the banner The Divas, there was a surprising lack of dramatics and petty posturing from the stars. "We're three sisters, divas I got a problem with," remarks Dionne Warwick, the closest a manicured foot gets to being stomped. Warwick, Gladys Knight and Randy Crawford made some of the biggest hits of the golden era of soul, from the early 60s to the mid 80s, and when they open together with That's What Friends Are For, it's difficult to guess who will come off best.

Randy Crawford, resplendent in layers of lilac, looks happy but self-conscious as she eases her way into Rainy Night in Georgia. While her gentle but soaring vocals sound ageless, and the widest smile in soul is kept in place, the fragility of her voice appears to be no gimmick. "I need to go on a diet," she says, forlornly. "Oh well, I guess some men like women like this." As she takes her time through a collection of gems including Almaz and Knocking on Heaven's Door, Crawford is surprised by the ecstatic reception she's given. "Do you like me?" she asks, less a pop princess than an eager-to-please child. Her urban street sound, always more New York than Motown, and genuine delight at the dancing crowd is a revelation.

But while dipping into the back catalogue means joy for Crawford, Dionne Warwick seems less thrilled. She sprints through the classics, just throwing in a chorus in the case of You Won't Get to Heaven if You Break My Heart. Walk On By, Alfie and A House Is Not a Home follow at breakneck speed. After witnessing Crawford's emotional response, Warwick's professionalism appears cold. As controlled as her vocals, Warwick knows all she has to do is turn up to get 'em gasping.

Gladys Knight, by contrast, is determined to put on a soul spectacular. Backing singers, two dancers - including brother Bubba Knight, one of the original Pips, as well as her band - show that Knight is out to party. And she parties hard. From the pure funk of Friendship Train to the gut-wrenchingly beautiful Memories, Knight has the personality, looks and moves of a superstar. You're always aware you're watching something special, even though the act is so polished it's more worthy of Vegas than Hammersmith. It's a shame there's so much time spent reminiscing about the good old days,when all you want to hear is that fantastically earthy yet delicate voice. With emotion, professionalism and passion on display, it was the night of the diva after all.

webTitle: US investors pull $2 trillion out of sin stocks

fields.headline: US investors pull $2 trillion out of sin stocks
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: More than $2 trillion (£1.31 trillion) of mutual fund and pension money in the United States has been redirected into companies that are deemed to be socially responsible, writes Phillip Inman .
fields.body:
More than $2 trillion (£1.31 trillion) of mutual fund and pension money in the United States has been redirected into companies that are deemed to be socially responsible, writes Phillip Inman .

In 1999 alone, more than $1 trillion was pulled out of industries that sell products considered damaging to the community - tobacco, gambling, weapons and alcohol - and switched into companies with a cleaner image.

US commentators credit much of the switch out of "sin" stocks, which took off in the 1960s, to communities influenced by age-old Methodist, Quaker and Jewish moral teaching, including pacifism and temperance.

Britain follows this pattern to some extent. Friends Provident is one of Britain's best known ethical investors and has Quaker roots. The exception is the brewing sector, which is considered an acceptable vehicle by most ethical investors and is not much of an issue now that Bass and Whitbread have turned themselves into leisure companies.

Size, however, is where the US ethical investment business wins, and the extent to which fund managers are prepared to table motions at annual general meetings complaining about various socially irresponsible practices.

British fund managers are timid by comparison. A recent report in the US pointed out that nearly $1 trillion of the $2.16 trillion invested in responsible companies is placed by "investors who play an active role in shareholder advocacy on social responsibility issues".

The report, by the Social Investment Forum, says that more than 120 institutions and mutual fund groups have used assets of £922bn to back shareholder resolutions.

Much of this activity is in support of more modern campaigns, such as improved labour relations, birth control and abortion and animal welfare.

webTitle: Start of quiet revolution in pension funds

fields.headline: Start of quiet revolution in pension funds
fields.standfirst:
Companies to face ethical questions from managers of mainstream funds
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The country's largest insurance company, CGNU, is putting the finishing touches to a new policy. Called Socially Responsible Investment, it means that companies in which the group has invested £200bn will in future be judged on how they make their money - and not just how much they make.
fields.body:
The country's largest insurance company, CGNU, is putting the finishing touches to a new policy. Called Socially Responsible Investment, it means that companies in which the group has invested £200bn will in future be judged on how they make their money - and not just how much they make.

The insurer - formed by the merger of CGU and Norwich Union - has joined a growing list of institutions which have decided that the companies they invest in should worry about pollution, child labour and other issues which are not normally the concern of fund managers or analysts.

It follows Prudential, CIS, and Friends Provident, which pioneered the idea of ethical investment in the 1980s with its Stewardship Fund, now worth £1.5bn.

They will shortly be joined by more large pension funds with investments worth about £150bn.

According to research by the consultancy Environmental Resources Management (ERM), 21 of the 25 largest pension funds will apply social responsibility criteria to at least part of their portfolios. Four of the largest funds - including BT's £29bn and the university lecturers' £20bn - will be managed entirely according to an SRI policy.

Company chairmen, chief executives and finance directors will need to take note of the trend.

A survey this week confirmed that social responsibility is taken seriously in the boards of the biggest groups, but beyond a small leadership cohort, money is all that counts.

So far most large companies have been able to ignore the relatively small ethical investment funds run by managers such as Henderson/NPI and Jupiter. But they are now likely to be faced with questions about social and environmental performance from the managers of mainstream funds, not just the ethical specialists.

The impetus for this quiet revolution is a minor amendment to pension law, which means that from Monday next pension funds will need to tell members whether they take account of anything except financial performance when choosing investments.

Social responsibility

Until a couple of years ago the idea of pursuing anything other than maximum financial returns would have been preposterous, except for the small band of ethical investors in specialist retail funds.

The new pensions regulation, which has already spread beyond pensions to other institutions, changes all that by bringing social responsibility into the mainstream.

The amendment to the 1995 Pensions Act says trustees must declare in their annual statement of investment principles:

"The extent [if at all] to which social, environmental or ethical considerations are taken into account in the selection, retention and realisation of investments; and their policy [if any] directing the exercise of rights [including voting rights] attaching to investments".

This is not about avoiding companies simply because they are in a controversial business, such as tobacco or arms manufacture, which is the traditional ethical investment approach.

Instead SRI is based on the hard-headed view that every business has an impact on society and those which take that seriously will produce the best financial returns.

Keith Jones, managing director of CGNU's Morley Fund Management, explained: "Our strategy will adopt the prin ciple of 'positive engagement'. It will not seek actively to exclude companies from our investment portfolios on the basis of ethical, environmental and/or social issues but will encourage companies to improve their performance."

Eventually, however, Morley will be prepared to divest, if it believes a company's failure to address issues is likely to hit investment performance.

Fund managers are taking a number of different approaches to the issue. Friends Provident announced in May that it was to scrutinise its entire £16bn investments for ethical issues. It is using its ethics research team to feed information to fund managers.

Merrill Lynch Investment Management (the new name - from last night - for Mercury Asset Management) says that it aims to encourage companies "to adopt and pursue socially responsible business practices".

But the business does not have specialist researchers to provide information to back such "encouragement"- nor does it offer an SRI portfolio service to pension funds.

Not thought through

Tom Woollard, a director of ERM, said this was typical of the pension funds surveyed. "When they were questioned further about what their policy of engagement means many of them didn't know. This hasn't necessarily been thought through", he said.

David Gould, investment director of the National Association of Pension Funds, said most trustees were keen to be seen to be doing something, but most were being cautious about introducing SRI into their investment criteria.

Local authorities, which are traditionally more interested in ethical issues, are at the forefront. Councils including Lothian, Norfolk, Lancashire and Nottingham have already handed out mandates for a portion of their funds to be managed on an SRI basis.

Not all fund managers are adopting SRI. Four of the 25 funds surveyed by ERM have decided to reject the whole idea and stick to investing purely on financial grounds. By Monday, they had better be ready to explain why to their members.

fields.headline: Hanging on every sound
fields.standfirst:
Terry Callier ****
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
fields.trailText:
Terry Callier ****
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
fields.body:
Gilles Peterson and Talkin' Loud brought Terry Callier back to the spotlight in the wake of the late 80s "jazz-boom". The grizzled, soft-voiced singer/guitarist was dropped into folk or soul racks for years, despite his jazzy agility. But a younger and more flexible audience over the past decade has been happy to hear Callier's diverse talents coexist, as naturally as they do in his head.

That's what happened at the Pizza Express, where Callier played two full-length shows back to back. He was accompanied by a subtle local jazz ensemble featuring Jim Mullen on guitar and Dave Barnard on bass, with Bosco D'Oliviera's mellow, propulsive congas. The band added fine nuance to passages that needed no more than that, swung Callier's reflective, confiding songs when it wouldn't hurt them to canter a little, and provided ideal bouyancy when he put his acoustic guitar aside to be a freewheeling, scat-singing jazz vocalist.

Callier has long been a songwriter of immense diversity and eloquence, with classics such as Occasional Rain and What Colour is Love still eagerly demanded by audiences who have maybe felt shortchanged by some of his more recent output. In this setting, the singer could relax and forget his profile before full houses that hung on every sound.

Guitarist Jim Mullen excelled himself (singers seem to bring out the best in him): in the eloquently spiritual Keep Your Heart Right, he doubled the tempo in a solo that somehow intensified the emotion while sustaining the song's eerie stillness. Then Mullen went the other way, supplying only a minimal chime and slur behind Callier's quiet wail on a bluesy shuffle. There, the singer's sudden eruption into a defiant falsetto tingled the spine. Callier's fine-tuning of timbre gives his voice immense power at low volumes, and his sense of drama and contrast creates an atmosphere of intense expectancy. He sang Summertime almost in a whisper (to the Miles Davis/Gil Evans chords), and Satin Doll in long, sliding elisions in which Mullen's high guitar fills sounded almost flute-like. Heartwarming music.

Guitarist Jim Mullen excelled himself (singers seem to bring out the best in him): in the eloquently spiritual Keep Your Heart Right, he doubled the tempo in a solo that somehow intensified the emotion while sustaining the song's eerie stillness. Then Mullen went the other way, supplying only a minimal chime and slur behind Callier's quiet wail on a bluesy shuffle. There, the singer's sudden eruption into a defiant falsetto tingled the spine. Callier's fine-tuning of timbre gives his voice immense power at low volumes, and his sense of drama and contrast creates an atmosphere of intense expectancy. He sang Summertime almost in a whisper (to the Miles Davis/Gil Evans chords), and Satin Doll in long, sliding elisions in which Mullen's high guitar fills sounded almost flute-like. Heartwarming music.

fields.headline: Telecom shares slump
fields.standfirst:
Ericsson chief's warning over high price of 3G licences sparks slide
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Shares in European telecommunications companies took a hammering yesterday after one of the industry's top executives warned that the high cost of third generation mobile licences could slow the pace of growth.
fields.body:
Shares in European telecommunications companies took a hammering yesterday after one of the industry's top executives warned that the high cost of third generation mobile licences could slow the pace of growth.

The sell-off was sparked by Kurt Hellstrom, the chief executive of Ericsson, the world's third largest makers of mobile phone handsets who said the fees being paid were "too high". 'The warning hit stocks hard. Britain's most valuable mobile company Voda foneAirTouch sank 7.9%, while Ericsson's rival Nokia plunged more than 10%.

Expectations about the amount to be raised from the sale of the new generation of mobile phone licence have escalated since Britain's auction in the spring raised some £22.5bn, prompting other countries to reconsider the way they planned to allocate their licences.

Germany, France, Italy and the Netherlands are among those where 3G licences will be up for offer over the coming months - with the German auction, for example, expected to raise more than £30bn. The new generation licences will allow mobile phone companies to offer services such as the internet and video-conferencing.

In an interview with the Swedish newspaper Dagens Industri, Mr Hellstrom was quoted as saying: "It is clear that growth on the mobile market risks slowing as a consequence of the high [licence] charges. It's like petrol. It's clear that we consume less petrol with the high price."

However, he made it clear that he believed growth would still be "quite strong because I believe the services offered are attractive".

His remarks had a sharp im pact on the sector, which has been undermined by worries that the cost of licences will force operators to scale back investment in their 3G networks and seek to pass on costs to consumers in the form of higher prices.

Ericsson shares lost almost 5% after the comments. In the City, BT shares lost 2.3% while the Vodafone fall contributed 60 points to the 74.5 point fall in the FTSE 100 share index which ended the day at 6239.

Deutsche Telekom, another big player in the battle for 3G licences, saw its shares fall 6%. "The whole sector is very weak today," said Trudbet Merkel, a fund manager at Deka Kapital in Frankfurt. "Investors are worried about the long-term profitability of [3G] licences, especially for companies with global ambitions like Deutsche Telekom."

A report that the German company was also planning a $99bn (£68bn) bid for Sprint also weighed on Deutsche Telekom's share price.

With share prices falling, Ericsson tried to soften the impact of Mr Hellstrom's remarks. The group forecast back in April that there would be 1.4bn mobile phone users and 1bn internet users by 2005 and yesterday said it was sticking to its forecasts.

Mr Hellstrom acknowledged concerns about the cost of 3G licences "but does not see any reason for a warning regarding the pace of market development," the company said.

Matthew Lewis, technology analyst at Daiwa SBMC Europe said the full impact of licence costs would not become clear until after the German auction which will begin at the end of July.

"There are obviously fears about the high cost of 3G licences but there's no evidence to justify these share price falls," he said.

webTitle: OECD puts pressure on Britain to toughen up corruption laws

fields.headline: OECD puts pressure on Britain to toughen up corruption laws
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ministers were under renewed pressure last night to toughen up Britain's century-old laws against corporate corruption after the west's most influential think tank said that rules to combat bribery did not meet international standards.
fields.body:
Ministers were under renewed pressure last night to toughen up Britain's century-old laws against corporate corruption after the west's most influential think tank said that rules to combat bribery did not meet international standards.

The Paris-based Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development said that Britain, along with Switzerland, needed to be tougher on companies that pay sweeteners to win lucrative contracts.

Despite being none of 21 countries ratifying an international convention outlawing bribery, Britain had been arguing that its 1906 Prevention of Corruption Act was sufficient to deal with any problems.

However, the OECD's finding that Britain's regime is insufficient because "there is no explicit provision in the UK law that criminalises bribery of foreign public officials" is said to have caused a change of heart in Whitehall, with the Home Office now drawing up plans for new laws.

Sources said that bribing foreign officials would be made a criminal offence so that Britain would come into lines with the other OECD countries that have amended their domestic laws as a result of the convention.

Despite resistance from civil servants, it will become an offence for a British citizen to offer, promise or give a bribe to a foreign public official to obtain or retain international business deals, irrespective of where the offence is committed.

fields.headline: Uefa plot refuses to thicken
fields.trailText: Some of her majesty's press were nursing thick heads and red faces here yesterday which, for once, could not be blamed on the 24-hour availability of Belgian beer.
fields.body:
Some of her majesty's press were nursing thick heads and red faces here yesterday which, for once, could not be blamed on the 24-hour availability of Belgian beer.

It was strong words, not ale, which led several newspapers to claim, sensationally if erroneously, that Uefa had officially accused Kevin Keegan of conning the English public. And ironically it was the newspapers who had poured most bile over Keegan during England's brief visit to the tournament who suddenly became most indignant on his behalf.

It is true that a withering indictment of Keegan appeared on the Euro 2000 website, which is said to get 69m hits a day, accusing him of "not knowing his best formation, let alone his best team". But it was written not by a Uefa bigwig but by a British journalist who has been working for the website during Euro 2000.

Conspiracy theorist scribes, however, leapt to the conclusion that it was a German attack, particularly as Germany, who had an even worse tournament than England, escaped similar chastisement.

The anonymous scribe on the Uefa website reported: "The way England stumbled through the qualifying process should have informed every England supporter not to make plans to travel to the Low Countries beyond June 20."

Warming to the attack on Keegan, it continued: "Unwisely, Keegan, a personable head coach who finds it hard to restrain his own enthusiasm, added to the delusion. He declared that having sneaked through the back door to Euro 2000, who was to say England could not win it?"

The report appeared on the website last Saturday but chunks of it were regurgitated in English newspapers only on Wednesday, when it was portrayed as an official Uefa assessment.

Emphasising how English fans were conned by Keegan's optimism about his team's chances here, it said: "They took the bait and swallowed it whole." A good day, then, for Uefa to announce an Englishman as its new director of communications: Mike Lee, currently the Premier League's chief press officer.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: Turkey get a new coach, Phnom Penh gets tough, Spain's coach owns up and a Turk defends his honour.
fields.body:
Italy's captain Paolo Maldini is fit to face Holland tonight, and the injured Antonio Conte's place goes to Luigi di Biagio or Massimo Ambrosini. Holland are expected to make one change, Giovanni van Bronckhorst replacing the injured Arthur Numan. Roy Makaay will miss the rest of the tournament with an ankle-ligament tear.

 Turkey have named Senol Gunes as their coach in place of Mustafa Denizli, who has joined Fenerbahce. Gunes, a former national goalkeeper, played for Trabzonspor and also coached the club in the late 80s.

 Police in the Cambodian capital Phnom Penh yesterday ordered dozens of illegal betting shops to close. "This kind of gambling is illegal and causing serious traffic jams. Many restaurants and almost all money-exchange shops have become betting shops," said Lach Vannak, the city's deputy police chief.

 Spain's coach Jose Antonio Camacho says he made an error by leaving Valencia's Fernando Morientes out of his squad. "I made a mistake, I accept that. But we did score seven goals... and that's not so bad."

 Turkey's defender Alpay Ozalan, who was sent off for punching Portugal's Fernando Couto in the quarter-final, is in further trouble for using his fists, this time on an Istanbul taxi driver. Apparently the cabbie banged on Alpay's windscreen shouting, "You destroyed us," and pushed a newspaper with the headline "Alpay, traitor" against a window.

The player and his father got out and the argument soon turned to blows. "Everybody is getting on my son's back. For this reason we had a fight in the street with a taxi driver," his father said.

webTitle: Another fado for Figo and co

fields.headline: Another fado for Figo and co
fields.trailText: Roy Collins sees Portugese ambition castrated by another heartbreaking semi-final defeat.
fields.body:
A nation that can adopt something as mournful as the fado as its national music is clearly used to the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune.

The outside world was ready to mourn with the Portuguese last night. The world loves them not just because of a natural sympathy for perennial losers but because their best teams have always lit up tournaments such as this with their passionate attacking football.

They were everyone's second team in the World Cup of 1966, where the abiding memory is of the distraught Eusebio, the team's leader then and their cheerleader here, after semi-final defeat by England.

In 1984 they pushed even harder at the door of the European Championship final, leading France 2-1 until denied even a penalty shoot-out by a 118th-minute winner by Michel Platini.

At first, last night, it seemed that Portugal, the great entertainers of this tournament, simply did not possess enough collective belief that they could overturn a side with the pedigree of the world champions. Either that, it seemed, or the prospect of another heartbreaking semi-final defeat had castrated their ambition.

But even Brazil understand that the beautiful game sometimes develops a few wrinkles. And we were soon to discover that the Portuguese had not gone awol. They were simply lying doggo, waiting for the right moment to spring the most elaborate ambush of Euro 2000.

And when that moment came, how brilliantly they executed the ambush. Nuno Gomes made France pay the highest penalty for Didier Deschamps's defensive indiscretion with a strike to match anything else we have seen here, his fourth goal of the tournament.

Luis Figo and Rui Costa, joint conductors of the Portuguese orchestra, rarely got more than a meaningless touch in the first 20 minutes. But as the Portuguese grew in belief, they began to weave their familiar silky patterns to establish more of a hold on the game.

The true test for them came, however, after Thierry Henry's equaliser. Their defence, after all, had not conceded a goal since the one scored by England's Steve McManaman in the 18th minute of the opening game, a championship record of 392 minutes.

Portuguese fans must have felt the gods were smiling on them when they found they had been allocated what, for the first half at least, was the sunny end of the King Baudouin stadium. But at the end they were still awaiting their day in the sun.

fields.headline: Arsenal shell out £6m in Brazil
fields.trailText: Arsenal have doubled their complement of Brazilians with the signing of the defensive midfielder Edu for £6m, according to reports from South America.
fields.body:
Arsenal have doubled their complement of Brazilians with the signing of the defensive midfielder Edu, according to reports from South America.

The 22-year-old says that his club Corinthians have agreed a £6m fee with the Gunners, who signed the full-back Silvinho from the same club a year ago.

Edu, whose full name is Eduardo Daude Gaspar, said: "It's incredible that they are willing to pay so much for me. I haven't played for Brazil yet but they have signed me on a five-year contract worth a lot of money.

"Even my coaches at Corinthians are surprised at the kind of money the English are prepared to pay. I'm flying to London to have a medical and taking my brother as my adviser."

The world club champions could hardly believe their luck either. "It took us by surprise; it was his agent who sorted it out," said Corinthians' spokesman Luciano Signorini. "It was a good deal for us so we let him go."

Edu has been a first-team regular only since the start of the year, when he stepped into the gap left by the departure of the Colombian Freddy Rincon.

Arsenal are also reported to be close to signing Edmilson, yet another Brazilian. But the 32-year-old Croatian Davor Suker is leaving Highbury after completing a free transfer to West Ham and signing a two-year deal.

Steve Watson should complete his £2.5m move to Everton from Aston Villa by the end of the week. The 26-year-old met the Everton manager Walter Smith at Goodison Park yesterday to discuss personal terms after the clubs agreed on the fee. The England B international, who can play at right-back, right midfield or centre-half, must still have a medical, possibly today.

Nick Barmby, meanwhile, has been given until the weekend to decide whether he wishes to stay at the Merseyside club. Everton have offered to make the England winger their highest paid player, on £27,000 a week, but if - as seems likely - Barmby rejects a new deal, Smith will seek to sell him for at least the £5.75m he cost from Middlesbrough.

Chelsea, who would be interested in Barmby, completed the signing of the Croatian international Mario Stanic from Parma of Serie A for £5.6m, bringing their summer spending to £25m. "I think I can play in two, or a maximum of three positions - right side, or striker, or a little bit behind the striker - but the decision will be from the coach," said Stanic.

The Birmingham City defender Gary Rowett yesterday agreed to join Leicester in a £3m deal. He will become new Foxes manager Peter Taylor's first major signing since he took over a fortnight ago.

Taylor's old club Gillingham have confirmed their midfielder and coach Andy Hessenthaler as their player- manager.

The former Dundee manager Jocky Scott has been named manager of Second Division Notts County.

England Under-21 will warm up for their Euro-pean Championship qualifying campaign by taking on Georgia at Middlesbrough's Riverside stadium on August 31.

fields.headline: Italy 0 - 0 Holland
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Italy: Toldo, Cannavaro, Iuliano, Nesta, Zambrotta, Fiore, Di Biagio, Albertini, Maldini, Del Piero, Inzaghi. Subs: Abbiati, Antonioli, Ferrara, Negro, Di Livio, Pessotto, Ambrosini, Montella, Totti, Delvecchio.

Holland: van der Sar, Bosvelt, Stam, F. de Boer, Zenden, Overmars, Davids, van Bronckhorst, Cocu, Bergkamp, Kluivert. Subs: de Goey, Westerveld, Reiziger, Seedorf, Konterman, van Vossen, R. de Boer, van Hooijdonk, Winter.

Referee: M Merk (Germany)

1 minute Less than a minute in and we already have the first off-side of the match. But - shock horor - it's not Inzaghi, but his strike partner Del Piero.

3 The first chance. Bergkamp spins off his marker, clips a delicate ball over the top, but Cocu's nifty toe-end goes over Toldo - and the bar.

6 Inzaghi falls over after a bit of a challenge - he goes off on a stretcher but is soon back on. Now there's a surprise.

8 Davids stands over the ball for a while, looking fierce.

10 It's all a bit scrappy at the moment - the Italians seem quite happy.

12 Van Bronckhorst crosses from the right and Bergkamp gets his head on to the ball. Sadly for the massed ranks of Oranje, he just uses his forehead to pad it back flabbily to Toldo.

14 Italy can't get the ball at all. The Dutch pass it around in the Italian half, Zenden has a shot, they get it back and pass it around a bit more. Suddenly, Bergkamp cuts inside from the right and is clear in the box - he smashes a left-foot shot past the advancing Toldo and full onto the face of the left-hand post.

16 The first yellow card - Zambrotta is booked for hacking down Zenden.

19 Juilano is boooked for cynically tripping up a speeding Overmars. Is the ghost of Gentile returning to the Italian team?

21 Dutch have had 70 per cent of the possession, but the Italian's are just hanging back and saying "Bring it on!" They nearly pay the penalty when van Bronckhorst's cross is met by Kluivert 15 yards out. However he can only loop it into Toldo's loving hands.

24 The Dutch win yet another corner. But yet again it comes to nothing - it's well taken by the dominant looking Toldo.

26 Overmars wins another free-kick after Maldini brings him down. The ball's whipped in but it glances off Stam's globe and wide.

28 The ball enters the Dutch penalty area for the first time in about 20 minutes. The Italians make nothing of it.

29 The astute Bergkamp takes a quick free-kick to release Zenden. He goes down in the box. Penalty? Don't be silly - not with a dive like that. Zenden is rightly booked.

31 Zenden is bundled down out wide and the Dutch win yet another free kick in a dangerous position. But once again it lands on an Italian head and is cleared. What's the Dutch for David Beckham?

33 SENDING OFF! Zambrotta makes a silly challenge - tripping Zenden again - and gets his second yellow. He holds his hands up in mock innocence but the referee's having none of it. "Off you go!" he says, manfully.

36 Italy seem to have gone even more defensive if that's possible.

37 PENALTY TO HOLLAND. Overmars turns past Maldini and plays it in the box. It zips around a bit then Nesta tugs Kluivert's shirt. Penalty! Toldo is booked in the verbal exchanges afterwards. Frank De Boer runs up to take it...

38 AND IT'S SAVED. Toldo leaps to his left and makes a brilliant save, right out of the top draw, Ron. Brilliant.

41 Italy get a free kick. The ball enters the Dutch box, and stays in there for about two seconds. Then it's cleared, but at least it's first time the Italians have made any sort of attacking effort in about 15 minutes.

43 Kluivert makes a decent contact from a cross but the increasingly calm Toldo plucks it out of the air like a Harlem Globetrotter. Smooth.

45 The ball comes to Kluivert 20 yards out and he juggles it - not once, not twice, but three times on his knee - and enters the area. What skill, what verve, what imagination!! Then he shins it wide...

First half injury time Yellow card! This time Maldini is booked.

HALF TIME: Italy 0 - 0 Holland Can anyone remember the last time the Italians were this negative? Surely it's just a matter of time before Dutch do them...

46 Zoff hasn't made any changes at half-time. Italy are still playing 4-4-1, with Del Piero playing right-wing. How long before will he resist the temptation to change things. I give it 10 minutes...

47 Italy have a shot on target! No really. Well sort of...Fiore fires one in from 20 yards, it deflects off Stam and it's clearly going wide. But Van Der Sar punches it out for a corner anyway.

49 Yellow card! Davids brings down Albertini 25 yards out. It's central and Del Piero is eyeing it the same way the Big Bad wolf eyed Little Red Riding Hood...

50 But.his lame shot strikes the wall and goes over the bar. Italy can't make anything with resulting the corner.

54 Holland have started sloppily this half, and Italy are actually attacking more with 11 men than ten. Inzaghi is fouled by Stam on corner of the box. He gesticulates wildly for a yellow card but the referee looks at him non-plused. Again this is a good chance for Del Piero to fire one of his trademark wicked crosses...

55 Or hit one straight into the first defender, as he does here...

58 The Dutch are still - not surprisingly - having the majority of the possession, but they're not looking particularly threatening. Oh wait, Zenden's just hit a smart shot from 20 yards out - but it's straight at Toldo.

61 PENALTY! David's bursts into the penalty area. And Juliano chops him down. It's a clear penalty despite Juliano's protestions. Will it be one of the De Boers? No this time it's Kluivert...

62 AND HE'S HIT THE POST. Incredible. Just incredible. It wasn't cleanly struck, but Toldo was going the wrong way...

66 Italy substitution Inzaghi (sorry spreadbetters, he's had no offsides whatsoever this game) goes off for Delvecchio. Zoff replacing an attacker for another attacker. Now that's bold - for him anyway.

68 Zenden fizzles one in but it goes well wide.

70 It's all Holland. Surely a goal is just a matter of time. Italy are defending deeper and deeper. Give it ten minutes and they'll be in the stands.

71 Del Piero moves out of the way and let's van Bronckhurst shot from 25 yards. It's a decent attempt but it crashes against the stanchion at the back of the goal.

72 Davids, who has had a fairly quiet game by his standards, makes one of his trademark 50 yard charges. He's finally brought down 25 yards out by Juliano (how long can it be before that man's sent off?). Jaap Stam looks like he's going to thump one...

73 But his free-kick hits Fiore, who can't be more than two yards away from him. Encroachment anyone? Apparently not, according to Mr Merk...

75 Yellow card! van Bronckhurst for a challenge on Albertini, who fell down and twisted like a girl. It was never a booking...

77 Holland substitution: Van Vossen for Zenden.

78 Italy substitution: Pessotto for Albertini.

81 Italy substitute: Totti for Fiore.

83 Italy enter the Dutch half for the first time in, oh, about 30 minutes and Delvecchio is suddenly played through. 20 yards out he shoots....

86 Holland substitution: Seedoorf on for Bergkamp.

88 Yellow card! This time it's for Di Biaggio.

91 Holland are straight on the attack again. The Italian's are now defending level with the penalty spot.

93 But another Holland attack breaks down and Del Piero plays an exquisite ball through to Totti, who is then cynically brought down by Jaap Stam. Not surprisingly, the Manchester United defender receives a yellow card.

102 Another great block! This time it's Juliano who hurls himself in front of a Bosveldt drive and the ball squirms away. It hasn't been a classic by any means, but it's still incredibly compelling...

105 Half time. Just 15 minutes to go before penalties...

106 Italy earn a free kick 40 yards out. Del Piero takes it. Poor, poor, poor!!! It's completely overhit and floats harmlessly out for a goal-kick.

108 Kluivert and Overmars exchange a great one-two, which sends Kluivert clear. But he shoots with his weaker left foot and it drifts agonisingly wide. 109 Kluivert again drifts into the area and wins a (slightly fortunate) corner. But he injures himself in the process and goes off the pitch.

111 The corner comes to nothing. Kluivert had just a minor knock on his ankle and is now back on the field.

113 Both teams are now very tired, but despite having the extra man and most of the possession, Holland aren't creating many chances. Will the Dutch regret substituting Bergkamp?

118 There's now just two minutes of extra time left (plus stoppage time) before penalties...

120 Oh no we're not. There's going to be two extra minutes of stoppage time. Can the Dutch steal it at the death?

121 Thirty seconds to go and the Dutch win a free-kick in a dangerous position... But the Italian clear yet again.

Italy will take the first penalty, but they're shooting into the goal at the Dutch end of the ground.

Di Biaggo will take the first penalty - the man who missed one in Paris in the World Cup two two years ago - he runs up...

SAVED! It's staight at Toldo and he saves it! Still 1-0 Italy.

Pessotto steps up.

He scores! 2-0 Italy.

Jaap Stam will be next. Surely he has to score.

NOOOOOO! He's blazed it way, way, over. The ball's now in orbit, and it's still 2-0 to Italy.

No! Van Der Sar blocks it! It's still 3-1 and Holland are just about still in the game.

SAVED! What a game Toldo has had.

fields.headline: Peers in power
fields.standfirst:
Reform of the House of Lords may have lessened the in-built Tory majority, but it has not succeeded in eradicating an anti-Labour bias
Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: The idea that the reformed House of Lords is now so packed with "Tony's cronies" that it is little more than the supine pet dog of parliament is exploded by a new analysis demonstrating that the upper house is as revolting as ever. Two new government defeats this week over ministers' social security plans demonstrated that, in spite of its reformation at the beginning of this parliamentary year, the Lords inflicts far more regular defeats on the Labour government than it ever did while the Tories were in power.
fields.body:
The idea that the reformed House of Lords is now so packed with "Tony's cronies" that it is little more than the supine pet dog of parliament is exploded by a new analysis demonstrating that the upper house is as revolting as ever. Two new government defeats this week over ministers' social security plans demonstrated that, in spite of its reformation at the beginning of this parliamentary year, the Lords inflicts far more regular defeats on the Labour government than it ever did while the Tories were in power.

The motive behind the expulsion of the hereditary peers from the Lords was to remove its in-built Tory majority. The "interim" house has 695 members (compared with 1,138 previously), some 83% of whom are life peers compared with 39% a year ago. The rest are 89 elected hereditaries, 26 bishops and two royal office holders.

So far Tony Blair has approved the creation of 202 new peers. At an average of 66 new peers each year, Mr Blair is appointing new life peers at a higher rate than any previous prime minister of the past 40 years. Only half of them are Labour; 37 are Tory, 31 Liberal Democrat, 32 crossbenchers and two are classified as "other".

This is almost as many as the 216 new peers Lady Thatcher created during her 11 years in power and certainly exceeds the 143 Harold Wilson created during his first Labour government, or the 83 he ennobled during his period in office between 1974-76.

The effect of these changes has, surprisingly, been to increase the average age of the Lords from 65 to 67 years. This is because with the hereditaries went a number of younger peers. The old Lords had 147 members under 50 but now has only 51 in that age group. There are 17 peers over 90. By contrast MPs' average age is 52. One of the difficulties facing Labour before it reformed the Lords was that the party had only 47 peers under the age of 70, making it very difficult for them to deliver a reasonable vote let alone a majority on a daily basis. There was a danger that without change the government would simply not be able to get its business through.

The expulsion of most of the hereditaries has reduced the direct influence of the Tory party. Before, the Tories had 41% of the votes, the crossbenches 29%, Labour 15% and the Liberal Democrats 6%. In the new Lords the Tories are still the largest party but their 232 peers now command 33% of the votes; Labour's voting power has gone up to 199 or 28%, the crossbenchers have been reduced to 24% and the Liberal Democrats have been boosted to 9%. The remaining 6% is made up of bishops and others who have no formal party allegiance.

Although its role as a "revising chamber" was often lauded during the Thatcher years in the 80s, there were far fewer government defeats than there have been since Labour's landslide victory in 1997. Indeed this has been the pattern throughout the last 30 years, as the chart demonstrates.

During Edward Heath's government from 1970-74 the Tory interest suffered a total of 26 defeats, giving an average of only 6.5 per session. During the Wilson and Callaghan period between 1974 and 1979 there were 356 government defeats in the Lords - an average of 59.5 per session. Harold Wilson had it particularly bad. There were 103 defeats in 1974/75 and 126 in 1975/76, when 85% of the votes that took place in the Lords ended in defeat for the government.

The contrast between the Major and Blair years is equally striking. In the last two years of John Major's administration, when the Lords was seen to be regularly bringing grief to ministers, and particularly to the home secretary, Michael Howard, and his "prison works" plans for criminal justice, there were actually only 10 government defeats in each session. In Tony Blair's first year the number had soared to 39 and a further 31 were inflicted during 1998/99. The frequency may not have reached the scale of the open warfare between the Lords and the Labour government that was seen during the second Wilson administration, but it demonstrates a level of hostility that just was not experienced during the years of Tory dominance in the Commons.

So what impact has the expulsion of most of the hereditary peers had upon the government's record in the Lords? Well, so far there have been 17 defeats since the start of the parliamentary year last November - about half the level experienced by ministers in the old unreformed house.

They have involved controversial issues ranging from the ban on the promotion of homosexuality to the question of war widows' pensions. Some, such as the abolition of defendants' choice of jury trial, involved a rebellion by Labour's own peers. Others, such as the abolition of grammar schools by parental ballot or sex education lessons, were opposition victories. It has been estimated that the government would not have lost seven out of these 15 key votes if they had expelled all the hereditary peers, as the number of surviving hereditaries voting against the government was larger than the scale of the defeat.

The evidence shows that the first stage of Lords reform may have removed its in-built Tory majority but not its anti-Labour majority. Despite many jibes to the contrary, the government is still operating in basically hostile territory whenever it tries to get its legislation through the upper house of parliament.

alan.travis@theguardian.com

*House of Commons library research paper 00/61, Lords reform: the interim house
www.parliament.uk

In the last two years of John Major's administration, when the Lords was seen to be regularly bringing grief to ministers, and particularly to the home secretary, Michael Howard, and his "prison works" plans for criminal justice, there were actually only 10 government defeats in each session. In Tony Blair's first year the number had soared to 39 and a further 31 were inflicted during 1998/99. The frequency may not have reached the scale of the open warfare between the Lords and the Labour government that was seen during the second Wilson administration, but it demonstrates a level of hostility that just was not experienced during the years of Tory dominance in the Commons. So what impact has the expulsion of most of the hereditary peers had upon the government's record in the Lords? Well, so far there have been 17 defeats since the start of the parliamentary year last November - about half the level experienced by ministers in the old unreformed house. They have involved controversial issues ranging from the ban on the promotion of homosexuality to the question of war widows' pensions. Some, such as the abolition of defendants' choice of jury trial, involved a rebellion by Labour's own peers. Others, such as the abolition of grammar schools by parental ballot or sex education lessons, were opposition victories. It has been estimated that the government would not have lost seven out of these 15 key votes if they had expelled all the hereditary peers, as the number of surviving hereditaries voting against the government was larger than the scale of the defeat. The evidence shows that the first stage of Lords reform may have removed its in-built Tory majority but not its anti-Labour majority. Despite many jibes to the contrary, the government is still operating in basically hostile territory whenever it tries to get its legislation through the upper house of parliament. alan.travis@theguardian.com *House of Commons library research paper 00/61, Lords reform: the interim house www.parliament.uk

webTitle: Controversial animal park owner John Aspinall dies

fields.headline: Controversial animal park owner John Aspinall dies
fields.trailText: Millionaire wild animal park owner John Aspinall died today  after losing a three-year battle against cancer, his family said.
fields.body:
Millionaire wild animal park owner John Aspinall died today after losing a three-year battle against cancer, his family said.

The 74-year-old is survived by his wife Sarah, two sons Damian and Bassa, daughter Amanda and two stepsons Jason and Amos Courage.

His half-brother James Osbourne said his two wild animal parks - Howletts, near Canterbury and Port Lympne, near Folkestone, Kent - would continue to be run by the John Aspinall Foundation "in the manner and philosophy of their founder".

webTitle: Backlash fears in Oxford elitism row

fields.headline: Backlash fears in Oxford elitism row
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The vice-chancellor of Oxford university has warned in a letter to former students that ministers who stoked up the row over state school admissions may have "harmed the very cause they were championing".
fields.body:
The vice-chancellor of Oxford university has warned in a letter to former students that ministers who stoked up the row over state school admissions may have "harmed the very cause they were championing".

In a sign of his continuing anxiety about accusa tions of elitism, Colin Lucas has taken the unusual step of writing to 150,000 graduates of the university in a letter enclosed with the latest edition of Oxford Today, its alumni magazine, sent out this week.

"What I fear ... is most damaging about the debate that politicians have been engaged in over the past weeks is the effect it may have on the confidence of able state school pupils to apply to world class universities," he wrote.

"I hope that by raising an issue which they clearly feel as strongly about as we do, politicians have not, in fact, harmed the very cause they were championing."

He describes Laura Spence, the Tyneside state school student whose cause was taken up by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, when she was refused a place to read medicine at Magdalen college, as "a well-qualified young lady".

"The college had five places and 23 applicants and the tutors' assessment was that, although she had the potential to make a good doctor, other candidates were stronger."

He adds: "I am drawing your attention to the matter again as I want you to understand Oxford's true position on admissions. I cannot state too strongly that we are committed to recruiting the brightest and best students, wherever they come from."

Independent sch ools yesterday denied that universities admissions were skewed in their favour. Philip Evans, head master of Bedford school, and Sue Fishburn, headmistress of Leeds girls' high school, said private schools not only won proportionately more A grades at A l evel than state schools, but an even bigger proportion of A grades in the toughest subjects.

"Far from independent schools taking an unfair proportion of places at the best universities, the evidence suggests that they are making a disproportionately large contribution to ensuring that the nation has a new generation of scientists, mathemeticians and linguists," Dr Evans and Mrs Fishburn said in a statement.

Giving evidence to the Commons education select committee, Dr Evans said it would be "a dangerous move" to introduce quotas for state school candidates and ignore private school pupils with better qualifications.

Mrs Fishburn conceded that there was a case for giving preferential treatment to students who had "fought their way through the system" from state schools with low-achieving pupils.

fields.headline: The best diary scene
fields.standfirst: The virgin suicides
fields.trailText: Grosse Pointe, the 1970s. Still trying to digest the inexplicable suicide of the youngest Lisbon sister, Cecilia, the neighbourhood boys pore over a loosely bound, bright pink book. One of their number, Tim Weiner (Jonathan Tucker), speaks in voiceover.
fields.body:
Grosse Pointe, the 1970s. Still trying to digest the inexplicable suicide of the youngest Lisbon sister, Cecilia, the neighbourhood boys pore over a loosely bound, bright pink book. One of their number, Tim Weiner (Jonathan Tucker), speaks in voiceover.

"Our collection of souvenirs of the Lisbon girls, which still exists, started with Cecilia's diary. Parkie had gotten it from Skip Ortega, the plumber's assistant, who found it next to the toilet in the bathroom. Chase and Paul decoded it."

Tim's friend Paul Baldino (Robert Schwartzman) scrutinises the journal.

"The main thing is no stability."

The other boys crowd round.

"Look at the i's. The dots on them. They're everywhere. Basically, what we have here is a dreamer. Completely out of touch with reality. When she jumped, she probably thought she was flying."

He reads aloud, as if to prove his point.

"Monday, February 13. Today we had frozen pizza."

His companions are fascinated.

"Thursday. Mom made cream corn for dinner. The worst."

He reads on.

"Mary chipped her front tooth on the monkey bars acting like an idiot. She made a big scene, and had to go and get her tooth capped. It looks OK, I guess."

Tim turns to his friends, a note of triumph in his voice.

"Told you she had a capped tooth."

See also: Young Frankenstein, Cruel Intentions, Heavenly Creatures

Don't see also: The Pillow Book

Pointless trivia: Robert Schwartzman's brother is Jason, star of Rushmore, and his cousin is Sofia Coppola, director of The Virgin Suicides.
