fields.headline: PPPPPPP(P), P (for preview) and P(R)
fields.trailText: POSTPONED PRONOUNCEMENT PROLONGS PARANOID PORTUGUESE PENALTY PALAVER (PROBABLY)
fields.body:
POSTPONED PRONOUNCEMENT PROLONGS PARANOID PORTUGUESE PENALTY PALAVER (PROBABLY)

It's a swizz the like of which the Portuguese haven't seen since Ferdinand Magellan failed to fall off the world. That's right, our Iberian cousins are uncharacteristically hot under the collar over the penalty which got them kicked out of Euro 2000 last night.

"What happened yesterday was inadmissible and unforgivable," the legendary Eusebio wrote in this morning's edition of sports daily O Jogo (Portuguese for the Yoghurt). "Portugal were eliminated by a linesman who was scared of France, scared of the world champions," he went on. "We were hindered in '66 and have been penalised again for being a country with a small voice at world level."

Eusebio is now so bitter and twisted that he has become a pretzel. Xavier himself is not far behind, and he is currently telling every Portuguese citizen individually that it wasn't his fault. Guv. "My conscience is clear," he told a priest in Porto. "If you try to block the ball, you cannot do that without your hand supporting you on the ground," he pleaded with an advocate in the Algarve. "You just can't do that without hands, that's impossible," he told a farmer in Funchal.

The only flaw in Mr Xavier's argument (who, following Slaven Bilic, becomes the second consecutive post-tournament villain to play for Everton) is that his hand did not support him until after he'd reached out to poke Sylvain Wiltord's cross behind, as any of the millions who've seen the incident on telly would be able to tell him.

In fact, the only people who haven't made their minds up about the incident are Uefa. A disciplinary committee have postponed until Sunday a decision on what to do about the post-penalty rumpus which saw Nuno Gomes sent off and Rui Jorge reportedly aim a headbutt at Igor Sramka, the eagle-eyed linesman in question. The Fiver presumes they're waiting to interview Xavier's amazing left arm.

ORANJE BUMMER

Ever since de Oranje crushed Yugoslavia 6-1, Euro 2000 expectations in the Netherlands have risen sky high. So high in fact, that even Johan Cruyff has been seen smiling. But one man who hasn't caught Orange Fever is dour-faced Dutch manager Frank Rijkaard, and he's injecting a smidgen of common-sense ahead of tonight's game against Italy.

"It's not right and it's not good," was his sober assessment of the mass hysteria. "We are facing an extremely strong opponent. The result against Yugoslavia doesn't matter any more. The final is still a long way away," he continued, before dramatically announcing: "One thing is certain; it's going to be really difficult." So difficult in fact, that he's beefing up his attacking options by bringing in Gio van Bronckhurst for the injured Arthur Numan.

Meanwhile, confident Italian coach Dino Zoff reckons his team are ready and relaxed. "Everybody is fit. We have no tired players and we have had enough time to recharge our batteries," he said. Everybody except the injured Antonio Conte, that is, whose place will be taken by Luigi Di Biagio. A shock starter - according to the Italian press - will be Alessandro Del Piero, with Francesco Totti relegated to the subs' bench. Not that anyone believes them - they've been saying since the start of the tournament.

Holland: (probable) Van der Sar; Bosvelt, De Boer, Stam, Van Bronckhorst; Zenden, Overmars, Cocu, Davids; Bergkamp, Kluivert.

Italy: (probable) Toldo; Cannavaro, Nesta, Maldini; Zambrotta, Di Biagio, Albertini, Fiore, Pessotto; Totti, Inzaghi.

QUOTES OF THE DAY: A JOHN-GREGORY-IN-AMSTERDAM SPECIAL

"Only 10 percent of my time in Amsterdam has been doing television work. It's the place to be. It's quite amazing" - an open-minded John Gregory.

"It is not a job for me at the moment, if ever. You have to have the credentials to get the job and the only credentials that I have for it at the moment are that I am English" - John Gregory returns to England, now curiously relaxed.

THE NEWCASTLE GUIDE TO GOOD PR

1. Sell £500 bonds to fans who believe they are buying a secure seat for ten years.

2. Stroke the money. Mmm, money.

3. Come up with super plan to shift 4,000 bond-holder's seats to another part of the stadium so the space can be used to entertain corporate freeloaders.

4. Sniff cash. Ooh yes.

5. Watch impassively as six angry fans take you to court in a test case on behalf of 250 others who also objected to being moved. Watch them lose.

6. Watch impassively as the fans subsequently lose their appeal too, with the Lord Chief Justice today ruling that you had the legal right to move the supporters, "however sympathetic one may feel" towards them.

7. Point out that you have run up £198,000 legal costs despite having previously told the fans - according to Jane Duffy, one of the aggrieved - that, "£100,000 would pay the costs of both sides in the action".

8. Say nothing when Duffy explains that the six angry supporters "raised money from fans throughout the country to take out insurance to cover £118,000 in legal costs but now Newcastle want £198,000... it seems to me that the club wants blood and that makes me very, very bitter and angry."

9. Keep very quiet as fans' solicitor Richard Cramer says: "We shall not be claiming any of our legal costs. It is now up to Newcastle as to whether they wish to make these fans bankrupt and put them at risk of losing their homes. This would fly in the face of earlier promises from the club which said the last thing they wanted to do was to take the houses from these individuals... the indications now are that they want to claim to the bitter end."

10. Pat wallet. Wow that's firm.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Juventus are still hoping to tempt Arsenal into selling Patrick Vieira this summer. The Italian club sent representatives to watch him play for France last night, and are prepared to offer £6.5m plus defender Igor Tudor and striker Juan Esnaider for his services. Arsenal look likely to resist all approaches for the combative midfielder.

Arsene Wenger has confirmed that Arsenal are set to sign Brazilian midfielder Edu today, but did not give a likely completion date for the transfer.

Don Hutchison is hoping to move to Celtic this summer according to his agent, Rachel Anderson. "Celtic is a massive club," she told the Daily Record. "Don would be happy to play in Scotland if the conditions are right in terms of football, money and lifestyle."

Real Madrid have offered Real Zaragoza £15m plus midfielder Guti for Savo Milosevic, according to reports from Spain.

Promising Tranmere Rovers midfielder Alan Mahon looks set to make a surprising move to Portuguese champions Sporting Lisbon this summer. The 22-year-old is available under the Bosman ruling and is expected in Lisbon today to tie up the move.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Ipswich have put goalkeeper Richard Wright on the transfer list. Wright, who has one year remaining on his Portman Road contract, has been unable to reach an agreement on a new deal. "This leaves the club no option other than to make him available for transfer," Ipswich chairman David Sheepshanks said today.

Brighton have won permission to stay at Withdean Stadium until the end of the 2002-03 season. Brighton and Hove Council planners also voted in favour of allowing the club to install another 960 seats to increase capacity at the athletics stadium to 7,000.

Dunfermline have completed the signing of PSV Eindhoven's Lithuanian defender Andrius Skerla. The Pars have also agreed terms with Rennes for Moroccan international Youssef Rossi but his move has been held up by work permit problems.

BBC1: Match of the Day Live (4.30pm)

Italy v Holland. Martin O'Neill v Alan Hansen. BBC sport v The patience of the viewing public.

MOTD @ Euro 2000 (12midnight)

The same thing but without rows.

Euro 2000 Replay (1.05am)

The same thing but without sleep.

ITV: Euro 2000 Today (11.30pm)

It's only a matter of time before Sideshow Bob accidentally presents the whole show sitting the wrong way round in his chair, with the back of his head to camera. Could tonight be the night?

The Big Match (2.35am)

Sit through this patiently and you'll be rewarded with...

World Football (4.15am)

Woo hoo!

Channel 5: Major League Soccer (4.30am)

San Jose Burger v Old El Paso Taco Kit

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (6.30pm, 8.30pm, 10.30pm SS3)

If it's not Uefa and their excellent competition, we don't want to know.

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Football (8pm)

One of the many Euro 2000 programmes on Eurosport tonight which, for some reason, we can't be bothered to list any more.

Radio 5 Live: Euro 2000 Live (5pm)

Live Euro 2000 football, from the home of live radio.

fields.headline: You bet your life: Day 15
fields.trailText: Yesterday Scott Murray recommended backing France to win with a goal golden at 14-1 - and scooped a phenomenal £280. Which explains why he's currently way ahead on a Donald Trump-esque £396.42.
fields.body:
Yesterday Scott Murray recommended backing France to win with a goal golden at 14-1 - and scooped a phenomenal £280. Which explains why he's currently way ahead on a Donald Trump-esque £396.42.

Our other columnists were close (Sean Ingle predicted a 2-1 France win after 90 minutes and Mike Hodgkinson went for 2-2 with Zidane scoring the golden goal winner) but just not close enough.

Two days to go, two bets left. It's the second semi-final - Italy v Holland.

Totals so far:
Scott Murray £396.42
Sean Ingle £60.97
Mike Hodgkinson £17.08
Paul MacInnes RIP

Scott Murray

Holland to win in 90 minutes 5/6 (£50)

If any team blows hot then cold, it's Holland. So because they've just flamed Yugoslavia to a crisp, their fans must be very worried indeed. Especially as they're facing Italy, who have won all their games so far, grinding out results with resolute defending and smash 'n' grab attacking.

But the followers of the Oranje shouldn't care. It's one thing keeping Emile Mpenza at bay, another altogether Patrick Kluivert. This will be Italy's first real test of Euro 2000, and even an out-of-sorts Holland may be too big a step up for them. The Italians have made a meal of every match they've played, and really rocked against Romania before the post and the red mist got the better of Gheorghe Hagi. So expect them to be found out tonight.

Sean Ingle

Italy to win on penalties 8/1 (£20)

Yesterday I not only predicted that Portugal would score first, but I then said that France would go on to win 2-1. Heck, I even pointed out a nice little earner from betting on Blanc kissing Barthez's bald palate. So what did I get for these rare moments of gambling foresight? Absolutely diddly squat, because after 90 minutes the score was 1-1. Next time I tell you, next time

Tonight's match will be also be tight, and there's a good chance it will be level after 90 minutes. But seeing as I'm a jaw-dropping £340 behind Scott Murray, the odds of 11/5 aren't exactly tickling my tender spots. For that reason, Holland to win during the golden goal period and Italy to win on penalties appeal. We haven't had a penalty shoot-out yet, so let's go for that. Both teams are equally inept at taking them but for some reason I fancy the Azzuri to break Oranje hearts. Just watch me weep when Holland win it with a golden goal.

Mike Hodgkinson

webTitle: MPs see 'no advantage' in education contractors

fields.headline: MPs see 'no advantage' in education contractors
fields.standfirst: Education and Employment Select Committee
fields.trailText: A committee of MPs agreed today that only a small number of schools would benefit from private management and that there was no innate advantage in bringing in private contractors.
fields.body:
A committee of MPs agreed today that only a small number of schools would benefit from private management and that there was no innate advantage in bringing in private contractors.

Declaring that each case must be examined on its own merits, the report of the parliamentary education sub-committee said: "We do not consider that private sector organisations are inherently more skilled or more likely to achieve high standards than public sector organisations."

The report, which recommends that successful local authorities are twinned with failing ones so that they can share expertise, said that although public and private sectors will continue to work together, only a small number of authorities need the intervention of private business in the management of their services.

In these cases there must be a 'clear case' made out that an LEA had proved incapable of rescuing the situation before private contractors could take over. Even then, the ultimate responsibility for education should remain with locally elected representatives.

School standards minister Estelle Morris claimed that the report endorsed the government's view that private companies can play a role in state education.

"We have not lost sight of the need for accountability where outsourcing occurs," she said. "LEAs retain responsibility for the monitoring of both the contract and delivery of service to schools."

The committee reached its conclusions after visiting the United States to compare the British education system with the American charter schools, which were publicly funded outside of school districts.

In England, they heard evidence from executives, teachers and councillors, some of whom said they could foresee a time when the whole education system would be privatised.

Neil McIntosh, from CfBT Education Services, said that while it was the state's job to ensure all children got a good education, "it was not necessarily the role of the state to provide education services to achieve this".

fields.headline: Transcript: Julie Myerson live online
fields.standfirst: The author of Sleepwalking and Laura Blundy discusses the importance of sex in fiction and reveals her ideas for her next book. Read the full talk thread here.
fields.trailText: The author of Sleepwalking and Laura Blundy discusses the importance of sex in fiction and reveals her ideas for her next book. Read the full talk thread here.
fields.body:
shem32
I've read quite a few otherworldly Victoriana novels recently - Peter Carey's Jack Maggs, Sarah Waters' Affinity, your Laura Blundy. Do you think it's a phase the early 2000's are going through?

JulieMyerson
I'm not sure about phases (and though I love Peter Carey generally I thought Jack Maggs was more like a piece of repro furniture - beautifully done, but what's the point? All I know is that I wanted a different landscape, somewhere exciting and (to me at least) new to go when I was writing.

I'm sure I ended up writing about the same old things (motherhood, love, ghosts, darkness) but to me it felt new and that was important. But other people have made the same point as you - I think it's sometimes possible that ideas are sort of in the air and you pick up on them - so suddenly you get a whole lot of writers doing something slightly similar ...

btanzilo
I am about halfway through the new book (in its galley form here in the US - I work at an independent bookseller) and I have a question about the era. It took me a bit of time to grasp the fact that the story takes place in a Victorian setting. My mind began to assemble what seem like clues to the time period, rather than knowing it from the start. Was this on purpose or am I simply a dim bulb? If it was your intention to insinuate rather than state the era, what was your reasoning? Do you feel the era is crucial to the story or more incidental. Is it a story that couldn't be set in London in 2000?

Anyway, a Bristol-born friend of mine introduced me to your books earlier this year and I have since devoured (it seems an appropriate word) all of them and was happy to discover a galley of the new one here in the shops.

JulieMyerson
Hello Bobby - who's your Bristol friend? i went to university in Bristol ... do I know him/her? To answer: no, you're not a dim bulb and yes, you're absolutely right on everything. I wanted the reader to be unsettled, confused, to have the rug pulled from under their feet a little. This is not easy-on-the-eye history, no balls, bonnets or sweet ladies with baskets on their arms.

I wanted to write about Victorian times in a modern, non-cliched way, getting rid of all the stuff we automatically bring to it (from costume dramas on TV and even a lot of fake Victorian novels). I wanted to make the people speak in a normal way, using the kind of slang that I'm sure they would have used but that novelists of the time did not always choose/feel able to write. I'm not good at history, but a couple of historians I've come across have confirmed this to be so.

And the story? Well, I'm not sure if it could be set in London now - my characters are living at street level in a way that only the homeless do now... to me the era felt crucial because I wanted the atmosphere of the river, and was especially inspired by photos of London before the embankments, sewers and underground railways were built. Everything was awkward, smelly, inept and skewed.

blackbird21
With all the fuss made over the sex in your previous books, are we to assume Laura Blundy, 'a Victorian pastiche', will not touch on the subject?

JulieMyerson
Page for page there's actually not much sex at all in any of my novels (no, really, I swear it!) - it's just the type of sex. In Sleepwalking, no one could believe I dared write about someone so very bulkily pregnant having and enjoying sex. In fact one (male) publisher who loved the book and wanted to publish it even asked if I could just make my heroine a 'little less pregnant' in the 'bonking scenes'. I did not realise I was addressing a taboo when I wrote it, to me it just seemed like the truth. I just try to write about sex as I truly perceive (or sometimes, let's face it, imagine) it to be - ie. wonderful, terrifying, and with all the bodily fluids, the mess, the uncertainty, the no going backness, etc.

I'm proud to do this - and yes, there's a small amount of sex in Laura B and, I suppose, yes, it's sex with an amputee - but what I'm really trying to say is that people are not always beautiful or thin or complete (of limb!) but love with them is still crucial, vital, still the business really... why do hardly any authors seem to write about this? To me it seems an obvious subject, not an exotic or saucy one!

btanzilo
Hello, me again. I had another question after reading blackbird21's. In all of your books sex plays a prominent role, but it's never the type of "fantasy"-style sex most authors write, nor is it what most people would call "normal" sex - sex with an amputee, sex with a tremendously fat man, pregnant sex.

Is this your way of driving home the point (no pun intended) that human sexual experience is not always a fantasy land and that people love one another and make choices based on reasons outside conventional ideas of beauty?

Or is it simply a way to spice things up, add dimension to the story?

Now i promise to leave you alone.

Bobby

JulieMyerson
Hi Bobby, back to you. I love your next question because basically you just illustrate and explain what I just said. So YES, absolutely, is the answer - oh, all right, and to spice things up a bit of course. Stories have to have drama, characters who are up against it, with something at stake. Love and sex and whether or not you should/can/dare have it seem to me to be one of the ultimate dramatic situations.

mmreed
Are you already working on your next book? What will it be about?

JulieMyerson
Yes I am, but if I tried to describe it it would sound either weird or very boring or both. The ideas I tend to begin a book with (ie very few) always seem very babyish and ludicrous. I just write my way through/into them until the smoke clears and I begin to see what I am writing about. The glimpses you get are SO exciting! The world seems to be divided into writers who would never write in such a fumbling way and writers who only can. I haven't told anyone this, but at the moment my heroine is called Lindsay and has short hair and an awkward stout body and no confidence in herself and she does a job that is very repellent to people. Can't tell you any more and all of this may change. (And she's not Victorian, not yet anyway.)

tamara
Dear Julie, who were your first influences to become a writer, and which authors do you rate today?

JulieMyerson
So many. I always read and I have always read. At 13 I read all Daphne du Maurier and wrote to her announcing that I was going to be an author like her (!) and asking for advice. She kindly wrote back to me (can't remember the advice) and kept on writing back when I kept on pestering her... she must have been extremely generous to write so many letters and I still have most of them. I loved so many people like Enid Blyton, Noel StreatfieldÉand I was amazed to read Tom's Midnight Garden by Philippa Pearce to my own children a few years ago and realise that it had influenced me in the writing of Sleepwalking, my first novel (ghosts, time, a sense of longing and beauty and mystery and sadness).

Today I love individual books more than writers. My top ones that spring to mind are - in no particular order - Sabbath's Theatre (Roth), Disgrace (Coetzee), A Child In Time (McEwan), The Tax Inspector (Peter Carey), any Updike, Sue Miller, Jane Hamilton, Anne Tyler, Alice Hoffman, Toni Morrison, some of Rupert Thomson, The Salesman by Joseph O'Connor. I'm especially aware that I love American writers (oh yes, and Jane Smiley) and I think it's that I love their lack of uptightness, their natural grace. Too many British writers are too busy being concerned with their own cleverness, instead of just getting on and telling a wonderful story.

miner49er
Julie,

Are you a pen and paper girl or do you write on a PC? And do you work conventional hours, or do you prefer burning the midnight oil?!

JulieMyerson
Have just moved from an old-fashioned Amstrad to a proper computer so now can email all my writer friends, and I also like that the printer's quick. Have to type, can't read my own handwriting and also can't believe anything I handwrite is any good (I would love to be one of these people who could write a whole novel in an exercise book in a cafe ...).

Three kids means I have to write in conventional hours, and on the whole I think that's fine because all this insisting that you can only write at dead of night is like imagining much great art has only ever been written by people who are stoned or drunk. On the other hand, both my man and I sometimes wish we could do that blissful thing of writing till, say, 7 or 8, and then sloping off to a wine bar together and then perhaps just doing another hour later on. Instead it's home at 6.15 and straight into spellings, times tables, the Romans in Britain... ah well, one day.

rgsharp
I liked the way that in Laura Blundy the language of the Victorians was so fresh - because today we can include words they would have considered obscene in a novel. Did you research all this language, and if so where did you find it? Or did you just use your instincts?

JulieMyerson
Yes, that's a good question. I did research the language and on the whole I can just about swear that it is all 100% genuine Victorian. But I hope it doesn't sound Victorian and I do want it to make people do a double take, to think hold on, could they have said that then... (to a certain extent I am asking for trouble by doing this, because one or two critics assumed I had tried it on or made mistakes). I chose to use only slang that is either still very much in use today, or else that we haven't ever heard on a BBC costume drama. The music that the language of the book makes in my head is very peculiar and very satisfying to me, and that was the point really. One critic took exception to my characters saying Yeah, but really she was wrong. Of course yeah wasn't written down or spelled like that then, but do we really mean to say that every Victorian from every walk of life always pronounced the 's' on the end of yes?

buttercup23
I read that your husband is also a novelist, as well as an Oscar-nominated screenwriter. Do you have any plans to collaborate, maybe turning one of your books into a film? Do you find it helps to have a partner who is also a writer?

JulieMyerson
Yes! He and I are just about to adapt Laura B for Channel 4 TV, all v exciting though nothing actually signed as yet. We work extremely well together because we have no reverence whatsoever for each other's work. Everyone, including my film agent, agreed that Laura B was unfilmable to start with, but Jonathan has produced a treatment that not only works, it's wonderful. That's the advantage of living with a screenwriter (the drawback is that he is SO BOSSY).

buttercup23
A recent report found that the majority of writers cannot afford to live off the money that they earn from writing. Do you think that this is a parlous state of affairs, or is it good for writers to get out into the world a bit? How did you sustain yourself while writing Sleepwalking?

JulieMyerson
Of course writers should earn more. I am not at all badly paid for my novels compared to some, but I couldn't live off just my novels so I do bits of journalism that pay so much better for so much less, which is not very gratifying (and the easier and crasser the bit of writing, on the whole the better you will be paid for it). My husband pointed out to me recently that I am paid for my novels at about the same rate as a barista at Pret A Manger.

It always sounds grand when a writer gets a large sum for a novel (and if, like me, more than one publisher wants to publish you, then there's competition so at least you get goodish amounts) but, stretched over two or more years, it's pathetic... I'd be happy if I just got paid what an editor of my age gets in any of the major publishing houses.

I wrote Sleepwalking at nights and weekends whilst doing a part-time job and having my third baby. We could not afford any childcare on my days off so it was all done in the scraps and fag ends of my day - and with a huge amount of support from my man, who understood how important it was to me that I did it. I had no idea it would be published and, looking back, I don't know how I kept going. It was a delight and a luxury to be able to write the second in the daylight (ie I got paid just about enough to give up the day job...).

blackbird21
Reading about your rather unusual childhood in a recent magazine article, I wonder whether you agree with the idea that having some emotional upheaval in a life makes for a better writer?

JulieMyerson
It would be nice to think so but I'm not sure, I really don't know - has anyone ever done any research on how many authors who win the Booker have divorced parents? All I know is that though I always thought I coped with my father's rejection of me and subsequent suicide rather well, there are definitely great dark holes in my head that I sometimes seem to explore when I write. I don't understand them and sometimes they scare me (in fact I realised quite recently that I tend to write about all the things that scare me - as a way of keeping control perhaps?).

What I'd be writing if I didn't have them I'm not sure, but I am sure I'd be writing. I don't write for therapy but because of the wonderful zingy moment of satisfaction when a group of words come together and express something absolutely perfectly. Yes, that's why I write.

Kudra
Following on from Bobby's question, there don't seem to be many novelists who write about sex in such an honest and unglamorous way - the choice is often between flowery, overblown descriptions, or the crass 'bonking and shagging' of the 'city girl' genre... Why do you think this is? Which other writers do you think tackle this subject in a realistic way?

JulieMyerson
Thank you for saying honest and unglamorous, because that's just what I'd like to be. I really honestly don't know why, though I tend to think that British women writers, though extremely clever, are disappointingly coy about sex. I just don't do coy, and I try to write before I think - that's how the best and sharpest things come out. As soon as you think too much you stop telling the truth.

I like men like Roth, Updike - as I said before. Life and sex are really pretty much entwined, aren't they - I mean even if you don't do it, you'll have an interesting attitude to not doing it. It's hard to understand much about a character if you don't understand how they feel about sex - that's where I'm coming from, whereas some writers seem to tack sex on as something incidental (and therefore a bit embarrassing). But I have been influenced by a huge number of good writers who can do sex.

shem32
Does a book begin with a character, or a situation, or a first line - or is it more complicated than that? Do you know what will happen as you write?

JulieMyerson
I think I answered this in a previous answer really. But to be more specific, the first line I write is never the one that ends up being the first line of the novel. I do so much editing all the time, going over and over refining and deleting what I've done, sometimes I can barely remember what I began with. But I do think writing novels is half about writing and half about knowing how to be ruthless and edit yourself, how to get rid of a passage even if you spend all day on it if it's not working... I read some bad novels that have simply not been edited by anyone, least of all their authors.

trapeze What's the next trend for women's contemporary fiction now that the 'Bridget Jones' genre seems to have saturated the shelves? Can we expect something a bit more intelligent than the 'get me a boyfriend, save my career' novel?

JulieMyerson Despite the massive publicity and sales, the Bridget Jones genre as you put it is still only a genre - more a product, like a magazine. Literary fiction is what interests me - by which I mean novels written not for quick easy sales, but because the author wants to express ideas/feelings and maybe play around with language/style etc. These novels are all over the tables at, say, Waterstones, all of the time, and they are new, fresh and deeply exciting. Some are not so good (authors take risks which don't always work out) but many are just brilliant. You won't have heard of them like you have Bridget Jones, but I bet you anything that the best of them will last longer.

btanzilo
Hello Julie,

My Bristol friend is Nick Peters, who, after seven years in America, recently returned to Bristol and bought a house with his hometown sweetie. They've spent the past three months stucco-ing, painting, and comparing swatches. Sickening, really. But before he was in Milwaukee, he was at university in Leeds for a few years, so it's been a long time since he's been in Bristol full-time, so I suspect your having crossed paths with him is unlikely. But he will be excited to know that we discussed him, so I couldn't help but respond to your question.

I just thought I'd tell you that I left off last night when Ewan's head bobs back up (p. 207 here in the States)!

As a small-minded person, I'm glad that you veiled the Victoriana as I would most likely have put off reading the book and felt a little disappointed that you'd sold out to grannies! Instead, I'm thoroughly enjoying the book, although I love Sleepwalking the best - although that may be because, as in love, there's nothing like the first time. The thrill of discovery, if you will.

Cheers, Bobby

JulieMyerson
Yes, tell your friend we discussed him and I think Bristol's a great city - in fact, one day I'm going to write a novel set there (Me and the Fat Man, which is published by Ecco in the States, was set in Bath, almost next door ...) Thanks for your great questions. Did you say you were a bookseller? Please try and sell Laura B for me. It comes out in October!

Best wishes, Julie

Have to type, can't read my own handwriting and also can't believe anything I handwrite is any good (I would love to be one of these people who could write a whole novel in an exercise book in a cafe ...). Three kids means I have to write in conventional hours, and on the whole I think that's fine because all this insisting that you can only write at dead of night is like imagining much great art has only ever been written by people who are stoned or drunk. On the other hand, both my man and I sometimes wish we could do that blissful thing of writing till, say, 7 or 8, and then sloping off to a wine bar together and then perhaps just doing another hour later on. Instead it's home at 6.15 and straight into spellings, times tables, the Romans in Britain... ah well, one day. rgsharp I liked the way that in Laura Blundy the language of the Victorians was so fresh - because today we can include words they would have considered obscene in a novel. Did you research all this language, and if so where did you find it? Or did you just use your instincts? JulieMyerson Yes, that's a good question. I did research the language and on the whole I can just about swear that it is all 100% genuine Victorian. But I hope it doesn't sound Victorian and I do want it to make people do a double take, to think hold on, could they have said that then... (to a certain extent I am asking for trouble by doing this, because one or two critics assumed I had tried it on or made mistakes). I chose to use only slang that is either still very much in use today, or else that we haven't ever heard on a BBC costume drama. The music that the language of the book makes in my head is very peculiar and very satisfying to me, and that was the point really. One critic took exception to my characters saying Yeah, but really she was wrong. Of course yeah wasn't written down or spelled like that then, but do we really mean to say that every Victorian from every walk of life always pronounced the 's' on the end of yes? buttercup23 I read that your husband is also a novelist, as well as an Oscar-nominated screenwriter. Do you have any plans to collaborate, maybe turning one of your books into a film? Do you find it helps to have a partner who is also a writer? JulieMyerson Yes! He and I are just about to adapt Laura B for Channel 4 TV, all v exciting though nothing actually signed as yet. We work extremely well together because we have no reverence whatsoever for each other's work. Everyone, including my film agent, agreed that Laura B was unfilmable to start with, but Jonathan has produced a treatment that not only works, it's wonderful. That's the advantage of living with a screenwriter (the drawback is that he is SO BOSSY). buttercup23 A recent report found that the majority of writers cannot afford to live off the money that they earn from writing. Do you think that this is a parlous state of affairs, or is it good for writers to get out into the world a bit? How did you sustain yourself while writing Sleepwalking? JulieMyerson Of course writers should earn more. I am not at all badly paid for my novels compared to some, but I couldn't live off just my novels so I do bits of journalism that pay so much better for so much less, which is not very gratifying (and the easier and crasser the bit of writing, on the whole the better you will be paid for it). My husband pointed out to me recently that I am paid for my novels at about the same rate as a barista at Pret A Manger. It always sounds grand when a writer gets a large sum for a novel (and if, like me, more than one publisher wants to publish you, then there's competition so at least you get goodish amounts) but, stretched over two or more years, it's pathetic... I'd be happy if I just got paid what an editor of my age gets in any of the major publishing houses. I wrote Sleepwalking at nights and weekends whilst doing a part-time job and having my third baby. We could not afford any childcare on my days off so it was all done in the scraps and fag ends of my day - and with a huge amount of support from my man, who understood how important it was to me that I did it. I had no idea it would be published and, looking back, I don't know how I kept going. It was a delight and a luxury to be able to write the second in the daylight (ie I got paid just about enough to give up the day job...). blackbird21 Reading about your rather unusual childhood in a recent magazine article, I wonder whether you agree with the idea that having some emotional upheaval in a life makes for a better writer? JulieMyerson It would be nice to think so but I'm not sure, I really don't know - has anyone ever done any research on how many authors who win the Booker have divorced parents? All I know is that though I always thought I coped with my father's rejection of me and subsequent suicide rather well, there are definitely great dark holes in my head that I sometimes seem to explore when I write. I don't understand them and sometimes they scare me (in fact I realised quite recently that I tend to write about all the things that scare me - as a way of keeping control perhaps?). What I'd be writing if I didn't have them I'm not sure, but I am sure I'd be writing. I don't write for therapy but because of the wonderful zingy moment of satisfaction when a group of words come together and express something absolutely perfectly. Yes, that's why I write. Kudra Following on from Bobby's question, there don't seem to be many novelists who write about sex in such an honest and unglamorous way - the choice is often between flowery, overblown descriptions, or the crass 'bonking and shagging' of the 'city girl' genre... Why do you think this is? Which other writers do you think tackle this subject in a realistic way? JulieMyerson Thank you for saying honest and unglamorous, because that's just what I'd like to be. I really honestly don't know why, though I tend to think that British women writers, though extremely clever, are disappointingly coy about sex. I just don't do coy, and I try to write before I think - that's how the best and sharpest things come out. As soon as you think too much you stop telling the truth. I like men like Roth, Updike - as I said before. Life and sex are really pretty much entwined, aren't they - I mean even if you don't do it, you'll have an interesting attitude to not doing it. It's hard to understand much about a character if you don't understand how they feel about sex - that's where I'm coming from, whereas some writers seem to tack sex on as something incidental (and therefore a bit embarrassing). But I have been influenced by a huge number of good writers who can do sex. shem32 Does a book begin with a character, or a situation, or a first line - or is it more complicated than that? Do you know what will happen as you write? JulieMyerson I think I answered this in a previous answer really. But to be more specific, the first line I write is never the one that ends up being the first line of the novel. I do so much editing all the time, going over and over refining and deleting what I've done, sometimes I can barely remember what I began with. But I do think writing novels is half about writing and half about knowing how to be ruthless and edit yourself, how to get rid of a passage even if you spend all day on it if it's not working... I read some bad novels that have simply not been edited by anyone, least of all their authors. trapeze What's the next trend for women's contemporary fiction now that the 'Bridget Jones' genre seems to have saturated the shelves? Can we expect something a bit more intelligent than the 'get me a boyfriend, save my career' novel? JulieMyerson Despite the massive publicity and sales, the Bridget Jones genre as you put it is still only a genre - more a product, like a magazine. Literary fiction is what interests me - by which I mean novels written not for quick easy sales, but because the author wants to express ideas/feelings and maybe play around with language/style etc. These novels are all over the tables at, say, Waterstones, all of the time, and they are new, fresh and deeply exciting. Some are not so good (authors take risks which don't always work out) but many are just brilliant. You won't have heard of them like you have Bridget Jones, but I bet you anything that the best of them will last longer. btanzilo Hello Julie, My Bristol friend is Nick Peters, who, after seven years in America, recently returned to Bristol and bought a house with his hometown sweetie. They've spent the past three months stucco-ing, painting, and comparing swatches. Sickening, really. But before he was in Milwaukee, he was at university in Leeds for a few years, so it's been a long time since he's been in Bristol full-time, so I suspect your having crossed paths with him is unlikely. But he will be excited to know that we discussed him, so I couldn't help but respond to your question. I just thought I'd tell you that I left off last night when Ewan's head bobs back up (p. 207 here in the States)! As a small-minded person, I'm glad that you veiled the Victoriana as I would most likely have put off reading the book and felt a little disappointed that you'd sold out to grannies! Instead, I'm thoroughly enjoying the book, although I love Sleepwalking the best - although that may be because, as in love, there's nothing like the first time. The thrill of discovery, if you will. Cheers, Bobby JulieMyerson Yes, tell your friend we discussed him and I think Bristol's a great city - in fact, one day I'm going to write a novel set there (Me and the Fat Man, which is published by Ecco in the States, was set in Bath, almost next door ...) Thanks for your great questions. Did you say you were a bookseller? Please try and sell Laura B for me. It comes out in October! Best wishes, Julie

webTitle: Fed holds rates steady as economy cools

fields.headline: Fed holds rates steady as economy cools
fields.trailText: Signs that the American economy is cooling down persuaded the US federal reserve to keep interest rates on hold yesterday.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson in New York, and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
Signs that the American economy is cooling down persuaded the US federal reserve to keep interest rates on hold yesterday.

The decision by the US central bank to keep the cost of borrowing steady at 6.5% was widely expected, after it raised rates sharply last month.

Wall Street rallied on the news. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1% after the announcement, while the Nasdaq composite index, hit hard by six rate increases in the past 12 months, gained almost 3%.

The Fed said the economy was slowing but it was watching for signs of inflation. "Recent data suggest that the expansion of aggregate demand may be moderating toward a pace closer to the rate of growth of the economy's potential to produce," its statement said.

Since May's 0.5% rise in rates, unemployment has risen from 3.9% to 4.1%, retail sales have slowed and house prices rises have moderated.

With the economy growing at an annual pace of 5.4% in the first quarter, analysts are reluctant to declare that the next rates move will be down.

"This means the market will shift its focus to the August 22 meeting," said Phil Orlando, chief investment officer of Value Line Asset Management. "We do think at this point there will be a 25 basis point tightening at that time but that will be the end of the tightening cycle."

Orders to US factories for big-ticket goods shot up in May, a sign that the slowdown may be a mirage. "The manufacturing sector is not cooling off anywhere near as much as previously believed," said Mark Vitner, economist at First Union.

Policymakers on both sides of the Atlantic are concerned that overconfidence may be pushing share markets dangerously high. The Bank of England today warns investors of the risk of a sharp correction. "Equity markets in general and hi-tech stocks in particular continue to be highly valued on conventional measures," the Bank says in its biannual report on the stability of the financial sector.

fields.headline: Nail bomber awaits jury's verdict
fields.trailText: David Copeland, the man who carried out the fatal nail bomb attack on a gay bar in London, was today waiting for an Old Bailey jury to return its verdict on three counts of murder.
fields.body:
David Copeland, the man who carried out the fatal nail bomb attack on a gay bar in London, was today waiting for an Old Bailey jury to return its verdict on three counts of murder.

The jury was told by Judge Michael Hyam to decide whether the nail bomber was suffering from diminished responsibility at the time he launched his attacks on minority targets in London.

Copeland, a 24-year-old engineer from Cove, Farnborough, Hants, has admitted causing explosions at Brixton, Brick Lane and Soho in London during 13 days in April last year, killing three people and injuring 129.

In his summing up, Judge Hyam said that the burden of proving that Copeland was suffering from diminished responsibility fell on the defence.

Copeland, an engineer from Cove, Farnborough, Hants, has admitted causing explosions at Brixton, Brick Lane and Soho in London during 13 days in April last year, killing three people and injuring 129.

The blast at the mainly gay Admiral Duncan pub in Soho killed Andrea Dykes, 27, who was pregnant, and her friends John Light, 32, and Nik Moore, 31, all from Essex. He is being tried for their murder after the prosecution refused to accept his plea of guilty to manslaughter on the grounds he was suffering a mental illness - paranoid schizophrenia - which diminished his responsibility at the time. Prosecution psychiatrist Dr Philip Joseph told the trial that he believed Mr Copeland was suffering from a personality disorder that did not impair his responsibility.

Nigel Sweeney QC, prosecuting, told the jury in his closing speech yesterday that Copeland had the choice of how to deal with his personality difficulties and "he chose to go by the bombing route".

"The prosecution say he suffers from a personality disorder not mental illness - that he is in the old-fashioned phrase, bad, not mentally ill." Michael Wolkind QC, defending, told the jury Dr Joseph was wrong in saying Copeland had not been mentally ill.

Mr Wolkind said Dr Joseph was "a man of charm, but as a witness in this case he is neither reliable nor fair."

He described Dr Joseph as "isolated, maverick and wrong" about Copeland. Defence psychiatrists were agreed he had been mentally ill. Mr Wolkind added: "Please do not approach this case as if Mr Sweeney is presenting this case for the angels and I am presenting the case for the devil."

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Wine online
fields.trailText: Wine online
fields.body:
According to Sir Richard Branson, admitting that you don't know much about wine can be as embarrassing as admitting that you're not very good in bed... That's why he has launched www.virginwines.com, intended to "do for wine what the Kama Sutra did for sex". Newly launched, the site offers personalised recommendations to wine lovers keen to try new varieties, but baffled by some of the terms used to describe them.

In addition to the usual region, grape and vintage classifications, wines are placed in taste categories such as Soft and Juicy or Clean and Crisp. You can sample them all by ordering the Virgin Welcome case, which represents the full range of taste categories.

The Wine Wizard puts you on the road to discovery with a series of questions designed to identify the styles you enjoy. There are more than 17,500 wines, making it the largest selection in the world from one retailer. If you know what you want, there's a Smart Search facility.

There are seven mixed cases, including Drinks Party (£68.99), Dinner Party (£94.99) and Seduction (£89.99). Contents vary from champagne at £17.99 to a £3.29 Hardys Stamp Riesling. Delivery is £4.99.

Stop off after you've placed the order for the oenological accessories you could ever need at www.drinkstuff.com - corkscrews, coolers, bottle-stoppers, bibs, wineracks, reference books etc.

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ... a paperclip?
fields.trailText: ... a paperclip?
fields.body:
What do celebrities and aristocrats spend their surplus wealth on? Something to clip it all together, of course.

At £70, Nigel Milne's solid silver paperclip won't be seen floating around many boardrooms, but it might occasionally emerge from the pocket of a Savile Row suit holding in check a cumbersome wedge of banknotes.

The clip, which measures 6cms and weighs 15g, is part of a range of luxury items from jewellers Nigel Milne that are more ornament than office equipment. Cynics may protest that it looks much like its common wire counterpart, but they are ignoring the subtleties. Its voluptuous curves slide seductively over its prey, two silver nobbles on the ends prevent claw marks.

Alas, though, its qualities are also its failings. So heavy are those silver curves that thin sheets crumble in its embrace. But who cares - the most lacklustre business report will be given added value by such a bauble. Just remember to take it off before handing that big sheaf over. Nigel Milne of Jermyn Street, tel: 020 7437 9343 or email: www.nigelmilne.co.uk

fields.headline: Clean money
fields.standfirst: As a vegetarian-friendly Visa card is launched,  Liz Stuart  looks into saving and investing with a clear conscience
fields.trailText: As a vegetarian-friendly Visa card is launched, Liz Stuart looks into saving and investing with a clear conscience
fields.body:
People are keener on saving and playing the stock market and building up savings but they are also more interested in how the money is invested. Increasing numbers of savers prefer to keep their consciences clear by not giving tacit support to arms manufacturers, dictatorships or tobacco companies, for example, through their managed savings and stocks.

Ethical investment is booming - around £2.8bn is now invested in such funds, which is about 1 %of all money in unit trusts, and this figure is doubling every three years. A recent survey of people with pensions showed that 77% would prefer to invest their money ethically if it made no difference to returns.

Ethical investing took a step further yesterday with the launch of the UK's first vegetarian credit card, backed by the former Beatle and famous non-meat eater, Sir Paul McCartney. For every £100 spent on the Visa card issued by the People's Bank of Connecticut, known as People's Bank in Britain, 35p goes to the Vegetarian Society. Every time someone signs up, the society gets £10. Even the government has acknowledged the importance of the issue: from next month pension fund managers will have to take social, environmental and ethical considerations into account when deciding where to invest members' money.

"The increasing concern many people have about the social and environmental impacts of the activities of some companies is spilling over into the way they think about their pensions and other invest ments," says Peter Frankental, business group mananger of Amnesty International UK.

Friends Provident were the first to launch an ethical savings vehicle, the Stewardship fund which it launched as long ago as 1984 with a promise to avoid buying into "bombs, booze and baccy". These tenets which emerged from Friends Provident's Quaker roots still apply, although the criteria have been extended to incude companies which do not breach any environmental or human rights issue.

Other companies have been much slower to catch on and the UK market lags far behind the US, where more than $2 trillion (£1,360bn) is invested ethically. According to the Ethical Investment Research Service (Eiris - an organisation which researches corporate behaviour to check their ethical claims are authentic), the most pressing concerns among savers are the environment, oppressive regimes and conduct in developing countries (whether the company buys from factories using child labour, for example).

There is now a comprehensive range of ethical investment products running from bank accounts, affinity cards and mortgages to Isas, pensions and insurance. There are even products tailored to religious beliefs: Muslims may buy into Islamic funds financially engineered so they do not, technically speaking, pay interest - Islam forbids making capital from capital.

But ethical investment is not as simple as it may seem. Those who feel very strongly about it may wish to consider the fact that many financial providers offer just one "green" product among its conventional ones. The Framlington Health unit trust, for example, is listed as an ethical fund because it puts cash into healthcare stocks. However, some of of these drug companies may be testing on animals during research: anyone who is anti-vivisection would be advised to check in advance.

If you invest through a fund, such as an Isa or unit trust, it is unlikely you will know exactly where your money is going to end up because it will be spread across a range of companies. Some companies are banned by one ethical fund and not by others - it depends on the criteria used by the individual fund manager. "We ourselves do not say what is ethical and what is not," explains Karen Eldridge of Eiris. "For example, British Telecom has a good environmental and social record but it used have a holding in a cable company which broadcast pornographic programmes. That might have been a problem for some people."

As People's Bank is American, there is little research available on the overall cleanliness of the company's slate, but Ruth Rosselson of Ethical Consumer magazine, suggests: "To get round the problem we would advise people to go to a bank or investment fund which has an overall ethical policy. In our report we recommended the Co-operative Bank, which is a high-street presence and offers affinity cards of its own."

Triodos Bank, a small Dutch clearing bank which has a presence in Britain, also has a clearly defined ethical policy. It specialises in banking facilities for charities and projects focusing on social and environmen tal. It aims to channel investments of between £10,000 and £1m into businesses with a clear green or social agenda. This may include organic food production, sustainable transport and social housing. It also offers an Organic Saver account in conjunction with the Soil Association.

For green insurance, Ethical Consumer recommends Britannic, Royal London, CGU, Cornhill and Naturesave. The Norwich & Peterborough building society offers a mortgage with preferential rates to borrowers who lag their roof for insulation and the Ecology Building Society has green savings accounts.

But does altruism come at a price? Not according to Eldridge. "A study we conducted last year showed that over the long term there was very little difference in performance between the ethical and standard funds."

Over three, five and 10 years investors would have been very slightly better off in a non-ethical fund, but the difference is negligible. In fact many ethical companies are smaller than those in the FTSE 100 and so have more growth potential.If you need advice on where to put your money, there are specialist ethical independent financial advisers, such as Gaia, which is based in Manchester. Eiris has details of others.

For more general information, Eiris publishes a bi-monthly newsletter, to which you can subscribe for £15 per annum, and the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds publishes a free guide to socially responsible investing. Friends of the Earth has an information pack which includes an ethical investment guide.

 Ethical Investment Research Services 0207 840 5700, Triodos Bank 0117 973 9339.

The UK Social Investment Forum can be found at www.uksif.org and Ethical Investors at www.ethicalinvestors.co.uk.

Gaia: 0161 799 6420; www.IslamiQ.com has advice and information compliant with Islamic principles.

fields.headline: How Dimension will spend $500m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Dimension Data, the South African IT group, plans to spend $500m (£330m) buying up three companies in which it already has stakes. The group is set to go straight into the FTSE 100 when it lists in London next month.
fields.body:
Dimension Data, the South African IT group, plans to spend $500m (£330m) buying up three companies in which it already has stakes. The group is set to go straight into the FTSE 100 when it lists in London next month.

The Johannesburg-based firm, which is looking to raise up to $1.25bn from the flotation, intends to buy the remaining equity in a network integration firm, Chernikeeff Networks, based at Sunbury-on-Thames, and GK Communications of Warrington. It will also take full control of Comtech in Australia.

The remaining funds are likely to finance the acquisitionof e-commerce businesses in the US and to support organic growth, according to the group chairman, Jeremy Ord.

Dimension is likely to be valued at around $9bn when it lists in London. Marketing of the new shares to institutions - co-ordinated by Deutsche Bank and Merrill Lynch - begins this morning, and first dealings are expected on July 19. Unconditional share trading begins on July 31.

Dimension aims to offer corporate customers a "one-stop shop" for all their networking, internet commerce and IT consultancy needs. It has 32 data centres around the world from which it controls a variety of networking requirements for clients including Vodafone, Unilever, Coca Cola and Virgin Mobile.

webTitle: Doctors declare no confidence in GMC

fields.headline: Doctors declare no confidence in GMC
fields.trailText: Doctors at the British Medical Association's annual conference today overwhelmingly backed a motion of no confidence in the profession's regulatory body, the General Medical Council.
fields.body:
Doctors at the British Medical Association's (BMA) annual conference today overwhelmingly backed a motion of no confidence in the profession's regulatory body, the General Medical Council (GMC).

In an impassioned debate, 600 representatives at the BMA said they had no confidence in the way the GMC was presently run and structured, and called for "urgent reform" in consultation with the profession.

The vote in London today is likely to trigger a huge rift between the two organisations over the way the profession regulates itself.

"The vast majority of doctors have lost confidence in the GMC - quite simply that is the truth," said Dr Peter Terry, proposing the motion and calling for reform. Some doctors went further, arguing for the abolition of the council.

The GMC is already looking at ways of reforming its processes after a series of scandals, including the cases of serial killer GP Harold Shipman, disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward and the Bristol heart babies inquiry.

The council has been criticised for not acting quickly enough against poorly performing doctors and having a huge backlog of cases due before its professional conduct committee.

The BMA is also sceptical of GMC plans for revalidation, which will subject doctors to a five-yearly appraisal - a kind of "MoT for doctors" - before they are allowed to stay on the medical register.

Doctors are furious at the way public confidence has been dented by delays and the fact that hundreds of their colleagues face up to a year's wait before their case is heard.

"Confidence has not been lost in the medical profession, but confidence has been lost in how the medical profession is regulated. The GMC has failed us. GMC is a shambles," said Dr Terry.

He added that his motion was "a call for substantial reform", demanding changes to the way members are elected to the GMC, saying all medical members should be practising doctors and that lay membership should be increased.

"The GMC's record on reform is not good. Without reform, there will be no confidence and the GMC will not survive," he warned.

BMA leaders said they would now work with the GMC for reform, but today's vote is likely to sour relations between the two most powerful bodies in the profession.

Speaking after the vote, Dr Ian Bogle, chairman of the BMA, said: "There will be some people on the GMC who resist reform, but the vast majority do want reform."

Asked if the vote meant doctors thought the GMC was unsafe, Dr Bogle said: "In a way, because it operates too slowly.

"When it gets there, it acts properly, but it is the delays that are the big problem, and to some extent because of the delays, it is not safe. It means that some doctors can practise when they shouldn't be able to."

Dr Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA's consultants committee, said: "I believe that the GMC is capable of reform, but the reform must be radical, it must be thorough and it must consult with the wider profession before proposals come forward."

But some doctors warned that backing the no-confidence motion could play into the government's hands and see the scrapping of self-regulation of the medical profession.

"This is the shortest suicide note in history. The GMC does have shortcomings, but it is initiating reform. We risk playing into the hands of Tony Blair," Dr Andy Ashworth said.

fields.headline: Police urged to stop forced marriages
fields.trailText: Police must do more to protect the 1,000 British women each year who are forced into marriages they do not want, a government report said today.
fields.body:
Police must do more to protect the 1,000 British women each year who are forced into marriages they do not want, a government report said today.

Every police force in Britain should put emergency procedures in place to rescue the predominantly British Asian women who are forced against their will into marriages arranged by their parents, a working party report chaired by two Labour peers, Baroness Uddin and Lord Ahmed, recommended.

Bangladesh-born Baroness Uddin called for a partnership approach between parents, communities, police and social services to help those women affected. "Service providers must ensure that their intervention is thoughtful, sensitive and safe," she said.

The report emphasised that being forced into unwanted marriages only affects a small minority of British Asians, although it is said to be growing because of the increasingly marked generation gap between parents brought up on the Indian subcontinent and their anglicised children.

In March, a 21-year-old student was rescued from a forced arranged marriage by Foreign Office diplomats in India. The British-born Indian woman had been duped by her parents into flying to Punjab to visit her ailing grandmother, where she was held captive while a marriage was set up with a man she had never met.

Some women with families from Africa and the Middle East have also had unwanted marriages foisted upon them.

Campaigners welcomed the report, but criticised its suggestion that social workers could act as mediators between women and their estranged families.

Hannana Siddiqui, of Southall Black Sisters, said the plans could force more vulnerable women back into abusive situations.

"The agencies should give protection not mediation," said Ms Siddiqui, a member of the working group. "Women are already under huge pressure from their communities, often with elders or community leaders acting as mediators.

"It will put more pressure on them to go back, often in to an abusive situation."

The report proposed that "forced marriage" teams should be established, working in embassies in some Asian countries. It suggested the creation of an "early-warning" system for marriage registrars, police and immigration officials as well as a "trigger mechanism" which brings in social services, schools or even Foreign Office officials based abroad, when police receive a complaint.

Since 1996, the Foreign Office has produced a leaflet for young Asian men and women visiting the subcontinent, informing them what to do if they fear they will be forced into a marriage while abroad. Officials say they currently get involved with between 30 and 100 cases a year.

Home Office minister Mike O'Brien confirmed that the government would take on board the recommendations before publishing a new joint action plan with the Foreign Office. The report did not propose any new laws to deal with the problem, instead suggesting that existing crimes such as rape, child abuse, abduction and false imprisonment could be invoked.

The review was prompted by a court ruling last year that parents who took their daughters abroad to be married against their will were guilty of abduction.

The report also endorsed government plans, announced earlier this year, to encourage teachers to tell police and social services about pupils they think could be at risk and it urged teenage magazines, TV soap operas and pop radio stations to carry stories that show Asian girls they are right to resist forced marriages.

fields.headline: Kohl denies taking bribes
fields.standfirst: Audio: John Hooper in Berlin
fields.trailText: Germany's disgraced former chancellor Helmut Kohl today denied taking bribes as he testified for the first time to the committee investigating his party financing scandal.
fields.body:
Germany's disgraced former chancellor Helmut Kohl today denied taking bribes as he testified for the first time to the committee investigating his party financing scandal.

Mr Kohl insisted he had not traded government favours for cash during his 16 years in power. "The accusation that we were corruptible in our political decisions is absurd," an unflappable Mr Kohl said at the end of a one-hour statement he read to a parliamentary investigating committee.

"Never in my entire life has anyone been able to buy me."

As expected, Mr Kohl also refused to talk about the central issue of the investigation: who gave him some DM2m in undeclared - and thus illegal - campaign funds in the 1990s, names even his own centre-right Christian Democratic party has pressed him to reveal.

"I have acknowledged the mistakes and apologised for them, but I say once again I will not name the anonymous donors," Mr Kohl said.

Mr Kohl insists the donors were citizens who wanted to support the party's work in former communist East Germany in the early 1990s.

He said he had promised them anonymity and refused to break his word.

After initial banter with members of a parliamentary investigating committee, Mr Kohl launched into a statement focused on his historic achievements as the chancellor who unified Germany in 1990.

Mr Kohl's long-awaited testimony gives him a chance to counter allegations about murky dealings under his administration that have dirtied that reputation. He made no secret of his view that the investigation was a well orchestrated vendetta by the committee - dominated by the governing centre-left parties - to destroy his legacy.

"The real reason is to wipe 16 successful years out of history," he said.

Mr Kohl also criticised the committee for not hearing his side of the story immediately after the investigation began seven months ago, as he had requested.

Mr Kohl will be questioned by committee members for the rest of today's day-long hearing. He is also expected to be called to testify again in the next few months as the committee digs deeper into the allegations.

The party financing scandal that erupted last autumn with Mr Kohl's admission that he accepted illegal donations as chancellor has developed into an enduring political drama that dogs the Christian Democratic party he once led.

Also under investigation by the parliamentary panel are several business arrangements under the Kohl government in which backroom deals were allegedly agreed, including a tank sale to Saudi Arabia and the privatisation of a major oil refinery in eastern Germany that was sold to French concern Elf Aquitaine.

Facing the panel, Mr Kohl denied receiving money to push those deals through and maintained that he was unaware of anyone in his administration being bought off.

Earlier testimony by former Kohl aides shed little light on the scandal or the role of a businessman at its centre, Karlheinz Schreiber.

Mr Schreiber, currently fighting extradition from Canada on German tax evasion charges, allegedly handed over DM1m in cash to Kohl aides at a Swiss shopping centre in 1991. He was also reportedly involved in the tank sale.

But Mr Schreiber shielded the former chancellor in an interview with the news channel n-tv this week, rejecting rumours that he lobbied the Kohl government with cash to support arms deals and other business projects. Mr Schreiber said he had met Mr Kohl a few times but "at no time" talked about business.

Mr Kohl, whose angry demands to testify early in the hearings were turned down, has been virtually banished from German public life, but he has received a steady string of visiting foreign dignitaries since the scandal broke, including US President Bill Clinton and, this week, French President Jacques Chirac.

In the latest accusation of criminal conduct, an independent investigator said large numbers of government files were destroyed during the last days of Mr Kohl's administration.

Two-thirds of the chancellery's records - equivalent to 1.2m pieces of paper - were wiped out in late 1998 shortly before Mr Kohl handed over power to newly elected Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder, the investigator, Burkhard Hirsch, told the committee yesterday.

"This massive erasing of data lacked any legal basis," Mr Hirsch, a former vice president of parliament, said after a four-month investigation of chancellery files ordered by Mr Schroeder.

fields.headline: The menopause
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the female life change, and why it may be a receding prospect
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the female life change, and why it may be a receding prospect
fields.body:
1. The menopause is one of life's major turning points for women. It means, literally, the last period (when a woman runs out of eggs in her ovaries at around the age of 50). And just as menarche, the first period, is happening earlier in girls, so menopause is generally occurring later in women.

2. Medical science has given this process a hefty helping hand, with treatments like hormone replacement therapy (HRT).

3. Now the Dutch pharmaceutical company, Organon, is working on what this morning's Daily Express calls a "wonder pill" which will allow women of 60-plus to conceive. Dutch researchers, however, stress that a pill which delays the menopause is still many years away.

4. Some women regard the menopause not as a threat or burden, but as a gift.

5. From being a no-no subject a few years ago, the menopause is now the focus of a plethora of information and discussion.

6. A good starting point for basic information seekers is provided by health charity Marie Stopes International.

7. The surge of interest in all things menopausal has inevitably led to an exploration of the male mid-life condition known to some as the manopause.

webTitle: The Mitchell brothers: Behind the Green Door

fields.headline: The Mitchell brothers: Behind the Green Door
fields.trailText: One reason for its success of was the fact that Marilyn Chambers, its star, who is pleasured by nuns, a well-known boxer and three trapeze artists in the film, was also the "99.44% pure Ivory Snow girl" of advertising fame at the time
fields.body:
Pornography has been a staple of the cinema from the year dot. At no time, however, was it so respectable as in the America of the early 70s. Hardcore porn was then shown in respectable mainstream cinemas, and respectable couples did not care a jot if anyone saw them going in or coming out.

Now such films, or the much more sleazy and slapdash modern equivalents, are relegated to backstreet porno houses and the pay-TV channels you get in foreign hotels. Have we progressed or declined? It isn't my job to answer that question. But I can say that there were breakthrough porno movies that deserved at least some of the limelight they were once afforded.

Two directors who were pioneers were Gerard Damiano (Deep Throat and The Devil in Miss Jones) and the Mitchell brothers, who made Behind the Green Door. This was the most stylish, and some say the most erotic, of all of these movies.

One reason for the success of Behind the Green Door, always slaughtered by the censor in this country, was the fact that Marilyn Chambers, its star, who is pleasured by nuns, a well-known boxer and three trapeze artists in the film, was also the "99.44% pure Ivory Snow girl" of advertising fame at the time.

She became an instant celebrity, was invited on to talk shows, and behaved like a Hollywood star. Serious critics reviewed the film, while it raced up the list of the most popular movies as if nothing untoward were happening at all.

It was Damiano's Deep Throat, a rather messy endeavour that concentrated on fellatio, that made porn fashionable in the first place, with Linda Lovelace becoming a household name. But while Damiano urged his women on to ever more extreme sexual gymnastics, the Mitchells opted for "art" and a semblance of respectability, and were delighted that women were the bedrock of their audience. There were as many female commentators who approved of the film as disapproved, since it was about a woman totally liberated by experiences that had previously been part of her private and unattainable fantasies.

I have to say that the climax of the film, which lasts for several minutes and has one of the trapeze artists ejaculating into the heroine's mouth in extreme slow motion, reworked over and over again with special effects, now seems more hilarious than arty. But the film does have a charge that you can't deny, Chambers is certainly some sort of an actress, and the Mitchells could at least claim some imagination in making it.

As for Chambers, she was well paid for her pains and received a cut of the film's profits that made her rich as well as famous.

webTitle: June 29: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 29: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Robert Downey Jnr "depressed" in jail, Michael Douglas to play art-fraud con man, Kevin Smith set for Fletch, Ivan Reitman evolves sci-fi comedy, and cyber-ads win awards
fields.body:
 Robert Downey Jr, currently serving a three year prison sentence for drug possession, is apparently sinking deeper into depression. A Vanity Fair journalist, who has visited Downey in prison five times in the last eight months, claims that the 35-year-old actor has taken on the "appearance and disposition" of a prisoner and was very angry during their last meeting in May. Downey was sentenced in August 1999 for violating his probation on a 1996 cocaine possession charge by repeatedly missing mandatory drug tests. In the interview, Downey claims he has not used drugs since June 1999 and that "[taking] Thorazine at LA County jail was my swan song."

 Michael Douglas is to team up with MGM to develop a film based on one of the biggest art-fraud scandals of the 20th century. Douglas will play John Drewe, a charming con man who, together with the painter John Myatt, reproduced copies of paintings by the old masters. The duo successfully fooled art experts for nine years in the mid eighties and early nineties before their scam was uncovered. Drewe is currently serving a six year sentence for fraud. The film will be based on an investigative article by journalist Peter Landesman, and M.Butterfly playwright David Henry Hwang is to write the script.

 Kevin Smith is set to write and direct a new Fletch film for Miramax films. Fifteen years after Chevy Chase popularised the Gregory McDonald series of Fletch novels, a new adaptation, provisionally called Fletch Won, will go into production in the next couple of years. "I was a huge fan of the series of books," Smith told The Hollywood Reporter. "I liked the movie quite a bit too, but the books were fantastic. That's actually where I learned to write dialogue." It is hoped Chase will have some involvement in the film, but Ben Affleck or Jason Lee are the names being talked about for the lead role.

 Ivan Reitman is to direct and produce Evolution, a sci-fi comedy, for Dreamworks studios. Reitman who last directed Touchstone's romantic comedy Six Days Seven Nights, with Harrison Ford, has said they will have a final draft in about two weeks and production should start in November. Evolution follows the chaos that ensues when a meteor hits Earth and the one-celled organisms living on it quickly mutate. Phil Tippett, who was special effects supervisor on The Haunting and Jurassic Park, has signed up for the project.

 At last week's 47th International Advertising Festival, the Cannes Lions, the Cyber Lion Category Jury awarded four joint winners. Among them was Earthwatch, the official UK site for Fox's animated sci-fi feature Titan AE (due to be released in the UK on 28 July). The UK's Fight Club site was one of the other winners.

webTitle: Star Trek captain plans film about wife's death

fields.headline: Star Trek captain plans film about wife's death
fields.trailText: William Shatner is planning to produce and direct a film based around the death of his wife, who was found drowned in a swimming-pool last August. And get this: it's a comedy
fields.body:
Captain Kirk star William Shatner is planning to produce and direct a movie based around his experiences following the death of his wife, who was found drowned in a swimming-pool last August. But if that sounds a bit of a downer, think again. The film is to be a comedy.

With a working title of The Shiva Club, Shatner's film will be set in the Hollywood home of a top Jewish comic in "shiva week", the traditional time of Jewish mourning. But the film promises not doom and gloom but funny lines and crazy antics. Shatner hit upon the idea in the weeks following his wife's death. "During the process of sitting shiva, the concept occurred to me: grief can be funny," he told the Hollywood Reporter.

The death of Shatner's wife made worldwide headlines last summer. Nerine, 40, an aspiring actress, was discovered by her husband lying face down in the garden pool of their Beverly Hills home. The LA county coroner ruled a verdict of accidental drowning, while an autopsy discovered quanities of alcohol and valium in the woman's body.

Since his Star Trek heyday, Shatner has enjoyed moderate success in TV shows like TJ Hooker and Third Rock From the Sun, and as an author of sci-fi novels. He is currently shooting a role as a sleazy beauty pageant host opposite Sandra Bullock and Michael Caine in the comedy-thriller Miss Congeniality.

But there are those who will wonder if the dead wife comedy offers yet more evidence of the Kirk star's increasingly eccentric behaviour. Only last week, he appeared on the Jay Leno show where he sang a satirical song mocking the chat-show host's appearance before smashing his guitar on the studio floor.

 The Shiva Club is expected to go before the cameras at the end of the year.
