webTitle: Mark Wahlberg signs for Burton's Ape remake

fields.headline: Mark Wahlberg signs for Burton's Ape remake
fields.trailText: Rapper turned actor Mark Wahlberg has signed on to star as the imperilled human in Tim Burton's eagerly anticipated remake of the 1968 sci-fi classic The Planet of the Apes
fields.body:
Rapper turned actor Mark Wahlberg has signed on to star as the imperilled human in Tim Burton's eagerly anticipated remake of the 1968 sci-fi classic The Planet of the Apes. The square-jawed star of Boogie Nights and Three Kings will play an American astronaut who crash-lands in a world overrun by fascistic talking gorillas - the role originally played by Charlton Heston

Discussing the film with Cindy Pearlman of Cinescape, the 29-year-old actor confessed that he was willing to work with maverick director Burton, no matter what the role. "Tim is the kind of guy where I just say yes to whatever he wants me to do," Wahlberg reflected. "I did say 'What kind of ape do you want me to play?' and Tim said, 'You're the human'."

The Planet of the Apes remake has been one of Fox's great unfilmed projects for several years now. It was initially to be filmed by director James Cameron and to star his old Terminator cohort Arnold Schwarzenegger in the Heston part, but when Cameron dropped out Schwarzenegger lost interest in the project.

Fox's decision to hire Tim Burton as director was prompted by the healthy box-office returns of his last film, Sleepy Hollow. Burton is regarded within Hollywood as a famously wayward talent whose films veer between mammoth hits (Batman) and horrendous flops (Ed Wood, Mars Attacks!). In the eyes of Hollywood's money-men, Sleepy Hollow proved he could be trusted again.

The casting of Wahlberg is the final piece in the Apes jigsaw. Shooting on the film is due to begin in September and it is hoped that the film will be finished in time to become Fox's top release for the summer of 2001.

fields.headline: Sympathy for the devil
fields.standfirst: He's listed in the Guinness Book of Records as the most prolific director in cinema history. So why isn't the Spanish film-maker Jess Franco a household name?  Will Hodgkinson  on the mysterious life of a true maverick
fields.trailText: He's listed in the Guinness Book of Records as the most prolific director in cinema history. So why isn't the Spanish film-maker Jess Franco a household name? Will Hodgkinson on the mysterious life of a true maverick
fields.body:
'The cinema's a show", says Jess Franco, the Spanish director who is currently in the Guinness Book Of Records for making something in the region of 200 films (even he isn't sure of the exact number). "And it must be a good show."

But what Franco considers to be a good show might not be to everyone's taste. He's made a career out of wallowing in a cinematic cesspool. Films like Vampyros Lesbos, Venus In Furs and Necromonicon mix surreal, beautiful images with paper-thin characters, nonsensical plotlines and big-breasted lesbian bloodsuckers gorging on the blood of virgins. Franco obsessed over the way a certain scene looked yet was entirely unconcerned if a character died not once but twice, and flashes of great vision are buried underneath the collective weight of porn and confusion. Now Pete Tombs's documentary on this true iconoclast, The Diabolical Mr Franco, goes some way towards helping us understand what made him tick.

Born in May 1930 to upper-middle-class parents, Franco received a highbrow weaning at the Real Conservatorio, Madrid, before going on to direct his first feature film, 1959's Tenemos 18 Años, at the age of 29. Although no masterpiece, it showed enough promise to provide Franco with backers for future projects, and his first horror film, 1961's The Awful Dr Orloff, was to make his name. The story covered similar territory to Georges Franchu's Eyes Without A Face: a mad scientist, played by Howard Vernon, kidnaps young women for the purpose of using their skin to graft onto the face of his daughter, who's been disfigured in an accident. Dr Orloff was the first of its kind: an atmospheric, stylish horror film with nudity and gore, and it resulted in its director being held up as Spain's answer to Jean-Luc Godard. General Franco was in power, the Catholic Church had a moral stranglehold on the country, and the film was banned then subsequently championed as a symbol of freedom. Franco caught the attention of Orson Welles, who was shooting Chimes Of Midnight in Spain and looking for an assistant director, and although the two fell out before the film was over, Franco admired Welles's determination to go his own way.

From then on, Franco appeared intent on rejecting any notions of good taste and craftsmanship. "He doesn't actually seem to like his films at all", claims Pete Tombs. "But he likes the process of making movies and couldn't care less about the outcome. He's a terribly learned guy, he can speak fluently in Italian, French, Spanish and English, but half the time he can't even remember which film he's supposed to be making." A more liberal mood after the death of General Franco in 1975 changed nothing for Jess; having stuck two fingers up at the establishment for so many years, he wasn't about to change just because his films were being praised for their pushing of cinematic boundaries. "The films got worse and worse, and more pornographic", says Tombs. "It was like he was saying, 'They say they like me now, let's see what they think of this.'"

There were some fine Franco moments, though. Necromonicon (1967), adapted from a medieval book on the occult, is often held up as his greatest film: the story of a beautiful young woman (what else?) who's being used by a demon to collect the souls of fallen people, it starts with the memorable voiceover: "Could it be a mystique that has enclosed us in a masquerade, or a cruel illusion... who knows?" Vampyros Lesbos (1970) starred the black-eyed Soledad Miranda as a mysterious countess who lures young women to her castle in Istanbul so that she can gorge on their blood. None of it makes much sense, but Miranda, who died as a result of a car crash before the film was completed, is utterly beguiling.

Daniel Lesoeur, a Parisian producer who's worked with Franco on 20 films, has faith in the wayward Spaniard as a real artist. "In the way that a painter has to paint every week, Jess has the same feeling about making movies. He has this in his blood, he has something to say." It's not always clear what exactly he is saying, however. "He forgets the story sometimes. But he always puts something of himself in his movies." Franco and Lesoeur are currently raising money for a remake of The Awful Dr Orloff, with effete German actor Udo Kier in the title role.

Jess Franco has a unique way of making movies. He rarely writes a script, and even if he does it's only a couple of hours before shooting. He likes to do everything himself on set, but leaves the completion of the film to somebody else. He considers himself a feminist and claims that he hates porn, but the films look like manifestations of his erotic fantasies. And he'll run over the same themes again and again, but never bother to tell a story. Perhaps this succinct explanation by one of his favourite leading men, French actor Michael Lemaine, is the most satisfactory: "He's a total madman."

fields.headline: Elvis, my son
fields.standfirst: Michael Ellison talks to Sam Phillips, the man who created rock'n'roll, Elvis Presley - and Holiday Inn
fields.trailText: Michael Ellison talks to Sam Phillips, the man who created rock'n'roll, Elvis Presley - and Holiday Inn
fields.body:
Ask Sam Phillips if he is happy to be known as the man who invented rock'n'roll and he speaks of many things - the Tennessee river, radio masts, the effects of Rocky Mountain spider fever, beautiful accidents, racial integration, the importance of family - before eventually getting down to it.

"The man who invented rock'n'roll? It's a big thing to say. I have had more accolades than I deserve." He is at home in upscale East Memphis, where the sideboard is stuffed with music-industry awards. Outside are two Cadillacs and a Lincoln. "Still, nobody can beat me behind a damn control board, nobody can beat me on sound, nobody can beat me on getting stuff out of people. Nobody can beat me in turning those damn knobs."

It's hard to argue with that. Put simply, the case for Phillips is that without his gifts as a producer there would have been no Elvis Presley and no rock'n'roll, and today's music scene would be very different.

It all began in 1945 when Phillips, the son of dirt-poor Alabama farmers, arrived to work as a radio sound engineer in Memphis, which at that time was the home of the blues. Labouring on the nightly big-band broadcasts from the Peabody hotel was not enough, and in 1950 he opened the Memphis Recording Service with the slogan: "We record anything - anywhere - anytime." Before long, he had worked with a staggering array of black talent, including BB King, Howlin' Wolf, Little Milton, Junior Parker and Rufus Thomas. "It was hard as hell," he recalls. "Blacks needed to have a forum for their music - there wasn't a radio station on every corner."

In 1951 Phillips produced the first rock'n'roll record, Rocket 88, credited to Jackie Brenston, though much of the creative input came from Ike Turner. And then came Elvis, a white man who sang like he was black. "Now let me tell you," says Phillips, a puckish, bearded figure. "Elvis had a beautiful voice. Untrained, and that was good. I like to sculpture some thing that hasn't been trampled on by someone else. We weren't going to go out there and try to be a Sinatra with this young dude, or Dean Martin. We weren't interested in that."

Presley first visited the studio in 1953, but it took a year before the pioneer and the young singer perfected Presley's new sound. It was a process that Phillips still doesn't entirely understand. "Hell, inventions are not just something that is physical, you know? You get down the road a little bit and think, 'How did we do this?' "

fields.headline: Campaign corruption
fields.standfirst:
Mugabe was right about one thing: western observers might as well have stayed away

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Mugabe was right about one thing: western observers might as well have stayed away
fields.body:
Foreign observers monitoring other countries' elections are part of the furniture of the post-cold war world. But rarely have they come under such strong attack as they did in Zimbabwe's just-completed poll. Robert Mugabe attacked them as intruders, and the grim fact is that he is right.

At best this new breed of globe-trotting groupies, the election tourists, may be no more harmful than the revolution tourists of the 60s or the war tourists of more recent times. They turn up a few days before balloting, interview the leaders of a handful of political parties, stroll round some polling stations on voting day, issue a report, and go home to bank the bulk of their generous per diems.

But there is also a pernicious side and the western election-observing industry is threatening to become the political counterpart to the International Monetary Fund's notorious conditionality. If you, Country X, don't tighten your belts enough to get the IMF seal of approval, you cannot get easy commercial credit or foreign investment. By the same token, Country Y, if your elections are not certified by the doyens of liberal democracy as free and fair, you will not be smiled on warmly at international conferences or be treated politely in the western press.

As with other forms of the new interventionism, observer missions are riddled with double standards. They often come with a preconceived verdict which has been mandated by their own governments in advance. In Albania in 1996, the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which has become the main observer-dispatching body in Europe, approved a highly dubious poll because the winner, the anti-communist Sali Berisha, was still favoured in European capitals. When corruption and his mismanagement of pyramid schemes produced a nationwide uprising and destructive looting less than a year later, the OSCE changed course and approved the conduct of the new elections which replaced him, though they were not much fairer.

In Russia in 1993 they turned a blind eye to the December referendum which Boris Yeltsin called to endorse a highly authoritarian constitution. The OSCE observers confined themselves to commenting on the parliamentary elections which took place simultaneously. They refused to acknowledge the signs that the government was manipulating the turn-out figures since Yeltsin would have lost the referendum if it was proved that less than 50% of the electorate came to the polls. But the main method for rigging elections is not deployed on polling day. It comes through control of television and the abuse of incumbency by a sitting presidency.

The most loaded misuse of the observers' seal of approval came in the Nicar-aguan elections of 1984. The United States announced in advance that they would not be free and fair and would therefore not send observers. The real reason was that had they gone and been honest, they would have had to admit the Sandinistas won an honest multiparty contest.

In Africa, threats to decent elections have come at all stages of the campaign, from misuse of state media to violence and intimidation and finally to rigging of the count. Outside observers gave an unjustified clean verdict to the Kenyan elections of 1992 because their governments were supporting Daniel arap Moi. Last year in Nigeria, when the west was pleased with the return to civilian rule, the head of the European Union's observer team gave a ludicrously favourable assessment of the poll within hours of its closing, apparently because he was under pressure to raise the EU profile. His colleagues were furious that he had not given them time to return to Lagos with details of numerous violations.

Now comes the EU verdict on Zimbabwe in what has been one of the most loaded clashes between a government and foreign observers in recent years. The quality of the EU's report on Zimbabwe is certainly higher than usual; it looked at the whole campaign, including manipulation by the state media and the only issue it missed was the unfair system of campaign financing, which grossly favoured the ruling party.

But even a relatively good report such as this leaves open the question of whether observer teams sent by foreign governments are really the right democratic tool. They are outside amateurs with an official agenda. It is far better to have several thousand local monitors, as Zimbabwe did this time, from civic groups who know their own country's culture better than foreigners. Add to that the contribution which professional and experienced non-governmental human rights groups such as Amnesty International can make: they produced an excellent report on the violent campaign which preceded the poll. Add also the role of foreign journalists: their operations may be patchy, brief, and volatile, but at least they tend to go to the coalface to get direct testimony, which diplomatic observers largely pick up second-hand. Robert Mugabe has a valid point. Observers appointed by foreign governments, stay away.

fields.headline: Let them drink coke
fields.standfirst: In a bid to win over India's 150 million fizzy drink fans, Coca-Cola recruited Bollywood's hottest new actor. Pepsi hit back with an ad which ridiculed him. Now it's become a religious issue.  Luke Harding on one of the world's most entertaining corporate battles
fields.trailText: In a bid to win over India's 150 million fizzy drink fans, Coca-Cola recruited Bollywood's hottest new actor. Pepsi hit back with an ad which ridiculed him. Now it's become a religious issue. Luke Harding on one of the world's most entertaining corporate battles
fields.body:
Towards the source of the Ganges, near the town of Rishikesh, boulders dot the riverbank. From a distance, they appear to be painted with venerable religious inscriptions. Monkeys clatter in the purple trees up in the woods; holy men dressed in orange robes gaze at the water and contemplate their next incarnation. It is a peaceful, unworldly spot. Or is it? Closer inspection reveals the boulders are painted with a well-known corporate logo. The words "Coca-Cola" loom into view. In case you missed them in English, they are also written in florid Hindi. The fact that Coca-Cola has taken to advertising on boulders alongside India's holiest river is a symbol, its critics say, of its increasing desperation.

The rocks are just a small salvo in what is shaping up to be one of the world's most entertaining corporate battles. Over in Bollywood, far away from the serene Ganges, the war between Coca-Cola and Pepsi in India has taken a sharply comic twist. Two months ago, Coca-Cola hired Bollywood's latest sensation, the rippling Hrithik Roshan, to front a new advertising campaign. Roshan has only appeared in one film. But he is already a superstar on the subcontinent, inspiring adulation from teenage girls and - it is said - less than maternal feelings from their mothers. ("They had to keep me down because I was getting so excited," Ritu Chadha, a 38-year-old Delhi-based exporter said, after watching Roshan in action with her children. "To me he looks like Jesus Christ." A 45-year-old woman from Mumbai added: "I react to him." She has watched his film 10 times.)

Pepsi was quick to respond. It released its own ad, starring Shah Rukh Khan, India's answer to Tom Cruise, poking fun at the muscle-bound Roshan. In the Pepsi commercial a Roshan lookalike wearing ugly braces on his teeth makes a brief appearance, only to be rejected by a pretty girl who kisses Khan instead. This, in itself, is something of a risque departure for Indian advertising. Roshan, in the words of one Pepsi executive, then "whinged". He fired off a letter complaining that as a novice in the cinema industry, he did not deserve to be lampooned. His fans wrote angry letters to newspapers. And in Calcutta, where Roshan's granny lives, there were even anti-Pepsi demonstrations. The actor's father, Rakesh Roshan, a successful Bollywood film-maker, who artfully turned his son into a star by directing and producing his debut movie Kaho Naa . . . Pyaar Hai (Say That You Love), also entered the fray. Pepsi was only "ridiculing" his son because it lost the bidding war to sign him up, he said.

This merry opera bouffe then took a more sinister turn. On June 22, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) - a powerful Hindu nationalist militia with close links to India's rightwing government - launched an attack on Khan and his equally famous actor brothers, Aamir, Salman and Saif. It claimed the Khans were part of a Muslim/mafia conspiracy to keep Hindu actors out of Bollywood, adding that the Pepsi ad poking fun at Roshan was an "ugly attempt" to discredit the Hindu actor. The RSS then suggested that cola in India was being drunk along communal lines: with Muslims choosing Pepsi and Hindus Coca-Cola. Both firms dismissed the RSS intervention as ludicrous. The Khans have long been popular with all sections of India's passionate movie-going community - and with audiences outside India: it was the spectacle of Khan gyrating on the roof of a train in the hit film Dil Se which persuaded Andrew Lloyd-Webber to set his next musical in Bollywood.

The feud between Roshan and Khan is merely the sub-plot in a bigger, global drama. At stake is control of the world's soft drinks industry. Ever since Coke was thrown out of India in 1977 for not revealing its secret recipe, it has been struggling to regain a foothold on the subcontinent. Unusually, India is one of the few countries in the world where Pepsi enjoys market dominance. Coke returned to India in 1993 with a bang by buying Thums Up, India's indigenous and comically misspelt cola brand. But by then it was too late. Pepsi had arrived two years earlier, and had cornered most of the $1bn (£600m) market. Pepsi is currently the number one cola in India, followed by Thums Up and Coke. Over the past seven years Coke has pumped $700m (£430m) into India. Elsewhere in Asia it has also been trying to topple Pepsi, which is ahead in Pakistan, Thailand and much of the Middle East. Last Wednesday the first consignment of Coke trundled across the Chinese border into North Korea.

Pepsi has responded to this multi-pronged assault by playing the underdog card. "The big difference between the two companies is that we have a sense of humour," Vibha Risha, Pepsi's marketing director in India, claimed. When Coca-Cola acquired the rights to the 1996 cricket world cup for $4m, Pepsi produced a series of irreverent adverts poking fun at the official sponsor. Its subsequent campaigns have been almost entirely focused on young people, who constitute half of India's 150m soft drinks buyers. Coke's ads, by contrast, have had more of a broad family appeal. Pepsi, the firm would like to make out, is a tiny David battling a po-faced, establishment Goliath.

Back in Bombay, Roshan appears to have got over his earlier distress. "I met him recently at a couple of parties," said Prahlad Kakkar, who made the Roshan spoof ad. "I said: 'I hope you didn't mind'. He replied: 'Everybody has been over-reacting.' He's a pretty cool kid." Coke is gambling that a combination of relentless advertising ("Half the walls in India are held up by our ads," one Coke executive said) and the Roshan factor will eventually pay off.

It is something of an irony, then, that in a ragingly hot country like India, most people do not drink cola. There is no mystery here: they are simply too poor. When the price of a 300ml bottle of cola went up last year from eight to nine rupees (15p), sales slumped. Even among those who do buy cola, consumption is low. India's per capita consumption of soft drinks is only six bottles a year, compared with 15 in Pakistan, 22 in China and more than 600 in Mexico. The fond hope among cola executives is that lifestyle patterns are changing in a country where more than a third of the one billion population is under 18. "It's a vast untapped market out there," Deepak Jolly, Pepsi's spokesman, said. His opposite number at Coke, Rahul Dhawan, points out that cola is still regarded in India as a special treat, bought only at children's birthday parties, cinemas and festivals. He wants to change that.

Roshan, meanwhile, is pondering the weight of celebrity. "I get out of bed, go out and the traffic stops. It's hard to digest," he said recently. He is more reclusive these days: busy with his next two films, his girlfriend Suzanne, his low-calorie shakes, and the weights. The industry buzz is not very kind - "Turkeys of the worst kind", one Bollywood insider said of his new movies. But the consensus is that Roshan has enough talent to come through.

Back at the Ganges, Coca-Cola is busy scrubbing off its advertising from the rocks; the work, the company says, of a renegade local distributor. Soon the boulders will look like they did at the beginning of time, before advertising and cola were invented.

Soon the boulders will look like they did at the beginning of time, before advertising and cola were invented.

webTitle: Government to accept child abuse report recommendations

fields.headline: Government to accept child abuse report recommendations
fields.standfirst: More about the Waterhouse report
fields.trailText: The government is expected to accept all of the recommendations made in the damning Waterhouse report into the sexual abuse of hundreds of children over two decades in North Wales children's homes.
fields.body:
The government is expected to accept all of the recommendations made in the damning Waterhouse report into the sexual abuse of hundreds of children over two decades in North Wales children's homes.

The report published in February said that systematic abuse, a climate of violence and a culture of secrecy existed in dozens of children's homes.

After a three-year, £13m investigation, Sir Ronald Waterhouse QC made 72 recommendations, calling for sweeping changes to the way local councils, social services and police deal with children in care.

He recommended the appointment of an independent children's commissioner for Wales, whistleblowing procedures to allow staff to raise concerns and a children's complaints officer to be appointed in every local authority to deal with allegations of abuse.

While ministers are set to accept all of the recommendations when the government formally responds to the report, many of the suggestions will be put out to consultation before any changes are made.

Victims of the scandal reacted with anger to the government's response to recommendations made in the damning Waterhouse report.

They accused ministers of "completely ignoring" them and demanded a national inquiry into child abuse.

Steve Messham, spokesman for North Wales Abuse Survivors, said: "The recommendations do not go far enough and do not apply to the whole of the country.

"We want a national inquiry into child abuse, not just one for North Wales.

"But most importantly, the victims are completely ignored. There is no mention of compensation, counselling or help and support for victims, and the government has failed to pick up on that."

The report exposed one of the worst child abuse scandals in history.

Hundreds of children had been physically, sexually or emotionally abused in care homes in North Wales between 1974 and 1990.

The inquiry heard from 240 people abused as children in 40 homes but there are thought to be hundreds more victims.

At least 12 victims have committed suicide, one has been convicted for murder and hundreds of others say their lives have been destroyed by the abuse they endured.

The report also mentioned 200 people who were abusers, alleged abusers or had failed to protect children in the homes, although not all of them have been named.

fields.headline: Abel Xavier's Excellent Adventure
fields.trailText: English coaches need schooling; Abel Xavier needs comforting; and Karel Poborsky needs some help.
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"I have to change my thinking, change the way I approach games" - You don't say, Mr Keegan.

THE EURO-TORIAL

It had to happen. As soon as everyone had concurred that this was the best footballing tournament of them all (and the Daily Mail had devoted two pages to this discovery) we had to be treated to a disappointing match. But at least it was a different kind of disappointing to watching Aston Villa play.

Last night's semi-final between France and Portugal failed to become the attacking feast we had all hoped for because the coaches were too canny. Humberto Coelho in particular set about creating a team that would nullify France's strengths. Pushing Sergio Conceicao forward and, initially at least, keeping Luis Figo on the left stifled the attacking threat from Lilian Thuram and Bixente Lizarazu. Coelho's two defensive midfielders then blocked the route to the defence, leaving Zinedine Zidane and occasionally Patrick Vieira to battle through a forest of red shirts.

Roger Lemerre also adapted his gameplan to suit the opponents: playing three defensive midfielders instead of the usual two to counteract Figo, Rui Costa and co., but also unexpectedly pairing Nicolas Anelka with Thierry Henry to give the occasionally ponderous Jorge Costa and Fernando Couto something to think about. Furthermore, Lemerre helped swing the game in extra time by abandoning the cautious shape of his midfield and introducing Robert Pires.

It struck the Euro while watching this game that Coelho and Lemerre, both fully qualified coaches, actually knew what they were doing. And then the Euro remembered Kevin Keegan bemoaning the technical standard of English players, and the general consensus that teaching kids more skills will solve the problems in the English game. Meantime English managers will continue to swan into £1m-a-year jobs with absolutely no qualifications and the tactical sophistication of a 14-year-old shoplifter. Double standards from the men in sheepskin? Surely not.

ABEL XAVIER: MY WONDERFUL TOURNAMENT

The ups and downs of Everton's hairy midfielder.

June 1: Joins Portuguese squad. Things are looking up.

June 5: Capitalises on new high-profile by dying all bodily hair blonde. We think.

June 12: Announces arrival on international stage by impressively stifling attacking thrusts of Phil Neville.

June 20: Dropped for Germany game. Instead attracts world's attention by sitting on bench and spinning ball on his finger.

June 24: Dropped again.

June 28: Returns to starting XI. Misses last-minute chance to send Portugal to first-ever major tournament final. Concedes heart-breaking penalty with blatant handball, then complains to ref. For ages.

June 29: Returns to Merseyside a star. Sort of.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Football and beer. They go together like... well, top sporting action and a tasty liquid beverage. Win a crate of beer from Lastorders.com for Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com and click on the link on the left hand side.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Abel Xavier has criticised referee Gunter Benko for awarding France their decisive penalty last night. "If you try to block the ball, you cannot do that without your hand supporting you on the ground," said the Everton man. "You just can't do that without hands, that's impossible." Xavier's hands later hit back at their owner. One claimed: "There's lots of other things he'd have trouble doing without us." "Yeah, like opening doors," the other added.

A Uefa disciplinary committee is meeting today to decide whether to punish Portugal for their penalty protests last night. Nuno Gomes was sent off for pushing referee Benko after the decision. A decision is expected from Uefa this afternoon.

Portuguese coach Humberto Coelho has resigned following his side's defeat against France. "This is a good time to go," he said. "It will allow a new man to take over for the World Cup qualifiers." Already the Portuguese style press are speculating over whether this "new man" is an ironic reworking of 1996's "new hombre", and whether he'll wear pantaloons.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hi, my brothers and sisters in Jesus Christ, it's Karel Poborsky. That's right, after my booze hell the other day, I've been reborn in the light of the Lord (or to be specific, the Church of the never-ending collection). So no more immoral activity for me!

Everton look set to lose Nick Barmby after the England man rejected an improved contract offer, believed to be in the region of £27,000-a-week. Both Chelsea and Liverpool are said to be interested in the 26-year-old valued at £7m. Naked ladies.

Newcastle want to sign tall striker (and close personal friend) Jan Koller to partner Alan Shearer next season. Koller would also cost £7m, and Bobby Robson hopes to finance a deal by selling Silvio Maric, Temuri Ketsbaia and Marcelino. Whipped cream.

Manchester United are the latest club to be linked with Zlatko Zahovic. The Slovenian star is set to leave Olympiakos only a year after joining the club and Sir Alex Ferguson is said to be interested. Powder-coated pork chops soaked in booze.

Hallo, is that Daniella Westbrook?

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

BBC1: Match of the Day Live (4.30pm, 1.05am)
Italy v Netherlands, or Italy v Holland if you want to annoy a Dutch pedant.

MOTD @ Euro 2000 (12midnight)
Dion Dublin? To couch it in the terms you used to dismiss an email some bloke sent in to the programme the other week: we don't care where you're from, mate, your analysis is rubbish.

ITV: Euro 2000 Today (11.30pm)
Sideshow Bob struggles to read the autocue, gets his timing wrong when cueing in VT, and fails to ask the panellists any relevant questions. What a professional!

The Big Match (2.35am)
It's on an hour-and-a-half later than the BBC one, but it may be worth the wait just to make sure you don't run into Dion Dublin.

British Eurosport: have scheduled their usual 73 different Euro 2000 programmes today. They're all on at different times, which is obvious when you think about it, and they're all very good. No live match, though, so you can forget that.

webTitle: Ealing becomes a fashionable neighbourhood once more

fields.headline: Ealing becomes a fashionable neighbourhood once more
fields.trailText: Two new British films will once again feature the 'Made at Ealing Studios' credit
fields.body:
The fortunes of the Ealing studios - at their height in the 40s and 50s but little used since the 60s, are about to be revived, as we reported six months ago.

The west London studios were recently bought for £10m by a consortium comprising Fragile Films (the company that produced the Spice Girls' Spiceworld), the property developers Manhattan Loft Company, and The Idea Factory, a San Francisco digital development company. The consortium plans a digital production arm at Ealing and to create films for internet broadcast alongside traditional film-making.

The partners say they will pump £20m into the studios and make 20 films in the next five years. The first two will shoot shortly. Lucky Break, directed by Peter Cattaneo (The Full Monty) has been written by Stephen Fry and is about prison inmates who put on a musical in order to mount an escape. It will be released next year with the credit 'Made at Ealing Studios'.

The second film is Mel Smith's High Heels and Low Lives, written by Kim Fuller (who also has the dubious distinction of being the writer behind Spiceworld).

The romance of Ealing, which made classics such as The Lavender Hill Mob, Passport to Pimlico and Whisky Galore, has never faded. The studio's future had looked bleak when the National Film and Television School - which has run it for the past three years as a facility for film and television producers - decided to sell.

But a Forever Ealing campaign launched by stars of the British film industry to preserve the 92-year-old home of British classics for film-making, rather than see the land used for a hotel or supermarket has achieved its aims, and Ealing will be producing films once more.

Meanwhile, the news that Hollywood is planning remakes of both Kind Heart and Coronets and The Ladykillers testifies to a revival of interest in this previously unfashionable genre.

webTitle: Merger to create Germany's biggest TV company

fields.headline: Merger to create Germany's biggest TV company
fields.trailText: Two of Germany's leading media companies, ProSieben Media and SAT1 announced plans to merge, creating the nation's biggest television company. It will control four main channels which are watched by an average of one in four German viewers nightly.
fields.body:
Two of Germany's leading media companies, ProSieben Media and SAT1 announced plans to merge, creating the nation's biggest television company. It will control four main channels which are watched by an average of one in four German viewers nightly.

The merger is seen as a defensive move against Bertelsmann, the German media empire that became the continent's largest broadcaster in April, when it merged its TV and radio arm with the television interests of Britain's Pearson group. With more than 22 channels in 35 countries, the Bertelsmann-Pearson group has about $3.6bn (£2.4bn) in revenues a year.

But the new group will knock Bertelsmann off the top spot in Germany itself with an annual revenue of $1.9bn. In true German fashion it will be called ProSiebenSAT1 Media AG.

The new company plans to develop alliances with broadcasters in other European countries. Its largest shareholder will be KirchMedia, which has strong links to Silvio Berlusconi's Mediaset group in Italy.

The deal is subject to approval from shareholders and regulators.

fields.headline: Jekyll-and-Hyde England turn it around
fields.trailText: This was a real mixed bag of an England performance. Toothless before tea, when the overcast conditions were perfectly tailored to their five seamers, they were incisive afterwards, turning the match on its head and sending the spectators home happy. At 175 for 2, after being asked to bat, West Indies were cruising. At 267 for 9, it was anyone's game.
fields.body:
This was a real mixed bag of an England performance. Toothless before tea, when the overcast conditions were perfectly tailored to their five seamers, they were incisive afterwards, turning the match on its head and sending the spectators home happy. At 175 for 2, after being asked to bat, West Indies were cruising. At 267 for 9, it was anyone's game.

England's Jekyll-and-Hyde display was personified by Dominic Cork and Andy Caddick. Cork, returning to the scene of his sensational debut in 1995, when he took 7-43 against West Indies, bowled with the aggression and intelligence of a man desperate to impress on his reintroduction to Test cricket after 20 months in the wilderness. There were bouncers, inswingers, smiles and grimaces, and Cork even managed to pick up his 100th Test wicket (Wavell Hinds) in this, the 100th Test at Lord's. His spell after tea (11-5-16-3) was the best by an England bowler since Darren Gough steamed in on the third evening here against Zimbabwe in May. Cork's successes even seemed to fire up Gough towards the end. How did we manage without him?

Caddick on the other hand was listless. Since nobbling the Zims at Lord's he has been back to his old, tentative self. He bowled at three-quarter pace for the third Test in a row, rarely breaking 83 mph, and his lack of edge was reflected by one half-hearted shout for leg before against Hinds. Replays showed it would probably have hit leg stump. Most bowlers would be delighted to be let loose under muggy skies on the first morning of a Test; Caddick just looked distracted.

He wasn't the only one. England's seamers weren't helped by three missed chances, but they still failed to take a wicket until the 57th over of the innings - and even then they had to rely on Sherwin Campbell's mis-timed hook. By tea, the apparently world-class opening pairing of Caddick and Gough had taken 1-99 between them. As scandals go, this was almost up there with Profumo. Matthew Hoggard, on debut, did better than both in his first spell (7-32-17-0) but spoilt things slightly by conceding 16 in four balls later on as Franklyn Rose threatened to run riot. Even so, it was a mystery that Alec Stewart waited 50 overs before bringing him back into the attack.

The early West Indian batting had been excellent. Campbell cut with the force and skill of a seasoned lumberjack, while Hinds, upright and unperturbed, unfurled a sequence of gloriously timed cover drives. Three of them, off successive balls from the innocuous Craig White, even brought applause from members of the press box.

But they were uncorked after tea as the tactic of playing the five-man seam attack finally bore fruit. You just wonder though what Angus Fraser would have done on his home ground in these conditions. He has never played in a Test with Gough and Caddick before, but a four-pronged attack of those three plus Cork, with a fit-again Andy Flintoff as back-up, could make the series even more interesting than this game is threatening to be.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
It's in the post

Mail order book and music clubs are those amiable inventions which lure customers with complete sets of inlaid Jane Austen/Mozart concertos for £1.99. The tiny print at the bottom of the advertisements is too tedious to decipher so we send off for the booty before finding ourselves obliged to buy a handful of full-price releases per quarter for the next two years. The tortuous conditions attached can perplex the most dedicated collector and Britannia Music Club, in particular, is becoming a familiar name in our postbag.

One of its habits - other book and music clubs operate this way too - is to dispatch a recommended recording to each member every month unless that member remembers to refuse it in advance. Julia McKiernan of London says that two such recordings were delivered although she had had no opportunity to refuse them. She also says that she was charged for two CDs which were supposed to be free. After a series of other slip-ups she tried to cancel her membership but was told her request would be delayed in the hope that she would fulfil her membership commitment. Despite this, her account was cancelled and she was charged a £60 penalty.

Terry Alexander of Bolton says he was also charged for a "free" CD, but that his numerous letters and phone calls have failed to produce a response.

Britannia argues that both customers had misunderstood their free entitlement, but admits that other mistakes were made. Alexander has now been refunded for the free CD and offered an extra two recordings gratis. McKiernan has been offered three complimentary CDs and her membership has been cancelled without penalty fee. Trading Standards says that it has received numerous calls, but that the company is entirely reputable.

Catching Freeserve

Much has been made of the race to lure customers on to free internet providers, but it has proved somewhat elusive. As a severely disabled man living alone in the countryside, Philip Dangerfield has found the internet a salvation and when Dixons's Freeserve offered unlimited access for £10 he tried to sign up.

A month later he was still trying. "Each time I'm told my account number and sort code don't match and each time I'm told they're working on the problem which was affecting a lot of people. Now I can't get through on the customer advice line at all."

Dixons blames it on demand. "We have a limit of 10,000 new customers that we can sign on each week and have had a backlog," says a spokesman. "The demand has caused some minor administrative errors of the type Mr Dangerfield has experienced, but we'll call him and register him right away." Lo and behold, a week later he is surfing contentedly.

And the wait continues

Keith Bailey, D Chieffo and Ken Wilson have been experiencing similar difficulties, in their case with NTL'S offer of free internet calls. All of them are existing NTL customers who registered for the scheme as soon as it was launched on April 17, and are still being billed for their internet exploits. Even more galling is the fact that new customers appear to be given priority as a bait to lure them away from rivals. Not so Joe Phillips, though. He transferred to NTL in April and is still waiting for his disc.

NTL is coy about the claim that new customers are queue jumping. Instead it explains how mighty demand has caused a backlog. "We underestimated exactly how many people would want to take advantage of the service," says a spokeswoman. "We are therefore controlling the ways in which our customers come online to NTL through a queuing system. Customers will have to wait until we are sure that we can deliver an excellent fee-free service. We have already stopped advertising the scheme."

Cut fails to ring a bell

BT has so far maintained a relatively clean profile in this column, but when it tries hard it can rival the activities of more familiar friends such as Cable & Wireless. Recently one Friday an engineer working on a telegraph pole managed to sever Peter Matthew's telephone connections. On contacting BT from a call box, Matthews was told that it would be four days before the fault could be repaired because: "It's a bank holiday" (in fact, says Matthews, it was a working Friday); "It's not procedure to call an engineer back to a job"; and he "should be on a business agreement", then he would get an emergency service.

Furthermore, Matthews was told, there would be no compensation and no point in transferring to another provider because their response times would be the same.

BT apologises for its staff's attitude, but insists that it aims to repair faults by the end of the next working day and weekends and public holidays are not working days. Compensation is only payable when the fault is not fixed within the target time. "In this particular case the fault was cleared in that time [ie four days later]," says a spokesman.

Debt doesn't stack up

Susy Brigden recently endeavoured to add to her stock of bank cards by replying to an offer from MSDW. To her surprise, her application was refused because, she was told, she had an outstanding debt at another address. "I have never owed money and have lived at my present address for seven years," she says. "MSDW won't tell me where I'm supposed to have been blacklisted, so how do I clear my name?"

This is a curious predicament because companies are not supposed to hold information relevant to addresses left over six years previously. "Customers should have the right to ask which credit reference agency the company in question is using and it's a criminal offence if the company does not supply the information within seven days," says a spokesman for the Institute for Trading Standards.

Once you know which agency has your details you can request your file for a £2 fee and challenge the information in it. You can also add a statement amending or qualifying the information and the agency is obliged to send this to every company who has recently requested the file.

Miles from home

Recently we awarded Cable & Wireless a prize for the most surreal excuse after it installed Barbara Smoker's new phone line in her neighbour's house and insisted that the neighbour shared her name. John Haynes, of Truro, Cornwall, read this with peculiar glee.

He wrote to our old friends last October when contractors laying cables managed to sever his gas, water and electricity service pipes and left temporary traffic lights fuelled by a generator outside his bedroom window. Four further letters, including three from his MP, were met with silence. Only later did he discover they had been replying to a Mr Haines - 60 miles away in Bude.

webTitle: Isabel Peake murder suspect dies in jail fire

fields.headline: Isabel Peake murder suspect dies in jail fire
fields.trailText: A Frenchman suspected of killing British student Isabel Peake was found dead yesterday at the Lisbon prison where he was being held.
fields.body:
A Frenchman suspected of killing British student Isabel Peake was found dead yesterday at the Lisbon prison where he was being held.

The exact cause of death was not immediately known, but a source at the Lisbon morgue said 21-year-old Sid Ahmed Rezala had set fire to his mattress and inhaled the fumes.

He was the prime suspect in the murder of Birmingham University student Isabel Peake, 20, whose partially clothed body was found beside a rail line on October 13 in France.

He was arrested in January near Lisbon. He lodged a final appeal against his extradition on June 7 after the supreme court and a lower court had granted France's extradition request.

Rezala's appeal questioned whether he would face a jail sentence in his home country of more than 25 years, which is the maximum allowed in Portugal.

Under the Portuguese constitution, a defendant cannot be extradited to a country which allows the death sentence or a jail sentence of more than 25 years.

Rezala was also wanted for the killing of Corinne Caillaux, a 36-year-old Frenchwoman who was stabbed to death in the bathroom of a train on December 14.

Police suspected he committed a third murder involving 20-year-old Emilie Bazin, whose body was found under a pile of coal in the basement of a building in Amiens, northern France, last December.

Law and sociology student Isabel Peake, from Staffordshire, was on a one-year course in Limoges, central France, when she was pushed from a high-speed overnight train to Paris just after 4am on October 13.

Rezala, a drifter who was part of a gang that robbed train passengers, last month told a French journalist that he had a flash and felt "ordered" to kill her.

The suspect's French lawyers, Jean-Claude Richard and Joel Batille, heard the news of his death this morning: "We haven't had official notification of his death, but we have heard it on the news. I find it very surprising that somebody is able to set fire to his cell without being seen or heard," Mr Richard said. "We are very sad that a boy of 21 has died in this way. To us, this does not mean he was guilty." Bill Cash, MP for Stone, said: "Given his confession, there does not appear to be any doubt that he did commit this dreadful murder.

"Having confessed, he obviously couldn't face the future. For the family of Isabel, this would appear to be the ultimate proof of his guilt and a trial would not have added anything to the fact that he committed this murder."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours laid bare on a bed of wild rocket, infused with a drizzle of olive oil and then finished off with Parmesan shavings. Delicious.
fields.trailText: Everton look set to lose Nick Barmby after the England man rejected an improved contract offer, believed to be in the region of £27,000-a-week. Both Chelsea and Liverpool are interested in the 26-year-old, who is valued at £7m.
fields.body:
Everton look set to lose Nick Barmby after the England man rejected an improved contract offer, believed to be in the region of £27,000-a-week. Both Chelsea and Liverpool are interested in the 26-year-old, who is valued at £7m.

Newcastle want to sign Jan Koller to partner Alan Shearer next season. Koller would also cost £7m, and Bobby Robson hopes to finance a deal by selling Silvio Maric, Temuri Ketsbaia and Marcelino.

Manchester United are the latest club to be linked with Zlatko Zahovic, reports the Star. The Slovenian international is set to leave Olympiakos only a year after joining the club and Sir Alex Ferguson is said to be interested.

Ipswich manager George Burley has confirmed his interest in Tottenham defender John Scales, according to Teamtalk. He said: "I had a long chat with John and will be waiting to hear from him again later in the week. He is a player I feel still has plenty to offer and as a result we have made certain proposals to him."

Aston Villa will open talks with representatives of Portugal striker Nuno Gomes in Amsterdam today, reports the Mirror.

Manchester United reserve team left-back Danny Higginbottom is a £1.5m target for Derby.

fields.headline: Scandal of Britain's ballet schools
fields.standfirst: 15-year study says young dancers are pressured to become anorexic
fields.trailText: 15-year study says young dancers are pressured to become anorexic.
fields.body:
It is a dream for many: to attend a ballet school, where the privileged atmosphere and intense hopes hint at a world of ethereal glamour. But the reality of training to be a ballerina is very different, according to new research endorsed by the outspoken Royal Ballet principal, Deborah Bull.

In a world in which the artistic director of the English National Ballet, Derek Deane, can regularly deride English dancers as "too stocky", trainee ballerinas are effectively "asked to be anorexic" as they battle to reduce their weight by up to a quarter, the study reveals.

The hothouse atmosphere not only damages young dancers by pressurising them into succumbing to the potentially fatal eating disorder, but produces "incredibly emotionally immature" youngsters who are ill equipped to cope with the complexities of life beyond their narrow, rarefied existence.

Low self-esteem is rife in a milieu where no tutors are required to undergo training, and teaching is often archaic.

Far from developing into well-rounded individuals, able to approach the classics with maturity and intelligence, today's young dancers are being emotionally and physically crushed by an approach to training which is "unethical" in its rigour.

The blistering attack on the training of Britain's ballet dancers is made in The Student Dancer, an academic treatise published by Julia Buckroyd, a psychotherapist and lecturer at the University of Hertfordshire. It draws on 15 years of research into the problems experienced by would-be Deborah Bulls - who is promoting the book at today's launch.

A former counsellor for five years at the London Contemporary Dance School, Ms Buckroyd interviewed or counselled more than 400 young dancers, as well as directors of dance schools, before writing her book, which calls for radical reforms.

A specialist in eating disorders, she became particularly concerned by the dance world's insistence that its protégées reach just 75% of average body weight. "I became very aware of what a stress it is for these women to reach this," she said. "But more than that, the definition of an anorexic is somebody who is 15% less than the accepted body weight for their height and age.

"So what we're asking is that dancers be, in effect, anorexics - and we have to ask if it's ethical to demand this of young girls. Is it ethical to require them to be so thin some of them will never menstruate and so will have problems with fertility, not to mention osteoporosis?"

Ms Buckroyd said recent research showed that 20% of Britain's ballet dancers were anorexic - 20 times more than in the female population as a whole - but estimated that "at least 50%" had sub-clinical conditions and were preoccupied with food to an unhealthy extent.

The eating disorder was only the most obvious outcome of a harsh teaching regime in which pupils, some of whom are as young as 11 when they enter full-time vocational training, are sometimes forbidden to speak to other students in class or to respond to the predominantly critical approach of their tutors, she said.

Although the Council for Dance Education and Training assesses its 20 accredited schools, and the Department of Education has begun to do so this year, many, unaccredited schools evade assessment. Moreover, no teachers are required to undergo any form of government-recognised training, ensuring that new ideas do not filter through.

"Although there have been massive changes in ways of teaching in mainstream education, it's light years away in the dance world," Ms Buckroyd said. "Teaching's often still very hierarchical and the lack of student-centred learning is quite significant. Training isn't structured in a way that helps them to interact, and it just doesn't help them to mature."

The picture she paints will no doubt be familiar to some former pupils of White Lodge, the Royal Ballet's prestigious school for 11- to 16-year-olds. Five years ago, Richmond social services were brought in after complaints and concluded that staff used "draconian methods" of teaching which "would not be tolerated anywhere else".

Last night, the school's new artistic director refused to comment, but heads of other ballet schools denied that such teaching practices were tolerated at their establishments. "The days when the only voice you heard was the teacher's are over. There's a lot of conversation between teachers and students," said Kathryn Wade, director of the English National Ballet School.

She insisted that her school - where the artistic director, Mr Deane, has derided English dancers as being too "bummy" or too "titty" - would never stipulate that a pupil should be a specific weight. "Most dancers are perfectionist and they impose very high standards upon themselves, which is really how you get wonderful performances," she said. "Dancers are aware if they need to slim. And weight is dictated by the profession. If you are going to get a job as a dancer, you have to look the way a particular ballet company feels you should."

But Jane Hackett, director of the Central School of Ballet, which employs a nutritionist as well as a sports psychologist for its 65 16- to 19-year-old pupils, said Ms Buckroyd's exposé was "a fair picture". "There are a number of schools that haven't addressed the best ways of nurturing talent and it's disappointing that dance teaching and training haven't kept pace with developments in the wider education sector," Ms Hackett said.

A spokeswoman for the Council for Dance Education and Training said this was an area that needed to be rigorously reviewed. "Children aged between 11 and 16 who are undergoing extreme physical training need to be protected and we need to ensure these students are getting the safest and most appropriate training - both physically and emotionally," she said.

Relentless regime is only way to the top

Most dancers start their training at the age of five with weekly classes at their local school - although aspiring Deborah Bulls could theoretically wait till the age of 10 or 11.

By eight, they will be taking hourly classes up to three times a week. In addition, they will enter a couple of competitions a year - requiring further rehearsals - and embark on junior syllabus exams, the elementary, intermediate and advanced versions of which will take them from ages 11-18.

At 11, the training becomes more rigorous. Each year, around 100 girls, and a sprinkling of boys, will win places at five specialist schools where, in addition to the national curriculum, they will take at least two hours of dance classes a day, as well as other sports such as swimming and tennis.

For those who fail to make the prestigious institutions, the local ballet school will be their focus for two hours each evening, as well as Saturdays. The extra keen may also spend their weekends in London at rehearsals with National Ballet, or the National Youth Ballet.

Those still undeterred must then, at 16, opt to go into two or three years of full-time professional training. A total of 20 schools are accredited, plus the Royal Ballet School which is regulated by Ofsted, and where 1,000 students will be training at any one time.

A-level dance will be taken, but further A-levels are not required. Students will spend up to five hours dancing a day - often in a mixture of classes in contemporary dances, classical ballet and jazz. In addition, they will often be encouraged to take body conditioning and Pilates, a system of gentle exercise to stretch and lengthen muscles.

webTitle: UK youth: the good, the bad and the sickly

fields.headline: UK youth: the good, the bad and the sickly
fields.standfirst:
The young generation is better educated than ever before, but is also less wealthy and takes more drugs than other age groups, says survey
Quiz: how old are you really?
fields.trailText: Britain's young people are the best qualified, and most mobile, defiantly single and sexually liberated young generation ever raised in Britain.
fields.body:
Britain's young people are the best qualified, and most mobile, defiantly single and sexually liberated young generation ever raised in Britain.

They are also the least well-paid group in society, suffer high rates of unemployment, are the most likely victims and perpetrators of crime, take more drugs than any other age group and are sicklier than previous generations.

These contrasting views of the nation's 8.7m 13- to 24-year-olds emerged in a survey published yesterday by the Office for National Statistics, examining the transitions made by young people as they move from education to work and from dependence to independence.

The majority of young people are raised in families headed by a couple, with 24% coming from single parent families. But while 71% still grow up in a married family environment this has done little to stem the decline in marriage rates.

In the 1950s young couples were four times more likely to marry than they are today, and the mean age at which people marry has steadily risen since 1971, from 24 to 30 for men, and 22 to 28 for women. Only 3% of men and 7% of women under 24 were married in 1998, the period of the study.

There has been a rise in the number of people cohabiting in the same period, with 9% of unmarried 19- to 24-year-old men and 18% of women of the same age living together. More than half of all 20- to 24-year-olds have moved out of the family home.

An increase in asthma and muscular complaints is thought to be responsible for one of the report's more worrying findings; that 20% of young people suffer from long-standing ailments, an increase of 8% since 1975.

Concerns about body image among young women are also borne out. Some 23% of 13- to 15-year-olds said they thought they were too heavy, rising to 28% among 16- to 19-year-olds and 38% for those aged 20 to 24. By contrast, more than half of all boys said they were the right weight.

The study reveals a marked difference in the experiences and attitudes of boys and girls in relation to health, sex and education. Girls are more likely than boys to be regular smokers by the age of 15 (29% against 19%). The gap narrows as people reach the 20-24 group, with 42% of men and 39% of women smoking regularly.

By contrast boys and men are far more prodigious drinkers than women, with 44% of 18- to 20-year-olds claiming to drink more than eight units (four pints) daily, compared with 29% of girls claiming to consume more than six units daily.

The 20-24 age group contains society's biggest drinkers regardless of gender, with regular extreme alcohol consumption tailing off as people pass into their mid-20s.

Around a third of all 16- to 24-year-olds have taken an illegal drug, with young men more likely to indulge (36%) than young women (24%).

The most commonly used drug is cannabis, followed by amphetamines and ecstasy. Cocaine use is much lower than in older age groups, where drug use as a whole is less prevalent.

Women are more sexually active than men of the same age, with 37% of 16- to 19-year-olds having one sexual partner in the past year, compared with 24% of men, and 33% having more than two, compared with 28%.

Educationally girls perform better than their male counterparts. In 1998-99 54% of girls achieved five or more GCSE grades A to C or equivalent, compared with 44% of boys. At A-level, 25% of girls have two A levels or more, 4% more than boys.

More people than ever stay in full-time education and for longer, with 2.4m people - around a third - staying on beyond the minimum age of 16.

Young men earn more than young women in full and part-time employment, although the gender discrepancy increases in the above-25 age group. Average weekly wages for 18- to 20-year-old women are around £20 less than for young men. Unemployment rates are high, with 19% of young men not in education out of work, and 29% of young women.

Nearly 21% of victims of violent crimes are young men, while 35% of all offenders are men aged between 16 and 20.

While 33% of those eligible supported Labour at the last election, nearly a third did not bother to vote.

webTitle: Rich live longer, poor die younger in a divided world

fields.headline: Rich live longer, poor die younger in a divided world
fields.standfirst:
UN report highlights growing gap between developed countries and those ravaged by war, poverty and Aids
The full list
fields.trailText: UN report highlights growing gap between developed countries and those ravaged by war, poverty and Aids
fields.body:
The mapping of the human genome may hold out the prospect of life expectancy in the west nudging 100 but it comes far too late for countries where poverty, war and HIV/Aids have turned the clock back on development by decades, the UN says in a report published today.

Its annual assessment of progress in 174 states finds that the super-rich are not only getting richer, they are living longer as well.

While the income gap between rich and poor countries continues to widen, the lifespan in some sub-Saharan Africa countries is only half that in the developed world.

The human development report (HDR) says the top 200 billionaires had a combined wealth of $1,135bn last, up by $100bn from the previous year. The total income of the 582m people in all the developing countries barely exceeds 10% of that: $146bn.

In the 30 countries considered to have the highest level of human development, life expectancy at birth is more than 75 years. In sub-Saharan Africa it is 48.9 years, falling to 39.1 years in Malawi and 37.9 years in Sierra Leone.

For the first time since it was launched in 1990, the HDR argues that these are inequalities which the UN classes as human rights violations.

A yawning gap

The report breaks new ground this year with the assertion that human rights must include economic, social and cultural rights, not just political and civil rights. Richard Jolly, the report's main author, says this is the most important of the 11 reports produced so far. "We've taken a major conceptual step."

The report says global inequalities have increased in the 20th century "by orders of magnitude out of proportion to anything experienced before". The gap between the incomes of the richest and poorest countries was about 3 to 1 in 1820, 35 to 1 in 1950, 44 to 1 in 1973, and 72 to 1 in 1992. Dr Jolly estimates that a calculation of a comparable figure today would show an even wider discrepancy.

Between 1990 and 1998, per capita income fell in 50 countries, only one of them in the 29 developed states which make up the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.

Some progress

The national disparity between rich and poor is similarly widening in many countries, the report says. In Russia the gulf is dramatic, but even in countries not undergoing great social changes, such as Britain, Sweden and the United States, there gap has been steadily widening for 20 years.

Progress has been made in some areas, it says. Between 1980 and 1999, the proportion of underweight children in developing countries fell from 37% to 27%, and access to safe water has increased from 13% to 71% since 1970.

But while income poverty in countries such as China has fallen dramatically, 1.2bn people - a fifth of the world's population - are living on less than $1 (66p) a day.

In addition, 100m children are estimated to be living or working on the streets and 1.2m women and girls under 18 are trafficked for prostitution each year.

Problems exist in the world's richest countries as well as the poorest, the UN says. In the OECD as a whole, 8m children are undernourished, and in the US 40m people are not covered by health insurance and one in five adults is functionally illiterate.

Britain remains 10th in the UN's human development index, which measures literacy and life expectancy in addition to living standards.

The report calls for bold new approaches to achieving economic and other human rights for all. "Advances in the 21st century will be won by human struggle against divisive values - and against the opposition of entrenched economic and political interests."

The report is upbeat about the surge of change in the human rights climate in many countries, involving many different civil groups, women's groups and media.

This in turn has brought about a new democratic climate far removed from formal election processes with no real participation by ordinary people.

In a special contribution to the report, the Nigerian president, Olesegun Obasanjo, writes of the "evil governance" experienced by his country before its return to civil government.

"The dark years spawned human rights activism . . . the more tyrannical the regime got, the more people became aware of what they were losing by way of freedom of expression and the right to determine how they were to be governed."

These changes, Dr Jolly says, are underpinned by the large number of countries ratifying the various UN conventions on human rights.

The convention on the rights of the child, for instance, has been ratified by every country except two: the US and Somalia.

And countries such as Norway, Belgium, Sweden, Brazil, South Africa and Sri Lanka have adopted special budgets for matters relating to children.

But these steps forward are against the background of some grim realities for children in other areas. For instance, Dr Jolly says, "HIV/Aids is the disaster factor for a dozen or more countries in Africa, pulling down their life expectancy and their ranking in the human development index. Meanwhile life expectancy at the top end is going up".

The cost of war

Botswana, which has enjoyed rapid growth in recent years, has income per capita on a par with Russia and Brazil, but its life expectancy has fallen by around 10 years as a result of the spread of HIV/Aids to more than 25% of the population.

Although the number of conflicts fell during the 90s, the cost to the international community of the seven main wars (not including Kosovo) was $200bn - four times the development aid in any one year.

"Not too surprising then that the volume of development aid went down substantially in the 1990s. The shift of resources away from development may even be contributing to future conflicts - as assistance is withdrawn just when needed to prevent escalation," the UN says.

fields.headline: Obituary: Judith Wright
fields.standfirst: Australian poet who championed Aboriginal rights and environmental issues
fields.trailText: Australian poet who championed Aboriginal rights and environmental issues
fields.body:
Judith Wright, who has died aged 85, was born into a pioneering bush family and managed to become the conscience of Australia on the vexed issues of Aboriginal rights and the environment before they became fashionable. One of only two Australian poets considered for the Nobel Prize for Literature - the other was AD Hope - her works have been standard texts for many years in Australian schools and universities, but she deplored the way poetry was taught. "Appreciation of poetry, one out of 10 or whatever it might be, is quite alien to what a poet feels about poetry," she once said.

She was described as feeling almost Aboriginal about the Australian landscape and she regularly described that love in her poems. "I've been a writer all of my life and a conservationist for far too much of it," she admitted.

In a poem called Eroded Hills, written in 1950, she described the de-forested scenery of the New England area of New South Wales where she grew up.

These hills my father's father stripped and beggars to the winter wind they

crouch like shoulders naked and whipped humbled, abandoned, out of mind...

when the last leaf and bird go, let my thoughts stand like trees. Here.

Her biographer Veronica Brady said that Wright, who was the first Australian to win the Queen's Gold Medal for Poetry, was a major poet almost in the "Russian way", because she made a political impact. "I think that Judith Wright's poetry speaks a sense of sacredness in the land, the sacredness of simple things like animals and plants, and the violation of that sacredness. She has a feeling not only for the land but also for the Aboriginal people."

Wright was born at Thalgarrah station near Armidale, NSW, to a leading and wealthy pastoral family. She was a solitary child who spent many hours riding her pony across the property, where a sense of public service and noblesse oblige was instilled in her at an early age.

At first she was educated at home, but on the death of her mother went to New England Girls' school and then the University of Sydney, where she read English. She was 25 before her first poem was published. Her first collection of verse, The Moving Image, appeared in 1946, and because it was full of her feelings for the land and its spirit helped change the traditions of Australian writing, which Veronica Brady said until then had been about men, horses and the conquest of the land.

During the next two decades she produced more collections of poems, including in 1949 Woman to Man, which was hailed at the time as being significant to the national canon because of its lyric intensity and frankness about women's sexuality.

There was also a biography about her pioneering grandparents and a series of acclaimed children's books which followed the birth of her daughter Meredith, who survives her, and her marriage to the unconventional philosopher Jack McKinney, who died in 1966.

The shadow of the cold war and the blossoming of her interest in conservation and wildlife preservation were reflected in her poetry, such as Birds (1961), which was devoted to describing them, and also in her public life as she became a dedicated campaigner against nuclear power and wanton development.

"Her environmental poems, loved and studied now by generations of Australians, are today stopping more bulldozers than any environmental activists," said poet Mark O'Connor.

Wright went on to receive numerous awards, five honorary doctorates from different universities for her poetry, and cemented her reputation as a literary critic with her 1965 work Preoccupations in Australian Poetry.

By the mid-60s she was widowed and had become a major force in Australian poetry. Her style was described as becoming more hardy and muscular with the freer rhythms of direct speech and anger at the materialism of most Australians.

She became more involved in public issues and was involved in successful battles to stop oil drilling on the Great Barrier Reef and the desecration of other areas of great heritage value. In 1976 she moved to the remarkable heritage town of Braidwood near Canberra, and lived in a virtual wildlife refuge which was the source of many of her later poems. She also wrote the book The Cry of the Dead, about the treatment of Aborigines by settlers in Queensland from the 1840s to the 1920s.

Wright also became progressively deaf, but academic Julian Croft said the misfortune seemed to reinforce her feelings about language. "Her deafness gave her poetry readings a directness and force any poet would envy," he said.

Australian poet Robert Gray said she filled the highest role of poet and became the conscience of the country. "There was a blazing quality of integrity about her," he said. "She wrote about values, mourning the way land was being destroyed, the way people were being destroyed."

Last year she published a volume of her autobiography called Half a Lifetime, which covered her life until the 1960s. Judith Wright's last public appearance was at a march for reconciliation with Aboriginal people in Canberra late last month. She was working on the second volume of her autobiography when she died of a heart attack.

One of the country's leading poets, John Tranter, said: "What she has left us is a spirited body of writing and a model for a humane and committed concern for the future of the human race."

She is survived by her daughter, Meredith.

I wither and you break from me;
yet though you dance in living light
I am the earth, I am the root,
I am the stem that fed the fruit,
the link that joins you to the night.

from Woman To Child, in Woman To Man (1949)

Die, wild country, like the eaglehawke,
dangerous till the last breath's gone,
clawing and striking. Die
cursing your captor through a raging
eye.

from Australian 1970, in Shadow (1970)

 Judith Wright, poet, born May 31 1915; died June 25 2000
