She has a feeling not only for the land but also for the Aboriginal people." Wright was born at Thalgarrah station near Armidale, NSW, to a leading and wealthy pastoral family. She was a solitary child who spent many hours riding her pony across the property, where a sense of public service and noblesse oblige was instilled in her at an early age. At first she was educated at home, but on the death of her mother went to New England Girls' school and then the University of Sydney, where she read English. She was 25 before her first poem was published. Her first collection of verse, The Moving Image, appeared in 1946, and because it was full of her feelings for the land and its spirit helped change the traditions of Australian writing, which Veronica Brady said until then had been about men, horses and the conquest of the land. During the next two decades she produced more collections of poems, including in 1949 Woman to Man, which was hailed at the time as being significant to the national canon because of its lyric intensity and frankness about women's sexuality. There was also a biography about her pioneering grandparents and a series of acclaimed children's books which followed the birth of her daughter Meredith, who survives her, and her marriage to the unconventional philosopher Jack McKinney, who died in 1966. The shadow of the cold war and the blossoming of her interest in conservation and wildlife preservation were reflected in her poetry, such as Birds (1961), which was devoted to describing them, and also in her public life as she became a dedicated campaigner against nuclear power and wanton development. "Her environmental poems, loved and studied now by generations of Australians, are today stopping more bulldozers than any environmental activists," said poet Mark O'Connor. Wright went on to receive numerous awards, five honorary doctorates from different universities for her poetry, and cemented her reputation as a literary critic with her 1965 work Preoccupations in Australian Poetry. By the mid-60s she was widowed and had become a major force in Australian poetry. Her style was described as becoming more hardy and muscular with the freer rhythms of direct speech and anger at the materialism of most Australians. She became more involved in public issues and was involved in successful battles to stop oil drilling on the Great Barrier Reef and the desecration of other areas of great heritage value. In 1976 she moved to the remarkable heritage town of Braidwood near Canberra, and lived in a virtual wildlife refuge which was the source of many of her later poems. She also wrote the book The Cry of the Dead, about the treatment of Aborigines by settlers in Queensland from the 1840s to the 1920s. Wright also became progressively deaf, but academic Julian Croft said the misfortune seemed to reinforce her feelings about language. "Her deafness gave her poetry readings a directness and force any poet would envy," he said. Australian poet Robert Gray said she filled the highest role of poet and became the conscience of the country. "There was a blazing quality of integrity about her," he said. "She wrote about values, mourning the way land was being destroyed, the way people were being destroyed." Last year she published a volume of her autobiography called Half a Lifetime, which covered her life until the 1960s. Judith Wright's last public appearance was at a march for reconciliation with Aboriginal people in Canberra late last month. She was working on the second volume of her autobiography when she died of a heart attack. One of the country's leading poets, John Tranter, said: "What she has left us is a spirited body of writing and a model for a humane and committed concern for the future of the human race." She is survived by her daughter, Meredith. I wither and you break from me; yet though you dance in living light I am the earth, I am the root, I am the stem that fed the fruit, the link that joins you to the night. from Woman To Child, in Woman To Man (1949) Die, wild country, like the eaglehawke, dangerous till the last breath's gone, clawing and striking. Die cursing your captor through a raging eye. from Australian 1970, in Shadow (1970)  Judith Wright, poet, born May 31 1915; died June 25 2000

webTitle: Can Blair win over the Germans?

fields.headline: Can Blair win over the Germans?
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair arrives in Germany today for talks with Gerhard Schröder. Will he get a sympathetic hearing for British fears over further integration?
fields.trailText: Tony Blair arrives in Germany today for talks with Gerhard Schröder. David McKie wonders if he will get a sympathetic hearing for British fears over further integration
fields.body:
Tony Blair has flown to Germany for talks with chancellor Gerhard Schröder. Over a quiet dinner together, they will no doubt discuss their holidays and the shared disappointments of Euro 2000, where neither national team made the finals.

At the end of the day a communique will be issued full of words and phrases such as amicable, cordial, looking forward to further opportunities... Nothing of any consequence will be announced. But you don't need communiques to understand the scenario - this is Schröder the pusher-on and Blair the hanger-back.

The argument over the euro is not in this context just a matter of what you do with your currency: it's a symbol of far greater tensions. The Germans want to move further towards integration, political as well as economic: the British remain apprehensive.

Even those who don't get too excited at the prospect of losing the pound feel they are trapped in a process that bit by bit will erode the country's right to self-determination. They fear it will take decision-making powers away from domestic politicians who, for all their faults, we can get at, and give them to remote and barely perceptible Euro-bureaucracies shielded from the electoral process.

Mr Blair clearly regards a lot of this concern as misplaced, hysterical even, bought uncritically from an overwhelmingly Euro-sceptical press. But, whatever its motivation, the political implications are too formidable to ignore. The latest ICM poll, published yesterday in the Guardian, showed 58 per cent of respondents saying they would vote no to the euro if a referendum took place tomorrow. Only 23 per cent - the lowest figure on record - would vote yes. Nineteen per cent - up 5 points since May and 9 points since April - did not know. They are at least are a group to be worked on.

It is nothing new for a British prime minister to set off for a meeting with the principal statesmen of Europe with a heavy heart. The problem used to be that we wanted progress only to have it blocked. Harold Macmillan, his earlier doubts put to rest, wanted to take Britain in, but was crushed by General de Gaulle's veto. De Gaulle thought the British were not good Europeans, not least because of their special ties with the US. He was cast as a villain for that, but his analysis was to some extent justified by Britain's record of lukewarm commitment and resistance to integration in subsequent years.

There has never been in this country the kind of positive belief in the project that flourished in France and Germany. When Edward Heath steered Britain into Europe in the early seventies, he did not risk putting it to a referendum. Harold Wilson won a referendum in 1975 but the issue then was staying in - preserving the status quo - rather than venturing into the bleak unknown. A venture into the unknown is how British electors now see a process, which to many throughout the EU seems simply a question of natural evolution.

This week's speech by French president Jacques Chirac, hammering away at the prospect of a Europe in which leading countries such as France and Germany steamed ahead with integration while others, like Britain, held back, must have increased the pressure on Tony Blair as he made today's visit.

Will Schröder endorse the Chirac approach, or can he be persuaded to judge it ill-timed and intemperate? Can the German chancellor - initially so close to Blair that the German press used to portray him as a kind of Third Way Blairite - be persuaded enough of the prime minister's need for caution to become an ally? Or at least a sympathetic interpreter of what otherwise may be seen across Europe as sheer political cowardice, of a failure to lead in difficult times and circumstances in the way that successful political leaders must always be ready to do?

fields.headline: Zidane finds golden touch
fields.standfirst: Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: The first of the semi-finals ended in acriminious controversy after France beat Portugal in sudden-death extra-time with a penalty from Zinedine Zidane awarded on the say-so of a Slovakian linesman. David Lacey reports.
fields.body:
Euro 2000 lost its rag in the King Baudouin stadium here last night. The first of the semi-finals ended in acriminious controversy after France beat Portugal in sudden-death extra-time with a penalty from Zinedine Zidane awarded on the say-so of a Slovakian linesman.

With the match six minutes away from a penalty shootout Igor Sramka drew the Austrian referee Günter Benko's attention to what he saw as a handball by Abel Xavier, Portugal's Everton right-back, who appeared to drop his left hand to intercept a narrow-angle shot from Sylvain Wiltord by the near post.

Play was delayed by at least three minutes as Portugal, their players and bench, raged at Benkö and Sramka. Luis Figo appeared to have left the scene in disgust, taking off his shirt, but returned seconds before Zidane drove the ball into the roof of the net and France to Rotterdam on Sunday.

The rumpus continued as the players left the pitch. The referee gave Nuno Gomes a red card and Paulo Bento had to be restrained from confronting Sramka. Eusebio, Portugal's most famous footballer, vainly tried to calm everyone down, and in the immediate aftermath Humberto Coelho, Portugal's coach, resigned. A not entirely relevant gesture; Coelho merely said he considered it a good moment to go.

Portugal were entitled to feel unlucky since they had dominated the first half after Nuno Gomes had given them the lead and withstood a strong French recovery once Thierry Henry had brought the scores level early in the second. But their subsequent outburst was disgraceful, whatever the justice of the penalty.

At the same time it was a sad way for any team in this European Championship to die suddenly, least of all the positive, pleasing Portuguese.

For a time last night it really did seem that Figo would upstage Zidane. At the very least Portugal could congratulate themselves on forcing the languid Frenchman to move as quickly as he thinks. Some of Zidane's footwork in the second half was exceptional even by his awesome standards.

Yet France never quite managed to achieve the momentum that had driven them to the last four. Their coach Roger Lemerre left out Youri Djorkaeff to pair Nicolas Anelka and Henry up front and although they eventually conspired to produce a French goal the ploy rarely worked.

Coelho's plan was simple enough: withdraw people behind the ball, use Costinha and Jose Luis Vidigal to close down French ambitions and hope that Figo and Manuel Rui Costa would link up with Nuno Gomes on the break.

Initially Portugal did little more than watch and wait, but in the 18th minute it became clear what they were waiting for. Sergio Conceicao dispossessed a sluggish Deschamps and made a run across the face of the defence before setting up Nuno Gomes for a left-foot shot past Fabien Barthez.

Portugal's football grew in confidence, reacquiring the casual flicks, nudges and backheels that have been their trademarks in Euro 2000. Figo was starting to run the game and France's defenders froze whenever he threatened to run at them. Much of this changed after half-time, mainly because Zidane was playing further forward and within five minutes a touch of pace from Anelka helped level the scores. Looking offside, Anelka beat Vidigal to a pass from Lilian Thuram and switched the ball across to Henry, who shot into the far corner of the net.

After that a semi-final which had lived up to its promise only in patches steadily fragmented. Yet Abel Xavier so nearly won it for Portugal in the 90th minute when he met a free-kick from Figo with a header which Barthez just managed to touch over the bar.

In the end it was Abel Xavier who lost it. What a pity David Trézéguet had not made the contact, from Wiltord's pass, which might have ended the game with a goal that brooked no argument. webTitle: Outrage as US TV news brands Britain violent

fields.headline: Outrage as US TV news brands Britain violent
fields.trailText: A report that Britain is one of the most violent societies in the western world which makes the US look safe in comparison was last night dismissed by tourist chiefs and the Home Office.
fields.body:
A report that Britain is one of the most violent societies in the western world which makes the US look safe in comparison was last night dismissed by tourist chiefs and the Home Office.

CBS News anchorman Dan Rather said in a report: "This summer thousands of Americans will travel to Britain expecting a civilised island free from crime and ugliness.

"And in many ways it is that. But now, like the US, the UK has a crime problem. And believe it or not, except for murder, theirs is worse than ours."

CBS went on to report that the chances of being assaulted, burgled or robbed were substantially greater in Britain than in the US.

The report noted that Britain still had one of the lowest murder rates in Europe but said that gun violence was spreading. CBS correspondent Tom Fenton added: "This year there have already been hundreds of shootings in British cities, dozens in London alone, three of them in one evening."

The report pointed to the violence of British soccer fans, "but that is only the tip of the iceberg. The streets and shopping malls of Britain are a battleground." It said the annual crime statistics out on July 18 were expected to show a 19% rise in violent crime.

The report mentioned the case of an American teacher on a school trip to London who was drugged and raped, and an 86-year-old widow from Cardiff attacked on her doorstep and left with a fractured skull.

But a British Tourist Authority spokesman said the report conveyed a worrying misconception."Britain has always been seen as a civilised, multicultural society with relatively low levels of crime," a spokesman said.

"It is perfectly possible to have a safe and enjoyable vacation here. The main crime against visitors to London is petty theft."

Last year 3.9m US visitors came to Britain and this figure is expected to top 4m this year, making the UK America's favourite European tourist destination.

In 1998 the 2.6m Americans who visited London spent £1.4bn.

The CBS figures came from a 1998 survey for the US Department of Justice, based on figures for 1995, that showed that the rates of murder and rape were much less in England and Wales than in the US, but also showed that the chances of being a victim of robbery, assault, burglary and car theft were higher.

These results confirmed the findings of previous surveys taken throughout the 1990s.

The findings appear dramatic because of the Hollywood myth that US crime rates are the highest in the world. The US is certainly near the top of the international league for murder, shootings and drug-related crime, but faces quite ordinary rates of other types of crime.

The Home Office minister Charles Clarke said the report was ridiculous and underlined a "serious tendency to trivialise an important issue".

He added that the report did not take account of the fact that Britain "has one of the toughest gun controls in the world and America one of the most lax".

The BTA spokesman said: "Yesterday's story on CBS News, which describes the streets and shopping malls of Britain as a 'battleground', is a worrying misconception."

Lee Jasper, special adviser to the mayor of London on policing, said the report was "alarmist and selective in its use of out-of-date facts".

The British crime expert Roger Graef said the American version was wholly exaggerated - although American crime figures have dropped recently, the individual is much more at risk in the US than Britain.

webTitle: Cook denies rift on euro as Blair flies to Germany

fields.headline: Cook denies rift on euro as Blair flies to Germany
fields.trailText: Foreign secretary Robin Cook today brushed aside new reports of a government split on the euro, hours before Tony Blair is expected to express reservations to Germany's chancellor Gerhard Schroeder about an EU fast track led by Paris and Berlin.
fields.body:
Foreign secretary Robin Cook today brushed aside new reports of a government split on the euro, hours before Tony Blair is expected to express reservations to Germany's chancellor Gerhard Schroeder about an EU fast track led by Paris and Berlin.

The prime minister is expected to voice concerns to Mr Schroeder at a dinner in Germany tonight about a speech made earlier this week by French President Jacques Chirac, who spelled out a vision of an inner core of EU members pressing for closer integration.

Mr Cook, a euro enthusiast, was forced on to the defensive after a German newspaper quoted a junior British minister as saying that the UK might enter the euro "faster than we all expect". Mr Cook told BBC radio that trade minister Helen Liddell had categorically denied making such a claim and said her remarks as they appeared in the Berliner Zeitung had been mistranslated.

"She is quite clear she did not use those words," Mr Cook said. Asked whether there was a cabinet split about when Britain would join the single currency, he said: "Politicians always use their own phrases... But there's no difference in the policy. The policy which chancellor Gordon Brown has expressed is shared by myself and others in the cabinet."

The foreign secretary restated government policy, saying: "Early in the lifetime of the next parliament, we will carry out an assessment of the economic conditions. If they are met, we will recommend to the British people in a referendum whether we should join and it will be their decision. In principle, we believe the case for Britain being part of a successful single currency has been made. In practice, the economic conditions have to be right. If they're not right, we won't convince them."

Mr Chirac's proposals envisage a "pioneer group" of states pressing for closer integration - raising the prospect of a two-speed Europe with Britain left in the slow lane. Mr Cook brushed aside suggestions of a French-German conspiracy but acknowledged that it would be damaging if Britain were left behind. Conservative leader William Hague accused Mr Blair of being in a panic over Europe and said the prime minister's private talks with Mr Schroeder showed that he was being "outmanoeuvred by France and Germany".

"The government are in a panic now. The prime minister has lost control of events in Europe rather like he has at home."

webTitle: No 10 rejects talk of early euro entry

fields.headline: No 10 rejects talk of early euro entry
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Downing Street was forced to slap down the industry minister, Helen Liddell, after she was quoted in the German press claiming Britain could join the single European single currency sooner than people expect.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, and John Hooper in Berlin
fields.body:
Downing Street was forced to slap down the industry minister, Helen Liddell, after she was quoted in the German press claiming Britain could join the single European single currency sooner than people expect.

Under the headline "We're making Great Britain fit for the euro", Ms Liddell said the government no longer had any fundamental reservations about the single currency, but needed to convince the British people of its merits. She was also quoted as saying flatly that a referendum would be held in the next parliament. Her remarks were seized on by Conservative Eurosceptics as signs of the government's hidden agenda to smuggle Britain into the single currency.

The row came at an unwelcome time - the day before Tony Blair was due to fly to Germany for talks with chancellor Gerhard Schröder.

webTitle: New age of cloning for health care

fields.headline: New age of cloning for health care
fields.standfirst: The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: Scientists in Edinburgh yesterday announced a dramatic new technique for the precise genetic engineering of large mammals, clearing the way for a wave of patented designer animals to be created to solve human health problems.
fields.body:
Scientists in Edinburgh yesterday announced a dramatic new technique for the precise genetic engineering of large mammals, clearing the way for a wave of patented designer animals to be created to solve human health problems.

The technique, which brings together the cloning and genetics expertise in which Scotland has a world lead, has produced two cloned lambs, Daisy and Cupid, with a human gene locked in their cells - and the cells of any offspring they have.

Human genes have been planted in animal s before, creating what are known as "transgenic animals". But the Edinburgh scientists have for the first time delivered the human gene to a specific point on the sheep chromosome, meaning that they are on the verge of being able to add, subtract and replace genes at will.

Up till now this has been possible only in mice. Now the age is upon us of the bespoke sheep, cow, pig, chimpanzee - even, perhaps, human, although there are practical, as well as ethical and legal, reasons why genetically modified people are still some way off.

A commentary in today's edition of the journal Nature, in which the company responsible for Daisy and Cupid, PPL Therapeutics, publishes its work, says: "We are clearly at the dawn of a new era in mammalian genetic techno logy."

PPL works closely with the Roslin Institute, where Dolly the sheep was cloned in 1997.

Daisy and Cupid were born last year, but PPL delayed full disclosure of its technique, known as gene targeting, in order to secure patent rights.

The fi rm's priority is to use gene targeting to create "knockout" pigs to produce organs for human transplant.

Earlier this year, PPL was the first to produce a litter of cloned pigs. But before the organs of cloned pigs can be used for human transplants, th ey need to have several genes added and at least one "knocked out" to prevent the human metabolism rejecting them as alien.

PPL also plans to use gene targeting to create "immunocows", cows with their own immune systems knocked out and replaced with human immune systems. This would allow the firm to extract gamma globulin, a group of plasma proteins used in the treatment of and immunisation against certain diseases, and which is now obtained from human blood, from cows instead.

All over the world, campus entrepreneurs are racing to create commercially viable transgenic animals: chickens with human proteins in their egg whites, goats with spider's webs in their milk, sheep which shed their fleeces at shearing time.

But they are all using the trad itional, haphazard method of getting alien genes into animals, which is a costly, hit and miss affair.

"In a sense this [new technique] has revolutionised the whole field of biology," said Milind Suraokar, a geneticist at the Baylor College of Medicine in Texas, who contributed to today's Nature commentary. "Now you can actually go and change a certain gene, not just insert it willy-nilly, anywhere in the genome. It's a very sophisticated change."

Mice genes are relatively easy to tinker wi th because scientists know how to isolate and grow mouse stem cells, the embryonic cells from which all other cells in the body grow.

The stem cells of larger mammals, such as sheep, cows and humans, cannot yet be manipulated in this way. But in its ge ne targeting experiment PPL scientists were able to use their cloning expertise to modify the DNA of a cell from an adult animal.

Ron James, chief executive of PPL, said another potential use for gene targeting was in human gene therapy. Human cells co uld be removed from the body, a faulty gene could be corrected or replaced, and the cells returned.

He said the technique could, in theory, be used to clone healthy human offspring from parents with genetic flaws, but pointed out that too many human eg gs would need to be sacrificed to produce a single clone to make it acceptable.

"Gene targeting would provide the technology to do the genetic engineering required," he said.

"The reason it would be illegal and at the moment unethical is because the next step - turning the modified cell into a human - is far, far from efficient, whereas for the sort of work we are doing, you can ethically justify using 10 or 12 animals to produce one.

"I'd rather people didn't keep banging on about cloning humans. There could be perfectly ethical uses of this technology in humans but only at some time in the future when the rest of this technology is effective. The real difficulty is you'd have to do lots of experiments in humans to make the technology work in hu mans."

Like many small biotech companies, PPL is listed on the stock market even though it has consistently lost money. It hopes to find partners ready to take its existing products - sheep-produced human proteins to treat illnesses such as cystic fibrosis - through the final stage of trials.

Pharming milestones

1980: US scientists implant rabbit gene in mouse, which is then able to pass the gene on to offspring

1987: Scientists in US and Scotland make transgenic mice with human and sheep proteins in their milk

1989: John Clark in Edinburgh creates transgenic sheep producing human Factor IX in milk - "pharming" is born

February 1997: Birth of Dolly, the first sheep to be cloned from an adult animal

December 1997: Edinburgh scientists combine cloning and transgenic technology to produce cloned lambs with the human Factor IX gene

July 1999: Edinburgh-based PPL Therapeutics announces the birth of two cloned lambs with a human gene planted in a specific location, but it keeps details secret to protect patent application

March 2000: PPL announces the birth of the first five cloned piglets at a US location

fields.headline: Dutch fans fancy faded France
fields.trailText: Daniel Taylor on why there was a hollow ring to France's semi-final victory after the all-attacking, all-conquering exploits in previous matches.
fields.body:
There were times in last night's semi-final when neutral spectators needed to double-check that it really was France out there, and not just because the world champions had left their traditional navy blue in the dressing room.

Who were these imposters in the all-white? It was certainly not the all-attacking, all-conquering bunch that has spread nauseating feelings of envy across the continent like a contagious green disease.

Perhaps the French are victims of their own success. But even discounting the World Wrestling Federation all-in scenes after Zinedine Zidane's late, late golden goal, there was something distinctly hollow about this victory.

Zidane, however, shall remain exempt from any criticism. It was fitting that the Juventus midfielder drove home the decisive penalty.

When it comes to ZZ, Isaac Newton would do well to rewrite some of his rules. Or at least someone at Uefa should check whether there is superglue on the Frenchman's toecaps. The victory will inevitably be overshadowed by the subsequent hullabaloo, but Zidane has earned the right to be in Rotterdam on Sunday. The final deserves Zidane and he deserves the final.

If only the same could be said of Didier Deschamps. Chelsea's creaking thirtysomething won his 100th cap and there were times, alas, when he played like a centenarian. It was a typical moment of dithering that led to Portugal's goal; instead of clearing the ball he was caught in possession and, one swipe of Nuno Gomes's left boot later, the French captain was wiping a considerable amount of oeuf from his visage.

Elsewhere, Emmanuel Petit was too busy swapping hairdressing tips with Abel Xavier to make any significant contribution, and the biggest impression made by Patrick Vieira was that left by his studs on the back of Luis Figo's calves.

Whereas Vieira had imposed his usual Arsenal-like influence against Spain, this time he was little more than a peripheral figure, shovelled out to the right of midfield. A whinger he may be, a winger he most certainly ain't.

Zidane, on the other hand, could probably play at left-back and get away with it. A flick here, a nutmeg there, it was mesmerising stuff - and that was just the warm-up.

Overall there were too many French players off their game last night. True, their shots-on-target column was superior to Portugal's but Thierry Henry's equaliser was still something of a surprise.

As it was, most of the noise inside the King Baudouin stadium came from the oranje section as the game entered its golden-goal phase. Thousands of Holland fans had crossed the border to check out the opposition. They will have been pleased with what they saw.

webTitle: After months of protests, pleas and passion, Elian returns to Cuba

fields.headline: After months of protests, pleas and passion, Elian returns to Cuba
fields.standfirst: After the protests, Elian returns home
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez, the most famous castaway since Robinson Crusoe, arrived back in Havana with his father early today at the end of a seven-month odyssey which forced the US and Cuba to pay more attention to each other than they had done for decades.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez, the most famous castaway since Robinson Crusoe, arrived back in Havana with his father early today at the end of a seven-month odyssey which forced the US and Cuba to pay more attention to each other than they had done for decades.

At Jose Marti airport to welcome Elian with hugs were relatives including his four grandparents, and hundreds of flag-waving children from his school. Ricardo Alarcon, president of Cuba's national assembly, was also there. "The little absent prince is coming back to his homeland," a state television commentator said as Elian was carried from the plane by his father. A military band struck up the national anthem and children began singing.

Three hours earlier, as the chartered Lear jet readied for takeoff at Washington's Dulles airport, Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, had thanked the American people and the US government for their support in his struggle to reclaim his son.

"Despite all the suffering of my family, this has allowed me to meet very beautiful and intelligent people and I hope that in the future this same friendship _ can happen between both our countries, Cuba and the US," he said. Elian, his father, stepmother and baby half-brother then took off, followed in another commuter jet by a group of classmates and teachers who flew from Cuba nearly three months ago to keep the boy company.

Elian was free to go after the supreme court rejected an emergency request by the boy's Miami relatives seeking to keep him in the US. It also turned down an appeal seeking a political asylum hearing, exhausting a legal process which has cost the US government $2m.

Mr Gonzalez, a tourist industry worker, had told the court that any delay in his son's departure would cause "immense and irreparable harm" to himself and Elian. Their lawyer, Greg Craig, said: "The perpetuation of these circumstances deprives Elian of his childhood and Juan Miguel of his right to raise his family. These losses are irreparable."

The court's action ended bitter legal wrangling between Elian's Miami relatives and the father over the child's fate after the boy was found by two fishermen floating on an inner tube off Florida on Thanksgiving Day last November.

The reaction in Havana to Elian's arrival last night was muted after months of huge rallies. Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, promised months ago that there would be no street celebrations or parades on the family's return.

A government statement urged the population to stay calm. "Now more than ever, our population must behave with the greatest dignity, serenity and discipline," the communique said as Granma, the official daily of the Communist party, welcomed "the triumph of justice and the end of the kidnapping".

Others were more moved. "When he took off, we all had goosebumps," said an Havana airport worker, Gisela Diazo, watching the live televised departure from the US. "We are all crazy for Elian."

But Jorge Sambiente, sitting on a park bench in the capital's Parque Central, said they should have remained in the US because they would have had a better life there. "I'm one of the 50% who wants him to stay," Mr Sambiente said. "The mother wanted him to stay. She died doing that. It was the last wish of the mother."

For the first two weeks after his return, Elian, his family and his classmates are expected to stay in a government villa in Miramar, a suburb of Havana, to allow him to catch up on his school work. He will then go on holiday before returning to his hometown of Cardenas.

In Miami, where there was turmoil on the streets at Easter when he was snatched from the home of his Miami relatives by federal agents and given into his father's care, anti-Castro activists said there would be no trouble this time.

"Everybody's in shock," said Ramon Saul Sanchez, spokesman for the Cuba Democracy Movement. "We have lost a person we love. There are many different reactions, but they are all sadness."

A spokesman for the Miami relatives, Armando Gutierrez, said: "We're devastated. Elian is going back to a country where he will never be free."

But President Bill Clinton said: "We operated an important principle and one that is clearly the law in the US. Do I wish it had unfolded in a less traumatic way? Of course I do."

But, asked if the way was now open to move faster towards normal relations with Cuba, he said: "I don't believe that we can change the law until there's a bipartisan majority [in congress] and some effort on the part of the Cuban government to reach out to us as well."

After his rescue off Florida last year Elian became the world's most politically potent child. His case was described routinely as an international tug-of-war, but in truth Mr Clinton wanted to return him to his family in Cuba almost from the start, and certainly once the immigration service ruled in January that there was no case for him to stay.

Opinion polls showed that most Americans agreed, and immigration lawyers said that had Elian been Mexican, he would have been sent home within hours. But the passions aroused by a six-year-old found clinging to an inner tube in waters where his mother and 10 other refugees had died reignited the anti-Castro faction among Florida's Cuban exiles.

The affair coincided with the first tentative movement towards better relations between the two countries, including the introduction of restricted flights between New York and Havana.

The defiance of the Cuban exiles earlier this year in the face of justice department orders to hand Elian over to his father, provoked a backlash in US public opinion which partly fuelled support for a bill agreed earlier this week in Congress to relax sanctions on the island.

The bill would remove 40 years of sanctions on the sale of food and medicines to Cuba, though the effect of this could be entirely symbolic.

webTitle: The long goodbye of the boy next door

fields.headline: The long goodbye of the boy next door
fields.standfirst:
Elian's return The shipwrecked child who won American hearts has had a big impact on US-Cuban relations
Who's who in the Elian saga
Special report
fields.trailText: The long-running saga of the six-year-old Cuban boy plucked from the Atlantic off the Florida coast last Thanksgiving Day finally reached its conclusion yesterday.
fields.body:
The long-running saga of the six-year-old Cuban boy plucked from the Atlantic off the Florida coast last Thanksgiving Day finally reached its conclusion yesterday.

In the months since Elian Gonzalez was rescued from the sea his fate has provoked huge controversy, a change in US-Cuba relations, a debate on the rights of parents and children, the departures of a police chief and other public officials in Miami, and a flurry of Hollywood film deals.

For Elian Gonzalez, one of the last views of the US will be of the news helicopters hovering over the house in north-west Washington where he lived with his father after being taken from his other relatives in Miami.

He and the four classmates who have joined him in the US from Cuba in the past two months waved at the crews. It has been a long goodbye.

Last week a unanimous ruling by the 12 judges of the federal appeal court in Atlanta opened the last chapter. The supreme court declined to hear further arguments and, in a curt statement, rejected the Miami relatives' request for a further hearing. It was doubtless influenced by submissions by Elian's father's lawyers that prolonging the legal argument would do "irreparable harm".

Juan Miguel Gonzalez

Elian's father, lived in a white stucco house in a working-class area of Cardenas, a town about two hours east of Havana.

A cashier at a Cuban beach resort, he is said to have known Elian's mother, Elisabeth Brotons, since they were teenagers.

The couple divorced and he remarried. He and his current wife, Nersy, have an infant son, Hianny.

Gregory Craig

Juan Miguel Gonzalez's lawyer, served as Bill Clinton's special counsel during his presidential impeachment trial. Since graduating from Yale law school in 1972, Craig has represented a variety of clients. He helped defend John Hinckley after his failed attempt to assassinate Ronald Reagan and has lobbied Washington power brokers on behalf of a wealthy Haitian family which tried to ward off economic sanctions harmful to its business.

The US attorney general, became the No.1 target of Cuban Americans in her home town after the raid to retrieve Elian. When they were acquitted in 1980, black rioters chanting her name burned and looted.

Elian's 50-year-old great-uncle, led the Miami relatives' fight for custody. The crowd that gathered outside of his Little Havana home often chanted his name. Lazaro Gonzalez was unemployed when the custody fight began, but soon got his own spokesman, a legal team and a new job as a mechanic.

webTitle: Havana good time: Elian's emotional return

fields.headline: Havana good time: Elian's emotional return
fields.standfirst: Elian Gonzalez's return to Cuba marks the end of a bizarre odyssey which may have changed Cuban-American relations for ever, write Julian Borger in Havana and Michael Ellison in New York
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez's return to Cuba marks the end of a bizarre odyssey which may have changed Cuban-American relations for ever, write Julian Borger in Havana and Michael Ellison in New York
fields.body:
Seven months after he was found drifting off the Florida coast on a car inner tube, Elian Gonzalez returned to Cuba in a Lear executive jet yesterday, marking the end of a bizarre odyssey which may have changed Cuban-American relations for ever.

The most famous castaway since Robinson Crusoe was carried down the steps of the plane to the Havana airport tarmac by his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, and was immediately enveloped by his grandmothers.

The Cuban government had heralded the occasion as a quiet family affair, but it bussed in 800 of Elian's fellow schoolchildren who chanted: "Elian! Elian! Elian!" and sang the national anthem with the backing of a military band. Elian smiled the shy smile which has made him a media icon around the world. The Elian saga, which began on November 22 last year when his mother took him along with her on a small unseaworthy boat bound for Florida with a dozen other would be migrants. When the boat sank only Elian and two others survived. He was quickly adopted by the family's relatives in Miami and with the backing of powerful Cuban exile organisations quickly turned into a symbol of Fidel Castro's repression.

Seven months on, the anti-Castro movement is in disarray, having staked all its authority on keeping Elian in the US and having lost decisively in the courts. The final blow came yesterday with a Supreme Court decision not to hear the case, effectively siding with Juan Miguel and the US government, who argued that only Elian's father could speak on his behalf.

In Cuba, Fidel Castro has been strengthened. Elian has been a rallying call for a population tired of the privations of isolation and central planning. An announcer on state television declared that Elian's teachers would now "undertake the masterful work of making him a model child". Elian and the schoolmates who have been keeping him company in Washington left the airport for a seaside government villa in the suburbs of Havana, where they are due to spend a couple of weeks catching up on schoolwork before returning to his home town, Cardenas.

Back in the US, the backlash against Cuban-American militancy has already contributed this week to an agreement in Congress to lift the 40-year-old food and medicine embargo on Cuba, a move which would have been unthinkable only a year ago.

The measure, which is expected to be passed in the next few days or weeks, is hedged with restrictions. Cuba must pay for imports from the US with cash, and will not be eligible for US trade credits. Nevertheless, it represents a symbolic death knell for the sanctions regime, which has been under intense attack from US farmers and businessmen eager to gain a foothold in a potential market.

Another victim of Elian's turbulent stay has been Al Gore's presidential campaign. The vice president vacillated over what should be done with the shipwrecked boy, and ultimately broke with the Clinton administration, which had ruled that Elian should be returned to his father. Mr Gore hoped to show he was his own man, and gain a few Cuban votes in Florida and New Jersey at the same time. The polls suggest he did neither, but reinforced perceptions of him as a cynical politician without fixed principles. Some pundits are even predicting that Elian's rescue from the high seas on Thanksgiving Day may yet to prove the turning point in Mr Gore's attempt to win the White House.

webTitle: Retreat as ministers tell new town hall committees to meet in public

fields.headline: Retreat as ministers tell new town hall committees to meet in public
fields.trailText: Ministers last night bowed to pressure from MPs and freedom of information campaigners by agreeing that new town hall executive committees must make key decisions in public.
fields.body:
Ministers last night bowed to pressure from MPs and freedom of information campaigners by agreeing that new town hall executive committees must make key decisions in public.

A late amendment to the local government bill paving the way for elected mayors in cities outside London will specify that so-called "cabinet meetings" must not be held behind closed doors. The move marks a climbdown for local government minister Hilary Armstrong, who was booed at Bournemouth earlier this week.

A government spokesman said some councils which had already adopted a cabinet style were not operating "in the spirit of openness which we had been hoping for".

Labour MPs last week met Ms Armstrong to express their concern. Local papers, backed by the Society of Editors and the National Union of Journalists, argued that the scrapping of old-style committees, where press and public were admitted, marked a backward step and threatened local democracy..

fields.headline: Orchestream defies doubters
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British software developer Orchestream Holdings yesterday defied negative investor sentiment towards internet companies by showing a 74% price jump on its stock market debut.
fields.body:
British software developer Orchestream Holdings yesterday defied negative investor sentiment towards internet companies by showing a 74% price jump on its stock market debut.

The stock reached a high of 322p shortly after listing, capitalising the group at £372m. Shares in Orchestream ended at 313.5p, compared with its issue price of 185p.

The surge in share price reflected strong demand for the stock, which saw its public offer nine times oversubscribed. The success of Orchestream ranks alongside that of fibre-optics maker Bookham Technology, which listed in April.

Both stocks have proved that wary investors are more willing to a pay a high price for shares in "infrastructure" style stocks that support the internet, telecommunications and personal computer markets rather than investing in e-commerce companies.

Orchestream has developed a piece of software that is designed to ensure the reliable transmission of data along computer companies' networks and the internet, using the basic internet protocol (IP) technology that allows computers to communicate with each other over the net.

Orchestream's software also allows the prioritising of data over the internet. The explosion in traffic has meant that IP transmissions have become errati c and slow, giving the software an edge over rivals.

Orchestream raised £49m through the issue of shares to institutions, which will own 37% of the company. Those funds will be used to expand the company's research and development and sales and marketing teams. Acquisitions and strategic alliances might also be considered.

Ashley Ward, Orchestream's chief executive, said: "It's important that we begin to widen the gap between us and any competitor that might emerge in this market."

He believes Orchestream has a 12-month lead on its competitors.

The competitive threat to Orchestream is expected to emerge from industry heavyweights such as Cisco, Lucent and Nortel. They are expected to develop their own software and could then use their marketing muscle to ease the likes of Orchestream to one side. Mr Ward said he was "pleasantly surprised" at the company's strong listing.

Orchestream had incurred a loss of £2.6m at April 30, on revenues of £411,000.

Analysts expect its losses to leap to £10m on sales of £2.7m this year and turn to profit in 2002.

The remainder of the company's share register will be split between management, owning 21% of the stock, chip maker Intel and Reuters holding 6%, and venture capital firms such as Atlas, Quester and Celtic House.

webTitle: This is a war of all worlds

fields.headline: This is a war of all worlds
fields.standfirst:
Fuss about the human genome just hides the brutality of global capitalism
The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: Nearly everyone debating the mapping of the human genome now agrees on one thing: that the identification of our genes invokes an unprecedented danger, as it might assist a handful of companies to seize something which belongs to all of us. I wish this were true.
fields.body:
Nearly everyone debating the mapping of the human genome now agrees on one thing: that the identification of our genes invokes an unprecedented danger, as it might assist a handful of companies to seize something which belongs to all of us. I wish this were true.

Terrifying as the impending capture of the essence of humanity is, it is far from unprecedented. The attempt to grab the genome is just one of many symptoms of a far graver disease. We are entering an age of totalitarian capitalism, a political and economic system which, by seizing absolute control of fundamental resources, destitutes everyone it excludes.

On Saturday I met a campaigner from Kerala, in southern India, who told me that, to the tribal people he works with, the ownership of land is as inconceivable as the ownership of air would be in the northern hemisphere. I told him the bad news. In several American cities, blocks of air, which (once legally transferred to a suitable site) allow their owners to build skyscrapers, change hands for tens of millions of dollars. There have been a number of legal disputes over the ownership of clouds, as firms battle for the right to make them drop their rain where they want it. Companies are now claiming they own asteroids and landing spaces on the moon.

None of these presumptions is any more absurd than the claim to possess exclusive control over part of our own planet. But, as property rights proliferate, almost everything which once belonged to all of us is being seized.

In Britain, for example, despite repeated pledges by the government, playing-fields and allotments are disappearing faster than ever before. Public squares are being turned into private shopping malls. Traditional stopping sites for travellers, some of which survived for five millennia, have nearly all disappeared during the past 15 years.

Knowledge is rapidly becoming the exclusive preserve of those who can afford to buy it. Intellectual property companies are monopolising image banks and picture archives, while academic publishers, concentrated in ever fewer hands, are able to charge outrageous prices for access to the work they publish. Companies are asserting ownership in perpetuity of the material in their electronic databases. A firm called West Publishing has tried to insist that it owned the entire archive of US federal law.

The biotech companies have been empowered to seize the human genome by the very people - Tony Blair and Bill Clinton - who are now begging them not to do so. Blair's government helped drive through the European directive on the legal protection of biotechnological inventions, which enables private companies to claim not only human genes, but also plant and animal varieties and even human body parts.

Every asset, once secured by the new totalitarian regime, is surrounded by a Berlin wall equipped with border guards. There are ranches in the United States in which you would be shot on sight if you tried to take a walk. Disproportionate responses to the feeblest threats are assisted by the private prison and security industries now seizing control of another fundamental asset: human freedom. We cross the economic frontiers at our peril.

The worst global inequality in history is a direct result of this totalitarian capitalism. Two hundred people now own as much wealth as half the world's population, for the simple reason that they have been empowered to steal it from the rest of us.

This empowerment emerges from an unwholesome union of neoliberal economics and feudal law. Our legal framework, which pre-dates democracy, protects property above individuals and individuals above society. We can't expect our governments to address this inversion of democratic priorities. The three men who could begin to reform our legal system - the home secretary, the lord chancellor and the prime minister - are all lawyers, and all wedded (literally in the prime minister's case) to the profession which benefits from its iniquities. Property-based law favours the interests of the rich, which, in turn, favours the interests of its practitioners.

The walls rising around us are beginning to look impregnable. But before we can decide how they might best be demolished, we must first recognise that the enclosure of the human genome is just a single cell in the privatised global prison the new regime has built.

webTitle: Oracle admits trying to dig up dirt on Microsoft

fields.headline: Oracle admits trying to dig up dirt on Microsoft
fields.standfirst:
Gates rival admits hiring private detectives
E-finance: special report
The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Oracle, the world's second largest software company, has admitted that it hired private detectives to dig up scandalous information on Microsoft, its biggest and most bitter rival.
fields.body:
Oracle, the world's second largest software company, has admitted that it hired private detectives to dig up scandalous information on Microsoft, its biggest and most bitter rival.

The investigation came to light when the detective firm, Investigative Group International, offered to buy rubbish being thrown out by a pro-Microsoft trade organisation.

In a statement late on Tuesday night, Oracle admitted hiring IGI, a firm headed by a former Watergate investigator, to make inquiries about two advocacy groups which publicly supported Microsoft in its fight against the US government's anti-monopoly lawsuit.

"Oracle discovered that both the Independent Institute and the National Taxpayers' Union were misrepresenting themselves as independent advocacy groups when in fact their work was funded by Microsoft for the express purpose of influencing public opinion in favour of Microsoft during its anti-trust trial," Oracle said.

"Left undisclosed, these Microsoft front groups could have improperly influenced the outcome of one of the most important anti-trust cases in US history."

Oracle said it retained the detective firm in June 1999 to investigate the Independent In stitute, a free-market policy body that placed full-page advertisements in the Washington Post and the New York Times defending Microsoft. The advertisements portrayed 240 academic figures as giving independent views.

In September, the New York Times reported that the Independent Institute's ad was paid for by Microsoft. The Times said the documents had been provided by a Microsoft adversary associated with the computer industry who refused to be further identified. A spokeswoman for the newspaper said it was policy not to disclose the names of confidential sources.

Oracle added that "Microsoft also funded the Association for Competitive Technology" without specifically admitting that it had paid IGI to investigate this Washington-based group.

IGI tried to pay two janitors $1,200 (£800) for the rubbish thrown out by the association, which also published pro-Microsoft statements during the trial.

Oracle said it insisted that any IGI investigation should employ legal tactics and was assured that was obeyed. Microsoft, which is appealing against a court decision that it should be broken up, jumped on the statement as proof that the government's case is underpinned by the firm's rivals.

This is the latest example of a long-running and often bitter feud between Oracle, which is headed by the flamboyant Larry Ellison, and Microsoft, founded by the cerebral Bill Gates.

A turnround in Oracle's fortunes this year, after it was quicker than Microsoft to realise the potential of the internet, meant Mr Ellison came close to usurping Bill Gates' position as the world's richest man this year.

In the past year, Mr Gates has watched his wealth shrink from $100bn to about $60bn, while Mr Ellison has increased his net worth from $9.5bn to $47bn.

webTitle: Martian attack implodes on new defensive shield

fields.headline: Martian attack implodes on new defensive shield
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: There's a parlour game played by Tories which you win by guessing members of the shadow cabinet. Everyone gets Michael Portillo, so that's just one point. No one has heard of Gary Streeter (international aid), so he scores a potentially game-winning 25.
fields.body:
There's a parlour game played by Tories which you win by guessing members of the shadow cabinet. Everyone gets Michael Portillo, so that's just one point. No one has heard of Gary Streeter (international aid), so he scores a potentially game-winning 25.

Or take Angela Browning, known to a tiny minority as shadow minister for trade. Name her for 15 bonus points, plus six plastic drink mats with vintage car motifs.

Anyhow, I learn that at a recent shadow cabinet meeting, Mrs Browning said - as soon as they'd worked out that she wasn't there to serve the coffee - that all her colleagues should read the American psycho-babble book Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus.

This is true. I like to think though that there would have been a stunned silence when she made this recommendation. "But Adela, I mean Annabel - don't you know that our leader doesn't really need this book, um, er, Anneka - because he comes from Mars?"

And so he does. The point about Martians is that they are very, very clever. Henry Kissinger is a Martian. So is Peter Jay. Martians are much better than us at everything, but because they don't fully understand our earth ways, they have to go to Martian school to be taught how to pass for us.

That's how William Hague was able to make that brilliant Tory conference speech at the age of 16. That's why he can knock out a top athlete like Sebastian Coe with one accidental blow of his arm. But he does need to be told how earth people think. So he has focus groups.

The Tory focus groups have just come up with the news that people are getting worried about the price of petrol. It's now possible to pay 90.9p a litre (though this is not a problem for Martians, since their mother ship got here by extracting the nuclear energy from a bottle of Beck's).

"The government has abandoned the fuel escalator and got into a lift!" Mr Hague said at prime minister's questions yesterday, a joke which must hail from the Martian school of scriptwriting (which also supplies jokes for Supermarket Sweep.)

Next he tried to imply that only the most deserving members of society ever bought petrol. "People who have saved up for their car", he said, a catch in his throat, (as opposed to the rest of us, who pay cash with cases full of cocaine-stained fifties), "people who need their cars in rural areas, and people who are old and disabled... "

The problem was that the Martian spin doctors hadn't been able to warn him about the unnerving new Tony Blair approach - honesty.

In the past the prime minister would never have admitted that petrol prices had gone up, or if they had, that he had anything to do with it. He'd insist that under Labour, motorists had been paid to come and take the petrol away.

This time he admitted it. "It is correct", he said, "petrol prices have gone up. And of course it's difficult for people in rural areas and for people who drive long distances."

Mr Blair admits that not everything is perfect in the New Britain! Loyalist MPs stirred uneasily. Lickspittles, poised to claim that under Labour a Volvo could go 250 miles on a pint of extra-virgin olive oil, mentally tore up their notes.

Radio signals take whole minutes to arrive from the Red Planet, so Mr Hague was left waffling about the government "banning musical chairs, getting the royal family to move house and counting up fat people on TV".

By next week the Martians will have worked out how to respond to the new Blair confessional strategy ("Yes, yes, I admit, we got it all wrong - wrong, I tell you... ") and we shall hear the results.

fields.headline: Would I be eliminated?
fields.standfirst:
Leah Wild, whose IVF embryos are being screened for a genetic condition, on the real consequences of unravelling the human genome

The ethics of genetics: special report
fields.trailText: Leah Wild, whose IVF embryos are being screened for a genetic condition, on the real consequences of unravelling the human genome
fields.body:
I am hoping to have a designer baby. Any offspring of mine will not be God's gift: I fully intend to exploit the latest medical advances to ensure my child is as perfect as possible. This involves selecting some embryos and eliminating others. He or she will be chosen according to how good their genes are.

This week's announcement of the near-complete sequencing of the human genome will undoubtedly make this selection procedure easier and more widely available. For, despite Bill Clinton's claim that "our children's children will know the term cancer only as a constellation of stars", human genetic engineering is not, in the short term at least, about preventing and curing disease. It's about whom we want to be born. This is a decision some parents have had to make already. It will increasingly be a decision that other people are going to make about us.

I am, in the new language we will quickly develop, "genetically disadvantaged". There is nothing overtly wrong with me, as is the case with most of those who carry a genetic condition. My only difficulty is when I try to reproduce.

I have a condition called a balanced translocation: two fragments have broken off from two of my chromosomes and swapped places, balancing each other out. This has no implications for my health. But a child could inherit these chromosomes in an unbalanced form, resulting in such a major disability that miscarriage is likely. Occasionally, a pregnancy may go to full term and a baby be born with severe, probably fatal, physical and mental difficulties.

There is no cure for chromosomal translocations and, despite the Human Genome Project, no prospect of a cure. But where genetic advances can help is by sorting good embryos from bad. By undergoing IVF treatment, tests can be made on the eight-cell embryos to determine if they have a chromosomal translocation. This process is called preimplantantion genetic diagnosis (PGD). Very few babies have been born through PGD, less than 20 in the UK. Just a handful of "live births" have resulted from PGD for chromosomal translocations. This is the reality of creating a designer baby.

At the assisted conception unit I attend, there are couples who carry, among other inherited disorders, spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) and cystic fibrosis genes. The emphasis and implication for diseases such as these is not - as we have been led to believe in the furore surrounding the Human Genome Project - on the search for a cure, on somehow replacing good genes with bad (though no one knows quite how yet). The emphasis here is to eliminate those who are affected, to make it so there are simply no people with SMA or cystic fibrosis; any embryos carrying these conditions are killed at just a few cells old. I use the word killed deliberately. We shouldn't flinch from it. This is also precisely what I intend to do - kill embryos I don't want to be born. Embryos are fledgling human beings. It is genomicide.

This is not destruction by mere whim. My choices, as those of the other "genetically disadvantaged", are not the same as the vast majority of the reproductive population. I either make this genetic selection, or risk further multiple miscarriages and accept infertility. I would prefer not to have to. No one in her right mind would opt for the procedure of PGD instead of what is quaintly called "the old fashioned method".

There are strict limits placed upon the genetic selection procedure. Each new PGD test must be licensed by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA). It forbids tests for "social or psychological characteristics" or "normal physical variations", such as sex or long legs.

Only those conditions associated with disability or serious medical conditions are permitted. But there are other considerations which those undertaking and licensing tests take into account. While my eight-cell embryos are in the dishes being assessed for chromosomal translocation, they cannot also be tested for Down's syndrome. Not one of the centres currently offering PGD in Britain has yet dared to apply to the HFEA for permission to carry out such a test. The elimination of Down's syndrome - unlike chromosomal translocation - has political implications. The issues here are complex, and there are lobby groups and disability movements to deal with. Elsewhere in Europe, such a Down's test for PGD patients would be commonplace.

It would make sense, and be perfectly possible, for the tests for both disorders to be done together. But ironically, while there is no licence for my hours-old embryos to be tested for Down's, if I proceed to pregnancy, testing is highly recommended. Due to my age (40) the medical advice will be to have diagnostic tests for Down's, either chorionic villus sampling (CVS) at 12 weeks into a pregnancy or amniocentesis at 18. Even more ironically in my case, both these tests carry a risk of miscarriage.

But it's not only nonsensical to prevent testing at the test tube stage, it's absurd. Imagine if an embryo which had been picked out to be re-implanted in me proved 12 weeks later to have Down's. After two months of IVF treatment, involving huge personal effort and medical commitment, to have striven to create a life, I would almost certainly be advised to destroy it.

I do not believe that having a child with Down's is a tragedy. The profound decisions women must make about continuing pregnancies with a risk of Down's are made in a climate heavily weighted in favour of termination. But I also believe that every woman should have the right to be tested how and when she wants. The practical, if unintentional, result of political pressures on testing is a system that condones late termination - abortion by any other name - yet precludes the relatively painless, and far less morally culpable, early prevention of a life.

So in this brave new world of human genome sequencing, what should we test for, when and why? And why should we stop at weeding out those who are going to have manifest symptoms? It is one small scientific step from eliminating the affected to eliminating the carrier. If I didn't have a genetic condition that could be passed on, there would be no problem. Why not nip the chromosomal translocation in the bud? Why restrict testing to those who will be catastrophically affected by a chromosome disorder? Why not extend it to those like me who simply pass on such catastrophes? Why shouldn't I be eliminated?

From where I'm lying - feet up in stirrups - this is not an abstract philosophical debate. Nor is it merely a matter of enabling people to benefit from medical advances. As with the choices being made about testing for Down's syndrome, these are not medical but political matters. It is up to us, with the knowledge given to us by the scientists, to decide.

We must begin to vigorously debate the limits of acceptable genomicide. To pretend that the human genome is all about saving, rather than destroying, lives is to be blind to the brutal truth about our very human, flawed condition.

webTitle: Seven held after raid by police in lorry deaths inquiry

fields.headline: Seven held after raid by police in lorry deaths inquiry
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Seven Dutch nationals will appear in court in Rotterdam tomorrow charged with the manslaughter of 58 Chinese nationals found dead in a lorry at Dover last week.
fields.body:
Seven Dutch nationals will appear in court in Rotterdam tomorrow charged with the manslaughter of 58 Chinese nationals found dead in a lorry at Dover last week.

The men were arrested following a raid on a harbour-side warehouse in Rotterdam thought to have been used as a meeting point for the group of Chinese.

An international arrest warrant was issued for another man wanted in connection with the incident.

Sixty Chinese nationals boarded the lorry, registered to a Dutch firm, in Rotterdam before being driven to Zeebrugge in Belgium, where they took a ferry to Dover. Customs officers discovered the bodies and two survivors during a routine search.

An inquest last week heard that they had suffocated, and that an air vent that might have saved their lives had been closed prior to the ferry crossing.

Menngs Garretsen, a spokesman for the Dutch illegal human trafficking unit, said: "All seven suspects will be charged with manslaughter and people smuggling on Friday. We arrested them at certain times between last Thursday and yesterday afternoon."

The men, one of whom, is a 24-year-old owner of a transport company, are from Rotterdam, Vlaardingen and two are from Capelle ann de I'Ussel.

Perry Wacker, 32, the lorry driver, was charged with 58 counts of manslaughter by Kent police last Friday.

Two other people, both of Chinese origin, were also charged with conspiracy to smuggle illegal immigrants. You Yi, 38, a chef and 29-year-old female interpreter Ying Guo, both from South Woodford, east London, were remanded in custody. The three charged in the UK are due to reappear at Folkestone magistrates on Friday.

Dutch detectives believe the Chinese group were brought to the warehouse at Waalhaven Zuidzijde in delivery vans.

Matching traces of unspecified materials were found in the warehouse and the lorry that brought the 60 people to the UK.

A spokesman for the Dutch authorities said yesterday's arrests represented "remarkable progress" in the inquiry.

"The Dutch police have managed to get a pretty clear picture of the organisation and of the individuals that have been organising the transport as well as the manner in which the suspects may have been involved," he said.

"In broad terms it appears that the organisation has rented a warehouse especially for the purpose of the smuggling operation and has a transport company registered in the name of a front man.

"After that an articulated truck and container have been purchased. It seems likely that the Chinese group has been brought to the Waalhaven warehouse on Sunday June 18 and has been transferred into the truck. Then the truck was driven to Zeebrugge and has been shipped to Dover."

Dutch police are already holding two men in connection with the incident, including Arie van der Spek, in whose name the lorry that carried the Chinese to their deaths was registered. The second man, who was not identified, was released yesterday.

Kent police said they had been working closely with the Dutch authorities, and that five police officers from the Fujian province in China, where the dead are thought to have originated, are due to arrive this week to help with the inquiry.

A police spokeswoman added that they were close to discovering the identities of 29 of the victims, but that none of the dead had been officially identified.

Archers veteran Joe Grundy has been named beer drinker of the year by a group of MPs.The real ale-swilling stalwart, voiced by actor Ted Kelsey in the 50-year-old radio series, is a Methodist by religion but is notorious in the soa p for his refusal to observe the church's traditional views on temperance. Reacting to the all party parliamentary beer group's award Kelsey said on behalf of his alter ego: "It's a great honour to be chosen and it's the pinnacle of Joe's beer drinking life."

Bad night

Peter Kilfoyle. The Liverpool Walton MP was spending a night patrolling with police seeing how new community initiatives were working.On returning to his office he found burglars had stolen office equipment and computers - although happily not from the Labour MP's own constituency office. He said: "This illustrates just what the police on Merseyside are up against."

Today

Commons: Agriculture questions. Tory-initiated debate on priorities in the NHS. Lords: Trustee bill, third reading. Postal services bill, report. R

webTitle: Druid takes the shine off FI

fields.headline: Druid takes the shine off FI
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: FI Group, the software and computer services group, yesterday unveiled a strong rise in underlying profits over the past year and claimed that the computing business is finally recovering from its Y2K woes.
fields.body:
FI Group, the software and computer services group, yesterday unveiled a strong rise in underlying profits over the past year and claimed that the computing business is finally recovering from its Y2K woes.

The company said that its short term priority was to restore Druid Group - the rival consultancy it bought for £763m in March - to acceptable profitability by the second half of the current year.

Hilary Cropper, the chairman, indicated that FI was disappointed with the performance of Druid in the seven weeks since the takeover was completed. She blamed tough market conditions following the Y2K debacle and uncertainty among clients over internet-related investment.

Ms Cropper said that because clients needed to make substantial changes to their systems for e-business, they were looking at their entire systems "rather than rushing ahead with implementation" on a piecemeal basis. But "current client wins by Druid are encouraging," Ms Cropper said.

Despite the problems with Druid - and having watched its share price underperform the FTSE software index by almost a third in the year to date - FI announced a pre-tax profit increase of 59% to £27m for the year to April 30, before an amortisation charge of almost £10m for Druid.

Looking ahead, Ms Cropper spoke of "positive forward momentum," pointing in particular to a significant growth in large outsourcing contracts over recent months. She also made it clear that further international expansion is a real possibility in the next 12 months, with Germany and the Benelux countries identified as target areas for the next acquisition.

The group reported annual turnover up 35% from £228m to £308m.

Earnings per share fell to 3.91p from 5.80p but the final dividend is being increased to 2.7p. The shares nevertheless slipped 10p to 445p.

webTitle: Bank of Scotland calls in IBM

fields.headline: Bank of Scotland calls in IBM
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland is today expected to announce an agreement with IBM to outsource all its IT systems. The aim of the scheme is to save the bank millions of pounds a year.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland is today expected to announce an agreement with IBM to outsource all its IT systems. The aim of the scheme is to save the bank millions of pounds a year.

Under the terms of the alliance, the bank's technology staff are expected to be transferred to IBM's payroll. It will be the first deal of its kind for a leading British bank.

Bank of Scotland refused to comment last night, but has said in the past that it would look for ways to keep costs under control through outsourcing.

The arrangement is expected to give the bank scope to embark on a new strategy after failing to convince the market that it had potential for further growth after its failure to win control of NatWest.

Among projects with which the Edinburgh-based bank has been connected are a new joint venture with Easyjet, which is said to want to set up an Easymoney website to add to a stable of products including car hire and internet cafes.

But the bank will be cautious about new joint ventures after being forced to abandon plans for a project with the American evangelist, Pat Robertson, when he made disparaging remarks about the Scots.

The outsourcing arrangement was described last night as "huge" by banking sources. IBM is already working on an internet project for the rival HSBC.

"It allows Bank of Scotland to get on with banking and IBM to get on with the computing," was how one industry source described the deal.

Arrangements of this kind are increasingly common in both public and private sector, but have not, until now, been used in British banking.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Little Richard, singer
fields.trailText: Little Richard, singer
fields.body:
Right now we're at the start of five nights of appearing at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas. I love it here because the crowd is very big and all the stars come to see me play, which is very flattering. I meet up with my old friends like James Brown, Ike Turner, Ray Charles, Chuck Berry, Bette Midler and Barbra Streisand. I've never gambled in my life, but I love Las Vegas and especially the hotels - nowhere else has ones quite like them.

My suite is beautiful - it's like a palace, a dreamboat or a pretty house with huge Roman posts and ornate fittings. I'm coming to perform live in England in July, and it's unbelievable how the audiences there are so lively - even more so than the Las Vegas crowd, they go all out for an artist they love. And audiences sparing nothing you don't see all the time.

I'm not recording anything new at the moment, and though I'd love to find another acting part like in Down And Out In Beverly Hills, nothing has come along that I've really liked. I think the part would have to be more like my real self. I'm still the architect of rock 'n' roll, which I'll always be, but I'm 68 this year and I've started to see things in a different light. I used to rush to do everything and now I take life more seriously. I've seen friends that are gone who I thought would never go, and know now that I'm not invincible and life is a vapour and you don't know when life ends - so I cherish each day.

I'll carry on performing for as long as God will allow. I still sing in the same keys, so God has been very good and very merciful. I tell the audience every night when I'm on stage what my age is because I'm just glad that I've lived to that age and thankful to be here.

 Little Richard will be appearing alongside Chuck Berry and Jerry Lewis at The Legends Of Rock And Roll concert at the London Arena on July 11.
