webTitle: A wristful of dollars settles court dispute over Tyson jewellery

fields.headline: A wristful of dollars settles court dispute over Tyson jewellery
fields.standfirst: Boxing: special report>
fields.trailText: His recent antics in and out of the ring may have cost boxing dear, but Mike Tyson has paid his dues for a wristful of diamond jewellery bought on a shopping spree in London. Or rather somebody did.
fields.body:
His recent antics in and out of the ring may have cost boxing dear, but Mike Tyson has paid his dues for a wristful of diamond jewellery bought on a shopping spree in London. Or rather somebody did.

Graff Diamonds told the high court in London yesterday that the matter had been settled "amicably" and that the full £426,000 bill for a diamond watch, bracelet and two pocket watches would be met in full by July 7.

The case of the unpaid baubles was one of the key controversies surrounding Tyson's recent trip to Britain when he defeated Lou Savarese in 38 seconds at Hampden Park in Glasgow.

He is alleged to have assaulted his promoter, Frank Warren, when he discovered that Mr Warren had not paid for the jewels, which he acquired during his last trip in January.

But last night it was not clear who had picked up the tab. A spokesman for Mr Warren said the promoter was on his way to America and could not be contacted. Mr Warren, who sported a badly bloodshot eye at the Glasgow fight, has already said he will not promote Tyson in future.

In court yesterday, a lawyer representing Graff Diamonds told Mr Justice Eady that the matter had been settled and the full price of the jewels would be paid next week. However, a separate action involving two other watches from the St Albans jewellers David Gillow, valued at a total of £185,000, is to continue.

The judge heard that Mr Warren, Tyson and an entourage of six minders arrived at the shop in New Bond Street, London, on January 20 and the boxer asked managing director Laurence Graff to "show me something". From a tray of watches, Tyson selected a diamond watch with a sapphire dial for which he agreed to pay $200,000.

The boxer then agreed to pay $250,000 for an emerald and diamond bracelet if it was altered to fit his wrist. When asked who was going to pay, Tyson said Warren would deal with it and the promoter agreed, according to papers before the court. Tyson then left the shop and showed off his new watch to the media and public ou tside.

Five days later the party returned to the shop with Tyson's sister, looking for presents for his children. He could not agree a price for two pocket watches, but later telephoned the jewellers offering $180,000, which was accepted. When Mr Warren rang the shop asking to collect the pocket watches, he agreed to pay the total $630,000 (£426,000) bill, the judge was told.

Graff Diamonds took the pair to court after unsuccessfully asking for payment for more than five months.

The second claim involved two watches lent to Mr Warren by David Gillow, the St Albans jeweller, to show Tyson during the same visit to Britain.

The judge was told that the watches were now being held by a neutral party as security, together with £100,000 from Tyson, who "hotly contested" the claim.

Andy Kerman, solicitor for Graff Diamonds, said after the hearing: "Laurence Graff is delighted the matter has been resolved. He will be even more delighted when he gets his money."

webTitle: Row between BSkyB and ITV hots up

fields.headline: Row between BSkyB and ITV hots up
fields.trailText: The row between BSkyB and ITV over the network's refusal to offer its channels to the satellite broadcaster's digital service intensified last night when it was claimed that viewing of ITV in Sky homes is falling to new lows.
fields.body:
The row between BSkyB and ITV over the network's refusal to offer its channels to the satellite broadcaster's digital service intensified last night when it was claimed that viewing of ITV in Sky homes is falling to new lows.

According to figures from audience researcher Barb, ITV's total viewing share in Sky Digital homes has slipped from 20.6% in March to 19.3% in June. The June figure was however a slight increase on the previous month.

BSkyB forecast that the network's share of the peak-time national audience would fall to 37% by year end - 1.5% below the target presented to advertisers at the beginning of the year - because of its absence from Sky's digital service.

ITV has so far resisted calls from BSkyB to take up a place on the satellite platform, arguing that the 27 different regions that the commercial terrestial network delivers programming to would make the cost of transmission too high.

The two sides have been at loggerheads for the past year.

A BSkyB spokesman said the viewing figures illustrated the "irrationality" of ITV staying off the satellite platform. "How much more financial pain must ITV bear to try to generate an artificial advantage for Ondigital, its terrestrial pay TV service? And how long before advertisers start getting restless and ask difficult questions?" he added.

ITV and ITV2 can both be received by ONdigital, the platform owned by Granada and Carlton Communications.

"In terrestrial-only homes ITV are ahead of the peak-time target at 41% but well behind in 'Sky Digital homes' at 28.6%," the BSkyB spokesman added. "Based on this level of performance and the growth in digital penetration to 5m homes by the end of the year we forecast a figure of 37% by the year end."

An ITV spokeswoman described Sky's figures as "disingenuous" and said of all the free-to-air channels, ITV had lost the least number of viewers in Sky Digital homes.

"Everyone looses share in multi-channel homes because there is more choice. It's not because we are not on the platform," she said.

fields.headline: Anger over Livingstone's Nazi jibe
fields.standfirst: Livingstone's London: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone was condemned by ministers and local government leaders yesterday when he likened government control over town halls to Nazi centralism under Hitler.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone was condemned by ministers and local government leaders yesterday when he likened government control over town halls to Nazi centralism under Hitler.

Barely two months into his job as London's mayor, the former GLC leader provoked a storm of protest by suggesting that the Vichy regime in France enjoyed as much freedom as councils under New Labour.

Clearly showing frustration at Whitehall's tight control over the new Greater London Authority, the Brent East MP also accused ministers of allowing the Treasury to be run by aliens "whose objective is the destruction of all life on the planet and they're just starting with local government." He added: "I have never known any local authority to achieve the levels of incompetence and mismanagement as I have seen in central government."

Accusing most ministers of being woefully ignorant of town hall life, Mr Livingstone suggested he would find it difficult to meet Londoners' expectations because of Whitehall constraints. He said the capital's mayor would be unable to change much without more cash.

Interviewed by a local government association newspaper yesterday, before addressing the organisation's annual conference in Bournemouth, Mr Livingstone drew loud applause from delegates when he said councils were over-controlled from the centre.

But some reacted with horror when he added in the newspaper: "From the end of the 1980s ... local government has had no more independence in Britain than the Vichy regime in France under the Nazis. So you just do your best to try and protect your local people as best you can. It has been 20 years of unremitting decline of local government and it's ... Treasury led. The Treasury has always had a contempt of democratically-elected people in parliament, let alone local government."

Later Mr Livingstone said his Nazi comparison was simply a "smidgeon of humour."

But speaking to delegates earlier the home secretary, Jack Straw, said the mayor's verbal onslaught could not be taken seriously. "It's a typical piece of Ken extravagance," he added. "Compared to the straitjacket under which councils operated in the 80s, we now have a very benign, liberal relationship - but we've all got to talk."

Sir Jeremy Beecham, Labour leader of the LGA, said he could identify with Mr Livingstone's comments about the level Whitehall control. But he added: "A perfectly good argument has been ruined by a silly statement."

Addressing delegates in his first major speech since becoming mayor, Mr Livingstone said that he would be pressing for more powers after his first term - hopefully bringing health, and higher education under the control of the GLA - providing his administration managed to update the Tube and introduce workplace parking charges, which would raise £250m annually. But if he failed he would not be re-elected.

Next Monday, when his administration assumes control of London buses, Mr Livingstone warned transport operators that they would be "turfed out" unless services improved. He complained that operators enjoyed a "licence to print money."

In a broad attack on New Labour's modernising agenda, he received loud applause from delegates when he said that elected mayors would do nothing to increase interest in town halls unless the government gave councils more freedom. "I thought they would have gone off the idea of elected mayors (after the London experience)," he added.

Ministers should stop their "gimmicky ways" and recognise that authorities were seriously under-funded. Until they allowed adequate investment in essential services, such as transport and housing, Britain would look "shabby" compared with every other western democracy.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: When advertising group Saatchi & Saatchi demerged from Cordiant in 1997 the received wisdom was that the rump would not have long as an independent company.
fields.body:
When advertising group Saatchi & Saatchi demerged from Cordiant in 1997 the received wisdom was that the rump would not have long as an independent company.

Three years on and it is Saatchi & Saatchi that has succumbed to a buyer after agreeing a £1.2bn bid from French network Publicis last week.

It is little surprise then that Cordiant's future is again under the microscope. The business which owns the Bates advertising agency network is a tier below the world's leading groups and the pace of consolidation in the industry means it cannot retain its independence for long, surely?

That at least seemed to be the reasoning which led to reports yesterday that Cordiant has opened talks with at least two American suitors - True North Communications and Interpublic.

Sources close to Cordiant suggested the rumours were easy conclusions to draw but otherwise wide of the mark.

It was enough to prompt an 18.5p increase in Cordiant's share price to 383.5p.

Market sentiment was guarded ahead of the decision on interest rates in the US - a mood which helped depress the FTSE 100 index 61.8 points lower to 6,313.5.

The close was the lowest for a month and was not helped by a 15p drop in the share price of Vodafone AirTouch, Britain's biggest company, to 286p.

Oil business BP Amoco , which used to claim the title, also did its worst - falling 20p to 618.5p.

Magazine and radio group Emap was among the companies bucking the trend. The group's shares were marked up 55p to £11 on the revival of vague talk that the business may be a takeover target in light of the Vivendi-Seagram deal.

Freeserve, which had been in freefall after the collapse of talks aimed at the sale of the business to T-Online of Germany at the beginning of the week, also had a better day. The shares were traded up 8p to 324p although Freeserve's March peak of 920p is now looking a very steep climb back.

Also rallying after recent declines were hi-tech group Sema , up 48p at 974p, and Granada, which was 19p better at 639p after a downgrade from Morgan Stanley dented the price on Tuesday.

The banks were also in demand. Halifax closed the day 14p higher at 616.5p, Royal Bank of Scotland rose 29p to £10.60 and Standard Chartered was 6.5p higher at 834p.

Outside the FTSE, HIT Entertainment continued to attract speculators adding a further 17p to 382p, due to rumours of a possible bid for the group from Britt Allcroft.

That at least seemed to be the reasoning which led to reports yesterday that Cordiant has opened talks with at least two American suitors - True North Communications and Interpublic. Sources close to Cordiant suggested the rumours were easy conclusions to draw but otherwise wide of the mark. It was enough to prompt an 18.5p increase in Cordiant's share price to 383.5p. Market sentiment was guarded ahead of the decision on interest rates in the US - a mood which helped depress the FTSE 100 index 61.8 points lower to 6,313.5. The close was the lowest for a month and was not helped by a 15p drop in the share price of Vodafone AirTouch, Britain's biggest company, to 286p. Oil business BP Amoco , which used to claim the title, also did its worst - falling 20p to 618.5p. Magazine and radio group Emap was among the companies bucking the trend. The group's shares were marked up 55p to £11 on the revival of vague talk that the business may be a takeover target in light of the Vivendi-Seagram deal. Freeserve, which had been in freefall after the collapse of talks aimed at the sale of the business to T-Online of Germany at the beginning of the week, also had a better day. The shares were traded up 8p to 324p although Freeserve's March peak of 920p is now looking a very steep climb back. Also rallying after recent declines were hi-tech group Sema , up 48p at 974p, and Granada, which was 19p better at 639p after a downgrade from Morgan Stanley dented the price on Tuesday. The banks were also in demand. Halifax closed the day 14p higher at 616.5p, Royal Bank of Scotland rose 29p to £10.60 and Standard Chartered was 6.5p higher at 834p. Outside the FTSE, HIT Entertainment continued to attract speculators adding a further 17p to 382p, due to rumours of a possible bid for the group from Britt Allcroft.

webTitle: Bigger slugs: Bars chain to expand in £29m SFI deal

fields.headline: Bigger slugs: Bars chain to expand in £29m SFI deal
fields.trailText: Slug & Lettuce, the chain of yuppie bars, is to expand throughout the country after a £29m takeover by pub company SFI.
fields.body:
Slug & Lettuce, the chain of yuppie bars, is to expand throughout the country after a £29m takeover by pub company SFI.

SFI intends to roll out Slug & Lettuce alongside its two existing pub brands - Bar Med and The Litten Tree. The company's long-term goal is to build a network of 600 outlets under these three formats. SFI's chief executive Tony Hall said: "Slug & Lettuce is more upmarket than our two existing brands. It's targeted at a different market, and we think they're complementary."

The Slug & Lettuce chain consists of 33 outlets, mainly in London and the home counties. The bars are aimed at affluent urban professionals, offering quality food and premium beers.

SFI already has 84 pubs. Mr Hall said the first stage in the group's expansion would be to have 250 outlets within 30 months: "We'll be looking to find locations typically in previously unlicensed premises, in key town and city centres."

Under the terms of yesterday's deal, Slug & Lettuce investors will get 106 SFI shares for every 100 shares they own.

The takeover ends a long period of uncertainty over Slug & Lettuce's future. In the past six months, the company has had unsuccessful takeover talks with rival pub chain The Old Monk Company and nightclubs operator Po Na Na.

Mr Kowszun said: "Size matters in terms of raising the cash to open new pubs. Hence the view that we should end up in a bigger company."

In a separate move, SFI intends to spin off its three table dancing clubs - call ed For Your Eyes Only - into a separate company.

SFI's shares fell 19.5p to 190.5p, while Slug & Lettuce jumped 18p to 190.5p.

webTitle: Nobody is taming the Celtic tiger

fields.headline: Nobody is taming the Celtic tiger
fields.standfirst: Ireland exposes ECB policy flawsi
fields.trailText: Yesterday's warning from the Bank of Ireland that the Irish economy is showing increasing signs of overheating will have brought a chorus of "I told you so" from around Europe. The most fundamental criticism of the European Central Bank's monetary policy is not that it has not done enough to stand up for the euro - though it hasn't - but that its "one size fits all" interest rate policy was and is flawed.
fields.body:
Yesterday's warning from the Bank of Ireland that the Irish economy is showing increasing signs of overheating will have brought a chorus of "I told you so" from around Europe. The most fundamental criticism of the European Central Bank's monetary policy is not that it has not done enough to stand up for the euro - though it hasn't - but that its "one size fits all" interest rate policy was and is flawed.

It is hard to see how a single monetary policy regime could foster growth in a struggling German economy while at the same time harnessing the "Celtic tiger".

The Bank of Ireland singled out the rate at which wages were rising as a particular concern. High costs could reverse the flow of inward investment. Headline inflation is likely to rise further even though the central bank, unlike some analysts, believes it may now be close to its peak. Bertie Ahern's government must be hoping so in the wake of this week's anti-inflation package - although freezing the price of booze is never going to be a vote-loser.

But two points. First, the outlook for the Irish economy is not one to drive the Bank to drink - even at pre-freeze prices. It is forecasting 8.5% growth this year and at least 7% next.

Second, responsibility for the risk of overheating cannot be laid entirely at the door of the ECB and an interest rate regime incapable of accommodating different growth rates in different economies. Monetary policy is not the only way of cooling economic growth. When governments round Europe handed over control of interest rates to central banks they were keen to hand the responsibility for unpopular decisions with it. But they cannot be allowed to escape so easily. Higher taxes can get the job done, too.

Unfortunately for Ireland, neither the ECB n or the government is reaching for the brakes. All the Bank of Ireland can do is sound the horn.

Return post
To those with memories going back to 1968, yesterday's move by the government to set up a "universal bank" in post offices may have evoked a sense of déjà vu.

Then, another Labour government was setting up what was to become Girobank with an aim of making banking facilities available to all. Girobank was eventually sold off by a Conservative government and has been owned by Alliance & Leicester since 1990.

This time the "universal bank" is being billed as the salvation of the ailing post office network at a time when the government wants to pay social security benefits directly into bank accounts.

Little wonder that Richard Banks, managing director of Girobank, admitted yesterday that recreating a post office-based bank, 30 years on, was "rather amazing". While supportive of any plan which keeps the post office network alive - still the life blood of Girobank's business - Mr Banks has a question or two to pose.

Who will be responsible for the new cards, handed out to social security recipients, which go astray and are used fraudulently? At present, the benefits agency decides whether cheques can be reclaimed. What will the "universal bank" do?

Another issue is the level of reassurance the banks will be offered by government that any commitment they make will not leave them with hefty bills as a result of any change in policy by future admini strations.

Despite the bashing the banks have received in recent months, they may be less than enthusiastic about rushing in to help the universal bank.

Monti muscle
Mario Monti's decision to block the WorldCom/Sprint merger will add to those who believe the European commission's competition commissioner is cultivating a tough guy image. He is already investigating America Online/Time Warner and Warner Music/EMI. The more pertinent question, however, is whether he is an empire builder.

There are two strands to Mr Monti's approach. Yesterday's decision shows the good working relationship between the EU's competition watchdog and its opposite number in the US. No harm in that. As companies become global in scope, regulators ha ve no choice but to cultivate a global reach of their own.

But as Mr Monti was blowing the whistle on WorldCom/Sprint he was also expressing disappointment that his trust busters were not getting enough work. More mergers, acquisitions and joint ventures should come within the competence of his directorate, rather than be dealt with at national level.

There is already a risk that global regulation, however informal, could lose touch with the mechanisms which give existing systems their political legitimacy. Undermining national authorities would be even more damaging.

webTitle: Positive trials for new heart drug

fields.headline: Positive trials for new heart drug
fields.standfirst: AstraZeneca shares rise
fields.trailText: AstraZeneca, Britain's second largest drugs company, has made a breakthrough in the treatment of heart disease by developing a drug which appears to cut patients' cholesterol levels by up to two-thirds.
fields.body:
AstraZeneca, Britain's second largest drugs company, has made a breakthrough in the treatment of heart disease by developing a drug which appears to cut patients' cholesterol levels by up to two-thirds.

Positive results from clinical trials of the product sent AstraZeneca's shares up 37p to £29.34 yesterday.

Rival Glaxo Wellcome also enjoyed a similar revival - its shares jumped 46p to £19.24 after good news about a key treatment for irritable bowel syndrome.

AstraZeneca's heart drug, provisionally called ZD4522, has been pinpointed by analysts as a potential blockbuster drug, although it has only been tested so far in small-scale trials.

In a phase two study, the drug triggered falls of up to 65% in patients' low-density lipoproteins - the type of cholesterol which causes hardening of the arteries, contributing to the risk of heart attacks.

An AstraZeneca spokesman said the results "certainly demonstrate the potential of the drug". He added that ZD4522 had yet to be tested against the leading existing anti-cholesterol drug - Lipitor, made by Warner-Lambert of America.

Analysts greeted the trial results enthusiastically. Alex Evans of Deutsche Bank said the drug had the potential to generate annual sales of $3bn (£2bn) by 2007.

"It looks very promising. At the moment, it appears to be marginally better than Lipitor," he said.

Anti-cholesterol drugs are among the most lucrative treatments in the pharmaceuticals industry, with world wide annual sales of more than $9bn.

For AstraZeneca, ZD4522 could help fill the gap left by its ulcer drug Losec, which contributes a third of the group's turnover but is about to lose its patent protection. Doubts persist about the company's follow-up gastric drug, Nexium, which critics say is little better than generic competitors.

AstraZeneca's chief executive, Tom McKillop, has described ZD4522 as a potential "mega-brand". The drug could be launched in 2002.

Glaxo Wellcome provided a further boost for the pharmaceuticals sector, as it successfully persuaded the food and drug administration in the US that its treatment for irritable bowel syndrome, Lotronex, was safe.

The FDA convened an urgent meeting to consider the product, after 21 patients were taken to hospital suffering from severe constipation and ischemic colitis - a condition blocking the blood supply to the colon.

There were fears that the FDA would insist on a strong "black box" warning on the packaging of the drug, or even a withdrawal of the product from pharmacies.

However, Glaxo successfully argued in favour of milder measures - a letter to doctors warning of possible problems and studies to examine the extent of the side effects.

Glaxo pointed out that 21 incidents was relatively insignificant, considering 115,000 people had taken the drug since its launch in February.

The company claims that Lotronex is the first effective drug for irritable bowel syndrome - which affects nearly a fifth of all adults.

fields.headline: Blair rejects US's Airbus protest
fields.trailText: The prime minister yesterday moved swiftly to reject American suggestions that the £8bn development of the world's largest jet aircraft, the A3XX, did not comply with international law.
fields.body:
The prime minister yesterday moved swiftly to reject American suggestions that the £8bn development of the world's largest jet aircraft, the A3XX, did not comply with international law.

Downing Street stressed that there had been no contact between Mr Blair and President Clinton on the issue, following reports that the US aircraft industry is beginning to lobby heavily in Washington against the project.

The British sources said that the government was "confident that the support we have set out for the project complies with our international obligations". A spokesman made it clear that the £500m launch aid from the government to BAE Systems was a loan and "we expect to get our money back". BAE, as part of the European Airbus consortium, will build the aircraft's wings.

This stance was underlined by the department of trade and industry which said that it would work with the European commission and other countries involved in the A3XX in responding to requests from the Americans for information. The new aeroplane is being developed by Airbus, in which Britain has a 20% share.

Since Airbus announced that it was ready to proceed with the project last week, there have been rumblings in the United States against the project.

These have been fostered by Boeing, which has so far decided against developing a larger civil aircraft than the Boeing 747.

The Americans are pressing the Airbus partners to hand over details of their proposed subsidies to see if they comply with international trade rules.

The project has secured the backing of eight customers, including Virgin Atlantic, which have ordered 60 models.

Detailed production plans will be revealed by the end of the year, and the first aircraft is due to begin trials by 2004.

Airbus says that the A3XX will start operating commercially in 2005. It will be able to carry between 550 and 900 passengers, depending on the configuration of the double-decker cabin.

fields.headline: Eurofighter looks east
fields.trailText: Eurofighter, the four-nation European consortium, yesterday launched a challenge to traditional US hegemony in the south-east Asian military market by offering to supply South Korea with 40 of its jet fighters at up to £90m each.
fields.body:
Eurofighter, the four-nation European consortium, yesterday launched a challenge to traditional US hegemony in the south-east Asian military market by offering to supply South Korea with 40 of its jet fighters at up to £90m each.

It is the latest threat by European industry to American dominance in global markets after last week's decision by Airbus to develop its A3XX super jumbo to take on Boeing in long-haul air travel.

Eurofighter executives aim to capture half the expected demand for 800 new generation fighters over the next 30 years - worth an expected £35bn to the group formed by British, German, Italian and Spanish companies.

Their move pits the consortium against US defence groups Boeing and Lockheed Martin, which are competing for the highly lucrative contract to supply the US air force and navy with the rival Joint Strike Fighter (JSF).

Eurofighter, in which BAE Systems holds a 33% stake, is already challenging Lockheed's F-16 in a number of European markets.

webTitle: The man who stared down globalisation

fields.headline: The man who stared down globalisation
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Mario Monti has stymied deal maker Bernard Ebbers
fields.trailText: Few people can hope to take on the world's biggest companies and win. Mario Monti, the EU competition commissioner, can - and does. The Italian yesterday flexed his considerable muscle and blocked the proposed merger between the US phone companies WorldCom and Sprint even though the two firms had already told Brussels they were withdrawing their merger notification.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Few people can hope to take on the world's biggest companies and win. Mario Monti, the EU competition commissioner, can - and does. The Italian yesterday flexed his considerable muscle and blocked the proposed merger between the US phone companies WorldCom and Sprint even though the two firms had already told Brussels they were withdrawing their merger notification.

The decision was technical in the face of Tuesday's ban by the US justice department. But it was the first time the European commission had blocked a merger between two non-EU companies. "The commission has decided to prohibit the merger as it would have created a company with a dominant position in the market for global internet backbone service," Mr Monti said.

If recent evidence is anything to go by, mergers involving internet companies will continue attracting Mr Monti's gaze. Besides blocking the WorldCom/Sprint deal, he has in the past month opened anti-monopoly inquiries into America Online's merger with Time Warner and Warner Music's joint venture with EMI of Britain.

'Avoiding bottlenecks'

"Competition policy has a key role to play in the light of the 'new economy' to preserve the incentive to innovate by avoiding bottlenecks and similar anti-competitive developments," Mr Monti said. Brushing aside suggestions the EU's action was not required, he said it was necessary to make a formal decision to reject the proposed £76bn merger because the companies did not say they were cancelling their agreement - only that they did not intend to implement it.

EU anti-competition rules can take into account the effect of a merger on the European market. The move underlines the increasingly global nature of business, and especially telecoms. "It is not the nationality of the companies or where they are based, but the sales they have in the EU," a commission official said.

The EU examined the merger in parallel with the US justice department, which filed suit on Tuesday to block the deal, saying it would increase prices for millions of consumers. The actions of the regulators highlighted how the American authorities often have to speed up their investigations to dovetail with the rigidly timetabled EU system.

Under EU rules, the commission has an initial four weeks to review a deal. At that point, it can either clear it or refer it for a further four months of scrutiny. In the US there is no deadline, making co-ordination difficult.

It was the 13th time the commission has blocked a merger since 1990, when EU member states gave it the power to review all mergers and acquisitions involving companies with combined global sales in excess of €5bn (£3.1bn) and EU sales of at least €250m for each, irrespective of their nationality.

Sprint's offer to divest its internet business was "insufficient to resolve the competition concerns resulting from the merger," the commission said.

Had WorldCom and Sprint merged the new company would have become the third biggest telecoms group in the world - worth more than $133bn (£88bn) - and carried 45% of the globe's internet traffic.

The deal, said the commission, would "dictate conditions and prices in the market to the detriment of consumers around the world and particularly in the 15 EU states".

Now the two firms face three choices, none of them particularly palatable. With regulators on both sides of the Atlantic against them, the two can either walk away from the deal, go to court to argue their case or offer to radically restructure the merger.

Wall Street analysts believe that a decision to pursue the merger through the US courts is the least likely option, particularly after the commission's decision to block the deal.

But without significant guidance from either company, most traders were divided about what could happen next. There is talk that WorldCom could sell its low-margin consumer long-distance business or that the acquisitive company could itself become a takeover target. And analysts believe that several non-US groups - including Deutsche Telekom or NTT - could be interested in bidding for either group.

Bernard Ebbers, who built WorldCom through a series of acquisitions, was not commenting on yesterday's decision. He prompted the regulatory inquiry into the Sprint deal months after announcing the acquisition of MCI a year ago.

Limited options

Courtney Munroe, a telecoms director at research group International Data, said the chances of WorldCom scrapping the deal or offering to sell its long-distance business were about 50-50. "I don't believe that the deal is dead yet. I still think there's hope."

WorldCom's options were severely limited by the EU's decision to block the deal. The company does not want to sell off UUNet, its internet backbone business. And Sprint has made clear that it finds EU demands to spin off a significant part of its long-distance business unacceptable.

Deals the EU blocked

Thirteen deals have been thrown out by Brussels in 10 years:

2000 WorldCom/Sprint, telecoms; Volvo bid for Scania, trucks

1999 Airtours' bid for First Choice, holidays

1998 CLT-Ufa/Kirch, digital TV alliance; Deutsche Telekom/CLT-Ufa, joint bid for stake in Kirch's BetaResearch

1997 Blokker bid for Dutch Toys R Us

1996 Gencor and Lonrho, merger of platinum interests; Kesko and Tuko, Finnish retail deal; Saint-Gobain/ Wacker-Chemie, silicon carbide venture

1995 Norsk Telekom/TeleDanmark/ Kinnevick, satellite TV venture; RTL4/Veronica/Endemol, media venture

1994 Bertelsmann/Kirch/Deutsche Telekom MSG, new media alliance

1991 Boeing sale of de Havilland to Aerospatiale and Alenia

The EU examined the merger in parallel with the US justice department, which filed suit on Tuesday to block the deal, saying it would increase prices for millions of consumers. The actions of the regulators highlighted how the American authorities often have to speed up their investigations to dovetail with the rigidly timetabled EU system. Under EU rules, the commission has an initial four weeks to review a deal. At that point, it can either clear it or refer it for a further four months of scrutiny. In the US there is no deadline, making co-ordination difficult. It was the 13th time the commission has blocked a merger since 1990, when EU member states gave it the power to review all mergers and acquisitions involving companies with combined global sales in excess of €5bn (£3.1bn) and EU sales of at least €250m for each, irrespective of their nationality. Sprint's offer to divest its internet business was "insufficient to resolve the competition concerns resulting from the merger," the commission said. Had WorldCom and Sprint merged the new company would have become the third biggest telecoms group in the world - worth more than $133bn (£88bn) - and carried 45% of the globe's internet traffic. The deal, said the commission, would "dictate conditions and prices in the market to the detriment of consumers around the world and particularly in the 15 EU states". Now the two firms face three choices, none of them particularly palatable. With regulators on both sides of the Atlantic against them, the two can either walk away from the deal, go to court to argue their case or offer to radically restructure the merger. Wall Street analysts believe that a decision to pursue the merger through the US courts is the least likely option, particularly after the commission's decision to block the deal. But without significant guidance from either company, most traders were divided about what could happen next. There is talk that WorldCom could sell its low-margin consumer long-distance business or that the acquisitive company could itself become a takeover target. And analysts believe that several non-US groups - including Deutsche Telekom or NTT - could be interested in bidding for either group. Bernard Ebbers, who built WorldCom through a series of acquisitions, was not commenting on yesterday's decision. He prompted the regulatory inquiry into the Sprint deal months after announcing the acquisition of MCI a year ago. Limited options Courtney Munroe, a telecoms director at research group International Data, said the chances of WorldCom scrapping the deal or offering to sell its long-distance business were about 50-50. "I don't believe that the deal is dead yet. I still think there's hope." WorldCom's options were severely limited by the EU's decision to block the deal. The company does not want to sell off UUNet, its internet backbone business. And Sprint has made clear that it finds EU demands to spin off a significant part of its long-distance business unacceptable. webTitle: Italy surrenders fascist redoubt to free market forces

fields.headline: Italy surrenders fascist redoubt to free market forces
fields.trailText: Europe's privatisation bandwagon finally caught up yesterday with IRI, the Italian state holding company set up by the fascist dictator Benito Mussolini to bolster the industrial and banking sectors during the 1930s depression years.
fields.byline: Mark Milner and Rory Carroll in Rome
fields.body:
Europe's privatisation bandwagon finally caught up yesterday with IRI, the Italian state holding company set up by the fascist dictator Benito Mussolini to bolster the industrial and banking sectors during the 1930s depression years.

IRI, the Instituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale to give it its full title, was formally placed in liquidation and its remaining assets transferred to the Italian treasury ministry where they are expected to be sold within the next two years.

Although IRI was set up as a crisis management vehicle with a limited lifespan, it survived to become a powerful driver behind the build-up of the Italian economy in the 1950s and 1960s. Through an array of subsidiaries it was instrumental in infrastructure projects such as construction of the country's motorway network and development of the telecommunications network. At its height the company employed more than 600,000 people.

In the 1970s, however, IRI's image as a model of state intervention became increasingly tarnished. It was a huge source of political patronage and was used to rescue bankrupt enterprises in order to avoid unpopular job losses, especially in the southern half of the country.

By the beginning of the 1990s it had debts of nearly £23.5bn and was coming under increasing pressure from the European commission's competition arm, concerned at the extent of state aid.

At a press conference yesterday to mark the obsequies of the 67-year-old organisation, Italian prime minister Guiliano Amato paid tribute to its work.

"This will be a day to remember in the history of Italy. A long chapter is closing, and it is closing with the greatest dignity. It [IRI] is going because times have changed but it has been a great protagonist in Italian economic history. It is an ending that is a success."

IRI is certainly going out on a high note. Last year it made a net profit of more than £2bn - the highest ever recorded by an Italian limited company.

All that remains in the portfolio are stakes in the airline Alitalia, the broadcaster Rai, a shipbuilding and a ferry company, an investment bank and a holding company for a number of manufacturing operations.

According to treasury minister Vincenzo Visco, all will be gone within two years. "Then there will be no more public shares." IRI, he promised, will not rise from the ashes. It will be the job of another Italian, EC competition commissioner Mario Monti, to make sure it doesn't.

Welcoming the liquidation of IRI, Mr Monti said: "It is a decision I fought hard for because it affected the quality of the relationship between Italy and the European Union."

webTitle: Smith & Nephew pulls out of consumer products

fields.headline: Smith & Nephew pulls out of consumer products
fields.trailText: Healthcare company Smith & Nephew is set to make £235m by selling its consumer products divisions, which make Elastoplast dressings, Lil-lets tampons and Simple soap.
fields.body:
Healthcare company Smith & Nephew is set to make £235m by selling its consumer products divisions, which make Elastoplast dressings, Lil-lets tampons and Simple soap.

The disposals are part of an attempt by the 144-year-old group to reinvent itself as a producer of "technologically advanced medical devices" such as endoscopy cameras and artificial hips.

Chief executive Chris O'Donnell said: "This is the changing nature of the business: we've got to recognise that the world has moved on."

Smith & Nephew has agreed to sell its feminine hygiene and toiletries business, which includes Lil-lets and Simple, for £140m to a management buyout team backed by the investment firm ABN Amro Capital.

Furthermore, the company's first aid operation, which manufactures Elastoplast and distributes Nivea suntan creams, is to be bought by a German group, Beiersdorf, for £80m.

Smith & Nephew will make an additional £15m by collecting debts owed by the two businesses' customers.

Mr O'Donnell said the company had recognised it did not have the marketing muscle to compete with global corporations such as Procter & Gamble and Johnson & Johnson: "You've got to be big, and an expert, in your sectors. In consumer product terms, we're a relatively small player."

The businesses being sold employ 750 people, with big factories in Birmingham and Corby. Mr O'Donnell said job losses would be "negligible".

The group intends to specialise in three areas: wound care, orthopaedics and endoscopy.

Mr O'Donnell believes there are good growth opportunities for products such as hi-tech bandages and replacement joints because of demand from Britain's ageing population.

Smith & Nephew's recent innovations include Dermagraft, a dressing for foot ulcers made from babies' foreskins.

The group also makes an ointment which eats away dead skin in festering wounds such as bed sores.

Following the disposals, Smith & Nephew will return £415m to shareholders by paying a special dividend, although this attracted criticism from some analysts who said the proceeds should be invested in hi-tech acquisitions.

Smith & Nephew was founded in 1856 by a pharmacist in Hull. Mr O'Donnell said: "I think Mr Smith will be clapping loudly in his grave at this."

The shares rose 9.25p to 213.5p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: US subpoenas petrol refiners
fields.body:
US subpoenas petrol refiners

The US federal trade commission has issued subpoenas to petrol refiners and others in the oil industry during its inquiry into high petrol prices in the midwest, FTC chairman Robert Pitofsky said yesterday.

"The objective is to determine who raised prices, and whether there was any illegal contact, communication or signalling among competitors before or during the time of the price increases," Mr Pitofsky said.

To find the answers to those questions, the commission has subpoenaed refiners, pipeline owners and operators, terminal owners and operators and blend plant owners and operators that are part of the midwest petrol supply chain, he said.

Telecom firm pursues float

The management at European Telecom has bitten the bullet and is to challenge what it sees as the stock market's undervaluation of the company.

Primarily a distributor of mobile phone handsets and accessories, European Telecom has appointed investment bank HSBC to consider a flotation of Global Telematics, one of its many joint ventures.

Online food has bright future

Online grocery sales in Europe are expected to surpass those of the US by 2003, Forrester Research said in a new market study yesterday.

More favourable delivery economics, greater supplier activity and customers already used to fax and phone-based delivery will allow European sales to exceed by 11% the $16.8bn of sales in the US in three years, it predicted.

Madeira faces EC inquiry

The European commission said yesterday that it had begun a formal investigation into tax breaks offered to firms on the Portuguese island of Madeira, saying it feared they represented illegal operating aid.

"The total amount of aid granted in the form of tax exemptions is thought to have exceeded €1bn [£623m] in 1997 and appears to be concentrated in the financial services and international services centres," the commission said, adding this amounted to more than all other Portuguese state aid schemes.

Leicester City rejects bid

Leicester City yesterday rejected a "wholly inadequate"' approach for Leicester City football club, a subsidiary of the company.

The 70p-per-share offer is thought to have come from a consortium close to Leicester City's largest shareholder, Roy Parker, one of the "gang of four" directors involved in a boardroom split last year.

Leicester City stated that the approach was a deliberate attempt at disruption ahead of a meeting to ask shareholders for approval for a media partnership with NTL, Britain's largest cable and broadcasting services group.

webTitle: Millions pledged to revitalise post offices

fields.headline: Millions pledged to revitalise post offices
fields.standfirst:
Plan to diversify into banking and internet
Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Hundreds of millions of pounds of subsidies to save the declining post office network have been agreed between the Treasury and the Department of Trade and Industry.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, chief political correspondent, and Geoffrey Gibbs
fields.body:
Hundreds of millions of pounds of subsidies to save the declining post office network have been agreed between the Treasury and the Department of Trade and Industry.

The precise sum will be made public at the spending review announcement next month, covering 2002-5.

The industry secretary, Stephen Byers, yesterday claimed the money, coupled with new commercial opportunities, would help to prevent "avoidable closures" of rural post offices. But Mr Byers gave little detailed definition of this reassurance, prompting Conservative claims he had still not guaranteed the safety of Britain's unprofitable post offices.

The government has also been warned that as many as 1,000 post offices could close over the next three years before new commercial opportunities come on stream.

Mr Byers made his announcements as he published a Cabinet Office report claiming the Post Office must diversify from its traditional core business if it is to survive.

Admitting the Post Office had been slow to modernise, Mr Byers mapped out three new commercial opportunities including e-commerce, one-stop shops for government information and a new post office-based Universal Bank for the 3m, mainly poor, who have no bank accounts. The Post Office could also make agreements to act as agent for commercial banks who have deserted rural communities and the inner cities.

Mr Byers also reassured pensioner groups, saying pensions will still be available in cash at post offices.

The post office network, already losing 400 offices a year, is on the verge of a crisis engendered by the government decision to switch to automated credit transfer (ACT) for the payment of benefits. The Post Office will lose £400m by 2005 when ACT will have been completed. Currently, the payment of social security benefits accounts for 35% of its income.

But figures published yesterday show nearly half the post office network already generates less income than it costs. In total these offices lose around £35-40m, mainly in rural areas.

But the Cabinet Office report claims the 18,000-strong network, the largest retail network in Britain, is a sleeping giant with 28m customers making 45m visits every week. Far more income could be engendered from these visits.

Attention focused yesterday on Mr Byers' promise that the government will put in place a formal duty to prevent any avoidable closures.

He defined an unavoidable closure as one in which "no one is prepared to take over from a departing sub-postmaster or where an associated retail business in the post office is no longer commercially viable".

The new duty, expected to last six years, will apply to rural post offices serving settlements of 10,000 or fewer people. The pledge would at present cover 10,000 post offices.

Mr Byers also promised a fund to modernise run-down post offices in deprived areas.

Plans for the proposed Universal Bank will be finalised by Christmas, but the bank will not offer an overdraft facility.

Mr Byers claimed the rural network could, eventually, "form the backbone of communication between government and citizens" and serve as the rural base for the internet.

'If it is going to keep us open, we have got to be more than willing to cooperate'

Dispensing advice and information, and providing a banking service to those without a bank account, hold no fears for Regan Jones and her mother, Susan Fellows, who run the post office and shop in Bwlch in the Brecon Beacons.

The office is the focal point of a community where almost three-quarters of the village's 1,000 residents are elderly, and barely a day goes by without someone calling in for advice.

"This would be a lot of new information to take in, but if it is going to keep the post office open we have got to be more than willing to cooperate," said Ms Jones, who became a postmistress at the age of 21 when the family took over the business four years ago.

"We have not got many buses here, so people rely on the post office. If it were to close, what would happen to village life? Everybody comes in to find out what is going on, and we are already like a tourist information service."

The two women have worked hard to build up the once rundown operation. They run a grocery delivery service, make sandwiches for the passing tourist trade, and have begun to take in laundry.

Like other rural post office owners, they are worried about the imminent loss of the contract to pay pensions and benefits. Given Bwlch's age profile, pensions form an important part of their work.

Not only would the loss of this and other benefit payments cut their post office turnover by about a third, it could, they fear, have a knock on effect on sales in the shop.

They hope the government's plans for a Universal Bank to be run through the post office network will provide the boost the rural post offices so badly need. "It should really help people in rural areas like this, where there are probably a lot of people without bank accounts," said Ms Jones.

Steve Like, who runs the post office in nearby Hay on Wye and represents 260 sub postmasters and mistresses in Hereford and central Wales, said the universal banking proposal would send a much needed lifeline to rural offices.

Eighteen communities in the region have lost their offices over the last two years, and he feared that a quarter of those that remained could be vulnerable if there was no work to replace the threatened loss of pensions and benefits.

He felt the banking proposals would gain widespread approval in rural areas where many people like to deal in cash and have a fear of banks.

webTitle: Designers back in step over bouncing millennium bridge

fields.headline: Designers back in step over bouncing millennium bridge
fields.trailText: The architect Lord Foster and engineers from Arup joined ranks yesterday to defend London's "bouncing bridge", the £18.2m Millennium Bridge across the Thames, insisting that its problem had been diagnosed and the solution would be designed, although the structure might remain closed for months.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The architect Lord Foster and engineers from Arup joined ranks yesterday to defend London's "bouncing bridge", the £18.2m Millennium Bridge across the Thames, insisting that its problem had been diagnosed and the solution would be designed, although the structure might remain closed for months.

"Can you ever be over-ambitious?" Lord Foster said, when asked if he regretted the radical design of the slender "blade of light", which bounced so alarmingly under the feet of the crowds that it was closed within three days of opening. "I would rather be accused of being over-ambitious than of being lily-livered and retreating into a nostalgic past that never existed," he said.

Tony Fitzpatrick, chief engineer for Arup on the project, said: "I am embarrassed - but not ashamed of our work, or our profession." The designers insisted the problem could not have been predicted on any of the available engineering data and standards, which will now have to be rewritten.

The problem was apparently caused by the wrong kind of walking as the crowds came in unexpected numbers.

At least 150,000 made the 320-metre crossing between St Paul's cathedral and the Tate Modern in the 72 hours before the bridge was closed. When pedestrians felt the natural movement of the bridge, they fell instinctively into step, and their own movements alarmingly increased the vibration and caused the swaying.

Since then, engineers have been working around the clock. Outside firms and experts, who would normally be commercial r ivals, have been brought in to vet and check the work.

Arup expects that the solution will be to vastly increase the damping of the bridge, by building in the equivalent of car shock absorbers to prevent the build-up of vibrations. The engineers have ruled out making the bridge stiffer by adding extra piers, which would destroy the elegance of the design.

Lord Foster furiously denied the existence of a "millennium curse" which has appeared to strike both the dome and the London Eye, the big wheel which missed its New Year's Eve opening date. He said the transformation and regeneration of tracts of the capital should be seen as "the millennium blessing".

"Moving around the world as I do, I hear nothing but people being incredibly supportive. They say 'wow, there's so much happening in London, it's unbelievable'."

Lord Foster appeared shoulder to shoulder with Arup engineers yesterday, declaring: "We are all in it together; we have all in our own ways put our reputations on the line."

On June 12, the day the bridge closed, he caused great resentment by appearing to shrug off responsibility for the bridge he co-designed with Arup and the sculptor Sir Antony Caro, describing the problem as "engineering led".

But he revealed he has joined in all-night sessions in Arup's offices, trying to devise a solution that will not spoil the slender beauty of the bridge.

Teams of volunteers have spent hours waddling like ducks across the bridge, trying to recreate the bouncing and snaking movements reported by members of the public. Shakers, vibrating metal weights normally used to test the strength of football stands, are still being used to trigger and study the vibrations in the bridge, and test rigs are being designed and built to study the problem further.

Tony Fitzpatrick, chief engineer on the project, yesterday blamed "unintentional synchronisation of walking".

David Bell, chairman of the Millennium Bridge Trust, said the priority was "to give the bridge back to the people of London, for 24 hours a day, for ever".

He is already planning the third opening celebration: the bridge was opened by the Queen when only two-thirds finished in May, opened to the public with a procession and fireworks display a month later, and should reopen in the autumn. "I think we'll do something a bit different this time," said Mr Bell.

The designers insisted the problem could not have been predicted on any of the available engineering data and standards, which will now have to be rewritten. The problem was apparently caused by the wrong kind of walking as the crowds came in unexpected numbers. At least 150,000 made the 320-metre crossing between St Paul's cathedral and the Tate Modern in the 72 hours before the bridge was closed. When pedestrians felt the natural movement of the bridge, they fell instinctively into step, and their own movements alarmingly increased the vibration and caused the swaying. Since then, engineers have been working around the clock. Outside firms and experts, who would normally be commercial r ivals, have been brought in to vet and check the work. Arup expects that the solution will be to vastly increase the damping of the bridge, by building in the equivalent of car shock absorbers to prevent the build-up of vibrations. The engineers have ruled out making the bridge stiffer by adding extra piers, which would destroy the elegance of the design. Lord Foster furiously denied the existence of a "millennium curse" which has appeared to strike both the dome and the London Eye, the big wheel which missed its New Year's Eve opening date. He said the transformation and regeneration of tracts of the capital should be seen as "the millennium blessing". "Moving around the world as I do, I hear nothing but people being incredibly supportive. They say 'wow, there's so much happening in London, it's unbelievable'." Lord Foster appeared shoulder to shoulder with Arup engineers yesterday, declaring: "We are all in it together; we have all in our own ways put our reputations on the line." On June 12, the day the bridge closed, he caused great resentment by appearing to shrug off responsibility for the bridge he co-designed with Arup and the sculptor Sir Antony Caro, describing the problem as "engineering led". webTitle: While Blair seeks the truth, Hague searches for votes

fields.headline: While Blair seeks the truth, Hague searches for votes
fields.standfirst:
Religion has moved centre stage - but for two very different reasons
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Religion has moved centre stage - but for two very different reasons
fields.body:
Tony Blair has been wrestling with religion since he was an Oxford undergraduate. It's an intensely personal engagement, and seems never to have stopped. Among prime ministers, only Arthur Balfour, and before him Gladstone, have apparently taken such a consuming interest in the ultimate purpose of life on earth, which certainly is not politics. Such questing passion distinguishes Mr Blair from contemporary politicians too, not least William Hague. Mr Hague is in the middle of his own calculated jousting with religion, but his approach could hardly be more different.

In his spiritual fascinations, Mr Blair is regarded by some people, including several in his own cabinet, as a bit of a weirdo. Some of the things he does indeed seem strange. Tomorrow, after an evening in Berlin straightening out Gerhard Schröder over Europe, a necessary public job, he will move to Tubingen to talk with Hans Kung, the priest-theologian long delicensed by the Vatican, and give a speech at Kung's Global Ethics Foundation. This he need not do. There are no votes in it. The speech he makes will reflect an entirely personal interest in the same kinds of exploration, into values and ethics and community, which Kung has conducted as an intellectual colonist reaching out far beyond his base in Old Catholicism.

What Kung and Blair share is, among other things, a concern about the role of public men. Blair is on a journey towards truth but also on a search for validation. Kung might give it to him. A leader of formidable certainty at one level, Blair needs definition at another. He wants to speak, but he also wants to know. Much of his life has been spent listening to gurus who might make him wiser, better or more successful. Though his political machine has raised manipulative cynicism to new heights, his personal desire is for the linkage of his life with goals that will pass muster at the last judgment.

So it did not strike him as odd - as even the philosopher Balfour might have found it - to spend his summer holiday reading the Koran and the history of Islam. There was no public reason to do that. Britain no longer has much to do in the Middle East and if we did, Foreign Office Arabists could supply the necessary precis in a trice. Maybe the reading was a prelude to Turkey's admission to the concert of Europe, which Blair importantly supported earlier this year, moving on from a definition of Europe, often voiced by Helmut Kohl, that confined it within the boundaries of Christendom. Essentially, though, this was part of Blair's pilgrimage in search of universal values.

It was a fulfilment, Kung-like, of the ultimate ecumenicism, wherein all religions have their points. Like religion, like politics. The Blair view of politics is that there are the Tories - and then there is everyone else, crowding into the same big tent. Likewise, there are believers: Christian, Hindu, Muslim, others, who scarcely need to be differentiated. And then there are atheists, infidels beyond the gates, deprived not just of the blessing of belief but of meaningful guidance as to the best way forward in the public realm.

The big point is that this is personal. It's not an electoral or political construct. Blair plans to give another "values" address to the evangelical Faith in the Future conference in Brighton next month. He does want to broaden the political audience. But there is no tokenism here. He never actually mentions God. The most serious believer among prime ministers for many decades eschews, in public, the source of the doctrine he believes in. He thereby shows good taste, and basic political discretion. But you can see a multi-headed god, or God, edging him forward, gnawing at him.

William Hague, on the other hand, has decided Christians are a political niche-market. This is a new discovery for him, and it's narrowly faith-bound. He has taken to mentioning Christianity, if not God, a lot. But his personal stance has no pedigree, and his interest is functional. He's a conventional politician, there to tell and never to learn. "Roll up your sleeves and get involved," he instructed 10,000 evangelicals at the Spring Harvest festival. "The church is very much alive and advancing in many parts of this land", he shamelessly preached, playing the audience like segmented voters. On the one hand, "Jesus called us to serve the lonely as well as the hungry" and similar pieties, on the other a series of claims that the Tories alone stand for marriage, the family and traditional British values of the kind that godly evangelicals believe in.

Palpably, Hague's only quest is for votes. He is not searching for purpose, which needs no further definition than a Tory victory. The message, like the technique, is American, trailing hopefully in the wake of George W. Bush and his oxymoronic "compassionate conservatism". Last week the Tories summoned Bush's own guru, Marvin Olasky, who delivered a message of such born-again intolerance and exclusivity that even Hague's people got worried: "God is a capitalist and free marketeer", "the evil of homosexuality", mothers should not work, women should not run for president, Olasky said. Aligning religious fundamentalism with core Tory positions may make the heartland vote feel better. Otherwise Hague's flirtation with faith-politics is already looking like opportunism gone wrong.

I think neither of these excursions away from the regular political agenda is likely to get far. The Hague approach treats Britain as if she were, or might become, America. The chances of that happening are as low as those of private charity here supplanting great tracts of public provision. Faith-politics works to some extent in the US, because many more Americans than British say they believe in a Christian God. For better or worse, God enters the political dialogue without embarrassment. Faith-based social programmes have reality because there are enough believers to carry them out. A Tory leader, whose own belief shows no sign of rising above the routine mouthings of generations of leaders before him, cannot be seen as anything other than a cynical dabbler in a market-place where honest trade is slow to non-existent.

The Blair approach to faith has the virtue of originality. Doctrine doesn't matter much nor, even, does allegiance. What matters is the search for some kind of transcendental purpose, a quest that bothers the leader as much as it's meant to inspire the led. Mr Blair's visit to talk again with Hans Kung is the gratuitous act of a decently troubled man. If it were calculated, you'd be hard put to name the group, in this pretty godless country, whom it had much chance of impressing. A morally ambitious leader makes another effort to raise self-examination to a higher level. It is strangely unpolitical. The conversion effect is hard to believe in. But public agonising about values makes him feel better. It's as close to religion as many people get.

fields.headline: Hostel fire suspect captured
fields.trailText: Police yesterday shot and detained the man suspected of starting the fire at the backpackers' hostel that killed 15 people, after tracking him down in bushland only four miles from the scene of the blaze.
fields.body:
Police yesterday shot and detained the man suspected of starting the fire at the backpackers' hostel that killed 15 people, after tracking him down in bushland only four miles from the scene of the blaze.

Police said Robert Paul Long, 37, was wounded in the arm after lunging at a police officer with a knife. He was last night under police guard at Maryborough hospital and is likely to be interviewed today. The officer was thought to have been stabbed on the chin in the struggle with Long.

Long's arrest, near the scene of the fatal blaze in Childers, Queensland, ended a nationwide hunt for the itinerant worker, who was named by police as a suspect after the arson attack on the Palace backpackers hostel last Friday. Long was seen near a rubbish bin fire in the lounge of the hostel on the night of the blaze.

"Long's injuries are not life-threatening," a Queensland police spokesman said. "He'll be interviewed by police after medical treatment."

Early on Tuesday, police uncovered a campsite littered with food scraps in dense scrub south of Childers which they suspected had been used by Long. There had been a confirmed sighting of him in the area. Police with dogs had been following him through the bush ever since.

Police spokesman Eric Meyer told Australian TV: "Police have been tracking a sighting of Long for most of the day. I understand - and information from the scene at this stage suggests - that at about quarter past four a male that they believed to be Long came out of bush scrub. At this stage, police fired upon him and he was injured in the arm."

Darryl Miller, from Howard motor repairs, said he saw police cars and helicopters converge on the site in the late afternoon to try to flush out the fugitive. "It's not very densely populated, just river banks, bush, a couple of houses in the vicinity, that's about all," he said.

The fire broke out just after midnight last Friday and so far six British, four Australians, two Dutch, one Irish, one Japanese and one South Korean have been confirmed dead. The two-storey timber building, popular among backpackers and fruit pickers, was fully occupied and 40 men and 29 women survived the blaze.

Long, who has been described as a lonely man, was wanted in Darwin for allegedly trying to burn down a caravan while his de facto wife and two of her children were inside.

Fourteen of the people who died in the hostel were trapped in two adjoining rooms, unable to escape because their doors opened to an area above a stairwell which was the centre of the inferno. Ten victims were in one room and four in the other, both on the first floor. The victims were found slumped in various positions. Some had struggled to escape through a single, barred window in the room where 10 died.

As the parents of some of the dead backpackers arrived in Childers, Bill Trevor, the mayor, said messages of support had been arriving from all over the country.

The Princess Royal is due to visit survivors and view the hostel on Sunday.

webTitle: In space, who is the doctor?

fields.headline: In space, who is the doctor?
fields.standfirst:
Finding water on Mars has revived dreams of a visit. But there are medical problems, writes Sanjida O'Connell
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Finding water on Mars has revived dreams of a visit. But there are medical problems, writes Sanjida O'Connell
fields.body:
The first thing anyone asks Dr Kevin Fong is: "Do you need an astronaut, do you need a rocket and do you need one of those big, whirly things - a centrifuge - like they have on James Bond?"

Fong thinks he doesn't really need any of those things, though the odd astronaut might come in handy. Fong is rather unusual: there can be few 29 year olds trained in astrophysics and medicine, who have worked for Nasa. In between dealing with patients in intensive care at Hammersmith Hospital, he is launching the first space biomedicine centre in Britain. The centre will be based at University College, London, and has the full support of the European Space Agency, ESA, and Nasa. Its main goal will be to teach and conduct research into how the human body is affected by space.

"In the past getting into outer space has been an engineering challenge, but you could measure these missions in hours or days - Mir was the longest at just over a year," says Fong. Now that liquid water has been (all but) discovered on Mars, one obstacle towards long haul space flights has been removed, namely carting water about and working out how to recycle it. Nasa wants to launch 8,000-day missions to Mars - that's almost 22 years. The problem is no longer engineering. Space, as Fong points out, is the biggest insult to the human body there is. Not only do muscles wither and bones disintegrate but space affects every single organ, every single cell in the body.

Nasa flight surgeon Dr Terry Taddeo says: "The first thing that happens is that once you're out of the pull of gravity, you experience a fluid shift. Standing around in 1G [earth's gravitational field] your blood and fluids tend to pool around your feet; once you're in microgravity [zero gravity], the fluids become more equally distributed and you tend to get this feeling of head stuffiness. You can see the veins in the neck become full of blood and it's described as the 'stuffy-head chicken-leg' syndrome."

Without gravity, astronauts don't use their muscles as they would on earth; no new muscle fibres are produced, and even the composition of the muscles changes. Likewise, bones need not be so robust and the skeleton starts to leach calcium into the blood. The result is brittle bones while the excess calcium can clog up the kidneys and cause renal failure. Even bone marrow disappears at the rate of 1.5% per month. The heart shrinks and is not powerful enough to pump fully oxygenated blood around the body. You lose red blood cells. The neurofibular system, which is responsible for balance, is also affected. We balance by using our sense of sight, touch - not available in space since crew members are floating not walking -and the otoliths and semi-circular canals in the inner ear - also no good when you're drifting around in space. Since the only fully functioning sense is vision, it is no wonder astronauts find hand-eye co-ordination a little tricky; on their return to earth, even walking round a corner can present problems.

The gut won't digest efficiently, lungs don't breath fully, and the immune system packs up resulting in a greater likelihood of succumbing to diseases caused by viruses, bacteria and fungal spores. The high level of radiation in space can cause cancer; even the minute organs within individual cells no longer function properly.

A recent study conducted by Nasa showed that eye sight can deteriorate. They locked six volunteers in a simulated rocket for three months: since the rocket was only 6 metres across, the volunteers had problems adjusting to seeing greater distances when they were let out.

"It's a fantastic thing," says Fong. "We evolved a hundred million years ago in a 1G world, and yet we adapt quickly to an environment with no gravity. The problem is readaptation on return to earth."

No astronaut wants to return home with osteoporosis, dysfunctional kidneys, riddled with tumours and the balance of a football fan.

The trouble with space travel doesn't just stop there: what if there's an emergency? As they say, no one can hear you scream in space. You can't resuscitate an astronaut with conventional ER techniques which rely on weight and gravity; even a drip won't work.

This is where Fong's vision of a Space Biomedicine Centre comes in: not only will the research be aimed at helping the astronauts on earth as in space, but there could be huge benefits for ground-based medicine.

There is an argument that spending vast sums of money on a few people who have chosen to risk their health is a waste, but Fong disagrees. "The truth is that space technology is the only thing that will drive research rapidly via an interdiscipli nary approach into new directions. We'll be looking at the same problem from lots of different directions, from the point of view of a physicist to an evolutionary biologist, and that doesn't happen often."

For example, Fong has created a portable system to turn non-sterile fluids into fluid so sterile it can be used intravenously. Obviously this is useful for astronauts who could recycle their washing water if need be, but one could imagine the potential of a microfiltration system for field hospitals, in flooded Mozambique, for example.

Telemedicine has recently progressed in leaps and bounds, again, good for surgeons who need to speak to astronauts in space, but equally useful for doctors who want to converse with patients in rural areas.

Much of the research will be particularly useful for patients in intensive care or accident and emergency wards since the focus of many space-age developments is geared towards high level miniaturisation of equipment and, in particular, for gadgets that will monitor patients minute by minute.

Drugs being developed by Nasa to prevent osteoporosis in astronauts could have an immediate impact for sufferers here.

But how do you do research into the effects of space travel without a rocket or an astronaut? Researchers will have to think of some pretty innovative ways of carrying out their studies. Currently ESA is looking at the effects of space travel bone wastage by asking healthy volunteers to spend three months in bed.

The Space Biomedicine Centre is still embryonic: ESA and Nasa are willing to fly lecturers over here and allow students to study over there. However, UCL needs £500,000 to get it going. "This is a screaming opportunity," says Fong, "I wake up in the middle of the night and want to scream what a big opportunity this is."

He points out that Britain used to be very good at tramping all over the globe, painting it pink and erecting flags, but when it comes to the final frontier, the UK is remarkably reticent. After all, there are no aliens on Mars to beat us at cricket.

"We've let ourselves be excluded from the space race,"says Fong. "The future of space exploration is now a global enterprise. For too long we've asked why should we be doing this, and we should be asking, why aren't we doing this?"

"The truth is that space technology is the only thing that will drive research rapidly via an interdiscipli nary approach into new directions. We'll be looking at the same problem from lots of different directions, from the point of view of a physicist to an evolutionary biologist, and that doesn't happen often." For example, Fong has created a portable system to turn non-sterile fluids into fluid so sterile it can be used intravenously. Obviously this is useful for astronauts who could recycle their washing water if need be, but one could imagine the potential of a microfiltration system for field hospitals, in flooded Mozambique, for example. Telemedicine has recently progressed in leaps and bounds, again, good for surgeons who need to speak to astronauts in space, but equally useful for doctors who want to converse with patients in rural areas. Much of the research will be particularly useful for patients in intensive care or accident and emergency wards since the focus of many space-age developments is geared towards high level miniaturisation of equipment and, in particular, for gadgets that will monitor patients minute by minute. Drugs being developed by Nasa to prevent osteoporosis in astronauts could have an immediate impact for sufferers here. But how do you do research into the effects of space travel without a rocket or an astronaut? Researchers will have to think of some pretty innovative ways of carrying out their studies. Currently ESA is looking at the effects of space travel bone wastage by asking healthy volunteers to spend three months in bed. The Space Biomedicine Centre is still embryonic: ESA and Nasa are willing to fly lecturers over here and allow students to study over there. However, UCL needs £500,000 to get it going. He points out that Britain used to be very good at tramping all over the globe, painting it pink and erecting flags, but when it comes to the final frontier, the UK is remarkably reticent. After all, there are no aliens on Mars to beat us at cricket. "We've let ourselves be excluded from the space race,"says Fong. "The future of space exploration is now a global enterprise. For too long we've asked why should we be doing this, and we should be asking, why aren't we doing this?"

fields.headline: Viewers choose ITV over BBC1
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: A week after the BBC's governors criticised BBC1's output for not being up to the mark, figures released yesterday show the channel's approval ratings have also suffered a knock in the past year.
fields.body:
A week after the BBC's governors criticised BBC1's output for not being up to the mark, figures released yesterday show the channel's approval ratings have also suffered a knock in the past year.

Viewers named ITV as their favourite channel, leaving BBC1 trailing. The gap was even wider in homes that do not subscribe to multi-channel television.

The Independent Television Commission research also found that, for the first time, more than half of all households questioned said there was a second television set in a child's bedroom: 53% in 1999, up from 46% the previous year. Among children aged between 12 and 15, the figure rose to 78%.

The BBC was sanguine yesterday, pointing out that the survey asked viewers what they thought rather than what they did.

Researchers asked viewers to name the channel they would keep if they were allowed only one. Last year 41% named ITV, up one point on the previous year, against 30% for BBC1, down five. In terrestrial-only homes, the drop in popularity of BBC1 was even more marked: the gap between ITV (48%) and BBC1 (34%) has more than doubled since 1998. ITV's lead has increased from six to 14 points.
