webTitle: Mandelson seeks middle way in battle for voting reform

fields.headline: Mandelson seeks middle way in battle for voting reform
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson last night warned both sides in the battle over electoral reform for Westminster not to close off options which might enable Britain to create a modern and accountable voting system.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson last night warned both sides in the battle over electoral reform for Westminster not to close off options which might enable Britain to create a modern and accountable voting system.

The Northern Ireland secretary warned passionate supporters of proportional representation that they may have to settle for the alternative vote system rather than a fully-fledged PR model of the kind Charles Kennedy's Liberal Democrats have sought for 70 years.

Mr Mandelson insisted he has not yet made up his mind and Downing Street's spokesman said that "if there was a referendum in the morning I suspect he [Mr Blair] would vote for first past the post [the existing system]".

But the thrust of last night's speech suggests that both men are clearly edging towards a compromise: the AV system which requires voters to pick a second preference and candidates to get more than 50% of the votes cast in order to win.

In a speech to the pro-PR Make Votes Count group Mr Mandelson implicitly appealed to hostile Labour MPs, activists and trade unionists not to use next weekend's national policy forum meeting to reject the case for change.

"Supporters of first past the post should stop presenting the argument as a crude choice between 'change' and 'no change'. There is a world of difference between pure PR and more limited change such as the alternative vote [PR system]," he said.

"And reformers should similarly acknowledge a range of options. They will greatly add to their credibility by acknowledging that the present first past the post system has considerable strengths and merits which we should not lose in any reformed system."

He used his Northern Ireland experience to illustrate how deeply divided communities could benefit from PR to give both sides a real voice in government and even conceded that Welsh and Scottish devolution had also shown how PR systems had helped "give people a greater say". PR could also end local monopolies of power in town halls, he added.

Mr Mandelson surprised some Labour MPs, most of whom are hostile to PR, by indicating that he too rejects that form of government for Westminster - preferring "cooperation, not coalition," he suggested.

"I do not believe that perpetual coalitions make for efficient or effective government," Mr Mandelson said before adding that attempts to "stifle or pre-empt debate" either way would not be in the national interest.

That is a slap in the face to PR campaigners. But Mr Kennedy refused to take offence. He is biding his time, waiting to see how Labour's internal battle resolves itself.

There are strong Labour factions on both sides. "Let's wait and see," one Kennedy aide said last night. Grassroots Lib Dem activists may be less patient as the election approaches - and underline the kind of tactical voting which won the Blair-Ashdown partnership 465 seats in 1997.

Mr Mandelson said: "We cannot simply shut up shop without further debate." But he warned that the choice is not simply between a pure form of PR, the single transferable vote (STV) is what purists favour, or the compromise advocated in 1998 by Lord Jenkins, a former Labour chancellor and SDP leader.

A private adviser to Mr Blair - even though he said last week that the prime minister has a "second class mind" - Lord Jenkins proposed a formula called AV-plus.

That would have seen most of Westminster's MPs, around 500, elected in traditional constituencies in the usual way, except that each MP would need to get 50% of the votes cast. PR purists hate it on the grounds that it can produce even more "unfair" results than first-past-the-post, and would have increased Labour's 1997 landslide. So Lord Jenkins added an element of PR, extra "top up" MPs elected from party lists to make the outcome fairer - much as is now done in Scotland and Wales.

webTitle: Cook cautious over upgrading of warning station for US missile defence shield

fields.headline: Cook cautious over upgrading of warning station for US missile defence shield
fields.trailText: The government would consider "with great care" any request from the US to upgrade the early warning station at Fylingdales, North Yorkshire - needed if America goes ahead with its planned national missile defensive shield - Robin Cook told MPs last night.
fields.body:
The government would consider "with great care" any request from the US to upgrade the early warning station at Fylingdales, North Yorkshire - needed if America goes ahead with its planned national missile defensive shield - Robin Cook told MPs last night.

However, pressed by the Commons foreign affairs committee to state his position on the project, he repeatedly refused to be drawn. It was "impossible to anticipate" the circumstances in which Washington might ask to use Fylingdales for the system, he said.

He referred to negotations between the US and Russia over America's plans to amend the anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty.

In a joint memorandum to the committee, the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence - the former distinctly cooler about the project than the MoD - said that whether or not Russia agreed to amend the ABM treaty, it would not be breached even if the US did go ahead.

This was because either there would be an agreement to amend the treaty, or the US would withdraw from it. If the US did withdraw, "such constraints as the ABM [treaty] currently places on the role of RAF Fylingdales would no longer be operative", the memo said.

Mr Cook said the government had had private talks with the US administration about the threats posed by what until recently Washington has called "rogue" states - including North Korea, Iraq, and Iran - and the impact of America's national missile defence project on existing arms control agreements, including the ABM.

But Mr Cook insisted that the government had not received any formal request from the US administration to use Fylingdales for the project, and so, he said, he "would not speculate on the consequences".

fields.headline: Sir William Glock
fields.standfirst:
His influence on our musical culture was immense, as BBC chief who transformed the Proms and founder of Dartington's summer school
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: His influence on our musical culture was immense, as BBC chief who transformed the Proms and founder of Dartington's summer school
fields.body:
When his period of office at the BBC still had a long time to run, William Glock was called upon to give evidence to the Pilkington committee on the future of radio and television. Committees of inquiry into broadcasting in the early 1960s were no doubt a good deal readier to examine the BBC's occupation of the high ground than they would be now, but when Sir Harry Pilkington popped the question - what did the Controller, Music want to offer listeners? - the reply was startling: "What they will like tomorrow".

It is hard to imagine anyone putting that view about in Broadcasting House now. Yet at a time when its Third Programme flourished, and the BBC was confident in itself, the resolve of Glock, who has died aged 92, carried all before it. More than for anything else he will be remembered for the 13 years he spent reviving the BBC's musical fortunes and restoring the corporation's role as musical patron and a leader of taste. The way he got on with it would make BBC management gasp now - or shudder; indeed, it would be unthinkable. But in a Reithian institution that its first director-general would still have recognised, Auntie gave him his head.

Yet Glock was no demagogue. To the end of his life nothing pleased him more than to share enthusiasms with others. They were born of instinct, insight, taste and judgment, as those of good musicians habitually are, but in his case with a special place reserved for the play of judgment. He had been a fine critic, encouraged first by Richard Capell at the Daily Telegraph, and then invited in 1934 to join the Observer, to which he contributed until 1945. To do one's job in broadcasting, he used to say, was rather like a form of higher criticism: you made choices. He was decisive but not dogmatic, and he was not arrogant. Like Lord Reith, he believed music was for everybody, and his reply to Pilkington had been meant only as shorthand for the notion that it was just as essential, in his view, to create new expectations in listeners as to satisfy the old.

When he went to the BBC, in 1959, Euroscepticism was still rife in the British musical establishment. Glock's appointment perplexed a lot of people, but already an underground movement had been pressing for change. By the time he left, in 1972, the reinvigoration of serious music broadcasting was complete. There had been great days before, and, in Edward Clark, Glock had had a distinguished predecessor whose programming of contemporary music in the years before 1939 was a model of enterprise. But in the period between them, BBC music was becalmed. I remember Peter Heyworth in the Observer in the 1950s berating the old music division for giving us always the latest cow-and-gate cantata and Cheltenham symphony, but rarely the latest Stravinsky. The Proms, BBC music's shop window, took no notice of a young audience growing up musically with the long-playing record - growing up, too, with the Third Programme. The BBC Symphony Orchestra, on its own, carried the burden of the concerts night after night, so no wonder the playing sounded tired. The programmes, too, were tired; in fact they were devised by a committee.

William swept the committee aside, for which he was labelled Hitler by the old guard in Broadcasting House. Yet, prominent as the Proms are, they represent only a fraction of BBC music, and his campaign of re-enlivenment had to be sustained on a broad front. He took charge of the Proms and the BBC Symphony Orchestra's public concerts, but left all the other programmes to his staff. There were no edicts: he gave a lead, but producers had the freedom to pursue enthusiasms he might not have shared at all. Little-Britishers who didn't flourish under his regime have put it about that he operated a "black list", or a cartel of composers who were encouraged over and over again at the expense of others equally deserving. The thrust of Glock's policy was obvious, and omissions there may have been, but the notion of such a list is absurd. The only requirement he made of his staff was that in the building of programmes there should be an effort to combine enterprise and attractivenesss.

As he acknowledged, he was lucky to come to the BBC when so much needed doing. With so much ground to be made up, periods of "creative unbalance", as he called them, could be justified. When he arrived, Schoenberg was rarely broadcast and Stravinsky by no means widely celebrated as a great composer. Webern was waiting for Pierre Boulez to conduct him. The work of Messiaen, Boulez, Berio, Nono, Dallapiccola, Carter, Tippett, Gerhard, Lutoslawski, Stockhausen, Henze and Ligeti needed to be regularly presented in the best performances that could be arranged. And younger composers, British in particular, had to be brought forward.

His transformation of the Proms was not all foreseen from the beginning. To read him in each prospectus during the 14 Glock seasons (1960 to 1973) is to follow his concerns. He introduced foreign conductors (imagine it - there hadn't been any), and foreign orchestras, and made different patterns for the programmes. The fundamental repertory was there, but he complemented it with repertories not previously explored in the concerts. Above all, he was adventurous and looked for what was vital. To recall what took place is to be made aware of what a distinguished musician working in public service broadcasting could achieve.

Before he came to the BBC - at the age of 50 - he was an outsider. He was born in Catford, south-east London: Christ's Hospital and Cambridge, where he read history, contributed something to his formation, though as organ scholar at Gonville & Caius he failed the second part of the examination leading to a degree in music. The college did lend him an excellent Steinway, however. One foggy day early in 1930, a friend suggested they should motor over to Oxford to hear a pianist of whom the friend had heard glowing reports. The journey took six hours and they missed the first work on the programme, but the experience of Artur Schnabel playing the other two - Schubert's late A major sonata and the last sonata of Beethoven - changed Glock's life: "I have always thought with deep gratitude of that foggy drive to Oxford, and of the standards and ideals of music-making it suddenly unfolded, and which I have tried never to lose." From then on, they fuelled his aspirations in everything, and not just as a pianist.

Schnabel was responsible for his next challenge. On a visit to play at the first Edinburgh Festival, in 1947, he made the suggestion that there should be a summer school in England where audiences and young musicians together could hear outstanding performances and attend classes and lectures. He also suggested that Glock, his pupil for three years after that Oxford encounter, would be a good person to direct it. Summer schools were something new, but a financial backer was found and a course established at Bryanston in Dorset the very next year. It moved to Dartington in 1953, where Glock continued to direct it until 1979. From the beginning, he insisted on inviting to it great musicians from abroad as well as from this country. In the first year, the young Amadeus Quartet came, as well as Nadia Boulanger, and Hindemith took the composition class. Boris Blacher was there the next year, and then the greatest instrumental teacher the school ever had, Georges Enesco. There were four recitals by Elisabeth Schumann in 1950 and 1951. In 1957 Stravinsky was a visitor to Dartington for a fortnight. In bringing all this about, Glock's driving concern was that young musicians should be confronted with the highest possible standards, as he had been.

During his BBC years, Dartington remained a fixture in his diary and nothing was allowed to get in its way, not even in the run-up to the Proms. He taught, lectured and performed there, and I often heard him say Dartington was a lifeline - not a sideline - because it kept him in touch with new work and new talent, and new ideas about music, and fed into what he was trying to achieve at the BBC. His editorship of the Score, from 1949, did the same, though after a while it became a casualty of the BBC appointment. It had been a magazine of exceptional quality, preoccupied with ideas rather than facts, with an international readership, and in the dozen years of its existence it caused storms. Through the 1950s it belonged, indeed, to the musical underground where Glock was a key player. He chaired the music section of the Institute of Contemporary Arts and ran the club and restaurant of the International Music Association ("William's cafe", as Sir Isaiah Berlin called it). The IMA was a good centre from which to dream of overthrowing the forces of British provincialism and plot the reform of BBC music division.

It has been said that William Glock had a greater influence on musical culture in post-war Britain than anybody, and perhaps that is true. He would have been happier, I am sure, with a more modest epitaph: that he helped to make the understanding of music more acute. Inside and outside the BBC, he sought constantly for a repertory that was stimulating, and he made a strong commitment to the new, but one might say he did as much for Haydn and Schubert as for Stravinsky and Boulez. As for his BBC legacy, it needs re-articulating and defending by his successors in the same way as John Reith's does; it cannot be denied. More particularly, at the Proms every summer we take it for granted, and there, surely, there can be no going back.

Glock's first marriage, to Clement Davenport, ended in divorce, and his daughter from it, Oriel, died in 1980. He married his second wife, Anne Geoffroy-Dechaume, in 1952, and she died in 1995. He is survived by four step-children: Natalie Davenport from his first marriage, and Nicholas, Sebastian and Veronica Balfour from his second.

He chaired the music section of the Institute of Contemporary Arts and ran the club and restaurant of the International Music Association ("William's cafe", as Sir Isaiah Berlin called it). The IMA was a good centre from which to dream of overthrowing the forces of British provincialism and plot the reform of BBC music division. It has been said that William Glock had a greater influence on musical culture in post-war Britain than anybody, and perhaps that is true. He would have been happier, I am sure, with a more modest epitaph: that he helped to make the understanding of music more acute. Inside and outside the BBC, he sought constantly for a repertory that was stimulating, and he made a strong commitment to the new, but one might say he did as much for Haydn and Schubert as for Stravinsky and Boulez. As for his BBC legacy, it needs re-articulating and defending by his successors in the same way as John Reith's does; it cannot be denied. More particularly, at the Proms every summer we take it for granted, and there, surely, there can be no going back. Glock's first marriage, to Clement Davenport, ended in divorce, and his daughter from it, Oriel, died in 1980. He married his second wife, Anne Geoffroy-Dechaume, in 1952, and she died in 1995. He is survived by four step-children: Natalie Davenport from his first marriage, and Nicholas, Sebastian and Veronica Balfour from his second.  William Frederick Glock, music administrator, born May 3 1908, died June 28 2000

webTitle: Second launch for sun storm satellites

fields.headline: Second launch for sun storm satellites
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: A space mission that went up with a bang four years ago is about to blast off again.
fields.body:
A space mission that went up with a bang four years ago is about to blast off again.

Cluster is a set of four European space satellites that are designed to orbit in tight formation in the wind from the sun, sending early warnings back to earth of the onset of solar storms and lethal radiation.

In 1996 the £400m experiment went up as "ballast" aboard the test flight of the European launcher Ariane V - and both rocket and payload blew up, uninsured, less than a minute after takeoff. A subsequent press release stated that the "Ariane 501 launch did not validate the performance of the launcher", and a British space chief bitterly remarked: "There's no such thing as a free launch."

For a while, European space chiefs and British scientists were stunned by the loss and prepared to write off the project. But, said Paul Murdin of the British national space centre, the scientific questions had not been answered, and the cycle of violence on the sun's surface had become even more of a burning issue.

At intervals the sun ejects sheets of electrically charged fragments of atoms at colossal temperatures and speeds towards earth, crashing into the planet's magnetic shield - and sometimes getting through.

In earlier times it little more than lit up the polar skies with aurorae, the northern lights, but today there is a risk from the storms to high-flying aircraft and to the electronic instruments that are carried in weather, navigation and communication satellites circling the earth.

"The more we know about the conditions in this environment, the better equipped these satellites can be to withstand the onslaught of magnetic and solar storms which can, and indeed do, destroy them," said Hugo Alleyne of the University of Sheffield.

Cluster, with its four satellites flying in tetrahedral formation at between 600km (370 miles) and 6,000km apart at different stages of its orbit, would drift between the sun and the earth, monitoring the flow of hazardous particles in three dimensions, and relaying the information to earth to warn of a storm.

"Of course we are never going to stop the sun from sneezing," said Dr Murdin. "But we could learn what is going on, we could learn how to predict when it is going to sneeze; and then we could turn our heads on one side so we don't catch a cold."

The new Cluster satellites have cost £210m - the engineers did not have to start from scratch with the designs - and will be launched two at a time by Soyuz rockets from Baikonur in Kazakhstan, the first pair being scheduled for early next month.

They will go into an orbit that will reach 100,000km into space - a third of the way to the moon.

There are five other satellites orbiting the sun, but Cluster's synchronised reports will be far more detailed.

"What have previously been just tantalising disturbances when measured from one spacecraft might turn out to be waves or even whirlwinds in space," said Andrew Fazakerley of the Mullard space science laboratory in Surrey. "Cluster will reveal a more complete picture."

webTitle: It came out of the sky

fields.headline: It came out of the sky
fields.standfirst: Duncan Steel  on stones from space rescued from the snow which may hold clues to the secret of life
fields.trailText: Duncan Steel on stones from space rescued from the snow which may hold clues to the secret of life
fields.body:
A natural explosion near the US-Canadian border in January released energy close to that of the Hiroshima nuclear bomb. No one was hurt, although it shook up hundreds of locals. The blast, high in the atmosphere, was the result of the arrival of a 150-ton rock from space.

Meteorites continually cascade down upon Earth. This was a big one. But its scientific importance stems from its composition. It is a member of a rare type known as carbonaceous chondrites.

These get their name from the large amount of carbon they contain, mostly in the form of organic chemicals. Hundreds of amino acids have been identified in the handful of samples found. Mostly black, a fragment held in the hand gives off a smell similar to sulphurous oil. Many researchers believe the basic building blocks of life were delivered to the early earth by such rocks.

This rare group of meteorites is thought to represent the most primitive material in the solar system: the first solid lumps to have coalesced as the sun, then the planets, asteroids and comets formed from a huge cloud of gas and dust about 4.56 billion years ago.

Many small samples have been found through recent searches in the Antarctic. When they arrived is not known, leading to worries about the extent of contamination. That's an especial problem if one is looking for evidence of extraterrestrial life, and the contamination question has been one of the major arguments in the furore over the Martian meteorites.

Nasa announced in 1996 that a meteorite from Mars found in the Antarctic possibly contained microfossils. That basic idea was not new. Back in the 1960s claims were made that carbonaceous chondrites contain microfossils. A few scientists still argue this is so.

From this perspective, any observed carbonaceous chondrite fall is invaluable. There were several in the 19th century, such as the Orgueil meteorite, which landed in France in 1864, then a hiatus. In 1969, two more arrived on opposite sides of the world: at Allende in Mexico, and Murchison in Victoria, Australia.

What happened in Canada? People living in the area where Alaska, British Columbia and the Yukon Territory meet saw the morning sky suddenly light up at 8:43 on January 18, a blue-green streak skimming rapidly over their region. Eye-witnesses described it as 10 times as bright as daylight.

Minutes later the shock wave produced by its destruction about 10 miles up was felt far and wide. US defence surveillance satellites had picked up the flash, the data indicating the energy released to be equivalent to about five kilotons of TNT. The incoming rock must have been five or six yards in size, and travelling at around 10 miles per second as it plunged into the atmosphere.

A week later Canadian outdoorsman Jim Brook was driving his truck home across the frozen expanse of Tagish Lake, about 50 miles south of the town of Whitehorse, when he noticed a multitude of strange black stones. Brook had been keeping his eye open for possible meteorites and, as he related later, he had "already been fooled several times by wolf droppings". But there was no doubt that these were space rocks.

He gathered up a few in the dusk, and returned to collect more the next morning. Researchers in Canada and at Nasa's Johnson Space Center in Houston were alerted, and it soon became apparent that this was a major carbonaceous chondrite fall; hundreds of fragments were spread over an area 10 miles by two.

The first group of scientists arrived in February. A big snowfall on January 27, just after Brook collected his samples, meant there was no chance of finding any meteorites then. But there would be a narrow window of opportunity starting in mid-April, with the spring thaw.

From then until mid-May there was a race against time to collect as many fragments as possible, before the lake became too unstable even to walk on. By the end of May, all the ice melted and drowned the remaining meteorites.

"This is the find of a lifetime," said Peter Brown of the University of Western Ontario, one of the team that recovered the meteorites. "The size of the initial object, the extreme rarity and organic richness of the meteorites combined with the number we have uncovered make this a truly unique event."

About 500 separate samples were spotted, but only 200 collected. The discrepancy was due to the meteorites burying themselves in the ice. Being dark, they absorb most of the sunlight striking them, and so melt their way down.

This, though, is a positive boon from the perspective of avoiding terrestrial contamination: the meteorites had sealed themselves into impervious cocoons of ice, which could be sawn out and kept refrigerated.

Another search team member was the University of Calgary's Alan Hildebrand. A decade ago he was one of the scientists who recognised a huge crater on the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico as the scar from the asteroid or comet impact that seems to have wiped out the dinosaurs 65 million years ago. Now he was working in the frigid conditions of the Yukon. "One day, while I was picking pieces of meteorite out of porous ice, I thought that the experience must be a bit like sampling on the surface of a comet," he commented.

This opportunity represents an extraterrestrial sampling project done at a tiny fraction of the cost of a major space mission. The observations of the meteorite entry have enabled us to determine its original orbit around the sun.

Detailed investigation of the Tagish Lake meteorite may tell us much about the origin of the solar system, and perhaps of life itself. Researchers at the Open University and the Natural History Museum, who will soon receive samples for analysis, are already licking their lips at the prospect.

 Duncan Steel researches asteroids and comets at the University of Salford.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Know your own mother | The eye of the storm
fields.body:
Know your own mother
Scientists think they now know which gene allows you to recognise your own mother. They bred mice which lacked the gene responsible for

producing the brain hormone oxytocin. When compared with normal mice, the "knockout" mice didn't recognise their friends - or enemies, although they were still able to recognise food and remember how to navigate. The study, reported in the July issue of Nature Genetics - timed neatly to the completion of the human genome - could lead to new treatments for autism and schizophrenia.

The eye of the storm
In 1775 a violent storm killed all but 20 of the inhabitants on a tiny island in the Western Pacific. Today, 5% of the 3000 Pingelapese suffer from a rare type of colour blindness and their DNA has helped scientists track down a gene for colour vision. In July's Nature Genetics, the scientists tell how they took DNA from 32 islanders, half of whom had the disorder and spotted a segment of DNA on chromosome 8 that appears in the colour blind inhabitants. The DNA includes a gene responsible for a protein in those eye cells that detect colour. The study "is a beautiful example of the use of isolated populations to study human disease," observes geneticist Val Sheffield.

Saving your liver's bacon
The ancient Greeks were smart. Around 700 BC Hesiod described how each day a giant eagle ate the liver of the chained Prometheus. Each day, he related, the liver replenished itself. We now know how. Scientists from Yale and New York have shown in humans that the new cells do not come from the liver itself, but from stem cells in the bone marrow. For years scientists have debated whether humans have liver stem cells. "The long-held belief has been that bone marrow is supposed toproduce blood cells and liver is supposed to produce liver cells," says Dr Diane Krause. "The goal is now to harness the potential of this exciting find."

fields.headline: Mowlam apology amid royal frugality
fields.standfirst:
Palace reports savings on travel and maintenance
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The royal family may not be about to follow Mo Mowlam's advice and move out of their palaces, but they claimed yesterday that they have done their best to economise.
fields.body:
The royal family may not be about to follow Mo Mowlam's advice and move out of their palaces, but they claimed yesterday that they have done their best to economise.

More than £5m has been shaved off the cost of maintaining them and from their travel expenses in the last year.

After a second day of tabloid outrage at Ms Mowlam's suggestion in an interview with Saga managzine that the palaces were no longer appropriate in the modern world, she yesterday felt the need to issue an apology to the Queen.

The Cabinet Office minister told reporters in Blackpool, where she was attending an Association of Chief Police Officers' conference on drugs: "I apologise for any hurt I have caused." The comments had first been made six years ago and had been in the context of the modernisation of the monarchy, she said. Buckingham Palace was now in the process of modernising.

Asked about her ministerial future she replied: "I have no idea. That's up to Tony Blair." Downing Street made clear that she had not spoken to the prime minister since the furore.

Two reports issued by Buckingham Palace claimed that maintenance of what are quaintly called the Occupied Royal Palaces was cut by £800,000 to £15m last year, nearly £9m down on eight years ago, and that an increased use of chartered helicopters had reduced the cost of travel, from £12.8m to £8.6m.

The savings follow a change three years ago in the mechanism for paying such costs. The money still comes from grants-in-aid from government departments, voted by parliament, but is now administered by the Royal Household.

Sir Michael Peat, keeper of the privy purse (effectively supervisor of the Queen's accounts), claimed that the reports showed good progress.

"These reports demonstrate the Royal Household's commitment to transparency and accountability, and show our determination to achieve value for money without lowering standards," declared Sir Michael.

As part of that commitment, the royal family is making less use of the RAF's 32 Squadron aircraft and more use of its leased Sikorsky helicopter, as well as a further chartered Sikorsky.

The charter use has tripled but the cost of using these helicopters is half that of the RAF Wessex helicopters used previously.

Nonetheless the report, in breaking down official journeys undertaken last year, gives the impression that the family pop into a helicopter as readily as others call taxis.

A trip by the Duke of Edinburgh from Windsor to Worcester for the county's centenary cricket match against the Australians, and on to Buckingham Palace cost £1,186, while the Prince of Wales's return flight from his home at Highgrove to Wembley to present the FA Challenge Cup came in at £1,484.

The cost of the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh's overnight visit by the royal train from Euston to Nottingham last December to visit a shopping centre, the city's hospital, university, and Nottingham Forest FC, came in at £14,200.

The report points out that the train has been cut back to two locomotives and nine carriages from 14 carriages, with only five to eight of the carriages in use at any one time.

Last June, the Princess Royal took a charter flight from Gatcombe to Lymington to attend an event at the Royal Lymington Yacht Club and then to Buckingham Palace at a cost of £3,086.

Her assiduous attendance at all Scotland's international rugby matches, as the team's patron, cost more than £1,000 each time, while flying from Gloucestershire to attend an annual award dinner at Ascot cost £2,621.

For the rugby World Cup final at Cardiff, the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh flew in by BAe 1456, costing £2,559, while the Princess Royal took a helicopter flight from Gloucestershire for £1,223. It cost £1,891 for the Earl of Wessex to use the helicopter to fly to open Middlesex University's millenium real tennis court in January, and it cost £992 for the Queen Mother to hop over from Windsor castle to Cheltenham races to present the Gold Cup at the National Hunt Festival in March.

The Prince of Wales's charter flights to the Caribbean and back on an official visit in February to foster British relations cost £192,500.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Raging Bull | The Deer Hunter | Play It Again Sam | South
fields.body:
Raging Bull

(Martin Scorsese, 1980)

10.50pm, FilmFour

Robert de Niro is awesome as world middleweight champion Jake La Motta in Scorsese's gruelling drama. The boxing scenes are savage, but it's outside the ring, where there's no referee, that he's most frightening, battering loyal brother Joe Pesci and wife Cathy Moriarty as his career takes a dive.

The Deer Hunter

(Michael Cimino, 1978)

1.05am, FilmFour

A moving account of the Vietnam war as experienced by three Pennsylvanian steel workers. Initially dwelling poignantly on a wedding celebration, it plunges into a hellish battle, and grows even darker in an obliterating conclusion. The performances are excellent, from Robert de Niro (pictured) as the survivor through sheer force of will, to Christopher Walken's living dead and the dignified suffering of Meryl Streep's woman back home. Despite shockingly violent images, a residual human warmth lingers.

Play It Again Sam

(Herbert Ross, 1972)

1.35am, Sky Cinema

Delightful homage to Casablanca, adapted from Woody Allen's play. Allen is in his element as the geek and dedicated film buff, dumped by his wife and trying to play the dating game again. The fun really starts when the apparition of Bogart (Jerry Lacy) appears to help him along but, after dallying with married Diane Keaton, he finds a heroism all of his own.

South

(Frank Hurley, 1919)

4.10am, FilmFour

This uplifting eye-witness account of Shackleton's abortive Antarctic expedition of 1914-16 provides a change of tack from FilmFour's heavy-hitting de Niro night. Hurley, the official cinematographer, recorded the last voyage of the Endurance, which was crushed by dense pack ice, leaving 28 men stranded. In the most haunting scenes, the ship stands illuminated by floodlights like a ghastly relic to their ambitions. Incredibly, they all survived, some only to perish in the Great War. Extraordinary.

The fun really starts when the apparition of Bogart (Jerry Lacy) appears to help him along but, after dallying with married Diane Keaton, he finds a heroism all of his own. Hurley, the official cinematographer, recorded the last voyage of the Endurance, which was crushed by dense pack ice, leaving 28 men stranded. In the most haunting scenes, the ship stands illuminated by floodlights like a ghastly relic to their ambitions. Incredibly, they all survived, some only to perish in the Great War. Extraordinary.

webTitle: Editors vow restraint over reporting of adult prince

fields.headline: Editors vow restraint over reporting of adult prince
fields.standfirst:
Press watchdog Lord Wakenham issues warning as Prince William comes of age
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Newspaper editors yesterday pledged continued restraint in their reporting of Prince William, after a call for privacy was made by the chairman of the press complaints commission, Lord Wakeham.
fields.body:
Newspaper editors yesterday pledged continued restraint in their reporting of Prince William, after a call for privacy was made by the chairman of the press complaints commission, Lord Wakeham.

The Queen and the Prince of Wales welcomed the peer's comments, made after consultation with editors, St James's Palace and the prince himself.

Lord Wakeham warned that an endless pursuit of the prince and any girlfriends would make his life a misery. "The absence of paparazzi at Eton during these last five years has been a significant success ... Prince William's 18th birthday is not an invitation for them to return," he said.

The prince can expect to dine in restaurants and walk in private gardens without fear of being photographed. But sitting outside a pub, or out shopping, he could reasonably be pictured.

And while Lord Wakeham conceded there would be interest in future girlfriends, he urged caution. Prince William was entitled to privacy in the same way as any other public figure. "Endless intrusion of the sort we have not seen for five years and the constant, powerful headlamps of unwarranted publicity would make his life a misery, make his friends' lives a misery, and make it much more difficult for him to forge proper and meaningful relationships."

Welcoming the speech, a joint statement by Buckingham Palace and St James's Palace said: "In explaining the terms of the editors' code, Lord Wakeham's speech underlines the importance of personal privacy for all young people - but at the same time recognises the special position of Prince William, and the legitimate public interest in him."

Les Hinton, chairman of the editors' code of practice committee, said that newspapers would take the speech seriously. "It underlines the fact that, although Prince William is now leaving school, he remains entitled to protection from intrusion and harassment under the editors' code. Similarly, Lord Wakeham makes clear that the prince is, of course, also a public figure, and that the manner in which he is photographed and reported will reflect that."

The prince, who turned 18 last Wednesday, leaves Eton today after taking A-levels. He hopes to take a year off before studying history of art at university.

As a minor, he has been protected by the newspaper industry's code of practice. The palace has accepted that there is legitimate public interest in William as second in line to the throne, and, in return for media co-operation, it has set up photocalls which will continue.

Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, said Lord Wakeham's proposals were sensible and realistic.

He added: "The biggest problem for the royal family is not going to be papers like the Mirror paying them too much interest. It will be us paying them too little."

David Yelland, editor of the Sun, said: "The old era of gross invasion of privacy has gone, and I will play no part in bringing it back."

fields.headline: Wizards of the weather
fields.standfirst: Could we make it rain or shine without witchcraft or offerings to the gods? asks  Michael Brooks
fields.trailText: Could we make it rain or shine without witchcraft or offerings to the gods? asks Michael Brooks
fields.body:
Perhaps, in order to get the weather we want for Wimbledon fortnight, we should be ripping the hearts out of virgins.

It worked for the Aztecs: concerned that the sun might not rise the next day, they ensured the new dawn with a ritual evening sacrifice. Not once did they fail to get the result they wanted. Finding periodicity and predictability in the processes of our natural climate is as important to us as it was to the Aztecs, says Michael Ghil, professor of climate dynamics at the University of California, Los Angeles.

Today's meteorologists focus on prediction, rather than the control the Aztecs sought. But the ancient urge may be coming back, Ghil says: improve our understanding of the processes involved, and the weather could eventually be ours to direct.

It's a long-term goal, of course, which will arise from the drive towards more reliable weather predictions. Currently, detailed forecasts are possible over only a few days. Even stretching to 10-day forecasts can be too inaccurate for many circumstances. To do better, Ghil says, we need to follow the example of history and identify the persistent and recurring features in the weather.

All ancient civilisations, he points out, learned astronomy to find out about natural patterns in the sun, moon and weather: with that information they could learn how to adapt and survive. Today, weather researchers use vast supercomputers to process data from satellites, aircraft, ships, drifting buoys and ground stations in an effort to find ways to determine next week's conditions. But as we accumulate decades of detailed information, Ghil says, we will eventually be able to control the weather, not just react to it.

Ghil spoke about his controversial idea earlier this month at a Los Alamos National Laboratory conference on the future impacts of science. He is unapologetic. "We have gradually been controlling more and more of our environment: it's natural that we should want to do this," he says. And with new technology and insights, he believes, it's no longer a pipe dream.

"With the theoretical tools that we now have and additional observations which will accumulate over the next decades, I really believe we are going to make substantial progress on this matter." The process could revolutionise world agriculture, he says. "We can't steer the detailed course of a storm but we should be able to control average temperatures and the length of growing seasons in large areas of the globe."

Ghil wants to exert climate control by controlling the radiation in the atmosphere: incoming radiation from the sun and outgoing radiation from the earth. There are substances in the atmosphere which can be used as "shutters. "Greenhouse" gases such as carbon dioxide tend to keep radiation in. Aerosols high in the atmosphere, on the other hand, keep it out.

With these shutters, Ghil says, it should be possible to control the radiation that heats the earth and oceans and drives our weather systems.

"If we understood all the other things that are happening within the climate system as we play with these shutters, there's no reason why we shouldn't be able to regulate climate - both globally and regionally - fairly effectively," Ghil says.

And, he adds, there should be no need to put additional greenhouse gases or aerosols into the stratosphere. The big stumbling block is that, as yet, we simply don't understand the processes involved in our climate well enough. Interactions between the air and the world's oceans and ice sheets, for example, have influence that scientists are nowhere near fully understanding.

But things are getting better. There has been significant progress in maths and physics, and researchers have gained a much better grasp of the nature of interactions within large natural systems over the last 30 years. Ghil is aware that, in the current environmental and political climate, tinkering with the meteorological climate is controversial, to say the least. But, he says, climate control will only come about because of an entirely justifiable scientific endeavour aiming to understand and predict the weather.

"I think it would be foolish not to stimulate the growth of that knowledge," he says.

When we reach the point where we could take deliberate action to change the weather, global authorities would have to make the decisions: after all, chaos would erupt if Nigeria could award itself more rainfall without paying heed to the consequences for its neighbours. But we might turn a blind eye if someone could switch on the rain when Tim Henman is losing in the fifth set...

fields.headline: Changing wombs
fields.trailText: Borrow A Baby | Wallace And Gromit Go Chicken |
fields.body:
Scheduling throws up some wonderful insights into the national consciousness. After witnessing the lengths to which the government was prepared to go to prevent two gay men from being fathers in Monday night's Real Life, last night we were granted an insight into the ongoing disaster of teenage parenthood in Borrow A Baby (Channel 4). It's worth trotting out the well-worn statistics: Britain has the worst record of teenage pregnancy in Europe, double that of Germany, six times higher than Holland. The government makes noises about wanting to halve it, but what can they do? Nothing short of a bobby in every bedroom, bus stop and bike shed can stop it happening - and yet, on last night's evidence, the children of these teenage unions face a far more perilous future than the off spring of two comfortable gay millionaires.

Borrow A Baby was essentially a light-hearted treatment of the subject, borrowing its format from lifestyle programming. Three sets of parents handed their babies over to three teenagers for the weekend, then watched their progress on CCTV monitors next door.

But despite the frivolous trappings, this was a serious show. The three teenagers chosen for the task lived in Scarborough, a town with an abnormally high incidence of teenage pregnancy, and were all "at risk" in terms of unplanned parenthood. They set about their task with enthusiasm. Zoe, 14, loved babies and was dead keen on having one of her own. Sam, 13, had spent a good deal of time looking after his younger brother. Only Amy, 15, was slightly diffident, and would much rather have been out with her boyfriend.

Babies and carers were introduced on the Friday night (which, naturally, became "Day 1"), and on the following morning were left alone with only a health visitor for company. It was then that reality, in the shape of projectile vomit and mountainous bowel movements, kicked in. Zoe, Sam and Amy fell to pieces. They couldn't get up in the night, and pulled duvets over their heads to block out the sound of crying. They made fundamental errors of hygiene, while health visitors clucked around them like panicking hens. The parents next door went various shades of purple. Zoe was dismissed after only one night; her baby's mother just couldn't stand the anxiety. In the end only Sam, the youngest of the three, made it to "Day 4", by which time he was whey- faced with exhaustion. For these three, the pitfalls of parenthood were over, but God help the millions like them for whom life is not a gameshow.

Omnibus weighed in with Wallace And Gromit Go Chicken (BBC1), a documentary about Aardman Productions' long journey from the bedrooms of Bristol to the boardrooms of Hollywood. In part, this was an affectionate homage to Nick Park, the endearingly goofy director of A Grand Day Out, The Wrong Trousers and A Close Shave, and there was some splendid footage of the animator at home with his father that left little doubt about the original inspiration for Wallace. More surprising was the uneasy alliance between Aardman and DreamWorks, the Hollywood animation giant that offered them a five-picture deal after Park had won his third Oscar. The first fruits of this, Chicken Run, are in multiplexes now - but only just. The transition from small-scale quirkiness to full-blown corporate production line was anything but smooth, and we saw Park shifting uncomfortably in meetings with his Hollywood bosses, furiously doodling Gromit on his notepad, clearly wishing that it would all go away and he'd be left along with his plasticine pals.

DreamWorks head man Jeffrey Katzenberg descended on Bristol every month, inspiring the special kind of energy that only terror can bring. "God help them", muttered Aardman fan Terry Gilliam, who feared that originality would fall victim to commercial pressure. Chicken Run was completed under sweatshop conditions, and there was a barely-repressed sense that it was not a happy experience. Park described it as "creativity with a gun at your head". Mel Gibson (the voice of Rocky the Rooster), Ray Harryhausen and internet film guru Harry Knowles all paid tribute to the genius of Aardman, and yet, for all the enthusiasm, there was a palpable sense of breaths held as Chicken Run went on general release.

fields.headline: Rainbow alliance
fields.standfirst: Why do we think of green as decadent, red as warm and black as glamorous?  Jonathan Jones continues his search for the meaning of beauty
fields.trailText: Why do we think of green as decadent, red as warm and black as glamorous? Jonathan Jones continues his search for the meaning of beauty
fields.body:
Oscar Wilde - now there was a man you could ask about beauty. In 1882, as reporters mobbed him on a ship in New York harbour, he delivered a perfectly cadenced lecture. "I am here to diffuse beauty," he said. "Beauty is nearer than most of us are aware. It's a wide field which has no limit, and all definitions are unsatisfactory. Some people might search and not find anything. But the search, if carried on according to right laws, would constitute aestheticism."

Wilde was wearing a green dressing gown as he polished off these remarks. Green was his colour - decadent, provocative. He told his followers in the Aesthetic Movement to wear green carnations supplied by his florist, Goodyears: "They grow them there."

Flamboyant colour has always been associated with the pursuit of the beautiful, with aestheticism, with hedonist visual pleasure. Think of Matisse and his painting The Red Studio, in which every object in the room is choreographed to the rhythm of an overwhelming red; the boundaries of walls, a table and a clock are visible only as traces in redness. Think of the old, sick Matisse lying in bed and directing his assistants to manipulate pieces of coloured paper to create The Snail. The very vocabulary of colour is saturated in ideas of beauty; the word "hue" comes from the Old English for "beauty".

John Gage, reader in the history of western art at Cambridge and the world's leading authority on colour, is an art historian who writes about art sensuously. In fact, he writes about it so sensuously that his books are prose poems, fantasias of colour disguised as academic texts. And Gage is wonderful to talk to. He discusses modern art and medieval stained glass with the same precision, describing the way artists use colour so acutely that he changes the way you look at art - you see more colours. When asked to explain the way Mark Rothko manipulates our emotions with colour in the Seagram Murals at Tate Modern, he says, "The Seagram things use an extremely low tone, and also very close tones - rather light, fiery elements in a few places. The overall tone is dark purple, black, blackish, very dark reds - colours that are very closely related to each other. Close [colour] relationships seem to induce a feeling of reverie or melancholy, whereas high contrast has the capacity to wake one up a bit."

There's more than a hint of the aesthete about Gage - he wanted to be a painter when he was young - and he talks with a deep sense of the joy of art. But he says I've come to the wrong place in my search for a definition of beauty. It's not his thing, because he's not a formalist. In art theory formalism is the doctrine - propagated by the Bloomsbury critic Roger Fry - that the value of art lies entirely in its formal properties. Formalism and the attitude it implies - that the love of art has nothing to do with everyday life and that art lovers are special people able to rise above the mess of existence - epitomise everything that has given the worship of beauty a bad name.

Matisse notoriously said he wanted his art to be like an armchair for a tired businessman - a place of luxury and intellectual rest. The way Matisse surrenders to colour, dives into colour, looks like the very definition of an art that leaves us with nothing to say but, "That's beautiful." Nonsense, says Gage. The unruly colours with which Matisse infused everything and that won him and his close associates Derain and Vlaminck the nickname "fauves" - wild beasts - deliberately evoke the way people play with colour in everyday life, especially in their clothes. "Matisse makes a lot of play with the colour of dress," he says. "If people use the Fauves as the indication that colour has floated free of representation, I find that extremely hard."

Colour moves us, Gage argues, because history saturates it with associations, connotations, symbolism. We're always talking about colour as if its impact on us was fixed and natural. We talk about red being a hot, warm colour, and blue cool, refreshing. But there's nothing natural or permanent about such ideas: the first mentions date from the 18th century. The meaning we attribute to light and darkness - associating light with joy, freedom, heaven - dates from the Renaissance.

Early medieval churches used heavily coloured stained glass to create a mystical gloom. In the late middle ages and the Renaissance there was a new cult of light: colours were praised according to how "luminous" they looked; painters learned to make the blue of the sky come alive, as it does in Titian's (restored) Bacchus and Ariadne in the National Gallery. Light was associated with "laughter", as can be seen in the oculus, the opening in the ceiling, that Mantegna painted in the ducal palace at Mantua, which has the celestial beings looking down from their world of blue light, laughing.

There are many histories of blue. In the 60s Yves Klein patented YKB, Yves Klein Blue, and used it in monochrome canvases and to cover everyday objects, which, by that gesture, were transformed into symbols. "Klein chose a colour that has an extraordinary resonance in Europe," says Gage. "It's a sort of ultramarine blue - it's got a slight reddish cast to it - and of course that has longstanding connotations of the divine, of the transcendental."

Klein's blue is a blue of darkness rather than light: it's the sublime blue of inner experience. Derek Jarman confirmed the poetic power of blue in his film Blue, about his experience of Aids and losing his sight. Gage praises Jarman's book on colour, Chroma (1994), as more useful than many scientific works on the subject, in the way it relates colours to personal history.

Black, says Gage, has often been considered the finest colour. From 15th-century nobles showing off their austere robes, to Coco Chanel, wearing black has been a way of marking yourself out from the crowd. "Black has always been a sign of high value, partly because it's extremely hard to produce a good black in clothes. It's extremely hard to keep clean and so it's an index of taking care of yourself, which is a rather smart thing to do."

Black is beautiful, black is aesthetic. Manet's group portrait The Balcony (1868-9) celebrates the sartorial grandeur of black by showing his friend Antoine Guillemet in a black coat before a black background. Yet Matisse, the supreme modern aesthete, exploited the frightening symbolism of blackness. In one of his essays Gage demonstrates how Matisse, in his 1914 painting French Window - Collioure, transformed the middle-class balcony scene into an image of the horror he saw ahead as Europe went to war. The painting shows two blue panel blinds swung open to reveal nothing but blackness - a "luminous" black as Gage calls it.

For all his scepticism, Gage gives an exciting description of the emotional impact of the beautiful. "It is all over the place - and in very surprising places," he says. "And because it's not the sort of subject that is talked about very much nowadays we don't actually have to engage very much with it, do we? In visual art it's become extremely unfashionable. I suppose architects do have a sneaking interest in it from time to time. Elegance is certainly something that I recognise - an economy of means. But beauty, I think, has to have more. It has to knock you off your feet a bit..."

Gage's writing demonstrates that even the most knock-you-off-your feet, contentless abstract painting, the emptiest wall of pure colour, delivers more than a rush. It connects you to the world.

 Next week, cultural critic Laura Mulvey. John Gage's books Colour and Meaning (£19.95) and Colour and Culture (£29.95) are both published by Thames and Hudson.

But he says I've come to the wrong place in my search for a definition of beauty. It's not his thing, because he's not a formalist. In art theory formalism is the doctrine - propagated by the Bloomsbury critic Roger Fry - that the value of art lies entirely in its formal properties. Formalism and the attitude it implies - that the love of art has nothing to do with everyday life and that art lovers are special people able to rise above the mess of existence - epitomise everything that has given the worship of beauty a bad name. Matisse notoriously said he wanted his art to be like an armchair for a tired businessman - a place of luxury and intellectual rest. The way Matisse surrenders to colour, dives into colour, looks like the very definition of an art that leaves us with nothing to say but, "That's beautiful." Nonsense, says Gage. The unruly colours with which Matisse infused everything and that won him and his close associates Derain and Vlaminck the nickname "fauves" - wild beasts - deliberately evoke the way people play with colour in everyday life, especially in their clothes. "Matisse makes a lot of play with the colour of dress," he says. "If people use the Fauves as the indication that colour has floated free of representation, I find that extremely hard." Colour moves us, Gage argues, because history saturates it with associations, connotations, symbolism. We're always talking about colour as if its impact on us was fixed and natural. We talk about red being a hot, warm colour, and blue cool, refreshing. But there's nothing natural or permanent about such ideas: the first mentions date from the 18th century. The meaning we attribute to light and darkness - associating light with joy, freedom, heaven - dates from the Renaissance. Early medieval churches used heavily coloured stained glass to create a mystical gloom. In the late middle ages and the Renaissance there was a new cult of light: colours were praised according to how "luminous" they looked; painters learned to make the blue of the sky come alive, as it does in Titian's (restored) Bacchus and Ariadne in the National Gallery. Light was associated with "laughter", as can be seen in the oculus, the opening in the ceiling, that Mantegna painted in the ducal palace at Mantua, which has the celestial beings looking down from their world of blue light, laughing. There are many histories of blue. In the 60s Yves Klein patented YKB, Yves Klein Blue, and used it in monochrome canvases and to cover everyday objects, which, by that gesture, were transformed into symbols. "Klein chose a colour that has an extraordinary resonance in Europe," says Gage. "It's a sort of ultramarine blue - it's got a slight reddish cast to it - and of course that has longstanding connotations of the divine, of the transcendental." Klein's blue is a blue of darkness rather than light: it's the sublime blue of inner experience. Derek Jarman confirmed the poetic power of blue in his film Blue, about his experience of Aids and losing his sight. Gage praises Jarman's book on colour, Chroma (1994), as more useful than many scientific works on the subject, in the way it relates colours to personal history. Black, says Gage, has often been considered the finest colour. From 15th-century nobles showing off their austere robes, to Coco Chanel, wearing black has been a way of marking yourself out from the crowd. "Black has always been a sign of high value, partly because it's extremely hard to produce a good black in clothes. It's extremely hard to keep clean and so it's an index of taking care of yourself, which is a rather smart thing to do." Black is beautiful, black is aesthetic. Manet's group portrait The Balcony (1868-9) celebrates the sartorial grandeur of black by showing his friend Antoine Guillemet in a black coat before a black background. Yet Matisse, the supreme modern aesthete, exploited the frightening symbolism of blackness. In one of his essays Gage demonstrates how Matisse, in his 1914 painting French Window - Collioure, transformed the middle-class balcony scene into an image of the horror he saw ahead as Europe went to war. The painting shows two blue panel blinds swung open to reveal nothing but blackness - a "luminous" black as Gage calls it. For all his scepticism, Gage gives an exciting description of the emotional impact of the beautiful. "It is all over the place - and in very surprising places," he says. "And because it's not the sort of subject that is talked about very much nowadays we don't actually have to engage very much with it, do we? In visual art it's become extremely unfashionable. I suppose architects do have a sneaking interest in it from time to time. Elegance is certainly something that I recognise - an economy of means. But beauty, I think, has to have more. It has to knock you off your feet a bit..." Gage's writing demonstrates that even the most knock-you-off-your feet, contentless abstract painting, the emptiest wall of pure colour, delivers more than a rush. It connects you to the world.  Next week, cultural critic Laura Mulvey. John Gage's books Colour and Meaning (£19.95) and Colour and Culture (£29.95) are both published by Thames and Hudson.

fields.headline: Move to counter steroid abuse
fields.standfirst:
Drugs in Britain: special report
The issue explained: Drugs in sport
fields.trailText: The General Medical Council is to issue new guidelines on the prescription of performance-enhancing drugs after claims that almost one in 10 British bodybuilders takes steroids and that needle exchange programmes set up for heroin addicts are being used by sportsmen.
fields.body:
The General Medical Council is to issue new guidelines on the prescription of performance-enhancing drugs after claims that almost one in 10 British bodybuilders takes steroids and that needle exchange programmes set up for heroin addicts are being used by sportsmen.

Dr Jane Milson from Grimsby told the British Medical Association conference in London that a survey showed 9% of bodybuilders were using anabolic steroids. She had been "shocked" to discover bodybuilders were using the needle exchange schemes.

One pharmacist running such a scheme regularly saw 25 bodybuilders, who came to him for clean needles, she said.

Doctors need more information about the extent of the drug abuse, she said. Doctors and bodybuilders were not sufficiently aware of the risks involved.

"Doctors may not be aware of the substances they may be using and the short- and long-term consequences of their use," Dr Milson said.

"When patients present themselves with the possible symptoms of performance-enhancing drugs we need to be in a position to advise them.

"There are an increasing array of substances that they may choose from and some cause minor side effects, some are potentially lethal."

One "extremely concerning" development was the alleged use of growth hormones to boost performance, she said. People taking legally prescribed growth hormones have been affected by CJD, and their use is strictly controlled.

Dr Milson called on the BMA to develop through the Board of Sciences and Education a policy on the use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport. The motion was carried overwhelmingly.

Side effects of steroid use range from acne and premature baldness to renal damage, impotence, sterility and shrinkage of the testes. It can also provoke psychological symptoms such as impulsive aggression and emotional instability.

The GMC guidelines will for the first time threaten doctors with dismissal if they "prescribe or collude in the provision of drugs or treatment with the intention of improperly enhancing an individual's performance in sport".

But doctors would not face being struck off the medical register in cases where they were believed to have acted to "protect or improve the patient's health".

Dr Evan Lloyd, chairman of the British Association of Sports and Exercise Medicine, said this clause could ease the dilemma faced by doctors who might prescribe steroid users smaller doses in an effort to wean them off the drugs gradually, rather than risk them rejecting all treatment.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Je, Guillaume | First Ladies
fields.body:
Radio 3's evening is devoted to the work of the 14th century cleric, poet and composer Guillaume de Machaut. Je, Guillaume (7.30pm, Radio 3) features readings of his verse, mostly dedicated to courtly love, and performances of his Ars Nova music by the Orlando Consort. Remarkably, all his scores have been preserved in different European countries for the past seven centuries.

Hillary Clinton may be the first presidential wife to try forging her own political career but, as Anthony Howard notes in First Ladies (8.0pm, Radio 4), that doesn't mean her predecessors have lacked political clout. Here Howard recalls Eleanor Roosevelt. Her husband's paralysis required her to act as his eyes and ears around the country - and she was rarely coy about presenting her own conclusions.

fields.headline: No: 1666
fields.standfirst: David LaChapelle
fields.trailText: David LaChapelle
fields.body:
Which one's David? The woman or the snake?
The woman's Liz Hurley, undistinguished actress and national icon. The snake's the kind of thing she's gotta do these days to keep herself in the papers.

Like this one?
Yup.

So where's David? Is he out of the picture?
No, Hugh's out of the picture.

Explain please.
Liz has recently split from Hugh Grant, floppy-fringed boyfriend of 13 years. Of her new-found freedom, she says: "I'd love to be swept off my feet and to gallop wildly into the sunset."

On a horse, presumably.
Or on David LaChapelle. The perfume purveyor interrupted her first post-split interview to receive David's phone call, which she greeted with the words: "I'd love to see you again! Goodie, goodie gumdrops! That would be fabulous!"

Gumdrops?
A sweet-but-throwaway confection often presented in garish wrapping.

A bit like Liz herself!
Boom boom.

So give me la spiel on LaChapelle.
Liz's latest is a hip fashion photographer, whose penchant for snapping the stars against surreal fantasy backdrops has earned him the sobriquet "the genre's Magritte". And he was responsible for the notorious Rolling Stone cover on which schoolgirl Britney Spears frolicked lewdly with a Teletubby.

How dare he?!
"I like to see outrageousness and sexiness and things that are out of control," says Dave. "Dreams should be part of our everyday life."

Does anyone take him seriously?
Says the blurb in one of his exhibition catalogues: "Performance obliterates banality, just like Drew Barrymore's breasts can become grapefruit halves with a cherry; we hear the distant echoes of Lewis Carroll; eat me, drink me, big becomes small."

Don't employ as:
Your wedding photographer.

Do employ as:
An excuse to print pictures in a national newspaper of a near-naked Liz Hurley getting slinky with a snake.

Not to be confused with:
David Bailey, Danny la Rue, the Sistine Chapel.

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: The internet is not killing off conversation but actively encouraging it
fields.trailText: The internet is not killing off conversation but actively encouraging it says, Douglas Rushkoff
fields.body:
However vehemently today's web enthusiasts proclaim that "content is king", I suspect very few have stopped to consider just what this stuff called content really is. If it's anything at all.

Take any well-branded cereal, for instance - one of those packages of sugar-coated corn meal with a recognisable cartoon character mascot on the box. What's the content there: the cereal, or the cartoon character?

Is the animal cartoon a communicator of the product's brand image, or is the food itself merely a medium through which the character is communicated? It's a tricky distinction. When my father was growing up, bubblegum companies competed by offering free trading cards inside their packages. Little pieces cardboard with the images of baseball players proved the most successful, and soon children were buying whole packs of baseball cards with only a single stick of bubble gum.

Today, baseball cards are sold without any bubblegum at all. Despite gum's textural attributes, baseball cards proved to be the "stickier" content. Why? Because it provides a richer media experience. Not only can collectors look at pictures, but they can compare and analyse the statistics of each player as chronicled on the card's back.

More importantly, this depth of data allows the card to serve as what I've started to call "social currency." While children can debate the merits of one brand of gum over another for only so long, they can talk endlessly about the players' whose cards they've collected, trade them, or even just peruse one another's collections.

See, the cards aren't really ends in themselves; they are the basis for human interaction. Johnny got some new cards, so the other kids come over to see them after school. The cards are social currency.

We think of a medium as the thing that delivers content. But the delivered content is a medium in itself. Content is just a medium for interaction between people. The many forms of content we collect and experience online, I'd argue, are really just forms of ammunition - something to have when the conversation goes quiet at work the next day; an excuse to start a discussion with that attractive person in the next cubicle: "Hey! Did you see that streaming video clip at streamingvideoclips.com?"

Social currency is like a good joke. When a bunch of friends sit around and tell jokes, what are they really doing? Entertaining one another? Sure, for a start. But they are also using content - mostly unoriginal content that they've heard elsewhere - in order to lubricate a social occasion. And what are most of us doing when we listen to a joke? Trying to memorise it so that we can bring it somewhere else. The joke itself is social currency.

"Invite Harry. He tells good jokes. He's the life of the party."

Think of this the next time you curse that onslaught of email jokes cluttering up your inbox. The senders think they've given you a gift, but all they really want is an excuse to interact with you. If the joke is good enough, this means the currency is valuable enough to earn them a response.

That's why the most successful TV shows, web sites, and music recordings are generally the ones that offer the most valuable forms of social currency to their fans. Sometimes, like with mainstream media, the value is its universality.

In the US right now, the quiz show Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?" is enjoying tremendous ratings because it gives its viewers something to talk about with one another the next day. It's a form of mass spectacle. And, not coincidentally, what is the object of the game? To demonstrate one's facility with a variety of forms of social currency!

Contestants who can answer a long stream of questions about everything from sports and movies to science and history, are rewarded with a million dollars. They are social currency champions. Content on the web is no different. Sure, the internet allows people to post their own content or make their own web sites.

But what do most people really do with this opportunity? They share the social currency they have collected through their lives, in the form of Brittney Spears fan sites or collections of illegally gathered MP3's of popular songs. The myth of the internet - and one I believed for a long time - is that most people really want to share the stories of their own lives.

The fact that "content is king" proves that they don't. They need images, stories, ideas, and sounds through which they can relate to one another. The only difference between the internet and its media predecessors is that the user can collect and share social currency in the same environment. Those of you who think you are creating online content, take note: your success will be directly dependent on your ability to create excuses for people to talk to one another. For the real measure of content's quality is its ability to serve as a medium.

fields.headline: Labour critic backtracks
fields.trailText: Outspoken former minister Peter Kilfoyle is to tone down his criticism of Tony Blair and Labour to concentrate his fire on William Hague and the Conservatives.
fields.body:
Outspoken former minister Peter Kilfoyle is to tone down his criticism of Tony Blair and Labour to concentrate his fire on William Hague and the Conservatives.

The Liverpool Walton MP, who spectacularly quit his defence post earlier this year after growing disillusioned with the government's direction, has been wooed by Millbank.

Mr Kilfoyle is to team up with Tory-turned-Labour MP Shaun Woodward and Blairite MP Fraser Kemp to write what he promises will be a "devastating blast" against Mr Hague and the rightwing. The book has the backing of the Labour leadership and marks a thawing in relations with the party hierarchy. The MP has remained friendly with Margaret McDonagh, Labour's general secretary.

Since he resigned from the government, Mr Kilfoyle has been one of the government's most trenchant critics, arguing it was neglecting traditional Labour voters and had turned its back on pensioners.

A series of speeches in Labour heartlands by Mr Kilfoyle to win back disaffected voters is also under consideration. A parliamentary colleague yesterday said he wanted to remain free to criticse the Labour leadership but would make clear who he regards the "real enemy" to be.

Earlier this year Mr Kilfoyle ridiculed Mr Blair's assertion there was no north-south divide, condemned Gordon Brown's 75p rise for pensioners, complained about NHS and education spending, dismissed electoral reform as "futile" and warned Labour voters were turning away "in droves... they see nothing in it for them."
