fields.headline: William and his girls
fields.standfirst: Press watchdog John Wakeham explains how he will protect the young prince from prying cameras
fields.trailText: Press watchdog John Wakeham explains how he will protect the young prince from prying cameras
fields.body:
Prince William leaves school this week. This has inevitably led to speculation about how the press will respect his privacy away from the security of the school environment.

There are wildly different expectations of what the future offers. One American commentator recently said that once Prince William was 18 he would be "fair game". At the other end of the spectrum is the view that there will be "no change" - that Prince William will still be entitled to the very substantial degree of protection that he was afforded at school.

The truth is between the two. He must absolutely not be "fair game", but at the same time, things will change. He has left school, he is growing up and has become a young adult. He is increasingly becoming a public figure, and the way the press covers him will reflect that.

No one is asking for special treatment for the prince. The principles in the newspaper editors' code of practice apply to everyone else as much as to him.

Editors want to continue to make things work, and to ensure that Prince William gets as much privacy as he can, while also ensuring that their readers can read about him and see pictures of him. None of them wants him to become the subject of endless, prurient intrusion - and all of them acknowledge that he has a right to a private life.

There will inevitably be more stories written about Prince William. While older members of the Royal Family may attract a degree of speculation and conjecture in stories about them, a public figure like Prince William who is also a very young man should be entitled to expect that things that are written about him are accurate.

He should not have to read about how he is part of a so-called set that is involved with drugs when he has never been part of that set. He should not have to read about family arguments that he is purported to have had when he hasn't had them. He should not have to read about how he is having a relationship with a girl that he has never met. Such inaccuracies create a misleading impression, and mud sticks.

The code of practice makes clear that everyone is entitled to respect for his or her private life. But we have to recognise that the prince is different to other people simply because of his position. That means there will be legitimate public interest in stories about him and pictures of him.

Private life includes someone's family life; their health; personal correspondence; telephone conversations; space at times of grief and shock; and pictures taken in private places. It also includes a degree of special protection from physical intrusion when someone is in hospital (although I can see occasions when a report about the prince's health may well be in the public interest, and the code allows for that).

Beyond those categories, newspaper editors will exercise their usual judg ment on what constitutes someone's private life. But there are going to be significant areas of the prince's life that can be reported, such as any job he might undertake in his gap year, or any charity events he participates in.

Inevitably, the question will be asked - I seem to have been answering it for years - about how newspapers should deal with stories of a romantic nature.

I know of three cases where newspapers have linked Prince William romantically to three different girls. In two cases, he had never met them; in one case, he had met the girl once.

Such fundamental inaccuracies are unacceptable - and are damaging, quite apart from anything else, to the poor girls in question, who may already have relationships of their own. It can't be acceptable for any newspaper or magazine to deduce a "relationship" solely from the fact of his being seen on his own with a girl in public.

That said, if a story is accurate, then a newspaper should consider - as in any case relating to personal privacy - whether there is either consent, or the material is in the public domain or there is sufficient and genuine public interest under the code.

As far as young people are concerned privacy means, probably more than anything else, that they must have the right to grow up and form relationships without having to read about them week in and week out in the newspapers. Endless intrusion and the constant, powerful headlamps of unwarranted publicity would make his life a misery, make his friends' lives a misery and make it much more difficult for him to forge proper relationships.

The question of what photographs of Prince William will be published is the most important one. From today, he will cease to benefit from the protection provided by the code and he can expect to be photographed in public places like any other young adult. Newspaper readers are going to be seeing somewhat more of him.

W hile Prince William has been at school, the code has been very clear on the issue of photography and physical intrusion. Now that those specific provisions no longer apply to him, the code is no less clear on the general issue of harassment. Neither I, nor the editors I have discussed this with, can foresee any circumstances in which it will be justifiable to publish pictures of Prince William that have been obtained as a result of intimidation or harassment or persistent pursuit.

Like other public figures, there should be no publication of snatched pictures of the prince taken when he is somewhere where there is a reasonable expectation of privacy - in private gardens, in restaurants and so on.

It would be quite unacceptable for paparazzi photographers to pursue Prince William around whichever uni versity he attends - and quite unacceptable for newspapers to publish photographs which have been obtained in this manner. The absence of paparazzi at Eton during these last five years has been a significant success. Prince William's 18th birthday is not an invitation for them to return. The PCC will come down hard on the publication of any pictures of Prince William that has been obtained through intimidation or persistent pursuit - just as we would for any other individual.

That will be easier if there is continuing cooperation between the press and St James's Palace to ensure that the public sees and reads about Prince William's progress and that what is written about him is accurate.

The palace fully understands that point and has made clear that, during his gap year and then during his time at university, regular facilities for the media will be made available to record his progress and continuing education.

That way, the successful balance we have achieved over the last five years can be maintained. There will be four winners. One will, of course, be Prince William. fields.bodyText: Prince William leaves school this week. This has inevitably led to speculation about how the press will respect his privacy away from the security of the school environment. There are wildly different expectations of what the future offers. One American commentator recently said that once Prince William was 18 he would be "fair game". At the other end of the spectrum is the view that there will be "no change" - that Prince William will still be entitled to the very substantial degree of protection that he was afforded at school. The truth is between the two. He must absolutely not be "fair game", but at the same time, things will change. He has left school, he is growing up and has become a young adult. He is increasingly becoming a public figure, and the way the press covers him will reflect that. No one is asking for special treatment for the prince. The principles in the newspaper editors' code of practice apply to everyone else as much as to him. Editors want to continue to make things work, and to ensure that Prince William gets as much privacy as he can, while also ensuring that their readers can read about him and see pictures of him. None of them wants him to become the subject of endless, prurient intrusion - and all of them acknowledge that he has a right to a private life. There will inevitably be more stories written about Prince William. While older members of the Royal Family may attract a degree of speculation and conjecture in stories about them, a public figure like Prince William who is also a very young man should be entitled to expect that things that are written about him are accurate. He should not have to read about how he is part of a so-called set that is involved with drugs when he has never been part of that set. He should not have to read about family arguments that he is purported to have had when he hasn't had them. He should not have to read about how he is having a relationship with a girl that he has never met. Such inaccuracies create a misleading impression, and mud sticks. The code of practice makes clear that everyone is entitled to respect for his or her private life. But we have to recognise that the prince is different to other people simply because of his position. That means there will be legitimate public interest in stories about him and pictures of him. Private life includes someone's family life; their health; personal correspondence; telephone conversations; space at times of grief and shock; and pictures taken in private places. It also includes a degree of special protection from physical intrusion when someone is in hospital (although I can see occasions when a report about the prince's health may well be in the public interest, and the code allows for that). Beyond those categories, newspaper editors will exercise their usual judg ment on what constitutes someone's private life. But there are going to be significant areas of the prince's life that can be reported, such as any job he might undertake in his gap year, or any charity events he participates in. Inevitably, the question will be asked - I seem to have been answering it for years - about how newspapers should deal with stories of a romantic nature. I know of three cases where newspapers have linked Prince William romantically to three different girls. In two cases, he had never met them; in one case, he had met the girl once. Such fundamental inaccuracies are unacceptable - and are damaging, quite apart from anything else, to the poor girls in question, who may already have relationships of their own. It can't be acceptable for any newspaper or magazine to deduce a "relationship" solely from the fact of his being seen on his own with a girl in public. That said, if a story is accurate, then a newspaper should consider - as in any case relating to personal privacy - whether there is either consent, or the material is in the public domain or there is sufficient and genuine public interest under the code. As far as young people are concerned privacy means, probably more than anything else, that they must have the right to grow up and form relationships without having to read about them week in and week out in the newspapers. Endless intrusion and the constant, powerful headlamps of unwarranted publicity would make his life a misery, make his friends' lives a misery and make it much more difficult for him to forge proper relationships. The question of what photographs of Prince William will be published is the most important one. From today, he will cease to benefit from the protection provided by the code and he can expect to be photographed in public places like any other young adult. Newspaper readers are going to be seeing somewhat more of him. W hile Prince William has been at school, the code has been very clear on the issue of photography and physical intrusion. Now that those specific provisions no longer apply to him, the code is no less clear on the general issue of harassment. Neither I, nor the editors I have discussed this with, can foresee any circumstances in which it will be justifiable to publish pictures of Prince William that have been obtained as a result of intimidation or harassment or persistent pursuit. That way, the successful balance we have achieved over the last five years can be maintained. There will be four winners. One will, of course, be Prince William. Another will be newspapers and magazines which, by continuing to respect his privacy, will demonstrate that the media can act responsibly and sensitively and that self-regulation really works. Another will be the public, which has consistently made clear that they want to see Prince William grow up with as much privacy as possible. fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
If there's one thing no intelligent reader can ever have enough of, it's articles by media smartarses about their heroic cocaine consumption at the Groucho Club. It's just so unbelievably fascinating. After Will Self got the ball rolling, Julie Burchill weighed in with tales of her staggering appetite, which in turn prompted Will's wife Deborah Orr to entrance Independent readers with accounts of coke-fuelled Groucho nights with Will and Julie. Nimbly sensing a gap in the market, Jules came back with her recollections of powered Groucho nights with Debs and Will. Now, also in the Indie, John Walsh records a feud between Julie and former Groucho waitress Deborah Bosley over who ingested more illegal drugs. Magnificent. Just one small question. Why does a police force that used to raid the Mangrove in Notting Hill for two micro-grains of hash never go near a club whose members boast daily of prodigious Class A activity? Is there some secret amnesty, or are officers scared off by the prospect of encountering Janet Street-Porter at the bar with a Pet Shop Boy or two? Most bizarre. And yet it's oddly comforting to know that there is a corner of Dean Street that will forever be Colombia.

 A letter arrives from Diary vicar the Rev Steve Chalke. "I hope you'll forgive the direct approach," it begins, "but I'm writing about another book I'm putting together, entitled Parent Talk - A Sideways Glance at the Art of Being a Parent." Yes? "The idea is to celebrate family life in a light-hearted way, with all its ups and downs but most often just plain 'quirkiness', and I would love you to feature." God be merciful, Steve wants "a short anecdote or a piece of parenting advice" - from me. Me. Reverend, let me have a little think about it and I'll get back to you.

 On Monday lunchtime, Labour MP George Galloway addressed a meeting at the British Medical Association conference in London about the effects of sanctions on Iraq. In a select audience, two men at the back taking notes, but with no visible conference credentials, stood out - and when confronted they admitted to being from Special Branch. They were attending, they said, through concern about Arab doctors being "intimidated by the regime". George plans to raise the matter in the Commons, asking how London came to be so crime-free that the Met could spare Special Branch officers for public meetings concerning health issues in foreign lands.

 I am concerned by an omission in Garry Bushell's TV column in the Sun: there is no mention this week of the mysterious comedian Mick Pugh, whose career was thought close to taking off after almost weekly mentions in the Currant Bun for about six or seven years. We tried to contact Mr Bushell but, like his editor, he seems strangely reluctant to talk.

 Tory frontrunner David Wilshire suffers a reverse in his Stupidest MP 2000 bid. He appears to have dropped his attempt to bully local Labour agent, Harold Trace, into apologising for a local newspaper letter attacking him for alleged scaremongering about the hospital at which Mr Trace is treated for cancer. "Why have I not heard from you in respect of the defamation action which you threatened?" Mr Trace asks the Spelthorne MP in a thus far unanswered letter. "Your ultimatum number one expired on May 19 2000. Ultimatum number two expired on June 10 2000." If Mr Wilshire wishes to pip the other contenders to the title, he ought to resume making legal threats at once.

 A thief has died trying to flee an art museum in Bonn. Peter Gruber panicked after being surprised by a security guard at the Klausmann Museum of Art and when he raced around a corner, impaled himself upon a 4ft-long sword held by a statue of a blindfolded soldier. The exhibit is called the Weapon of Justice.

webTitle: Lib Dems claim health cover-up in new spin row

fields.headline: Lib Dems claim health cover-up in new spin row
fields.trailText: Tony Blair faced renewed embarrassment over spin yesterday when leaked government documents showed that ministers are drawing up plans to bury news of a drop in funding for a flagship health initiative.
fields.body:
Tony Blair faced renewed embarrassment over spin yesterday when leaked government documents showed that ministers are drawing up plans to bury news of a drop in funding for a flagship health initiative.

The documents, which were unearthed by the Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy, show that the Department of Health is attempting to manipulate a new funding announcement for health action zones (HAZs) because "it will not be received as good news".

In a draft letter to the chairmen of the 26 HAZs, which were set up to improve health care in deprived areas, the health minister, John Hutton, was forced to admit that funding "is less than we had previously indicated".

Another document recommends that the Department of Health should not issue a press release on the new funding and ministers should avoid writing letters to MPs. "This will not be received as good news and we would not recommend a press release," the document says. Mr Kennedy challenged Mr Blair about the documents in the Commons yesterday. "Why does the government continue to announce funding which doesn't exist and won't you admit that this is another attempt at a triumph of spin over substance?" he asked.

Mr Blair rejected Mr Kennedy's accusations as "absurd" because funding for the action zones is to increase by 37.6% to £120m, although this is lower than the government had originally allocated.

The row came as the prime minister made light of new accusations that his official spokesman is overstepping the mark by ordering civil servants to prepare a public relations offensive to boost the government.

Asked about the disclosure in yesterday's Guardian about Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair joked that he was now redundant because there was so much good news about the government.

But ministers faced further embarrassment over spin yesterday when the head of a care in the community enquiry said that the publication of her report had been delayed to ensure it did not interfere with "good news" about the NHS.

The report by Aswini Weereratne into the case of Shane Bath, who bludgeoned to death his partner nine months after leaving the care of Dorset health authority, has been ready for several weeks. But Ms Weereratne said that the health authority had called for the report's publication to be delayed until after a series of positive announcements about the NHS.

"A date of July 6 was initially agreed upon by all those who would have to attend publication of the report," Ms Weereratne told Radio 4's The World at One. She added that that she was then informed that July 6 would not be possible "because the DoH had indicated that that date fell in what is designated NHS good news week."

The government dismissed her claims.

The Department of Health said: "There is no mystery here. The launch of the report was moved because of the availability of all the interested parties to attend. There will be a full press conference to publish the report next month."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Iraqi guns down two UN workers
fields.body:
Iraqi guns down two UN workers

An Iraqi shot dead two United Nations workers - one a Somali, the other a fellow Iraqi - after forcing his way into the Baghdad office of the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation yesterday, demanding an end to sanctions against his country and an increase in government rations.

International workers said the man grabbed a machine gun from an Iraqi guard before storming into the building. Six people were seriously wounded, including four Iraqi guards, according to witnesses and UN officials.
AP, Baghdad

Council rejects Putin reforms

Russia's upper house of parliament defied President Vladimir Putin's plans for a radical shake-up of the constitutional order yesterday, voting overwhelmingly to veto his campaign to tame Russia's 89 unruly regions.

The ballot - 129 against and 13 in favour - means that the bill returns to the lower house, the duma, where it was passed last week by 308 votes. A two-thirds majority in the 450-strong lower chamber would overrule yesterday's veto.
Ian Traynor, Moscow

Army to bypass Fijian rebels

Fiji's military authorities said yesterday that they would appoint a new civilian government without further talks with the gunmen holding 27 members of the ousted government, including the prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, hostage.

On Tuesday the hostage-takers rejected an ultimatum to sign an agreement within 24 hours. "Thousands of people are losing their jobs [and are] without food, and the whole country is being held for ransom," an army spokesman said.
AP, Suva

fields.headline: Tell-tale Kohl files wiped
fields.standfirst:
Revelations turn up the heat before Kohl testifies today
German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Two-thirds of the computer data in Helmut Kohl's chancellery was wiped out in the month before he and his party handed power in Germany to the Social Democrats, a government-appointed special investigator said yesterday.
fields.body:
Two-thirds of the computer data in Helmut Kohl's chancellery was wiped out in the month before he and his party handed power in Germany to the Social Democrats, a government-appointed special investigator said yesterday.

Burkhard Hirsch added that key documents which could have had a bearing on the scandal that subsequently developed over fund-raising by the former chancellor and his Christian Democratic Union were also missing.

"This wasn't just a slip of the finger. This was instead a massive annihilation of data and document manipulation that was carried out without any sort of legal justification," he told a parliamentary commission of inquiry.

The files hastily deleted between September 30 1998 - two days after the CDU was defeated in the general election - and October 22, five days before power was transferred to the present chancellor, Gerhard Schröder.

Mr Hirsch, a politician and member of the liberal Free Democrats, said traces left on computer hard drives showed that the three gigabytes of data destroyed included records of deals at the core of the scandal over CDU funding sources.

The timing of this evidence may not be coincidental: it piles on the pressure as Mr Kohl is due to appear before the inquiry today. Frank Hofmann, an MP and senior SPD official, said Mr Hirsch's findings took the affair into a new dimension: that of potential "government criminality".

The special investigator was appointed in February at the height of the scandal over the CDU's undeclared, and therefore illegal, donations. He was given a team of detectives and told to conduct an exhaustive inquiry after prosecutors reported they had been unable to find key documents.

Mr Hirsch said the deleted data would cover more than a million sheets of paper. He could find no one, he said, who would admit ordering the deletions. The scale of the destruction made implausible the claim by Kohl advisers that some files had been struck out should not fall into the hands of the incoming Social Democrats, he added.

Last night the government announced that preliminary disciplinary proceedings had begun against several civil servants.

Mr Kohl's appearance before the commission of inquiry has revived interest in the scandal after a period when voters seemed to have lapsed into shock fatigue.

His party lost support heavily as details emerged of the millions of pounds it was secretly given over several years in the 90s. But under a new leader, Angela Merkel, who has virtually disowned the former leader, the CDU has made up much of the ground.

One of the two opinion polls published last weekend showed the party fractionally ahead of Mr Schröder's troubled Social Democrats.

Funds which Mr Kohl himself admits having received - about £650,000, meant to help build up CDU support in eastern Germany - formed only a small part of the total involved. But they were the first to be mentioned, and the former chancellor has created a scandal within a scandal by indignantly refusing to say who his benefactors were.

His attitude has prompted speculation that an even more discreditable affair lies below the surface.

But his lawyer was adamant yesterday that Mr Kohl would not change his mind when faced at the inquiry with what German newspapers were billing as his High Noon.

"They can ask the same question 400 times between 1pm and 7pm, then threaten him with a fine or arrest as punishment. No matter what, Mr Kohl will not name the donors," the Rheinische Post quoted his lawyer, Stephan Holthoff-Pfoertner, as saying.

webTitle: EU losing race to end Austrian sanctions

fields.headline: EU losing race to end Austrian sanctions
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: European Union leaders were racing against time last night to agree a mechanism for ending sanctions against Austria, with paralysis looming if they do not succeed by tomorrow.
fields.body:
European Union leaders were racing against time last night to agree a mechanism for ending sanctions against Austria, with paralysis looming if they do not succeed by tomorrow.

The Portuguese prime minister, Antonio Guterres, said he had not managed to build a consensus among the 14 states which took unprecedented collective action against Austria, the EU's 15th member, in February.

France, a hardliner on Austria, takes over the EU's rotating presidency from Portugal on Saturday.

"At the moment there is no common stance," Mr Guterres admitted. Diplomats said a proposal for a committee of "wise men" to monitor the human-rights record of the Austrian coalition was complete but, crucially, there was no agreement on a date to lift the sanctions.

The measures were imposed after Austria's conservative chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, formed a government with the far-right Freedom party, then led by the controversial Jörg Haider.

Mr Guterres had hoped to bring about an agreement before handing over the EU's helm to France. But it was touch and go last night whether he would manage before tomorrow evening.

Sweden, which takes over the presidency next January, will be far keener than France to find a way out of the increasingly embarrassing impasse.

The French president, Jacques Chirac, has said he will not lift the sanctions during his turn at the presidency. But an EU official said: "The trick will be to leapfrog over the French so that the Swedes can recommend suspending or lifting sanctions."

Any agreement will have to be endorsed by Austria itself, which could create further difficulties.

Portugal's idea is to appoint three wise men - a classic EU trick to wriggle out of a tight corner - to assess Vienna's commitment to "common European values" - in particular the rights of minorities, refugees and immigrants.

The three, likely to be judges of the European court of human rights in Strasbourg, would also examine "the political nature" of the Freedom party, which EU governments regard as racist.

The Austrian vice-chancellor, Susanne Riess-Passer, who replaced Mr Haider as the Freedom party leader last month, says an indefinite delay would be unacceptable.

The bitter row has overshadowed EU business and threatens to delay the vital work of reforming the union before it takes in new members, starting in 2003. At last week's EU summit in Portugal, Austria demonstrated its capacity for disruption when it blocked a deal on the controversial scheme to withhold tax on savings, and insisted that for "constitutional reasons" it could not endorse it.

Mr Schüssel has warned that he will hold a referendum in the autumn to ask voters to express their disapproval if no method of ending the sanctions is in place by tomorrow.

Other member states have warned that a referendum could whip up anti-EU sentiment, which many argue is the single most significant outcome of an ill-considered and hasty move.

Britain is anxious to end the boycott, having been bounced into the original decision by Tony Blair's direct contacts with other EU leaders, against the advice of the Foreign Office. Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, pointed out last week that 70% of Austrians had never voted for the Freedom party.

Mr Haider said yesterday that the latest EU proposal represented mere "tactical games" and urged Mr Schüssel to go ahead with the referendum.

The sanctions have caused bitterness in Austria, where officials complain they would not have been imposed on a bigger member state.

Diplomats said a proposal for a committee of "wise men" to monitor the human-rights record of the Austrian coalition was complete but, crucially, there was no agreement on a date to lift the sanctions. The measures were imposed after Austria's conservative chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel, formed a government with the far-right Freedom party, then led by the controversial Jörg Haider. Mr Guterres had hoped to bring about an agreement before handing over the EU's helm to France. But it was touch and go last night whether he would manage before tomorrow evening. Sweden, which takes over the presidency next January, will be far keener than France to find a way out of the increasingly embarrassing impasse. The French president, Jacques Chirac, has said he will not lift the sanctions during his turn at the presidency. But an EU official said: "The trick will be to leapfrog over the French so that the Swedes can recommend suspending or lifting sanctions." Any agreement will have to be endorsed by Austria itself, which could create further difficulties. Portugal's idea is to appoint three wise men - a classic EU trick to wriggle out of a tight corner - to assess Vienna's commitment to "common European values" - in particular the rights of minorities, refugees and immigrants. The three, likely to be judges of the European court of human rights in Strasbourg, would also examine "the political nature" of the Freedom party, which EU governments regard as racist. The Austrian vice-chancellor, Susanne Riess-Passer, who replaced Mr Haider as the Freedom party leader last month, says an indefinite delay would be unacceptable. The bitter row has overshadowed EU business and threatens to delay the vital work of reforming the union before it takes in new members, starting in 2003. At last week's EU summit in Portugal, Austria demonstrated its capacity for disruption when it blocked a deal on the controversial scheme to withhold tax on savings, and insisted that for "constitutional reasons" it could not endorse it. Mr Schüssel has warned that he will hold a referendum in the autumn to ask voters to express their disapproval if no method of ending the sanctions is in place by tomorrow. Other member states have warned that a referendum could whip up anti-EU sentiment, which many argue is the single most significant outcome of an ill-considered and hasty move. Britain is anxious to end the boycott, having been bounced into the original decision by Tony Blair's direct contacts with other EU leaders, against the advice of the Foreign Office. Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, pointed out last week that 70% of Austrians had never voted for the Freedom party. Mr Haider said yesterday that the latest EU proposal represented mere "tactical games" and urged Mr Schüssel to go ahead with the referendum. The sanctions have caused bitterness in Austria, where officials complain they would not have been imposed on a bigger member state.

webTitle: Ofsted tells second 'fresh start' school it is a failure

fields.headline: Ofsted tells second 'fresh start' school it is a failure
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government's drive to revive failing schools will be dealt a fresh blow today, when governors of the Islington arts and media school are told that the education watchdog, Ofsted, has ordered that it be taken back into emergency rescue measures.
fields.body:
The government's drive to revive failing schools will be dealt a fresh blow today, when governors of the Islington arts and media school are told that the education watchdog, Ofsted, has ordered that it be taken back into emergency rescue measures.

The former George Orwell school is the second of the nine "fresh start" schools to be put on special measures after being deemed to be failing.

The Ofsted order came after a two-day visit by inspectors last week who found that it had not made sufficient progress since its reopening last year.

Governors at the comprehensive school in north London will be told the news at a meeting this evening by the acting head, Jim Hudson, who has been handed a draft report which confirms initial verbal feedback from inspectors. The full findings will be published in the next few days.

The London borough of Islington, whose school services were "outsourced" to private-sector consultants Cambridge Education Associates (CEA) earlier this year, has spent more than £3m trying to turn the school around.

It reopened with a new name and Britain's first "superhead", Torsten Friedag, last September. But in March he resigned unexpectedly from his £70,000 post after reports of a serious breakdown in discipline and concerns about poor academic performance.

The draft report is understood to praise the management at the school and CEA for starting to improve standards at the school, while criticising Islington council for failing to support the school under the previous regime.

But the inspectors concluded that despite the hard work of the management team, the school "had not achieved the level of progress hoped for", with unsatisfactory teaching in many lessons.

Among some positive findings understood to be in the draft report are that the average daily attendance level increased by 10% during the summer term, while progress was made in "curriculum development" and lesson preparation and planning. Overall, the school was found to be "a calm and orderly environment which cares for and recognises the diverse needs of the pupil community".

CEA and the school will respond tomorrow by publishing a plan for urgent improvement. Among the measures are understood to be: developing the work of the governing body by appointing extra governors; setting up a training programme to improve the work of middle managers; identifying a range of subject-specific consultants; working with the education welfare service to boost attendance and punctuality; and supporting the school by recruiting and retaining staff who will bring the experience and expertise necessary to maintain the progress of a fresh start school.

Defending the fresh start programme, a Department for Education spokesman said: "Fresh start is not an easy option, but the alternative of leaving a school to fail until it drifts into closure is not acceptable."

Mr Friedag's departure was followed by a rash of resignations by other heads of "fresh start" schools, including Tony Garwood, who quit as head of East Brighton arts and media college.

The school, which is also being run by an acting head, was taken into special measures this month amid criticism of Mr Garwood's leadership by Ofsted inspectors.

A total of 95% of trainee teachers passed the first numeracy test designed to raise standards of numeracy in the profession, it will be announced today. The results of the test, taken earlier this month at a cost of £900,000 to taxpayers this year, show that only 1,145 students failed.

webTitle: Dramatic heist:  Prizewinner demands more cash for mystery event

fields.headline: Dramatic heist:  Prizewinner demands more cash for mystery event
fields.trailText: Barrie Rutter, founder of the rumbustious touring company Northern Broadsides, yesterday scooped the richest British arts prize and promptly bit the hand that fed him.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Barrie Rutter, founder of the rumbustious touring company Northern Broadsides, yesterday scooped the richest British arts prize and promptly bit the hand that fed him.

Clutching the £100,000 cheque which proclaimed him Creative Briton of the year, in the tones in which he has bellowed Shakespeare at bus depots, cattle markets and prisons, Rutter barked that he and the other five on the shortlist had just got together over coffee and decided to create an arts event. Nobody was leaving the champagne award ceremony in Covent Garden, central London, until somebody agreed to sponsor it, he warned.

Within minutes the Prudential, which had stumped up £200,000 for the awards, gave in gracefully and agreed to pay the unspecified cost of whatever it is the actor, poet, violinist, contemporary dancer, video expert and arts administrator comes up with next year.

Rutter is the founder, director, and often lead actor of Northern Broadsides, which mounts earthy touring productions making up in blood, sweat and tears what they might lack in subtlety. Based in a former carpet factory in Halifax, the company is best known for its Shakespeare but has also tackled contemporary work, including poet Tony Harrison's Millennium Mystery Play cycle.

In September the company will mount the world premiere of Ted Hughes' translation of Euripides' Alcestis, left finished but unperformed at the poet laureate's death. Hughes bequeathed the rights to Rutter's company, for which theatre managements around the world would kill. Rutter yesterday simply said: "Great man, Hughes - born three miles from me."

Northern Broadsides is run on a shoestring and has often teetered on financial disaster. The Arts Council has warned that touring and regional theatre are in crisis but Rutter said the company was "just above the red line" and promised to spend his prize "wisely".

webTitle: Council knew of 'horrific' abuse for five years

fields.headline: Council knew of 'horrific' abuse for five years
fields.trailText: Four children who suffered "horrific" parental neglect for years while social services took no action to remove them were subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment, the British government conceded yesterday at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.
fields.body:
Four children who suffered "horrific" parental neglect for years while social services took no action to remove them were subjected to inhuman and degrading treatment, the British government conceded yesterday at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.

The government admitted it had breached article three of the European convention on human rights, which guarantees protection from "torture or inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment", because Bedfordshire county council knew of the children's plight for nearly five years before it took them into care.

A child psychiatrist who assessed the two boys and two girls, called "Z and others" to conceal their identities, described their case as "horrific" and the worst case of parental neglect and emotional abuse she had seen in her career.

The two boys were regularly locked in their bedroom from 5.30pm till 8am without any light or heating. The windows were nailed closed and there were no sheets on the bed and only a single blanket.

They were not even allowed to go to the toilet. When a social worker visited the house she found the children's beds sodden with urine and soiled with faeces. Faeces were on the floor of the bedroom and open cans of food under the bed with jagged metal edges.

The children were never properly fed and were often found foraging for food in waste bins in the school playground and stealing food from other children's lunchboxes. They ate out of park bins on the way to school and were often locked out of the house during the day. The elder boy was beaten by his father with a metal rod.

From November 1987 relatives, neighbours, police, the family GP, the NSPCC, a headteacher, a social worker and a health visitor told social services the children were at risk. Their father twice asked the council to take them into care and put them up for adoption. But it was only in June 1992, after their mother threatened to batter them unless they were taken away, that the council put them on the child protection register and placed them with foster parents.

Eight years after they were taken into care, the boys, now aged 16 and 14, are severely psychologically disturbed and may never be able to work.

Yesterday the grand chamber of 17 judges heard the children's claim that they were denied a fair hearing by the British courts when their negligence action against Bedfordshire was thrown out by the House of Lords on grounds of public policy. The law lords held in June 1995 that it would not be "fair, just and reasonable" if local councils could be sued for failures in carrying out their childcare duties.

Last November, the European commission of human rights held in a preliminary ruling on the case that the UK had violated both article three and article six, which guarantees the right to a fair hearing for civil claims. Although the government now concedes that it breached article three, it still denies that it breached article six.

It says restrictions on suing local councils are justified because they have a sensitive task calling for difficult judgments, and the childcare system involves a number of agencies among whom it would be difficult to apportion blame. Social workers would become cautious and defensive if they could be sued for negligence, and scarce funds would be consumed by costly and vexatious litigation.

Ben Emmerson QC, for the children, told the Strasbourg judges: "The requirements of public policy do not dictate that a local authority should be immune from liability in a situation as grave as this." Judgment will be given later.

fields.headline: Methodists debate stance on drink
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's Methodists will today consider a new relationship with one of their oldest enemies, the demon drink.
fields.body:
Britain's Methodists will today consider a new relationship with one of their oldest enemies, the demon drink.

For the first time in 40 years the church's governing conference will debate the long-standing ban on alcohol in Methodist chapels, which extends even to communion wine.

The issue is expected to cause deep divisions among the 400 delegates to the annual conference in Huddersfield, but reformers are keen to reach a decision.

Chapels and local Methodist circuits, or branches, have been consulted for the past year, and traditional teetotal attitudes among individual Methodists have been widely replaced with accepting drink but strongly emphasising moderation.

Chapels have already relaxed other restrictive rules on ancient vices, such as gambling in the form of raffles, and this year's conference has displayed a radical nature by overwhelmingly backing a forgiving acceptance of sex offenders in congregations.

Delegates voted to respect the privacy of convicted offenders in return for safeguards, including a written agreement never to be alone with young people and attendance at household support groups to help rehabilitation.

After today's alcohol debate, delegates will decide whether to change the rules. Methodist minister David Deeks, secretary of the consultation working party, said: "If we decide to allow alcohol in church premises in principle, it would then be up to individual church councils to apply for a licence. There might be concern about division within church councils, but another view of the church is that we should be strong enough to face issues that divide us."

Methodism earned its reputation for a stern attitude to alcohol during the worst days of cheap gin and wholesale drunkenness, when hymns inveighed against the destruction of health and families by drink.

Chapels were influential in the foundation of temperance movements and used the rituals of the Women's Bright Hour and Boys' Brigade to encourage the signing of the teetotal pledge.

fields.headline: Notes and queries
fields.standfirst: Animals that like to get stoned  Civil war doggerel in the playground  Sinking ships
fields.trailText: Animals that like to get stoned  Civil war doggerel in the playground  Sinking ships
fields.body:
I once caught my cat eating my cannabis plants. He loved them, and after a few munches fell over and went to sleep. He has never eaten any of my other houseplants. Is it normal for animals to take naturally occurring drugs?

 During the hot summer of 1976, one of my student housemates succeeded in growing two cannabis plants about eight feet high in our terrace backyard. Our cat loved standing on the adjacent fence and nibbling the leaves, after which she would sit on the fence - in a state that can only be described as "spaced out" - until she recovered enough to step daintily along the fence for another helping. None of the other cats in our house, or locally, showed any similar interest.

Mary Gibbs, Rusholme, Manchester.

 In the mid-1970s, our English setter pup dug up our lodger's dope stash, which he had buried in the garden. We returned from work to find the pup prostrate on the lawn with a glazed expression in his eyes. He recovered after a couple of hours and seemed none the worse for the experience. Indeed, he must have enjoyed it. From then on, he would seek it out dope at every opportunity, showing great enthusiasm and affection for anyone carrying any. Is this how the police train their sniffer dogs?

Bob Newbury, Jersey.

 French friends of mine keep a canary, which they feed on mixed seeds bought from the local pet shop. They noticed that, whenever they re-stocked the bird's feeder, it ate first all of a particular type of seed. But when they asked the shop owner if he could let them have just this type he said that, since the seeds were cannabis, he was unable to do so.

Geoffrey Taunton, London E1.

 It is more usual than we imagine. Cats are known for eating catnip, and researchers found out that its effects are similar to LSD in humans. Several species eat wild plants that have moderate hallucinogenic effects. More impressive are some monkeys in tropical forests. During the fruit season, they eat over-ripened fruits on the ground that, due to fermentation, have a mild alcoholic level. Some eat so much they get drunk.

But animals do not look for "recreational" drugs only. Wounded animals look for specific plants that researchers have shown to have anti-inflammatory or antibiotic properties. Plant-eating cats and dogs often have parasitic infections. It is possible that early human beings learned how to use medicinal (and hallucinogenic) plants by observing animals.

Karin von Schmalz-Peixoto, Animal behaviour research group, University of Oxford.

My wife, as a schoolgirl before the war in Wensleydale, North Yorks, recalls reciting the lines: "29th of May, Royal Oak Day, if you don't give us a holiday, we'll all run away." Why should this memory of the 17th-century civil war persist in children's doggerel? Is this a specifically regional memory?

 I am 91, and as a small child in a north Yorkshire village (Hensall) I remember well the Royal Oak Day custom. Until 12 noon on that day, we girls had to wear a sprig of oak to prevent us being chased by the boys carrying nettles with which they tormented us!

Elsie Edmundson, Upminster, Essex.

 I chanted the same rhyme in the Lancashire village of Mawdesley before the war. The children wore a spray of oak leaves - green for Protestants, a reddish colour for Catholics. My husband, then in the nearby village of Skelmersdale, remembers the same custom, except that the different colours had no significance.

Joan Sockett, Skelmersdale, Lancs.

 May 29 was celebrated in Northamptonshire, but known there as Oak Apple Day. The book Like Dew Before the Sun - Life and Language in Northamptonshire, by Dorothy Grimes, states: "On May 29, 1660, Charles Stuart re-entered London after the ending of the Commonwealth . . . Oak Apple Day recalls this event and also the time when Charles was forced to hide in an oak tree after his defeat at the battle of Worcester in 1651. When Northampton was rebuilt after the Great Fire of 1675, the king gave a thousand tons of timber, including oak, from his forests of Whittlebury and Salcey. His statue, standing above the portico of All Saints Church in the centre of the town, is crowned with a garland on Oak Apple Day."

As far as I know this custom is still observed. In the same book, a Miss Jessie Curtis remembers: "We used to dance the Shutlanger Clap Dance . . . on Oak Apple Day." Shutlanger is a village in the old Whittlebury Forest.

Bob Floyd, Milngavie, Glasgow.

I have no kneejerk reflex. But despite doctors' failure to find one, none has suggested there is anything wrong with me, sent me to a specialist or offered an explanation. So what is the point of the test?

 The kneejerk is one of the fastest and most primitive in the body: it uses only two nerve cells via the spinal cord, and does not use the brain. However, the brain does preset the strength of the reflex. If the questioner interlaces her fingers and strains to pull her hands apart, tapping her knee will elicit a brisk reflex (because the brain thinks she is carrying a heavy load and needs extra support if she stumbles). If the brain or its connections are damaged - for example by a stroke - the reflex will be uncontrolled and grotesquely huge in the knee opposite the damaged side. This is what doctors look for. So the questioner's brain is working fine!

Dr Anthony Carr, McMaster University, Ontario, Canada.

Recently the Russian forces in Chechnya used "vacuum bombs". What are they, how do they work, and has Britain ever used them?

 Fuel-air explosives, popularly known in Russia as "vacuum bombs", are weapons that use an initial explosive charge to burst open and disperse a container of liquid fuel before a second explosive charge detonates the resulting fuel/air mix. The cloud of fuel penetrates structures and flows around objects so that when it is detonated, massive enveloping blast waves are created. If multiple warheads are deployed the different blast waves reinforce each other, increasing their destructive power. The effect, enhanced in buildings and enclosed spaces, can be up to 16 times more destructive than conventional high explosives. The term "vacuum bomb" probably comes from the vacuum that occurs after the initial blast wave. It is this pressure effect that makes the weapon deadly even to people hiding in shelters. In addition, the most commonly used fuels are themselves highly toxic, so even if the fuel cloud fails to detonate, people caught in it will more than likely be killed. Fuel-air explosives were first developed by the US and were used in Vietnam.

James McCreery, London W6.

 The US, Russia and China are all known to possess fuel-air explosives and others have at least displayed an interest. Not all FAEs are for offensive purposes. The technology is also used in mine-clearance, with the blast overpressure being used to detonate buried devices.

Marc Arnold, Jane's Information Group, Coulsdon, Surrey.

How did captains of ships develop the tradition of going down with their vessel; is there any sense in it and, given the value of experienced seamen in a war, has the Navy ever issued orders forbidding it?

 This probably lies in salvage law. The captain, colloquially, is "the Owner", and is the owner's representative in law. As long as he is on board, the salvors cannot take the cargo, so he often stayed till it was too late to get off. Besides, most traditional sailors were non-swimmers and did not bother to learn because the odds of dying of exposure, exhaustion and sharks were shorter than those of rescue.

In the navy - besides Admiral Byng, shot "to encourage the others" - until the 20th century there were enough routine courts martial on the loss of ships to make sure captains tried to save the ship till the last moment possible. Ships have always been expensive beasts.

Frank Adam, Prestwich, Manchester.

Any answers?

In the novel The Devil Rides Out, Dennis Wheatley refers to the "Sussamma Ritual" - the only one of his mythological references I have been unable to track down. Was it made up by the author?

Stephen Bailey, Sutton, Surrey.

Is there any proof that homeopathic medicine works?

J Burgess, Norwich.

Among our small garden birds, some hop, some walk, and some do both. Why? Is there an advantage for a particular sort of bird to use a particular gait?

Anthony Bullock, Southfield, Glos.

Why are some countries, such as The Gambia, prefixed with "The", even when they are not plural (like The Netherlands).

Nicholas Beare, Blantyre, Malawi.

Why do wasps and bees hover outside windows trying to get in, then hover inside trying to get out?

Morag Christie, Sherwood, Notts.

Why did the Elizabethan theatre invariably begin performances at 3pm? In the summer, shows could have started at 7pm and still have seen enough daylight. Were audiences reluctant to be out in the town in the evening?

John Hole, London SE10.

Indeed, he must have enjoyed it. From then on, he would seek it out dope at every opportunity, showing great enthusiasm and affection for anyone carrying any. Is this how the police train their sniffer dogs? Bob Newbury, Jersey.  French friends of mine keep a canary, which they feed on mixed seeds bought from the local pet shop. They noticed that, whenever they re-stocked the bird's feeder, it ate first all of a particular type of seed. But when they asked the shop owner if he could let them have just this type he said that, since the seeds were cannabis, he was unable to do so. Geoffrey Taunton, London E1.  It is more usual than we imagine. Cats are known for eating catnip, and researchers found out that its effects are similar to LSD in humans. Several species eat wild plants that have moderate hallucinogenic effects. More impressive are some monkeys in tropical forests. During the fruit season, they eat over-ripened fruits on the ground that, due to fermentation, have a mild alcoholic level. Some eat so much they get drunk. But animals do not look for "recreational" drugs only. Wounded animals look for specific plants that researchers have shown to have anti-inflammatory or antibiotic properties. Plant-eating cats and dogs often have parasitic infections. It is possible that early human beings learned how to use medicinal (and hallucinogenic) plants by observing animals. Karin von Schmalz-Peixoto, Animal behaviour research group, University of Oxford. My wife, as a schoolgirl before the war in Wensleydale, North Yorks, recalls reciting the lines: "29th of May, Royal Oak Day, if you don't give us a holiday, we'll all run away." Why should this memory of the 17th-century civil war persist in children's doggerel? Is this a specifically regional memory?  I am 91, and as a small child in a north Yorkshire village (Hensall) I remember well the Royal Oak Day custom. Until 12 noon on that day, we girls had to wear a sprig of oak to prevent us being chased by the boys carrying nettles with which they tormented us! Elsie Edmundson, Upminster, Essex.  I chanted the same rhyme in the Lancashire village of Mawdesley before the war. The children wore a spray of oak leaves - green for Protestants, a reddish colour for Catholics. My husband, then in the nearby village of Skelmersdale, remembers the same custom, except that the different colours had no significance. Joan Sockett, Skelmersdale, Lancs.  May 29 was celebrated in Northamptonshire, but known there as Oak Apple Day. The book Like Dew Before the Sun - Life and Language in Northamptonshire, by Dorothy Grimes, states: "On May 29, 1660, Charles Stuart re-entered London after the ending of the Commonwealth . . . Oak Apple Day recalls this event and also the time when Charles was forced to hide in an oak tree after his defeat at the battle of Worcester in 1651. When Northampton was rebuilt after the Great Fire of 1675, the king gave a thousand tons of timber, including oak, from his forests of Whittlebury and Salcey. His statue, standing above the portico of All Saints Church in the centre of the town, is crowned with a garland on Oak Apple Day." As far as I know this custom is still observed. In the same book, a Miss Jessie Curtis remembers: "We used to dance the Shutlanger Clap Dance . . . on Oak Apple Day." Shutlanger is a village in the old Whittlebury Forest. Bob Floyd, Milngavie, Glasgow. I have no kneejerk reflex. But despite doctors' failure to find one, none has suggested there is anything wrong with me, sent me to a specialist or offered an explanation. So what is the point of the test?  The kneejerk is one of the fastest and most primitive in the body: it uses only two nerve cells via the spinal cord, and does not use the brain. However, the brain does preset the strength of the reflex. If the questioner interlaces her fingers and strains to pull her hands apart, tapping her knee will elicit a brisk reflex (because the brain thinks she is carrying a heavy load and needs extra support if she stumbles). If the brain or its connections are damaged - for example by a stroke - the reflex will be uncontrolled and grotesquely huge in the knee opposite the damaged side. This is what doctors look for. So the questioner's brain is working fine! Dr Anthony Carr, McMaster University, Ontario, Canada. Recently the Russian forces in Chechnya used "vacuum bombs". What are they, how do they work, and has Britain ever used them?  Fuel-air explosives, popularly known in Russia as "vacuum bombs", are weapons that use an initial explosive charge to burst open and disperse a container of liquid fuel before a second explosive charge detonates the resulting fuel/air mix. The cloud of fuel penetrates structures and flows around objects so that when it is detonated, massive enveloping blast waves are created. If multiple warheads are deployed the different blast waves reinforce each other, increasing their destructive power. The effect, enhanced in buildings and enclosed spaces, can be up to 16 times more destructive than conventional high explosives. The term "vacuum bomb" probably comes from the vacuum that occurs after the initial blast wave. It is this pressure effect that makes the weapon deadly even to people hiding in shelters. In addition, the most commonly used fuels are themselves highly toxic, so even if the fuel cloud fails to detonate, people caught in it will more than likely be killed. Fuel-air explosives were first developed by the US and were used in Vietnam. James McCreery, London W6.  The US, Russia and China are all known to possess fuel-air explosives and others have at least displayed an interest. Not all FAEs are for offensive purposes. The technology is also used in mine-clearance, with the blast overpressure being used to detonate buried devices. Marc Arnold, Jane's Information Group, Coulsdon, Surrey. How did captains of ships develop the tradition of going down with their vessel; is there any sense in it and, given the value of experienced seamen in a war, has the Navy ever issued orders forbidding it?  This probably lies in salvage law. The captain, colloquially, is "the Owner", and is the owner's representative in law. As long as he is on board, the salvors cannot take the cargo, so he often stayed till it was too late to get off. Ships have always been expensive beasts. Frank Adam, Prestwich, Manchester. Any answers? In the novel The Devil Rides Out, Dennis Wheatley refers to the "Sussamma Ritual" - the only one of his mythological references I have been unable to track down. Was it made up by the author? Stephen Bailey, Sutton, Surrey. Is there any proof that homeopathic medicine works? J Burgess, Norwich. Among our small garden birds, some hop, some walk, and some do both. Why? Is there an advantage for a particular sort of bird to use a particular gait? Anthony Bullock, Southfield, Glos. Why are some countries, such as The Gambia, prefixed with "The", even when they are not plural (like The Netherlands). Nicholas Beare, Blantyre, Malawi. Why do wasps and bees hover outside windows trying to get in, then hover inside trying to get out? Morag Christie, Sherwood, Notts. Why did the Elizabethan theatre invariably begin performances at 3pm? In the summer, shows could have started at 7pm and still have seen enough daylight. Were audiences reluctant to be out in the town in the evening? John Hole, London SE10.

fields.body:
"He said : 'I love that you love animals, but I hate that you are obsessed by them. Call me when you have the time.' I haven't done so yet. I thought, no, get on with your mission. I've had a bellyful of love and romance. I don't let anyone get to know me now and I can't do that domestic bit, or be with any man who wants that"

Carla Lane on why animals come before a lover, Daily Mail

"Is it simply social convention that dictates a man should be at least as tall as his partner or his fear that the awkward manoeuvrings of the first goodnight kiss would require his taller companion to stoop like a curtseying flamingo? ... Their [tall women's] forbearance is probably the kind of saintliness that is produced by suffering; a shortage of partners on the dance floor, for example, or of having the more adventurous of shorter men clamber clumsily about them like novices on a climbing wall"

Geoffrey Phillips, Evening Standard

"A man would not get this. The minute another woman arrives in a field where there haven't traditionally been many, comparisons are made. I wasn't prepared for it"

New Gardeners' World presenter Rachel de Thame on being called "The New Charlie Dimmock", Daily Telegraph

"Now it's OK to buy new breasts when previously a perm would have to do, date boys young enough to have been tucked up in bed for Live Aid, have babies without nominating a father ... Why stop there when you can take personal choice to the limit and start rebranding the male population to suit every taste? Why not shop for a man as you would for a property ('I'm looking for something bigger, in an up-and-coming area. Happy to do major work so long as it's got good quality features, charm and potential')"

Shane Watson, Evening Standard

webTitle: 'It's nice to walk down the street and not be looked at'

fields.headline: 'It's nice to walk down the street and not be looked at'
fields.standfirst: How David McAlmont changed his wardrobe - and his music. By  Garry Mulholland
fields.trailText: How David McAlmont changed his wardrobe - and his music. By Garry Mulholland
fields.body:
The first thing that strikes you when you meet David McAlmont is the obvious, distressing sign of self-abuse. No, not track marks or sunken cheeks or missing bits of nose. He looks perfectly cool and healthy and grown-up in his downbeat black clothes. The shocking thing is what he is doing to his precious vocal cords. He's smoking , for God's sake! "It amazes me as well," says McAlmont. "I've tried to stop but I actually don't want to. I'm at the point where I'm thinking, well, I'll take the risk. You only live once, c'est la vie, here today, gone tomorrow, blah blah blah. A-huh a-huh!"

That is the McAlmont laugh - a slow, deep, slightly dirty laugh that seems to sum up where the Nigerian/Guyanan/British singer- songwriter is at present. Indeed, the quietly knowing guffaw and "You only live once, blah blah blah" philosophy are constant undercurrents on his forthcoming album Be, a surprisingly upbeat, radio-friendly, dance pop-embracing affair. The album further establishes his credentials as both an extraordinary soul singer and one of British pop's most chameleon-like performers.

McAlmont's journey began a decade ago with the Cocteau Twins-like guitars and falsetto delirium of indie duo Thieves. His impact stemmed less from the hysterical vocals than from the hysterical dress sense. As the rest of indie Britain settled into its drab blokeishness, McAlmont was a vision in pineapple dreads and canary-yellow blouses, lipsticked mouth spraying out gay diva invective. The press loved the attitude, but it and the public were bewildered by the music.

"My early career coincided with me coming to terms with what I was," he says. "There was a joyous militancy about that, and I was a militant - loud 'n' proud, get a load of me - but I made my point, resoundingly. There's only so much of wearing a white frock that I can take! I suspect the music would have been better served by a less flamboyant personality."

At that time the desperation to be a star seemed to ooze from him. Today he just seems like a guy. "Oh, I've always been a guy - I just didn't dress like one," says McAlmont. "I was dealing with issues. In my earlier life a lot of the men let me down, and the women closest to me got mistreated by them as well. I didn't have any man that I could really admire, that all-important figure a boy needs. But since then my faith in men has been restored and I've realised that a man is quite a cool thing to be. I've really gotten into that whole black Moses vibe. I like being concerned about my audience's spiritual needs. And I think Malcolm X specs and a small Afro are more becoming for that than peacock feathers. But it's a comfort thing as well. When you're glad-ragging the way I was, it's stressful. It's nice to walk down the street and not be looked at."

If David has regrets about his pop beginnings, they are nothing compared with his lingering discomfort over phase two. From 1994 to 1995 he formed a partnership with ex-Suede guitarist Bernard Butler. On the plus side, it provided his only two proper hit singles, Yes and You Do, the relatively successful The Sound of McAlmont and Butler album, and his first taste of fame. On the minus, the break-up was acrimonious, with McAlmont publicly questioning Butler's attitude to homosexuality.

"I just behaved so badly," he recalls. "I went to the Brit awards, took far too much cocaine, went to parties and met famous people and didn't think about how I was behaving."

Looking at Butler's subsequent career - sober dadrock riffage, sessions with folk guitar legend Bert Jansch, a complete rejection of pop frontman frippery - it seems bizarre that there was ever a partnership at all. "I don't think Bernard and I will be friends again because I was far too cruel," says McAlmont. "He bugged me and, rather than use my common sense to sort it out, I took advantage of my position and conducted a deliberate, premeditated public annihilation of the guy. That's really embarrassing. I can't say it was unnecessary because I felt so strongly about it at the time, but would I do it now? Absolutely not. The problem is I've gone through a lot of my life not thinking about how people react to me."

After a long break interrupted only by a couple of so-so singles, McAlmont returned with a drastic reinvention in 1998. A Little Communication remains the high point of his career to date - a low-key, overtly classic soul-influenced album about the pain and pleasure of a love affair. For the first time you could hear his voice in all its subtle glory - which in turn revealed a storyteller with an incisive eye. The critics raved but it didn't really sell - though it produced a significant change in his constantly shifting audience.

"I went travelling after McAlmont and Butler, and when I got back the first thing I did was go to my manager and say, 'I want a black band.' It was time. So I started auditioning and I had my fears, but the people I was meeting weren't paying any attention to my sexuality. I was with a group of black men who respected me for what I'm capable of, and other issues weren't important at all. I've realised that to define yourself as anything in particular is not the whole story. I'm Nigerian, Guyanan, British, I'm black, I'm a man. But at the start, these were not things I'd bang on about. It was always just the one thing. Obviously, I felt I needed to, but it didn't do me any favours. So suddenly this thing I'd been resisting for so long was happening, and it took me straight back to church. A Little Communication gave me a 50% black audience for the first time."

Be carries a similar black sensibility but is deliberately light and radio- produced - more Macy Gray than Marvin Gaye. Its mature positivity is the result of McAlmont's new fascination with chaos theory and some vivid travel experiences - particularly in Madagascar - and it is probably Britain's first zen pop album. Its redemptive tone is encapsulated by the first single, Easy, a gently rippling drum'n'bass open letter to his parents, in which he seeks to mend a rift by taking his share of the blame.

"At times I've hated my parents," he says. "But how could they not make mistakes when I've made so many? The song's about remembering what a nightmare I was as a kid, and realising that I was just another issue for them to deal with."

Do they accept your sexuality? "Well... um... once they know there's not a lot they can do... And it doesn't stop them loving you really. But, based on the information they have, I would argue that they actually have no choice but to react in whatever way they do."

Unfortunately, though Easy is perfect for radio, one suspects that neither it nor any of the obvious singles on Be will get much airplay, perhaps because the music's charm and intelligence will throw the rest of daytime radio's shallow fodder into too sharp relief.

But if McAlmont does get another pop at fame's bittersweet cherry... "I'm gonna party like it's 1999," he says without a pause. "And if it isn't, I'm still gonna party like it's 1999. Success has already changed me, but for the better. What I do now has pushed me to a deeper spiritual place and I wouldn't exchange it for more success. I remember the giddy heights of McAlmont and Butler and I wasn't ready. I made a complete arsehole of myself. I'd handle it now with dignity rather than running around screaming, 'Look at me - I'm fabulous!' "

 Easy is out now on Hut. Be will be released on September 4.

fields.headline: The hidden depths of handbags
fields.standfirst: As the Iron Lady's bag goes up for grabs,  Polly Vernon delves into women's favourite accessory
fields.trailText: As the Iron Lady's bag goes up for grabs,  Polly Vernon delves into women's favourite accessory
fields.body:
Bizarrely, Margaret Thatcher's black Salvatore Ferragamo handbag - due to be auctioned for charity early next month, alongside a zebra-print number of Cherie Booth's and a Jaeger piece that once nestled in the crook of Mo Mowlam's arm - is thumpingly fashionable. It's snakeskin (as the season requires), it's resoundingly 80s (in keeping with the retro sensibility du jour) and it boasts a slightly slaggy chain (a bonus in anyone's books). It merges effortlessly with the prissy, ladylike sartorial vibe of the moment, the pussy-bow blouses and pleated skirts, the tidy court shoes and borderline frumpy jumpers that dominated runways from Milan to Paris, and had all aspiring hipsters hotfooting it to their local Prada store.

But the profound trendiness of Lady Thatcher's handbag is, needless to say, the very least of its charms. Was any basic accessory ever so potent? Thatcher's handbags were, after all, never simple receptacles for her stuff. As fun as it is to speculate over what they actually contained (pocket packs of Kleenex? Bottles of Tweed? A well-thumbed copy of Rivals? Cocaine?), as metaphors, they were infinitely more significant. They began life as symbols of frail, meek girlishness which served to contrast violently with her less-than-meek demeanour, morphed into weapons, loaded with the promise of a physical expression of her hardline, cold-blooded, take-no-hostages fierceness, peaked as a symbol of state and wound up, inevitably, being used against her. Everything that she was - terrifying, cruel, relentless, intensely powerful, capable of orchestrating a war and falling foul of a scheming, epic usurpment - was distilled down, folded up and sewn into the linings of those little pieces of leather, as though she were in reality little more than a grotesque Carry On-type woman, likely to batter the opposition/Denis with her mock croc at the slightest provocation, but ultimately a bit silly.

Consider her political legacy as defined by the Oxford English Dictionary: "To handbag, transitive verb (of a woman politician), treat (a person, idea) ruthlessly or insensitively." That, it would seem, is what you get as a politicised woman: defined by your decorative trimmings. You may be scary in theory, but you are, after all, only a woman, with a woman's foolish attachment to well-structured leather, solid silver clasps and a silk lining.

But Lady Thatcher and her political cohorts aren't the only women to suffer reverse handbagging. We all, to a greater or lesser extent, fall foul of the handbag factor. In a fairly literal way, handbags equal gender baggage incarnate. They contain the silly frippery of womanhood, the make-up and miscellaneous fluff that bolsters us on the one hand, inhibits us and physically weighs us down on the other. It's hard to know which came first: the undermining of women for their handbag dependence, or the undermining of handbags because they are women's things. Whatever, they are innately comical concepts now: Oscar Wilde camp, Essex girl crass, drag queen ineffectual.

All of this means that, regardless of how moisturiser-friendly 21st-century man is becoming, he will always draw the line at possessing a handbag. (British men at any rate. Continental equivalents have long exhibited a fondness for overgrown wallet-type affairs and have been derided for it, which might suggest there's something innate in handbags that draws criticism.)

Increasingly, women are defined in handbag terms. We position ourselves on a sliding scale of accomplished handbaggery: the smaller and more ordered our bag, the more accomplished and organised we believe we are as people. We envy women with smaller bags than ours, the mythical credit-card-and-car-keys brigade who move sylph-like through life with little more than a Fendi Croissant to their name. These girls must surely have broad-shouldered men hovering in the background, their pockets weighed down with hard cash and house keys and responsibility for the logistics of their ladies' lives. And we are reassured by the sight of women with more cumbersome bags than our own, because their lives must be more cluttered, more complicated than ours. We still openly deride those whose handbags are so in evidence that they dance round them at parties. Aren't they ashamed at the disarray of their lives overflowing like that? Like our hips and our thighs, we'd rather our luggage stopped taking up space and getting in people's way.

What are we left with? A campaign to reclaim handbags as a symbol of our enlightened womanhood? Or a perceived reliance on Osprey and Burberry and Prada totes, which will never come to any good?

Personally, I think there is a glory in the disorganised depths of a handbag. I hoard various treasures in my various bags and feel constantly prepared and curiously protected. I pity men their lack of a luggage identity and will carry on clutching my current favourite (an olive green faux ostrich bowling bag) firmly to my side. Because I, like Maggie, will let go only for a good cause.
