Thatcher's handbags were, after all, never simple receptacles for her stuff. As fun as it is to speculate over what they actually contained (pocket packs of Kleenex? Bottles of Tweed? A well-thumbed copy of Rivals? Cocaine?), as metaphors, they were infinitely more significant. They began life as symbols of frail, meek girlishness which served to contrast violently with her less-than-meek demeanour, morphed into weapons, loaded with the promise of a physical expression of her hardline, cold-blooded, take-no-hostages fierceness, peaked as a symbol of state and wound up, inevitably, being used against her. Everything that she was - terrifying, cruel, relentless, intensely powerful, capable of orchestrating a war and falling foul of a scheming, epic usurpment - was distilled down, folded up and sewn into the linings of those little pieces of leather, as though she were in reality little more than a grotesque Carry On-type woman, likely to batter the opposition/Denis with her mock croc at the slightest provocation, but ultimately a bit silly. Consider her political legacy as defined by the Oxford English Dictionary: "To handbag, transitive verb (of a woman politician), treat (a person, idea) ruthlessly or insensitively." That, it would seem, is what you get as a politicised woman: defined by your decorative trimmings. You may be scary in theory, but you are, after all, only a woman, with a woman's foolish attachment to well-structured leather, solid silver clasps and a silk lining. But Lady Thatcher and her political cohorts aren't the only women to suffer reverse handbagging. We all, to a greater or lesser extent, fall foul of the handbag factor. In a fairly literal way, handbags equal gender baggage incarnate. They contain the silly frippery of womanhood, the make-up and miscellaneous fluff that bolsters us on the one hand, inhibits us and physically weighs us down on the other. It's hard to know which came first: the undermining of women for their handbag dependence, or the undermining of handbags because they are women's things. Whatever, they are innately comical concepts now: Oscar Wilde camp, Essex girl crass, drag queen ineffectual. All of this means that, regardless of how moisturiser-friendly 21st-century man is becoming, he will always draw the line at possessing a handbag. (British men at any rate. Continental equivalents have long exhibited a fondness for overgrown wallet-type affairs and have been derided for it, which might suggest there's something innate in handbags that draws criticism.) Increasingly, women are defined in handbag terms. We position ourselves on a sliding scale of accomplished handbaggery: the smaller and more ordered our bag, the more accomplished and organised we believe we are as people. We envy women with smaller bags than ours, the mythical credit-card-and-car-keys brigade who move sylph-like through life with little more than a Fendi Croissant to their name. These girls must surely have broad-shouldered men hovering in the background, their pockets weighed down with hard cash and house keys and responsibility for the logistics of their ladies' lives. And we are reassured by the sight of women with more cumbersome bags than our own, because their lives must be more cluttered, more complicated than ours. We still openly deride those whose handbags are so in evidence that they dance round them at parties. Aren't they ashamed at the disarray of their lives overflowing like that? Like our hips and our thighs, we'd rather our luggage stopped taking up space and getting in people's way. What are we left with? A campaign to reclaim handbags as a symbol of our enlightened womanhood? Or a perceived reliance on Osprey and Burberry and Prada totes, which will never come to any good? Personally, I think there is a glory in the disorganised depths of a handbag. I hoard various treasures in my various bags and feel constantly prepared and curiously protected. I pity men their lack of a luggage identity and will carry on clutching my current favourite (an olive green faux ostrich bowling bag) firmly to my side. Because I, like Maggie, will let go only for a good cause.

webTitle: Zimbabwean opposition claims vote was rigged

fields.headline: Zimbabwean opposition claims vote was rigged
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's defeated opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, is to take 10 dossiers listing alleged election rigging to the high court.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele  and Andrew Meldrum  in Harare
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's defeated opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, is to take 10 dossiers listing alleged election rigging to the high court.

At its first meeting since failing to win control of parliament in last weekend's elections, the MDC executive said: "Disturbing facts have come to light."

The dossiers are believed to cover events in Buhera North, where the MDC leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, was defeated by Zanu-PF.

The MDC won 57 seats to Zanu-PF's 62 in the new parliament. Even if the court challenges succeed, the change in the number of seats in favour of the opposition will not be enough to undermine Zanu-PF's grip on power, since President Mugabe has the constitutional right to nominate 30 seats in addition to the 120 contested.

Mr Tsvangirai has ruled out any chance of working formally with Zanu-PF. "He [Mugabe] must clear up his own mess," he said.

With presidential elections just two years away the MDC wants to build on its success in emerging from nowhere in less than a year to challenge Zanu-PF.

It is aware that compromising with Zanu-PF might alienate its supporters and tarnish its image of freshness and honesty. "We've got to guard against being seen to be retreating," Mr Tsvangirai said.

He acknowledged this week that Mr Mugabe might try to win some of the new MPs over to his side, with job offers or other inducements. "It would be naive to think no individuals will be ready to be co-opted," he said.

At its strategy meeting yesterday the MDC also discussed its priorities. Although it has no hope of promoting legislation, it wants to propose motions in parliament that will keep it in the public eye.

The first is to call for the withdrawal of the 11,000 troops Zimbabwe has in Congo, a deployment which is highly unpopular. The government has said it will bring the soldiers home only when the United Nations gets its peacekeepers in place. The MDC also intends to oppose President Mugabe's plans to introduce price controls on basic foodstuffs to protect the poor.

Mr Mugabe too was meeting his senior colleagues yesterday. Their agenda was topped by a postmortem on how the party lost so many seats - particularly in the urban areas as well as in Matabeleland.

The election results have reduced Zanu-PF from a national movement to an almost entirely Shona peasant party.

Apart from small segments of the new middle class which have benefited from government patronage by getting civil service jobs or help with their businesses, this is a reversion to the pattern of support found during the liberation war, and it means that Zanu-PF has lost the other constituencies it had tried to cultivate.

The government also gave notice yesterday that it will press ahead with its seizure of 804 white-owned farms.

"The land issue is on," said the minister of information, Chen Chimutengwende, yesterday. "The process of acquisition and redistribution could start within weeks."

The government had no second thoughts about taking the farms, Mr Chimutengwende said. Mr Mugabe confirmed last month that the designated farms would be confiscated and resettled by poor black farmers.

He said that since the British government did not pay for the farms, taken from Africans by Rhodesian colonialists, then his government would not pay for the land.

In April Mr Mugabe pushed through a constitutional amendment stating that the government is not obliged to pay for the land and last month it published an enabling law, which gave the farm owners 30 days to appeal against the seizure of their properties, expiring on July 3.

"So far I understand no one has appealed," said Mr Chimutengwende, indicating that the seizures would proceed smoothly.

But Tim Henwood, chairman of the Commercial Farmers Union, said hundreds of farm owners were preparing their appeals and intended to file them on Friday.

About 500 farmers are expected to seek to keep their farms, while 300 are either not contesting the confiscation or are attempting to negotiate to give up another property in place of the one designated by the government.

The appeals may well be futile, since the government has already stated that there are no valid grounds for appeal.

fields.headline: The witch is back
fields.standfirst: Blame Harry Potter. Blame women's belief that frogs won't turn into princes without a little help. Whatever the reason, the dark arts are in the ascendant.  Anita Chaudhuri falls under their spell
fields.trailText: Blame Harry Potter. Blame women's belief that frogs won't turn into princes without a little help. Whatever the reason, the dark arts are in the ascendant.  Anita Chaudhuri falls under their spell
fields.body:
Something most irregular is occurring in the world of pentagrams and pointy hats. After 2,000 years of persecution and bad publicity, witches have finally been rehabilitated as icons of female power.

Don't believe me? Switch on the TV and there's Buffy the Vampire Slayer and Sabrina the Teenage Witch acting as unofficial pagan ambassadors. Visit the New Age section of any bookstore and behold how the shelves are crammed with dozens of glossy tomes devoted to spells and magic. The bestselling of these, Hocus Pocus, a coffee-table guide for the apprentice sorcerer, has shifted a supernatural 150,000 copies in hardback. On the internet, e-covens and Wicca mailing lists are a growth area. A recent study by the University of Newcastle estimated there to be 50,000 practitioners of witchcraft in the UK, around 60% of them female.

It is a curious phenomenon, this resurgence of interest in the dark arts, particularly among otherwise rational, 21st-century women. Is it a quest to reconnect with an authentic, intuitive inner goddess or another manifestation of an innate sense of powerlessness? Certainly the idea of being able to wave a magic wand over a particularly trying situation has great appeal; the thought that a spell might exist to turn a frog, if not into an actual prince, then into Dr Kovak from ER, is positively intoxicating.

"Women want more control over their lives, that's why they are turning to magic," claims Gillian Kemp, author of The Good Spell Book (Gollancz). "All women are witches and everybody can do magic, simply by accessing their intuition," she insists. "What makes a spell work is the emotion you put into it. So if someone wants to get their husband back, there isn't much point getting an official witch to do a spell - it's far better to do it yourself."

This is where her book comes in handy, containing as it does spells to cover most of life's more pressing requirements, including To Get A Lover To Call, Eternal Triangle and (clearly designed with Euro 2000 in mind) To Communicate With An Absent Partner. There are also spells for avoiding divorce, dieting, finding a job and winning the lottery.

My favourite was To Deter Straying, until I discovered it was a spell for pets and involved burying a lump of the animal's fur in a hole in the garden. Would it work as effectively if you used a clump of an errant spouse's hair? Kemp thinks not, but then the effectiveness of her enchantments is dubious to begin with. After all, why has she not won the lottery herself and retired by now? "A spell is like a driving test," she says. "They don't always work first time round. You need perseverance."

With this in mind, I search for a suitable spell. The section on love looks promising, but they all seem to demand ingredients more appropriate for a forensics lab than a romantic encounter - lumps of hair, fingernails, clothing samples. If we had access to such intimate parts of our chosen love god, would we really need spells to entrap him anyway?

Some of the incantations are a bit worrying, too. "May the flame of passion burn within your heart/From me you will not part" reads a spell To Attract the One You Love. But what if I get sick of him? Even the author admits her spell To Rid Yourself Of A Persistent And Unwanted Lover is "more complicated than most".

Kate West heads the Hearth of Hecate, a coven in Norfolk with 20 members. She believes women are embracing "the craft" in droves, not because they need miracle spells but because they want to form more profound links to nature and their own unconscious. "Ultimately it's about the belief that you can change the world around you - that's a nurturing, female concept. It is also liberating to accept that there is a goddess protecting us and our earth."

Every week, West is inundated with requests for spells, or "magical assistance", and for advice, both from the local community and the internet. "There isn't exactly a poster in the window saying Witch Lives Here, but people do know. There's a lot of fear of us, particularly from men, but that has ever been the case. I get email from worried parents about daughters who have just got into magic."

Now she is writing a handbook for young witches for the post-Harry Potter market, offering step-by-step guidance to becoming a witch. "There are a lot of misconceptions. People think magic will solve all their problems and it won't. Most of my work is used in healing. I do 10 to 12 spells per month but I don't charge. Often I do them for people who have done my babysitting. Money spells are the hardest because you have to be really specific - there's no point in just asking for cash or you'll wake up to find a 5p piece on your doorstep. Love can be tricky, too, because I think it's immoral to tamper with the emotions of a third party."

West is adamant that the vast majority of witches use their power to good ends. Even her own principles have their limits, however. "I'm not ashamed to say I often cast spells to find a parking space in a hurry."

West claims not to have read Harry Potter, probably the real source of the current boom in bewitchment. "I'm not sure if Harry Potter is a good thing," says Sally Taylor, a third generation witch who has read the books. "It makes magic seem too simplistic."

Taylor should know; she previously ran a school for witches in Folkestone, the Kent College of Magic and Metaphysics, which sounds suspiciously like the Hogwarts School of JK Rowling's fiction. "There are fake covens around, people with plastic bats nailed to their doors - we've got a real bat cave here. There's a lot of hypocrisy, too, particularly when dealing with kids. Most British children are taught their first spell at the age of three - blow out the candles and make a wish. Then it's all stamped out of them."

Taylor, now 60, is pragmatic about the use of magic in women's lives. "Most witches I know have to combine their day jobs with the craft which can be very stressful. They're not all going around with pointy hats, you know - they're just as likely to be a member of the Mothers' Union. I even go to church, which freaks people out. I think they're scared of what a witch represents."

It is interesting to examine why witches have historically been outcasts, while male practitioners of pagan rituals have by and large been allowed to conduct their business without fear of the ducking stool. Some of the unease clearly stems from a universal fear of female power. Wiccan lore celebrates the triple goddess of maiden, mother and crone, three archetypes of womanhood.

"The crone is the most feared because she is postmenstrual; the mother is feared because she has the secret of reproduction, a form of immortality she is withholding from men; the maiden is feared because of her suppressed power," observes Shahrukh Husain, folklorist and editor of the Virago Book of Witches. Her own research among teenage witches explores links between witchcraft and adolescent sexuality.

"Being a witch is about embracing your dark side, which women are not supposed to accept. It lets you celebrate the part that's a slut or that has a foul mouth. Ultimately witchery is all about accessing one's own power, dressing up outrageously and showing off." With a manifesto like that, what woman could resist?

webTitle: NHS chief executive says centralisation is deterring local initiative

fields.headline: NHS chief executive says centralisation is deterring local initiative
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Ministers were warned yesterday by the outgoing chief executive of the NHS that the drift towards excessive centralisation of the health service was in danger of squeezing out the local initiative essential for meeting patients' needs.
fields.body:
Ministers were warned yesterday by the outgoing chief executive of the NHS that the drift towards excessive centralisation of the health service was in danger of squeezing out the local initiative essential for meeting patients' needs.

Sir Alan Langlands, who steps down as NHS chief executive in August, gave his first public indication of concern about the direction being taken by the government in its review of the service.

He told health service managers at the NHS confederation conference in Glasgow that staff needed to be able to look up to their local bosses and respect them for doing innovative things.

"I don't think that happens much now because people don't have the space to reflect on the work they are doing. They don't have enough time - given the torrent of instructions from the centre - to work through the needs of their local communities and to manage them in a way that makes sense locally."

He added: "We need to keep a balance between a centralised service and a decentralised service."

It was not inevitable that the national plan for health, due for publication next month, would draw power further towards the centre in Whitehall.

Ministers were taking an inclusive approach to working out ideas for reform, drawing a wide range of experts into the six action teams that are preparing the ground for the national plan. But Sir Alan added: "The real inclusion has to start when the implementation stage is reached ... You [the local health authority and hospital managers] need to have some discretion to drive your part of the system in a way that makes sense locally."

Sir Alan was addressing fears raised by health service managers that their freedom of movement is excessively restricted by orders from Whitehall designed to fulfil political targets.

The national plan is expected to include a wide range of additional targets to reduce waiting times at every stage of health service activity. The health secretary, Alan Milburn, is expected to address the problem in a speech to the confederation tomorrow. It has been working on proposals which give health authorities that are achieving targets more freedom to choose how they invest capital and set local objectives.

The conference heard the first detailed exposition of Conservative plans to "dramatically extend" the private health sector by encouraging employers to support new forms of insurance for their staff.

Liam Fox, the shadow health secretary, also pledged that a Tory government would scrap Labour's decision to merge the two top jobs in the health service, head of the NHS executive and permanent secretary at the department of health.

Dr Fox said insurance schemes were inflexible and expensive. "If patients know that the most serious conditions will be guaranteed treatment within a maximum time under the NHS, there will be no need for them to seek inclusion of these in private health care policies."

So the Tories would "dramatically reduce costs in the personal health insurance sector". They would increase demand by removing disincentives, such as the tax on employees' benefits in kind that nets the Treasury £368m and extra national insurance on employers that adds £100m to their health insurance bill.

Under the Conservatives, the NHS would "remain a comprehensive not a core service, free at the point of use and funded from central taxation". He added: "We will match the spending plans of the present government, but we will also seek ways of expanding private provision on top of this."

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation, said Dr Fox's plan was unimaginative. Although the NHS might buy marginal spare capacity in the private sector, it would suffer if that area expanded significantly. There would be competition for a scarce supply of doctors, pushing up prices and reducing productivity, he said.

They would increase demand by removing disincentives, such as the tax on employees' benefits in kind that nets the Treasury £368m and extra national insurance on employers that adds £100m to their health insurance bill. Under the Conservatives, the NHS would "remain a comprehensive not a core service, free at the point of use and funded from central taxation". He added: "We will match the spending plans of the present government, but we will also seek ways of expanding private provision on top of this." Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation, said Dr Fox's plan was unimaginative. Although the NHS might buy marginal spare capacity in the private sector, it would suffer if that area expanded significantly. There would be competition for a scarce supply of doctors, pushing up prices and reducing productivity, he said.

fields.headline: Oleg Efremov
fields.standfirst: Putting Moscow back on the theatrical map
fields.trailText: Oleg Efremov, who has died aged 72, was one of the most important figures in 20th century Russian theatre. His name will always be associated with two Moscow theatres: the Sovremennik (contemporary), which he founded in 1957; and the Moscow Arts Theatre, which, under his direction, regained its place on the map of world theatre.
fields.body:
Oleg Efremov, who has died aged 72, was one of the most important figures in 20th century Russian theatre. His name will always be associated with two Moscow theatres: the Sovremennik (contemporary), which he founded in 1957; and the Moscow Arts Theatre, which, under his direction, regained its place on the map of world theatre.

Efremov's own acting career began in the early 1950s. During the subsequent thaw of the Khrushchev years, Efremov's teacher, Maria Knebel, was appointed to Moscow's Central Children's Theatre. She recruited a number of young actors and directors , including Efremov and the director Anatoli Efros. The latter brought to the repertoire the plays of Viktor Rozov, which dealt with the problems of the young generation and provided ideal parts for Efremov - such as In Search Of Joy (1957) - and he became the prototype of the rebel hero of the 1960s.

The Sovremennik started as a studio of the Moscow Arts Theatre School, and opened with Rozov's Alive Forever. Efremov had begun acting when monumental realism was receding. At the Sovremennik, he did not aim at outward verisimilitude, and he consciously combined a stylised, abstract set with an authentic way of life - everyday "kitchen drama" realism. In terms of acting, psychological development prevailed over theatricality.

Apart from Rozov's plays, a number of contemporary Soviet and foreign plays found their way to the Sovremennik. Efremov was often criticised by the authorities for putting on too many contemporary plays (for example, when he tried to stage Vasiliy Aksenov's work), yet his renderings of modern plays and contemporary readings of the classics were highly popular.

In 1970, Efremov left the Sovremennik to accept the most prestigious and challenging position in Russian theatre: chief artistic director of the ossified Moscow Arts Theatre, which had been denied genuine artistic leadership for 30 years. There Efremov introduced a generation of young dramatists into the repertoire, and a new generation of actors, which, in turn, attracted audiences. And finally, he gave young directors an opportunity to gain their first theatrical experiences with actors from his collective. In this respect, he was the only director in Moscow who thought of the future of the profession.

In his own, often controversial, productions, Efremov investigated work ethics in relation to the individual conscience. He was the first to offer a successful stage interpretation of the complex plays of Alexander Vampilov. His production of The Duck Hunt remains a theatrical landmark for the subtle investigation of the hero's psychology. Efremov played numerous film roles. His last stage role was that of the lone tsar, Boris Godunov.

In the 1980s Efremov supported glasnost and organisational reform. He argued for a reduction of the theatre staff and for a reform of the management. He met resistance but in 1987 oversaw the partition of the Arts Theatre's massive, unmanageable ensemble into the Chekhov Moscow Arts Theatre, situated in the theatre's old building - which he headed - and the Gorky Arts Theatre. In December 1986 he presided over the reorganisation of the All-Russian Theatre Society into the Theatre Workers' Union, endowed with new powers to block interferences by censorship bodies.

Russian theatre has lost the gentleman-captain who never needed a loud voice to make his points. Film and theatre colleagues attended his funeral, as did President Vladimir Putin. He was buried next to Konstantin Stanislavsky.

 Oleg Efremov, actor and theatre director, born October 1 1927; died May 24 2000

webTitle: Britain opposes Japanese hunt for two whale species

fields.headline: Britain opposes Japanese hunt for two whale species
fields.trailText: Britain is to oppose Japan's plans to hunt two protected species of whale and further undermine the international ban on whaling, Elliott Morley, the fisheries minister said yesterday on the eve of the international whaling convention meeting in Australia.
fields.body:
Britain is to oppose Japan's plans to hunt two protected species of whale and further undermine the international ban on whaling, Elliott Morley, the fisheries minister said yesterday on the eve of the international whaling convention meeting in Australia.

Mr Morley, who is joining New Zealand and Australia in proposing a whale sanctuary for the South Pacific, said the Japanese plans "fly in the face of world opinion".

The Japanese propose to kill 50 Brydes whales and 10 sperm whales in the Pacific this year - the first time the two species have been targeted since commercial whaling was banned in 1985. Sperm whales, the family of the fabled Moby-Dick, have the largest brains of any mammal and also the most valuable flesh. The Japanese eat the meat raw and will pay up to £20 for a 100g slice in Tokyo restaurants for special parts of the rump. An ordinary whale steak is £15.

A loophole in the 1946 convention allows states to take whales for "scientific purposes" and under this guise the Japanese have been killing minke whales in the Antarctic and selling the meat and blubber to restaurants. This year they propose to kill 440 minke whales in the Antarctic and another 100 in the Pacific, as well as the two new species.

"The Japanese decision in exploiting the scientific whaling loophole has caused considerable alarm. We think the scientific argument has no validity, it is just a way of getting round the moratorium on hunting," Mr Morley said.

In a Commons written reply Mr Morley confirmed Britain's continued opposition to all commercial whaling. A compromise Irish proposal in 1997 which would allow Norway and Japan to kill whales in their 200-mile coastal waters comes up again for debate.

The proposal remains controversial because countries such as Britain oppose whaling on principle, but others see it as a way of limiting the practice and would support it provided Japan and Norway were prepared to stop whaling in international waters.

Mr Morley said Britain's opposition was partly based on cruelty involved in whaling, and the inhumane methods used in the killing of dolphins and porpoises, something for which the Japanese are also blamed.

The main allies of the Japanese are the Norwegians, who will kill 655 minke whales off their own coasts this year, some in the North Sea. Britain also objects to this whaling, particularly since the whales being killed are the same minkes which are the basis of the whale watching industry in Scotland.

fields.headline: Orchid spotted
fields.standfirst: Kew botanists trace lost Himalayan species
fields.trailText: It was one of botany's mysteries. What evidence was there that William Griffith, Victorian explorer and scientist, really discovered a new orchid in the remote forests of Bhutan?
fields.body:
It was one of botany's mysteries. What evidence was there that William Griffith, Victorian explorer and scientist, really discovered a new orchid in the remote forests of Bhutan?

Ever since he supposedly stumbled across Vanda griffithii in 1843 , the botanical community regarded Griffith's "discovery" with increasing scepticism.

There was no trace of the purported specimen filed away in a dusty drawer at Kew Gardens and forgotten, and the orchid was never seen in the wild again.

Until last month, when two botanists from Kew vindicated Griffith's work by finding his lost orchid growing on a tree.

Phillip Cribb and Nicholas Pearce also found a genus of orchid new to botany - though not to local people - during their "leech-ridden" expedition to chart the world's last great unexplored forests at the request of the Bhutan government.

Their findings will be published next year as part of a monumental study of Bhutan's flora which began in 1974.

"We found it growing 30km [18 miles] north of the Indian border on an oak," Dr Cribb said yesterday.

"It has fleshy leaves and purple and green flowers."

Bhutan has little history of botanical exploration, and finding orchids is particularly difficult, because many grow epiphytically: in crevices high up in trees or on mossy rocks.

"Bhutan is an amazing jewel," Dr Pearce said. "It has got some of the best-preserved forests in the world. They have not changed in thousands of years. And all of these trees are just covered with orchids."

The forests have survived because, until recently, the small Buddhist state avoided almost all contact with foreigners. Almost threequarters of Bhutan is still covered with trees, and King Jigme Wangchuk prohibits large-scale logging.

V griffithii and the new genus, which has been called bhutanthera, were almost certainly known to locals. The Bhutanese have long used a species of orchid, Cymbidium elegans, as an ingredient in curry.

fields.headline: Inescapably partisan
fields.standfirst:
Time to change the rules for spin doctors?
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A golden rule in the spin doctor's book of wisdom is that the spinner must never become the story. When the rule gets broken, as it did for Charlie Whelan at the Treasury 18 months ago, the offender usually has to pay with his job. Not so Alastair Campbell.
fields.body:
A golden rule in the spin doctor's book of wisdom is that the spinner must never become the story. When the rule gets broken, as it did for Charlie Whelan at the Treasury 18 months ago, the offender usually has to pay with his job. Not so Alastair Campbell. He has been a story for as long as he has been the voice of Tony Blair, first in opposition and now as chief press secretary to the prime minister. Soon there will be a TV film covering his exploits. And yesterday he came up at prime minister's questions.

Teresa Gorman asked if it was time to take Mr Campbell off the public payroll and reclassify him as an apparatchik of Millbank. Her question was prompted by the Guardian's publication yesterday of a leaked memo which revealed that he had ordered civil servants to prepare a public relations offensive to promote the government through the news-dry months of summer. No task for a public employee, Ms Gorman contended. Not so, said Mr Blair - though he agreed Mr Campbell need not have bothered since Labour's record has been so wonderful.

But is that answer good enough? A Downing Street spokeswoman insisted yesterday that a summer PR drive is perfectly routine: the legitimate task of a civil service machine charged with explaining the work of government. But was that Downing Street official speaking for the government - or for Labour? There is the rub. For even if this specific case is within the rules, there is good evidence that Mr Campbell's other activities are at least within the twilight zone that separates government and party. While Bernard Ingham was a loyal Thatcherite when he served in the job, he was not quite the party operative that Mr Campbell often appears to be. The latter is too close to Labour's drive for re-election to pretend he is a mere civil servant.

Which does not mean he should change his ways. Perhaps it is we who should do so. It might be time to recognise that, in a democracy, partisanship is essential - and not always bad. We could end the pretence that an aide as intimate as a press secretary might ever be non-partisan - and replace it with a resolve to codify and legitimise that partisanship. We might decide that both government and opposition deserve official spokespeople, paid to be as partisan as each other. Since Mr Campbell has often crossed the line between government and party, the best course might be not to punish him, but to redraw the line.

fields.headline: Act on pay
fields.trailText: I found much to agree with in your Road to the Manifesto article (What women want and Britain needs, June 26).
fields.body:
I found much to agree with in your Road to the Manifesto article (What women want and Britain needs, June 26). Pay audits, pensions, representation etc continue to need implementation, reform or pressure for improvement. The recent report of the Women's Unit on women's incomes over a lifetime has provided valuable evidence on which unions and others can build to bring about greater equity of income.

However, one of the things women really want is for society to take their issues seriously because they believe them to be important, not just to make political capital. The recent example of the TUC-organised event to mark 30 years of the Equal Pay Act (and the continuing 20% pay gap) being almost entirely ignored by the media in favour of the Oxbridge-class issue is a case in point: the chattering classes taking up thousands of column inches giving us the benefit of their opinions on this particular form of discrimination; not a jot about the years of pay discrimination suffered by women, many of whom were present at the TUC event. Yes, the manifesto is hugely important, as are actual legislation and policy programmes. But society can't shift its responsibilities and the media have an influential part to play.

Margaret Prosser
Deputy general secretary, TGWU Treasurer, Labour party

fields.headline: Fire deaths are avoidable
fields.trailText: I heard of the tragic deaths of the young backpackers in the Australian hostel with deep sorrow (Tears cannot extinguish town's trauma, June 26). As a fire chief, I encounter such needless loss on a regular basis ... and it is needless, for we now have the technology to prevent most fires.
fields.body:
I heard of the tragic deaths of the young backpackers in the Australian hostel with deep sorrow (Tears cannot extinguish town's trauma, June 26). As a fire chief, I encounter such needless loss on a regular basis ... and it is needless, for we now have the technology to prevent most fires.

In the past 10 years, the development of effective low-cost fire sprinkler systems has taken place. They don't go off by accident, they are so beautifully engineered that there is only a one in 16m chance of a manufacturing error; they use less than 5% of the water of a fire hose and they put out more than 99% of all fires at a very early stage, saving lives and protecting property. They cost less than fitted carpets to install.

The National Fire Sprinkler Network has been set up to campaign for their more widespread use. We won our first test case on superstores earlier this year and now we are working on housing and schools. Along with the Residential Sprinkler Association, we are pressing the government to make the installation of sprinklers compulsory in all houses in multiple occupation (which would include hostels). The Department of Environment is working on these guidelines for the new licensing system - most fire deaths occur in HMOs and social housing.

In Scottsdale, Arizona, in the 10 years since sprinklers were made compulsory, there has not been a single fire death and the same picture is shaping up in Vancouver.

Peter Holland
Chief fire officer, Lancashire

fields.headline: Ugandans go the president's way
fields.trailText: Ugandans will choose in a referendum today between resuming multi-party politics and sticking with President Yoweri Museveni's system, the Movement, which is described by its supporters as a form of democracy and by its detractors as a one-party state in another guise.
fields.body:
Ugandans will choose in a referendum today between resuming multi-party politics and sticking with President Yoweri Museveni's system, the Movement, which is described by its supporters as a form of democracy and by its detractors as a one-party state in another guise.

But the main political parties are boycotting the poll, and the president's system seems likely to win.

The parties argue that their fundamental right of association and assembly are being violated. The US organisation Human Rights Watch agrees: in a recent report it said the referendum was "incompatible with human rights standards".

President Museveni says his way is democratic because anybody can compete for political office on individual merit. Parties can exist in name, but cannot function.

fields.headline: Nuts to monkey-work
fields.trailText: The skills crisis (Firms say 2m not up to the job, June 27) is due to the failure of the education policy of successive governments, the lack of under- standing by government and industry on the value of training, especially the destruction of the apprentice system, and the denigration of industry by the cultural establishment.
fields.body:
The skills crisis (Firms say 2m not up to the job, June 27) is due to the failure of the education policy of successive governments, the lack of understanding by government and industry on the value of training, especially the destruction of the apprentice system, and the denigration of industry by the cultural establishment.

Thirty years ago an apprenticeship was a good route into a steady job and opened up a career pathway for the talented to the top of their chosen industry. Today this system does not exist - and I write as a professional engineer who took that path. The status of manufacturing has also declined and many graduates chose paths such as accountancy or law, where the rewards and status are higher.

The nation still needs steel. I am aware of the computer and IT revolution. I use both every day. What worries me is why there is such an apparent shortage of skills in these areas. Did successive governments not realise the demand, or are the schools not producing the skills? This throws a spotlight on the teachers; they are not producing the level and quantity of technically demanding subjects required (mathematics and physics). Yet the apparent answer is to pay them more for failure, rather than reward the successful.

In a country that once claimed to be "the workshop of the world", the image of industry is very poor. This is not true of countries such as Germany, which has an enviable record of engineering success and post-school training. We need to enhance the status of engineering and manufacturing and have less of this Cool Britannia nonsense, where the transient values of what passes for "art" are overblown.

Our problems as a country are highlighted in the Millennium Bridge, in which architecture and sculpture were given the credit for the concept as "art". The engineering was sidelined until the problems of basic structural instability of a virtually horizontal suspension bridge allowed a culprit to be found.

R Rogers
Neath, W Glamorgan evansr@BP.com

 Perhaps I can help. Am I numerate? Well, I have an A-Level in mathematics. Does that count? And three other A-levels including chemistry and physics. I have nine years' experience of technical management in manufacturing. I have a further nine years' experience of business systems analysis and computer systems design in financial services.

But have you kept your learning up to date? Well, in the last five years I have notched up four further qualifications and now teach, albeit part-time (that's because the government won't fund further education adequately). I do it partly through the love of it and partly because it's about the only work I can find that even begins to be intellectually stimulating. The vast majority of work on offer in Britain is monkey-work. So perhaps those firms who complain about the shortage of literate, numerate and articulate employees might want to contact me.

Chris Waller
Gloucester chriswaller21@yahoo.co.uk

fields.headline: Northerners declare their interests
fields.trailText: Your Analysis (Men, again, June 26), focused on a report by Durham University, presents too negative an image of public service in the north-east. One fact which has been overlooked is that, to the credit of people in the region, I was elected not once, but twice. This despite the fact that 99.4% of my constituents in Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland are white.
fields.body:
Your Analysis (Men, again, June 26), focused on a report by Durham University, presents too negative an image of public service in the north-east. One fact which has been overlooked is that, to the credit of people in the region, I was elected not once, but twice. This despite the fact that 99.4% of my constituents in Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland are white.

It is important to ensure that public bodies represent the communities they serve and people need to know that they can be a part of that. Labour is working hard to ensure that leaders within civic society are representative of the communities which they serve firstly, but also of society as a whole. It is with this in mind that we are educating children in the importance to citizenship: to reduce this imbalance in the future.

Dr Ashok Kumar MP

 Of course inner London boroughs face huge problems of poverty (Letters, June 23). So do northern towns. According to the Commons library, Newham receives £1,237 from the government for each of its inhabitants compared with the £726 a head that Rotherham council receives. Local government finance is fiendishly difficult to get right, but the new proposals which will introduce a degree of balance after the years of Tory favouritism for the much richer south-east are overdue and welcome.

Denis MacShane MP

 Your headline (A helping hand? June 27) asks a question about freemasonry declaration which, from the body of the report, appears superfluous. The four freemason members of the council of Newcastle University who abstained from voting did so because they believed that they had an interest to declare. Therefore, how can you suggest that they are members of a "secret society"?

Freemasons are reminded throughout their membership that where a conflict of interest might arise or be perceived to exist, or when freemasonry becomes an issue, a freemason must declare an interest. That is being open. Why should that provoke an "angry response"? Perhaps anger will be felt by those who note the comments of an academic unwilling to ascribe his name to the comments he makes.

John Hamill
United Grand Lodge of England

fields.headline: Schools and democracy
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead's attack on the effectiveness of local education authorities deserves a response (Schools watchdog questions LEAs role, June 28).
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead's attack on the effectiveness of local education authorities deserves a response (Schools watchdog questions LEAs role, June 28). LEAs are turning failing schools round faster than ever, but the misconception constantly stated is that LEAs wish to control or manage schools. That is the task of heads and senior staff. Our role is to help drive up standards. The successful LEA does depend on effective political leadership just as national government does. The advantage of that is that in a democracy the people elect their local representatives.

Replacing local democracy with appointed people and private companies will not raise standards and not improve schools.

Almost all educational reform in this country has come from local government. LEAs continue to fund schools at a higher rate than national government thinks we should. Those who wish to abolish LEAs really want to make schools self-governing and unaccountable to their students and local communities. Ofsted is hardly a model of democratic accountability.

Graham Lane
Local Government Association

fields.headline: Ring of steel
fields.trailText: English Heritage were proud to host a Royal wedding reception at Kenwood House last year (Hello! Glitz too much for MPs, June 27). David Hencke's article is seriously misleading in comparing his estimate of a £10-20,000 fee for a reception today with the £5,000 donation received from former King Constantine following his daughter's wedding last year.
fields.body:
English Heritage were proud to host a Royal wedding reception at Kenwood House last year (Hello! Glitz too much for MPs, June 27). David Hencke's article is seriously misleading in comparing his estimate of a £10-20,000 fee for a reception today with the £5,000 donation received from former King Constantine following his daughter's wedding last year. Former King Constantine also paid English Heritage a substantial sum for the reception. This arrangement was designed to ensure that we were fully reimbursed for the unusually high costs to us of this special event.

The whole estate was not closed. Security arrangements for the reception were planned so as to minimise disruption to the public, who have free access to Kenwood House and its grounds all the year round.

Pam Alexander
Chief executive, English Heritage

 You have conflated my name with that of my colleague Jeremy Wright. Apart from that, your report on the goings on at Kenwood and the "royal" wedding celebration which caused this famous house and world class gallery to be closed to the public, is accurate. We are grateful to David Rendel MP and his colleagues on the Commons public accounts committee for having reopened a serious matter on which we were ignored at the time and our protests treated with Olympian scorn by the chairman of English Heritage, Sir Jocelyn Stevens.

Martin Humphrey
Chairman, The Heath & Hampstead Society

fields.headline: Behind the facade
fields.trailText: The facade of Buckingham Palace did not replace anything by Nash (Francis Wheen, G2, June 28): it did not have an east front when it was built for George IV. What got covered up was a seriously ugly front added by Blore later in the 19th century.
fields.body:
The facade of Buckingham Palace did not replace anything by Nash (Francis Wheen, G2, June 28): it did not have an east front when it was built for George IV. What got covered up was a seriously ugly front added by Blore later in the 19th century. Although not particularly distinguished, Aston Webb's facade does not, surely, count as the ugliest building in London.

Geoffrey Thompson
London

 While Charles Kennedy (Letters, June 28) might not be "totally out-of-touch" he is not quite with-it. The coolest late-night entertainment at Glastonbury for the last two years has been the Lost Vagueness casino and dancehall, where smart dress is the only option for entry.

Tim Chatterton
Norwich

 There used to be a post office bank - it was called Girobank (Ministers unveil Post Office bank, June 28). Whatever happened to it?

Catherine Wykes
Derby

 Finally, the true meaning of the proverb, fine words butter no parsnips, becomes apparent (Parsnips on a pension, June 26).

Nicholas E Gough
Swindon, Wiltshire

 Amidst all the furore and angst about Our Boys last week, I was staggered that no one commented on the issue that really matters: no more double reward card points at Sainsburys. A nation mourns.

Pauline Hayes
Tunbridge Wells, Kent

 "Too many births this month. It's because of the eclipse" (Ultrasoundings, G2, June 27). I used to work in the lab of a large London hospital where we did ante-natal screening. The major increase in workload four months after Christmas, Easter etc led to them being renamed "bonk holidays".

John Purser
Hoddesdon, Herts

webTitle: Labour donor who lost livelihood sues Dobson

fields.headline: Labour donor who lost livelihood sues Dobson
fields.trailText: A Labour party donor is taking the former health secretary, Frank Dobson, to the European court of human rights in a £2m claim for destroying his livelihood after he gave the government an idea of how to raise £100m a year for the NHS.
fields.body:
A Labour party donor is taking the former health secretary, Frank Dobson, to the European court of human rights in a £2m claim for destroying his livelihood after he gave the government an idea of how to raise £100m a year for the NHS.

Frank Adlam, 57, a former police officer, was put out of business in April last year after he gave the Department of Health details of a simple change in the law which would give hospitals millions of pounds of extra cash provided by insurance companies for treating patients from serious road accidents.

Mr Dobson took up the idea but legislated to create a state monopoly to collect the cash, declaring the 120 contracts Mr Adlam had with local NHS hospitals "null and void". Mr Adlam's firm, the National Road Traffic Accident Claims Centre, in Raunds, Northamptonshire, was pushed into bankruptcy. Ministers refused to give him compensation although his business had raised £24m for the NHS.

Instead ministers set up the compensation recovery unit, staffed by 53 civil servants, at a cost of £1.4m a year, to collect the cash, promising up to £165m a year for the NHS and taking over 500,000 uncollected cases.

Now, a year later, Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, is to investigate why the new state body has managed to collect only £30m in the first year and settle only 112,020 of the 500,000 outstanding cases. In the first three months of its operation the unit did not collect a penny because, according to the ministry, of "teething troubles caused by banking arrangements". It is also alleged ministers broke Cabinet Office guidelines by not testing whether the service could be run more efficiently in the public sector.

Mr Adlam, who had funded his local Labour party, is being backed by a former Conservative health minister, John Horam, and a Tory peer, Earl Howe, in taking his case to court and getting a Whitehall investigation.

Documents sent to the court and obtained by the Guardian show Mr Adlam is claiming that the Department of Health "deprived me of my business" and "by their own admission, the UK government have made no effective remedy for me or others before a national authority in respect of this violation of one of my rights and freedoms".

The documents show Phil Hope, Labour MP for Corby, wrote to Mr Dobson asking for Mr Adlam's company - which had put his idea to NHS civil servants - to be considered as providers for the collection service. But instead the government bill proposed a state monopoly and Mr Dobson and ministry officials refused to discuss the matter with Mr Adlam.

Three months after the business had been closed, John Hutton, the junior health and social services minister, wrote to Mr Hope saying: "There is no issue of 'compensation' to be discussed." He added that the new system had already identified more income due to the NHS than was collected in the previous quarter under Mr Adlam. In fact, at the time not a penny had been collected.

The claim also points out that whereas Mr Dobson had not included under his road traffic (NHS charges) bill any provision for compensation, under European law, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, had agreed to compensation to fur farmers who were deprived of their livelihood.

Internal documents from the Department of Health's lawyers - obtained by Mr Horam - show that officials advising ministers were well aware he might have a case. The advice reads: "He may be entitled to payment for the adoption of his idea and for loss of business ... SOL [solicitors for the Department of Health] warns the department is not guaranteed to win the legal argument."

Mr Horam said yesterday: "It is disgraceful that ministers have deprived a man of his livelihood and not even considered whether he could bid for the work."

Mr Adlam said: "I now wish I had never told the Department of Health about this. They just think I am some person in the sticks you don't have to bother about."

The department would not discuss the case but a spokeswoman said they had overestimated the amount of money they could recover from insurance companies for the NHS.

webTitle: Scientists reveal project for pill that puts off menopause

fields.headline: Scientists reveal project for pill that puts off menopause
fields.standfirst:
Fertility - How stopping egg growth could slow the ageing process
European Society of Human Reproduction and Embriology
fields.trailText: Scientists are working on a contraceptive pill that could have the effect of delaying the menopause, slowing down the ageing process and allowing a woman to postpone children until later in life.
fields.body:
Scientists are working on a contraceptive pill that could have the effect of delaying the menopause, slowing down the ageing process and allowing a woman to postpone children until later in life.

The research in the Netherlands is in its earliest stages, but could have dramatic consequences if successful, preserving women's youth and theoretically allowing them to have children in their late 50s and 60s.

Women are born with a million eggs in their ovaries, one or sometimes two of which mature each month after puberty and are released by the egg follicle to travel down the fallopian tubes. If they are fertilised, they implant in the lining of the womb. Hundreds more fail to mature and disintegrate each month.

Once all the eggs have gone from the ovaries at around the age of 50, the menopause sets in. Hormone levels drop because they are no longer needed to prime the fertility cycle, and many women take hormone replacement therapy to get over such side effects as hot flushes and night sweats.

Originally it was thought that the first-generation contraceptive pill might postpone the menopause, but research presented at the European Society of Human Reproduction and Embryology conference in Bologna, Italy, yesterday confirmed that this notion was wrong.

A group of Dutch scientists from Utrecht studied 12,000 women who had taken the first-generation pill, which was a high dose of the hormone oestrogen. They expected that they might have reached menopause later than average - but in fact they reached it six months earlier.

As yet, the scientists could not explain this finding, but their research had convinced them that neither the first generation nor the current low-dose combination pills will postpone menopause. The pills work by tricking the body into believing it is pregnant, so that if an egg is fertilised, it will not implant in the womb on the assumption that an embryo is already growing there. It does not prevent eggs maturing and dying.

Egbert te Velde, a gynaecologist involved in the work, explained that the maturation of the egg had to be prevented much earlier than ovulation to stop the oocyte (egg) reserves becoming depleted.

"The oocyte makes a very long journey of perhaps half a year," he said. "The small oocyte sits there and at a certain moment starts developing and growing. Why does the small oocyte start to grow? That is the question.

A company spokeswoman, Ellen Havemarr, said: "I can confirm we are working on this. It is very early research. "We are looking at ways of arresting the process of ripening the egg at the time of its development. It could be 15 to 20 years, or sooner or later."

webTitle: IVF stampede puts women at risk, says expert

fields.headline: IVF stampede puts women at risk, says expert
fields.trailText: Couples are losing faith in their ability to conceive naturally, creating a stampede for fertility treatment that might be unnecessary, a gynaecologist said yesterday.
fields.body:
Couples are losing faith in their ability to conceive naturally, creating a stampede for fertility treatment that might be unnecessary, a gynaecologist said yesterday.

Cultural change and the pace of modern life, together with a wrong but generally held belief that the fertility of the human race is declining, are causing couples to head for the clinics when there is no need, Egbert te Velde, head of the department of reproductive medicine at the University of Utrecht, told the conference.

Dr Te Velde said couples should be encouraged to try for children for a little longer before embarking on potentially harmful fertility treatments.

There was a perception, he said, "that fertility is not natural any more - that we should seek to get children as soon as possible and that our fertility may be impaired".

He spoke of a "calculating society" where every aspect of life was carefully planned. "If everything is certain - the stable relationship, a good career and enough money, and a nice house - then the time is right for children, but then we are rushing.

"A lot of couples who have tried for six months give up, thinking it is not natural, and rush to do the fertility thing. Because infertility, especially in the United States, is extremely commercialised, they are accepted with open arms. I think that is a development which is regrettable, because a lot of couples - if they had waited not for long but maybe for another year - would have quite a good chance of conceiving spontaneously without all the risks and complications of IVF."

Those risks were underestimated by people who assumed fertility treatment by doctors in a clinic was necessary.

The drugs used to encourage the ovaries to produce a lot of eggs could have severe side effects that put some women in hospital. "The risks for the mother are first of all ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, which affects 10% and is life-threatening in 2% of cases," Dr Te Velde said.

"Then there is the question mark over ovarian cancer in the long term. We do not know, but it is not yet excluded. We are not inclined to tell all this to our patients. Doctors don't always tell couples. And people who are desperately wanting a child don't listen very well."

Fertility specialists usually meant well and wanted the best for their patients, he said, but in many cases that might be achieved by advising them to wait for a while and keep trying to conceive naturally.

"The spontaneous chance to conceive is underestimated," he said, although he acknowledged that each couple's circumstances had to be taken into account.

"In a 39-year-old woman, I would not advise her to wait for more than maybe six months - not two or three years."

webTitle: TV quiz to offer unlimited cash

fields.headline: TV quiz to offer unlimited cash
fields.trailText: As the hit TV quiz Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? shows signs of losing its lustre, its creators are launching a show offering unlimited prize money.
fields.body:
As the hit TV quiz Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? shows signs of losing its lustre, its creators are launching a show offering unlimited prize money.

For The People Versus, viewers will submit questions to contestants on chosen specialist subjects. A correct answer will net the contestant £5,000, but a wrong answer will result in disqualification and replacement by the viewer who put the question. There is no limit on the amount of money a participant could rack up.

The team behind Millionaire is responsible for the new show, which will form a centrepiece of ITV's autumn schedule. A spokeswoman for Celador Productions, which will make the programme, said: "There's never going to be another Millionaire, but there is the potential to win big money here."

Ratings for the last season of Millionaire, while remaining huge, have shown signs of falling off. Some 12m watched a celebrity edition of the show, which had 18m viewers at its height. No one has yet won the top prize in the British version. Millionaire will return to ITV for a new run.

ITV said it had not yet decided whether The People Versus would be shown every day. However, it seems likely that the show will appear a number of times a week, to maintain interest. At the end of each show, the presenter will outline the specialist subjects chosen for the next episode, and invite viewers to submit questions by telephone, email, or via the associated website.

Each show will start with three participants; replacements will not take their seats until the subsequent programme. Celador is seeking a high-profile star to present The People Versus.

The ABC network is on the verge of signing up the Celador format for broadcast in the US.

Celador is seen to have the magic touch. The BBC is trying out new game shows, including one for Terry Wogan, a quiz presented by Nick Ross, and a programme fronted by Anthea Turner.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Beckhams' minder arrested
fields.body:
Beckhams' minder arrested

A former bodyguard to David and Victoria Beckham has been arrested in connection with death threats received by the couple, police said yesterday.

Mark Niblett, 35, was questioned by Scotland Yard detectives over hate mail sent to the footballer and his wife, including a defaced photo of Victoria Beckham with a bullet aimed at her head drawn on it. Angelique Chrisafis

Sports kit bill tops £1bn

Sports kits have become the biggest drain on British parents' day-to-day school spending, with families forking out more than £1bn a year. Spending on shorts, hockey sticks and shin pads now outstrips the amounts spent on uniforms, computer games and books, online youth sports magazine sportscore.co.uk reported.

PoW produces key to Colditz

A former prisoner of war who returned to Colditz 50 years after being freed by US troops let himself back in - with his own key.

Brigadier Jock Hamilton-Ballie was met by curators who had lost the keys to cells in the notorious Nazi castle. But the 81-year-old produced one he had crafted during his year-long incarceration in the 1940s.

Irish 'still being stereotyped'

The Irish in England are still stereotyped as being stupid, lazy, ignorant, violent and fraudsters, according to a new study. Almost half of those questioned said they had felt they were discriminated against, the Irish national committee of the European Cultural Foundation reported.

Ramsay named chef of the year

Celebrity cook Gordon Ramsay has been named Chef of the Year in the catering industry's annual awards. Ramsay, who is as well known for his fiery temper as his cuisine, was honoured with a Catey, the industry's Oscar, at a ceremony in London.

fields.headline: Mr Chirac calls the shots
fields.standfirst: The pressure on Tony Blair is tightening
fields.trailText: The French president used the occasion of his Reichstag oration to grandstand. He flattered his hosts, promising French backing for a permanent German seat on the United Nations security council.
fields.body:
The French president used the occasion of his Reichstag oration to grandstand. He flattered his hosts, promising French backing for a permanent German seat on the United Nations security council. He tweaked his cohabitee, Lionel Jospin, who only a few weeks ago talked about building Europe "in small steps" - that is the sort of language London likes. But Jacques Chirac's achievement is not to be gainsaid. After the blood shed during the past 130 years, Franco-German amity is too precious to be taken for granted. So if he has "relaunched" a relationship lately gone tepid, well and good. His euro-rhetoric matched that of German foreign minister Joschka Fischer, affirming Berlin's harmless pride in custodianship of the European Union. Mr Chirac also delighted the geo-politicians of Paris who feel France is back in the game of charting all available utopias. A close reading of Mr Chirac's speech is recommended to all those who fear European integration is diminishing national differences; a certain cast of French mind looks pretty eternal.

As for his substance, the coat Mr Chirac trailed needs the attention of his couturier. His idea of an "avant-garde" of countries is our old friend "variable geometry" in new guise. But would the postulated inner group join together on the basis of an inter-governmental treaty, juridically outside the EU, or constitute themselves as in effect an executive sub-committee of the council of ministers? The Schengen agreement is an example of the former arrangement. Enough has been whispered of late to suggest it is that kind of fortress-building that good (west) Europeans have in mind - to keep out east Europeans who have not made the grade.

But now at least the French and Germans are thinking practically and openly about the consequences of enlargement, no longer pretending the EU can expand without a dramatic overhaul of its institutions, perhaps even of its purposes. Mr Chirac said little about the Poles, Czechs and other aspirants, despite their physical proximity to where he was speaking. Perhaps his speech should be read as de facto postponement of accession as it has been understood by aspirant countries. When Mr Fischer talks, semi-privately, of a new window of opportunity opening for accelerated integration of the few between 2001 and 2003, it looks as if two-speed Europe has arrived.

Which gear is Tony Blair in? Mr Chirac's discourse has done the prevaricators on this side of the Channel no favours. The Tories say they would be far from unhappy to stand there on the platform waving their blue hankies at the departing TGV. But talk of slow lanes is altogether unwelcome to Labour. Spokespeople complain on the sidelines about the continentals' love of hifalutin' talk when the reality - they say -is that the French and the Germans have yet to agree on such basics as reweighting votes in the council of ministers to recognise the size of Germany's population. But UK empiricism seems increasingly out of tune. The Fischer-Chirac line is that the EU must now move, explicitly, to write a constitution. In Mr Fischer's formulation it has to be an anti-centralist document, entrenching the respective positions of Brussels, nations and the regions below them (a German imperative, that). Mr Chirac, mindful of his forbears of 1789, is no less vehement about the need to sit down and draft. The Blair government sits silent. Where are the British bright ideas in his briefcase when he flies to Berlin today to try to de-programme a German chancellor exposed to the seductive doctrine of European unity?

fields.headline: Stand and deliver
fields.standfirst: Small post offices no longer look doomed after all
fields.trailText: It has taken the internet age to unlock the sleeping assets of the Post Office. Dot.com companies everywhere are suddenly realising that what they lack is an effective delivery system for goods ordered online and somewhere they can leave their orders when people are not at home.
fields.body:
It has taken the internet age to unlock the sleeping assets of the Post Office. Dot.com companies everywhere are suddenly realising that what they lack is an effective delivery system for goods ordered online and somewhere they can leave their orders when people are not at home. Suddenly, the Post Office with its nationwide delivery service and 18,000 outlets - the biggest retail network in Europe - becomes an old economy solution for the problems of the new. Yesterday's report from the Cabinet Office performance and innovation unit could prove a milestone in the PO's history. Although it criticises the PO for its slowness to modernise (hardly surprising since it has been kept on such a tight rein by the Treasury), it does offer a blueprint for survival which could transform the PO and, maybe, reduce the catastrophic loss of £400m it will suffer when payments can be made directly into banks.

The report, commendably, urges the PO (which was forced to privatise its own Giro bank under the Conservatives) to establish a Universal Bank with help from existing operators in order to provide banking services, but not overdrafts, for more than 3m people who do not have a bank account at all. Add in the provision of internet services, the provision of information about other government services, plus a refurbishment programme and, suddenly, the PO's network could have a future as well as a past.

It will not be easy to generate £400m of extra income, but at least there is now a framework to make it possible and some money (in next month's spending review) to oil the wheels. Above all, the PO has now been given a more entrepreneurial role so it can view its vast network with different eyes. What used to be seen as a rotting asset it is now an opportunity. Some 94% of Britons live within a mile of a post office and two-thirds of town dwellers within half a mile of at least two. It is a delivery network that internet sellers would die for.

fields.headline: A drop in net profits
fields.standfirst: Edward Helmore looks at how online retailers are coping as the stock market loses confidence in them
fields.trailText: Edward Helmore looks at how online retailers are coping as the stock market loses confidence in them
fields.body:
If last week's 19% drop in the value of Amazon.com told internet retailers anything, it was that the market will no longer tolerate the business model that has so far dominated internet commerce.

By far the net's largest consumer retailing operation with 20 million customers and nearly $3bn dollars in annual revenue, Amazon's stock plunged after a number of prominent Wall Street analysts warned that the company's outlook was bleak. A credit analyst at Lehman Brothers called Amazon's credit "extremely weak and deteriorating" and said that the company, whose stock is down 55 % so far this year and has never posted a profit, risks running out of cash by the middle of 2001.

Though Amazon issued fierce denials that it is in any trouble and called Lehman comments "hogwash", the drop in its stock has sobered even the most bullish believers that all that matters in internet business is to build brand and a strong consumer base while ignoring the necessity for actual profit.

Against the background of recent e-commerce failures such as Boo.com and Toysmart.com, it's no longer a secret that internet retailers are in big trouble. Stock prices have skidded, venture capital has dried up and the markets are shunning those who cannot demonstrate how they will be profitable soon.

Earlier this week, for instance, Oxygen, the high-profile media company providing cable-channels and websites for women, said it was discontinuing its e-tailing sites and will not now carry inventory items as part of its service.

To please testy investors, dot.coms are trying numerous tactics including employee layoffs, reconceptualising their businesses and raising advertising rates to show they can have a future in the black.

But the biggest obstacle to profitability remains the practice of selling products beneath cost to lure new customers. That appears to be changing and instead of promoting discounts, net retailers are now bragging of price increases as a way of steadying the hands of nervous investors.

Last Christmas, the luxury watch retailer Ashford.com was selling Tag Heuer watches at roughly 35% below their suggested retail price. Since then, the site has raised prices by more than 20%.

This pattern is being repeated across net retailing. To the delight of bricks-and-mortar retailers, net companies are raising prices and curbing numerous internet bargains cherished by consumers. "The artificial pricing of 1999 is history," said Mark Goldstein, chief executive of Bluelight.com, the web arm of the US retailer Kmart.

Against expectations, there are signs that consumers don't mind paying more so long as they get service and convenience to match. In a May survey, Jupiter Communications, the internet consulting firm, found that cyberspace customers were growing fractionally less price-sensitive. Some 73% of the 1,500 people who replied to the survey rated price as the most important factor in their decisions to buy a product, but that was down from 80% two years earlier.

"Our research shows that people are clicking at the higher price range, because they will pay a premium for convenience - like being in stock now, or excellent customer service," Daniel Ciporin, president of Deal Time.com, a service that allows customers to compare web prices, told the New York Times.

Other profit-boosting strategies include raising costs indirectly by increasing shipping and handling fees or reducing special offers, cutting back on discount coupons and free extras, while adding limits on who gets them. Starting next month, Amazon will raise the monthly fee it charges small businesses that sell through its zShops and Amazon auctions from $9.99 to $39.99.

But many firms, including Amazon itself, are resisting the new strategy to raise prices on merchandise, preferring to concentrate on growth and rewarding repeat customers for their loyalty with added incentives.

How far struggling web retailers can push prices remains to be seen. In the short term, things are likely to get tougher still. Next month, the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a US agency that sets accounting conventions, is expected to approve a new system whereby retailers calculate "gross profits".

Many of the big etailers, including Amazon.com and eToys, list the costs of shipping and handling under their marketing budgets, a practice that inflates gross margins.

If the board ends this practice and instead requires businesses to deduct these costs from the value of goods sold that could cause margins to drop to 10% from 20%. And that, of course, is only going to create additional pressure to raise prices.
